{"duration": "1:35:00", "runner": "Kruncha, NotSoNewby, Enkaybee, michael_goldfish, MooMooAkai, spikevegeta", "data": {"site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/donkey-kong-country-tropical-freeze/3030-42932/", "expected_release_quarter": null, "description": "<h2>Overview</h2><figure style=\"width: 320px\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2606316\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/8/82063/2606316-wiiu_screenshot_tv_01v1kuy.jpg\" data-size=\"small\" data-align=\"right\" data-ratio=\"0.5625\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:56.3%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/8/82063/2606316-wiiu_screenshot_tv_01v1kuy.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2606316\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/8/82063/2606316-wiiu_screenshot_tv_01v1kuy.jpg\"/></a><figcaption>Swimming and underwater sections return.</figcaption></figure><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">Donkey Kong Country: Tropical Freeze is the second game in the <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/donkey-kong-country/3025-155\" data-ref-id=\"3025-155\">Donkey Kong Country</a> franchise developed by <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/retro-studios/3010-1507\" data-ref-id=\"3010-1507\">Retro Studios</a> and the first made for the Wii U (this time with assistance from <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/monster-games-inc/3010-1419\" data-ref-id=\"3010-1419\">Monster Games</a>, who ported the previous title to the Nintendo 3DS). The game also marks the return of <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/david-wise/3040-33306\" data-ref-id=\"3040-33306\">David Wise</a>, the composer of the original SNES trilogy, providing an original soundtrack for the game. The game was released in Japan on February 13, 2014 and in North America and Europe on February 21. Retro Studio's trademark 60 frames per second gameplay also makes a return with the added benefit of a native 720p resolution this time.</p><h2>Gameplay</h2><figure style=\"width: 320px\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2606156\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/8/82063/2606156-4871667520-wiiu_.jpg\" data-size=\"small\" data-align=\"left\" data-ratio=\"0.5625\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:56.3%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/8/82063/2606156-4871667520-wiiu_.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2606156\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/8/82063/2606156-4871667520-wiiu_.jpg\"/></a><figcaption>Donkey Kong does not have to enter dimly lit ice caves alone.</figcaption></figure><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">Tropical Freeze includes more more dynamic, three-dimensional levels than those that appeared in Donkey Kong Country Returns and also brings back underwater stages (which haven't been seen since <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/donkey-kong-country-3-dixie-kongs-double-trouble/3030-4547\" data-ref-id=\"3030-4547\">Donkey Kong Country 3</a>). Levels now often feature multiple gameplay styles such as platforming mixed with underwater segments or rocket/mine cart segments instead of being limited to levels solely dedicated to one gameplay type. Players can choose to play as <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/donkey-kong/3005-299\" data-ref-id=\"3005-299\">Donkey Kong</a>, <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/diddy-kong/3005-304\" data-ref-id=\"3005-304\">Diddy Kong</a>, <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/dixie-kong/3005-303\" data-ref-id=\"3005-303\">Dixie Kong</a>, and for the first time in the series, <a href=\"/cranky-kong/3005-311\" data-ref-id=\"3005-311\">Cranky Kong</a>. Like the previous title, Tropical Freeze supports a local two-player mode with player one taking the role of Donkey and player two getting the chance to chose between the three support characters.</p><h4>Diddy Kong</h4><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">All support characters have unique abilities with Diddy again bringing his trusty jetpack that lets him float a short distance in the air, just like in the previous title. On top of that, the jetpack provides a speed boost when using it underwater, making Diddy the fastest swimmer. Diddy retains his signature cartwheel animation when \"rolling\" forward and carries objects on front of him. His support weapon is again the peanut gun which, like all the other characters' support weapons, will stun enemies.</p><h4>Dixie Kong</h4><figure style=\"width: 320px\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2606318\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/8/82063/2606318-iclxdkbp0mpqb.jpg\" data-size=\"small\" data-align=\"right\" data-ratio=\"0.5625\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:56.3%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/8/82063/2606318-iclxdkbp0mpqb.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2606318\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/8/82063/2606318-iclxdkbp0mpqb.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/8/82063/2606318-iclxdkbp0mpqb.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Still one of the most powerful hair dos in gaming.</figcaption></figure><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">While Dixie Kong makes use of her pony tail as she did in her appearances in DKC 2: Diddy's Kong Quest and DKC 3: Dixie Kong's Double Trouble, this time it allows her to execute a quasi double-jump by twirling her hair mid-jump to briefly gain extra height. Dixie's pony tail also comes in handy when swimming against strong currents underwater since she can use it like a rotor to propel herself forward slowly but steadily. In this game, Dixie no longer carries objects like barrels with her pony tail above her head but instead just uses her hands and carries it in front of her. Her \"rolling\" animation is her classic pirouette with the hair spin. Dixie's support weapon is the bubble gum popgun.</p><h4>Cranky Kong</h4><figure style=\"width: 320px\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2580928\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/8/82063/2580928-9d68bf313df265376b998af6bd16b20f9a4afd04.jpg\" data-size=\"small\" data-align=\"left\" data-ratio=\"0.5625\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:56.3%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/8/82063/2580928-9d68bf313df265376b998af6bd16b20f9a4afd04.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2580928\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/8/82063/2580928-9d68bf313df265376b998af6bd16b20f9a4afd04.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/8/82063/2580928-9d68bf313df265376b998af6bd16b20f9a4afd04.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Scrooge McDuck and Cranky Kong would probably not get along very well.</figcaption></figure><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">Cranky Kong does not have an ability that grants him extended air time, however he uses his can to bounce around which lets him jump higher. This also enables him to jump on spikes or enemies that would otherwise harm him. Combining his cane bounce with a roll lets him move extremely fast while making it very tough to navigate safely through levels. In underwater segments, he can use his cane as a melee weapon to damage objects or enemies that are in the way. Cranky is now the character carrying objects above his head since he needs one hand to hold his cane. His support weapon comes in the form of dentures the throws around.</p><h3>Various Mechanics</h3><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">Tropical Freeze brings back another mechanic from the past, this time being from producer <a href=\"/kensuke-tanabe/3040-35535\" data-ref-id=\"3040-35535\">Kensuke Tanabe</a>'s very first game: <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/super-mario-bros-2/3030-7406\" data-ref-id=\"3030-7406\">Super Mario Bros. 2</a>. Donkey Kong &amp; company are are now able to pluck things from the ground to reveal items, much like <a href=\"/mario/3005-177\" data-ref-id=\"3005-177\">Mario</a> and his fellow adventurers did, or alter the environment to open new or previously blocked paths.</p><figure style=\"width: 320px\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2606150\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/8/82063/2606150-8483089867-wiiu_.jpg\" data-size=\"small\" data-align=\"right\" data-ratio=\"0.5625\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:56.3%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/8/82063/2606150-8483089867-wiiu_.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2606150\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/8/82063/2606150-8483089867-wiiu_.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/8/82063/2606150-8483089867-wiiu_.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Imagine this screen had one heart less.</figcaption></figure><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">Additional, climbing and swinging from vines, grabbing onto grass hanging on ceilings and walls and destroying certain objects in the environment by pounding on the ground is often required of the Kongs. Throwing objects or enemies now is a bigger part of the game, too with secrets and collectibles often being hidden by a barrier that can be broken by throwing heavy objects at it. The blowing mechanic from the previous game does not make a return in Tropical Freeze.</p><h3>Kong-Pow</h3><figure style=\"width: 320px\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2582417\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/8/82063/2582417-wiiu_dkctf_gi_scrn_06.jpg\" data-size=\"small\" data-align=\"left\" data-ratio=\"0.5625\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:56.3%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/8/82063/2582417-wiiu_dkctf_gi_scrn_06.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2582417\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/8/82063/2582417-wiiu_dkctf_gi_scrn_06.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/8/82063/2582417-wiiu_dkctf_gi_scrn_06.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Up top!</figcaption></figure><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">A brand new ability for the partner characters to use with Donkey Kong is the Kong-Pow move. Collecting 100 bananas will fill a gauge next to the heart meter that can then be activated by a button combination. Depending on who Donkey Kong is currently partnering with, the results will change. Executing a Kong-Pow clears the screen of all visible enemies and turns them into items. With Diddy, they turn into 1-Up balloons, with Dixie, they turn into golden hearts that grant one extra hit for each one the player(s) manage to collect (with a maximum of four extra hits possible) and Cranky Kong cause them to turn into banana coins.</p><h3>Features</h3><figure style=\"width: 320px\" data-align=\"right\" data-size=\"small\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/8/82063/2594345-103755_funky_kong_shossipm.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2594345\" data-ratio=\"0.5625\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:56.3%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/8/82063/2594345-103755_funky_kong_shossipm.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2594345\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/8/82063/2594345-103755_funky_kong_shossipm.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/8/82063/2594345-103755_funky_kong_shossipm.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Right... \"Surfboard\"...</figcaption></figure><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\"><a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/funky-kong/3005-1647\" data-ref-id=\"3005-1647\">Funky Kong</a> also makes his return to the series, but this time, with Cranky now part of the adventuring crew, he will be taking care of the item shop that debuted in the previous game.</p><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">Tropical Freeze also features online leaderboards that allow sharing of level replays in Time Attack Mode, secret exits to secret levels, Hard Mode and the return of <a href=\"/rambi-the-rhino/3005-11310\" data-ref-id=\"3005-11310\">Rambi the Rhino</a> as the only animal buddy in the game. Notably, the game lacks any Wii U specific features and in fact even turns the GamePad screen off entirely when playing on the TV. Aside from regular Miiverse Community support on a system level, the only special Wii U feature in the game is <a href=\"/off-tv-play/3015-7482\" data-ref-id=\"3015-7482\">Off-TV Play</a>.</p><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">Supported controllers are: Wii U GamePad, Wii U Pro Controller, Wii Remote (held sideways), Wii Remote + Nunchuk.</p><h3>Hard Mode</h3><figure style=\"width: 320px\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2606280\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/8/82063/2606280-irgk3fc67uuzd.jpg\" data-size=\"small\" data-align=\"left\" data-ratio=\"0.5625\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:56.3%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/8/82063/2606280-irgk3fc67uuzd.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2606280\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/8/82063/2606280-irgk3fc67uuzd.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/8/82063/2606280-irgk3fc67uuzd.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Diddy has clear eyes, a full heart but he can most definitely still lose. </figcaption></figure><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">Similar to Mirror Mode in Donkey Kong Country Returns, Hard Mode in Tropical Freeze limits players to one heart, meaning one-hit deaths, no buddy characters, no support items from Funky's shop and presents blue K.O.N.G. letters to collect. Additionally, Hard Mode lets solo players choose any of the four characters to play any given level with from the world map, in contrast to the normal mode in which player one is automatically assigned Donkey Kong and only the second player can choose between the three support buddies. Hard Mode does not feature mirrored levels like in DKC Returns but instead removes all checkpoints from levels making it significantly harder to reach the end.</p><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">Hard Mode is unlocked by finishing all levels in all worlds. Beating every level in Hard Mode grants players <a href=\"/over-100-completion/3015-4070\" data-ref-id=\"3015-4070\">200% game completion</a> on their save file.</p><h2>World Map &amp; Levels</h2><figure style=\"width: 320px\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2606315\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/8/82063/2606315-wiiu_screenshot_tv_01ddkco.jpg\" data-size=\"small\" data-align=\"right\" data-ratio=\"0.5625\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:56.3%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/8/82063/2606315-wiiu_screenshot_tv_01ddkco.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2606315\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/8/82063/2606315-wiiu_screenshot_tv_01ddkco.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/8/82063/2606315-wiiu_screenshot_tv_01ddkco.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Mine carts. In 3D.</figcaption></figure><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">Since Tropical Freeze is all about DK and his friends being banished from Donkey Kong Island by the Snowmads and thus being forced to make their way back, players will travel across several unique worlds before they reach their frozen home.</p><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">The main game features six distinct islands, each with its own theme ranging from tropical jungle, a temperate climate mountain region, savannas and canyons, giant fruit jungles, beaches, flooded ruins, etc. The sixth world is Donkey Kong Island and features levels set in the main areas from Donkey Kong Country Returns. These levels reference key locations from the previous game but are completely new and significantly altered by the snow and ice brought on by the Snowmads.</p><figure style=\"width: 320px\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2592898\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/8/82063/2592898-wiiu_dkctf_janpr_19720.jpg\" data-size=\"small\" data-align=\"left\" data-ratio=\"0.5625\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:56.3%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/8/82063/2592898-wiiu_dkctf_janpr_19720.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2592898\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/8/82063/2592898-wiiu_dkctf_janpr_19720.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/8/82063/2592898-wiiu_dkctf_janpr_19720.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Even Cranky manages to barely hold on to his dear life.</figcaption></figure><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">Each world features two secret levels that have to be unlocked by finding secret exits in one or two of the regular levels. Just like in DKC Returns, especially challenging K-levels are unlocked by finding all the K.O.N.G. letters in each level of any given world, including the secret levels. These K-levels do not have checkpoints and often don't even provide buddy barrels.</p><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">Levels in Tropical Freeze are very long compared to most platformers and are designed around many scripted events that often significantly alter the level and affect the intensity to keep players engaged and on their feet. Hidden inside these levels are puzzle pieces and bonus rooms that offer a short break from the often tense action.</p><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">Completing all levels (including the K-levels) in the regular six worlds will unlock a special bonus world featuring a set of challenging levels that also lack any checkpoints while introducing several new hazards.</p><h2>Trivia</h2><figure style=\"width: 320px\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2606146\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/8/82063/2606146-0615910541-wiiu_.jpg\" data-size=\"small\" data-align=\"right\" data-ratio=\"0.5625\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:56.3%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/8/82063/2606146-0615910541-wiiu_.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2606146\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/8/82063/2606146-0615910541-wiiu_.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/8/82063/2606146-0615910541-wiiu_.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>One of these things does not belong here.</figcaption></figure><ul><li>The fourth playable character, Cranky Kong, was originally teased at E3 2013 by Kensuke Tanabe and was to remain a mystery until his official reveal at the Spike VGX Awards 2013 by <a href=\"/reggie-fils-aime/3040-89632\" data-ref-id=\"3040-89632\">Reggie Fils-Aime</a>. However, Amazon Italy unintentionally leaked the character's identity by posting the final European box art of the game early which clearly features Cranky Kong holding onto Donkey Kong's leg just days before the planned reveal at the Spike VGX show.</li><li>In Donkey Kong's idle animation, he pulls out a blue <a href=\"/nintendo-3ds/3045-117\" data-ref-id=\"3045-117\">3DS XL</a> and plays one of four possible Nintendo 3DS games which can be determined by the music coming from the device: <a href=\"/donkey-kong-country-returns/3030-31732\" data-ref-id=\"3030-31732\">Donkey Kong Country Returns 3D</a>, <a href=\"/super-mario-3d-land/3030-34303\" data-ref-id=\"3030-34303\">Super Mario 3D Land</a>, <a href=\"/mario-kart-7/3030-31747\" data-ref-id=\"3030-31747\">Mario Kart 7</a> or <a href=\"/animal-crossing-new-leaf/3030-31752\" data-ref-id=\"3030-31752\">Animal Crossing: New Leaf</a>.</li><li>In level 1-B Busted Bayou, a model of <a href=\"/samus-arans-gunship/3055-1193\" data-ref-id=\"3055-1193\">Samus Aran's Gunship </a>can be seen in the background.</li></ul><h2>Reception</h2><p>As of December 2014, the game shipped 1.12 million units worldwide.</p>", "deck": "Donkey Kong Island is being threatened by a group of vikings called the Snowmads who kicked the Kongs off their island and covered it in snow and ice. Play Donkey, Diddy, Dixie, and for the first time ever, Cranky Kong and travel across multiple islands to reclaim your home in this 2D platformer by Retro Studios.", "aliases": "DKC Tropical Freeze\r\nDKCTF\r\nDKC TF", "image": {"icon_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/square_avatar/8/82063/2684855-dkc5crop.jpg", "medium_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_medium/8/82063/2684855-dkc5crop.jpg", "tiny_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/square_mini/8/82063/2684855-dkc5crop.jpg", "small_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/8/82063/2684855-dkc5crop.jpg", "thumb_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_avatar/8/82063/2684855-dkc5crop.jpg", "screen_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/screen_medium/8/82063/2684855-dkc5crop.jpg", "super_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_large/8/82063/2684855-dkc5crop.jpg"}, "date_last_updated": "2016-02-29 07:41:53", "expected_release_month": null, "api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/game/3030-42932/", "number_of_user_reviews": 0, "original_release_date": "2014-02-13 00:00:00", "original_game_rating": [{"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/game_rating/3065-6/", "id": 6, "name": "ESRB: E"}, {"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/game_rating/3065-7/", "id": 7, "name": "PEGI: 3+"}, {"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/game_rating/3065-14/", "id": 14, "name": "OFLC: G"}, {"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/game_rating/3065-25/", "id": 25, "name": "CERO: A"}], "date_added": "2013-06-11 07:29:10", "platforms": [{"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/platform/3045-139/", "abbreviation": "WIIU", "site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/wii-u/3045-139/", "id": 139, "name": "Wii U"}], "expected_release_day": null, "expected_release_year": null, "id": 42932, "resource_type": "game", "name": "Donkey Kong Country: Tropical Freeze"}, "platform": "Wii U", "title": "Donkey Kong Country: Tropical Freeze"}
{"duration": "1:23:00", "runner": "JustinDM", "data": {"site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/metroid-prime/3030-15473/", "expected_release_quarter": null, "description": "<h2>Overview</h2><p>The first game in the critically acclaimed Metroid Prime series is the <a href=\"/metroid/3015-1081\" data-ref-id=\"3015-1081\">Metroid</a> series' first foray into 3D, as well as an initially controversial shift from a <a href=\"/third-person-perspective/3015-464\" data-ref-id=\"3015-464\">third person</a> to a <a href=\"/first-person-perspective/3015-330\" data-ref-id=\"3015-330\">first person</a> perspective.</p><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/9755/454850-m_metroid_art_12_jpg.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-454850\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"1.3872832369942\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:138.7%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/9755/454850-m_metroid_art_12_jpg.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-454850\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/9755/454850-m_metroid_art_12_jpg.jpg\"/></a><figcaption>An enthroned Chozo.</figcaption></figure><p>Developed by <a href=\"/retro-studios/3010-1507\" data-ref-id=\"3010-1507\">Retro Studios</a> along with important members from Nintendo's <a href=\"/nintendo-ead/3010-463\" data-ref-id=\"3010-463\">EAD</a> and <a href=\"/nintendo-rd1/3010-928\" data-ref-id=\"3010-928\">R&amp;D1</a> divisions, the game was proclaimed a \"First Person Adventure\" by <a href=\"/nintendo/3010-90\" data-ref-id=\"3010-90\">Nintendo</a>. Metroid Prime combines multiple gameplay elements, such as platforming, <a href=\"/puzzles/3015-932\" data-ref-id=\"3015-932\">puzzles</a>, <a href=\"/exploration/3015-767\" data-ref-id=\"3015-767\">exploration</a> and shooting, while presenting a large, <a href=\"/open-world/3015-207\" data-ref-id=\"3015-207\">open-ended world</a>.</p><p>Metroid Prime revolves around <a href=\"/phazon/3015-49\" data-ref-id=\"3015-49\">Phazon</a>, a highly radioactive substance with mutagenic properties. The game takes place on <a href=\"/tallon-iv/3035-168\" data-ref-id=\"3035-168\">Tallon IV</a>, which has been corrupted by this substance. Throughout her journey, <a href=\"/samus-aran/3005-99\" data-ref-id=\"3005-99\">Samus</a> learns more about the nature of Phazon, as well as how her enemies, the <a href=\"/space-pirate/3015-1137\" data-ref-id=\"3015-1137\">Space Pirates</a>, intend to use it. She also learns of the <a href=\"/chozo/3015-605\" data-ref-id=\"3015-605\">Chozo</a>'s struggles, an ancient race that lived on Tallon IV when the infection first arrived.</p><p>As well as maintaining most of the traditional Metroid gameplay features, Metroid Prime introduces a number of innovations to the series. The first person perspective led to the introduction of <a href=\"/auto-aim/3015-145\" data-ref-id=\"3015-145\">lock-on targeting</a>, which allowed for a more intuitive combat system, as well as the ability to strafe around enemies. A <a href=\"/heads-up-display/3015-180\" data-ref-id=\"3015-180\">heads-up display</a> was introduced, which showed Samus' health bar and ammunition, among other details. A multiple visor system was incorporated, which allowed for different kinds of displays. The most intriguing display was the scan visor, which allowed a multitude of objects and creatures to be surveyed in great detail, as well as activating lifts and revealing <a href=\"/weak-spot/3015-296\" data-ref-id=\"3015-296\">weak points</a>. A hint system was built into the game to aid players.</p><p>Metroid Prime saw great success worldwide, particularly in America. This commercial success led to the development of a Metroid Prime trilogy, as well as other Metroid Prime spinoffs.</p><h2>Gameplay</h2><p>When Metroid Prime was revealed, the most controversial aspect of the game was its first-person perspective. With the game's release, however, reception eventually turned positive, with many generally accepting that the gameplay did not suffer at all from the new perspective.</p><p>Metroid Prime, like its predecessors, places a large emphasis on exploration. <a href=\"/tallon-iv/3035-168\" data-ref-id=\"3035-168\">Tallon IV</a> is an open world, ready for Samus to discover all its secrets, fitting with Metroid tradition. There are only a few instances in the game where the player is given a linear direction, albeit through subtle hints.</p><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/5911/492600-mp_queen_2.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-492600\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.75\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:75.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/5911/492600-mp_queen_2.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-492600\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/5911/492600-mp_queen_2.jpg\"/></a><figcaption>The Parasite Queen blasts Samus with a beam of energy.</figcaption></figure><p>The player controls Samus using the analog control stick. Unlike other first-person games of the era, Metroid Prime is controlled primarily with a single analog stick, rather then the dual stick format. In order to look around, players must use the R button. The R button allows the players to use the analog stick to look around and observe the environment, as well as aim at opponents. Samus also has the ability to jump using the B button. Platforming is an important element of Metroid Prime, as in previous entries in the series. Metroid Prime has been praised for its excellence in platforming, something few thought executed well in the first-person perspective.</p><p>Combat in Metroid Prime is similar to that of most other first-person shooter games, utilizing a variety of weapons. Samus fires using the A button, and when in the <a href=\"/morph-ball/3055-1049\" data-ref-id=\"3055-1049\">morph ball</a>, Samus uses the A button to drop bombs. To lock on to enemies, Samus uses the L button. By lightly pressing the L button while locked on, Samus can swap out targets. If the player does not wish to lock on, they can look freely using the R button, and aim at opponents through that method. While locked on, the player can press the B button to dash from side to side. Samus must use all of her beam weapons, as well as her missiles, activated with the Y button.</p><p>The C-stick is used to select the weapon which Samus will use. Samus's basic weapon is the power beam, which she begins with. Throughout the course of the game, Samus can obtain the <a href=\"/plasma-beam/3055-1024\" data-ref-id=\"3055-1024\">plasma beam</a>, the <a href=\"/wave-beam/3055-1023\" data-ref-id=\"3055-1023\">wave beam</a>, and the <a href=\"/ice-beam/3055-906\" data-ref-id=\"3055-906\">ice beam</a>. The plasma beam shoots short tang molten energy and can potentially ignite enemies, as well as melt ice. The wave beam fires three oscillating waves of electric energy, and has a limited homing effect. The ice beam is a cold blast of frozen water, and has a slow rate of fire. It can also potentially freeze an enemy in their tracks for a brief amount of time. Each weapon is strong against particular enemies, and all can be combo fires with Samus' missiles for greater effect. Once Samus obtains the charge beam, all weapons can be charged up as well, providing greater firepower.</p><p>In order to access many areas, Samus must use her weapons to destroy obstacles. Many doors are blocked by shields which require certain weapons to activate, and others have blast shields that must be destroyed with the missiles.</p><p>Samus has a variety of <a href=\"/heads-up-display/3015-180\" data-ref-id=\"3015-180\">visors</a> which will come in handy throughout the game, as well. The standard visor is the combat visor, which is used through regular gameplay. One of the most important visors, which Samus has at the beginning of the game, is the <a href=\"/scan-visor/3055-1040\" data-ref-id=\"3055-1040\">scan visor</a>. The scan visor is used to scan nearly everything in the environment. Scanning proves useful for gathering details about enemies, and discovering the most efficient way of taking them out. Scanning is also one of the main ways that Metroid Prime implements world-building, providing information on the lifeforms in proximity to Samus, as well as translating diary entries and other logs. Another useful visor is the <a href=\"/thermal-visor/3055-1042\" data-ref-id=\"3055-1042\">thermal visor</a>, which helps Samus track objects in the environment based on their heat signature. This visor is quite helpful in dark areas, enabling samus to see lifeforms clearly. Finally, the <a href=\"/x-ray-visor/3055-1041\" data-ref-id=\"3055-1041\">X-ray</a> vison allows Samus to look through walls to find secret passages, and track enemies who use <a href=\"/stealth-camouflage/3055-846\" data-ref-id=\"3055-846\">optical camouflage</a>.</p><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/5911/492601-mp_orpheon_parasite_specimen.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-492601\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.7\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:70.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/5911/492601-mp_orpheon_parasite_specimen.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-492601\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/5911/492601-mp_orpheon_parasite_specimen.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/5911/492601-mp_orpheon_parasite_specimen.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>A deceased Parasite specimen in Orpheon.</figcaption></figure><p>Like all previous Metroid games, Samus can transform into the morph ball. The morph ball is activated using the X button. Combat is limited, however, in morph ball mode, and Samus can only use the bombs, dropped using the A or Y buttons. The bombs prove most useful for morph ball jumping. A morph ball jump is performed by laying a bomb, then lingering over the bomb, which will shoot Samus into the air. Multiple bombs can be laid to reach higher areas.</p><p>One of the most useful tools in the game is the map. The <a href=\"/world-map/3015-611\" data-ref-id=\"3015-611\">map</a> is accessed using the Z button, and is a detailed three dimensional depiction of Tallon IV. As exploration is so important in Metroid Prime, consulting the map becomes regular throughout the course of the game.</p><p>As in all Metroid games, items are scattered across the planet. Samus begins with a number of suit upgrades. After an accident on the Frigate, however, Samus begins on Tallon IV with merely her power beam and power suit. As she explores more and more, she can regain her arsenal. Most weapons and visors are hidden throughout the game, and in order to obtain them and move further on in the game, Samus must find out how to reach them. Not all items are essential to the player's progress; however, some will prove very useful. Energy tanks and missile tanks are not required, but are still of great assistance. Some of the more notable items Samus can find are the <a href=\"/varia-suit/3055-1032\" data-ref-id=\"3055-1032\">Varia Suit</a> and <a href=\"/gravity-suit/3055-1033\" data-ref-id=\"3055-1033\">Gravity Suit</a>, as well as the <a href=\"/hi-jump-boots/3055-1448\" data-ref-id=\"3055-1448\">space jump boots</a>, which allow Samus to <a href=\"/double-jump/3015-1\" data-ref-id=\"3015-1\">double jump</a>. Metroid Prime also marked the return of the <a href=\"/grapple-beam/3055-1053\" data-ref-id=\"3055-1053\">Grapple Beam</a> from <a href=\"/super-metroid/3030-8292\" data-ref-id=\"3030-8292\">Super Metroid</a>, which allowed Samus to grapple onto specific points and swing over great distances.</p><h3>Wii Release</h3><p>On October 2, 2008, Nintendo revealed plans to bring various Gamecube games over to the Wii with new controls, including Metroid Prime. The official name of the Wii release is called \"<a href=\"/new-play-control/3025-1197\" data-ref-id=\"3025-1197\">New Play Control</a>! Metroid Prime\". In this rerelease, players control Samus with the Wiimote and Nunchuck, matching the controls of <a href=\"/metroid-prime-3-corruption/3030-4725\" data-ref-id=\"3030-4725\">Metroid Prime 3</a>. Movement is controlled by the analog stick on the Nunchuck. The biggest change to the controls is the aiming, which is now controlled by the Wii's IR pointer. Lock-on is still available and is done via the Z button. Shooting is mapped to the A button (missiles and other weapons on the directional pad) while jumping is controlled by the B button. As in Metroid Prime 3, changing visors is done by pressing the minus button and choosing the visor wanted by pointing on screen. Despite these changes, the Wii rerelease is the same Metroid Prime that was played on the GameCube. The Wii release also has 16:9 Widescreen and 480p support.</p><h2>Regions</h2><h3>Frigate Orpheon</h3><p>A Space Pirate frigate, this vessel was used by the Space Pirate Science Team for <a href=\"/experiments-gone-awry/3015-2046\" data-ref-id=\"3015-2046\">experiments</a>, some more bizarre than others. This is where the <a href=\"/parasite-queen/3005-4286\" data-ref-id=\"3005-4286\">Parasite Queen</a> resides, as well as the place that gave birth to a reborn <a href=\"/ridley/3005-1305\" data-ref-id=\"3005-1305\">Ridley</a>. In the beginning of the game, it is still partly functional. Samus eventually returns to the ruins of the Frigate.</p><h3>Tallon Overworld</h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/9336/208454-metroid_prime_4.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-208454\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.75\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:75.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/9336/208454-metroid_prime_4.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-208454\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/9336/208454-metroid_prime_4.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/9336/208454-metroid_prime_4.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>A cavern in the Tallon Overworld.</figcaption></figure><p>The place where Samus first lands, the Overworld is a green place, always raining. It serves as a <a href=\"/hub-world/3015-1855\" data-ref-id=\"3015-1855\">central hub</a>, linking to most major areas on the planet including the Impact Crater, along with being the place where the frigate crashed.</p><h3>Chozo Ruins</h3><p>The dusty, abandoned <a href=\"/chozo-ruins/3035-853\" data-ref-id=\"3035-853\">ruins</a> of a Chozo city, filled with stone buildings. <a href=\"/flaahgra/3005-4291\" data-ref-id=\"3005-4291\">Flaahgra</a>, the first boss of the game, is in this area, and rooms are often crawling with Chozo ghosts waiting to ambush Samus.</p><h3>Magmoor Caverns</h3><p>An underground area filled with <a href=\"/lava-stage/3015-532\" data-ref-id=\"3015-532\">lava and rock</a>. Long and narrow, the <a href=\"/magmoor-caverns/3035-921\" data-ref-id=\"3035-921\">caverns</a> are a dangerous place.</p><h3>Phendrana Drifts</h3><figure data-align=\"left\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/4745/254451-metroid_5.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-254451\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.68024132730015\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:68.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/4745/254451-metroid_5.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-254451\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/4745/254451-metroid_5.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/4745/254451-metroid_5.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Samus engaged in battle in Phendrana Drifts.</figcaption></figure><p>A <a href=\"/ice-stage/3015-2076\" data-ref-id=\"3015-2076\">snowy area</a> filled with icy creatures. The Space Pirates have a <a href=\"/phendrana-drifts/3035-855\" data-ref-id=\"3035-855\">base</a> here. It is also home to <a href=\"/sheegoth/3015-1332\" data-ref-id=\"3015-1332\">sheegoths</a> and the gigantic <a href=\"/thardus/3005-4274\" data-ref-id=\"3005-4274\">Thardus</a>.</p><h3>Phazon Mines</h3><p><a href=\"/phazon-mines/3035-1132\" data-ref-id=\"3035-1132\">The central point</a> for all Space Pirate activity on Tallon IV, the mines house many labs, much Phazon, and some sinister creatures in the depths.</p><h3>Impact Crater</h3><p>An area sealed off by the Chozo, the Impact Crater is the source of the Phazon infiltration on Tallon IV. This is where the <a href=\"/metroid-prime/3005-3974\" data-ref-id=\"3005-3974\">final battle</a> takes place between Samus Aran and the Metroid Prime.</p><h2>Weapons</h2><p>By the end of the adventure, Samus collects four different beam weapons.</p><h3>Power Beam</h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/4745/254485-metroid_14.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-254485\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.7\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:70.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/4745/254485-metroid_14.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-254485\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/4745/254485-metroid_14.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/4745/254485-metroid_14.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Charging the Power Beam.</figcaption></figure><p>The quickest to fire, and also quickest moving bullet but has the lowest damage per shot, good to use on fast moving enemies. The charged version is simply more powerful, and is the quickest to charge of all the beams.</p><h3>Super Missiles</h3><p>A big explosion dealing high amounts of damage, the Super Missile is good for taking out enemies quickly. It can destroy Cordite objects. Using a Super Missile depletes five missiles.</p><h3>Wave Beam</h3><figure data-align=\"left\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/4745/254551-metroid_25.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-254551\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.72837632776935\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:72.8%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/4745/254551-metroid_25.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-254551\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/4745/254551-metroid_25.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/4745/254551-metroid_25.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>A mouthful of Wave Beam.</figcaption></figure><p>An electrical beam with a partial lock on, the Wave Beam is useful against machinery. The charged version can stun some enemies, and has homing capabilities, serving best against quick enemies. This beam can also be used to return power to depleted electrical systems by firing at a conduit.</p><h4>Wave Buster</h4><p>This fires a continuous stream of energy that automatically homes in on targets. Although it is expensive to use, it is particularly useful against invisible enemies or when Samus's target systems are interfered with. The Wave Buster depletes ten missiles, as well as an additional five per second.</p><h3>Ice Beam</h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/14945/894716-metroidprimewii05.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-894716\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.56281407035176\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:56.3%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/14945/894716-metroidprimewii05.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-894716\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/1/14945/894716-metroidprimewii05.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/1/14945/894716-metroidprimewii05.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>A demonstration of the Ice Beam.</figcaption></figure><p>The Ice Beam has the lowest rate of fire, and the shots themselves move slowly as well, making it hard to hit moving enemies. It can also freeze them, allowing Samus to dispatch them with a single missile. Difficult targets require the charge shot in order to freeze them.</p><h4>Ice Spreader</h4><p>Sends out sheet of ice when it hits, freezing those it hits. Quite useful in confusing situations with an overwhelming number of enemies. The Spreader uses ten missiles.</p><h3>Plasma Beam</h3><p>The Plasma Beam, while fast, has a short range. It can set some enemies on fire due to the extreme heat. The charged version of this beam can melt thick ice with cracks.</p><h4>Flamethrower</h4><p>The flamethrower is a short range weapon that leaves behind fire on whatever it makes contact with, damaging things that touch it. It uses up ten Missiles over two seconds.</p><h2>Suit and Ability Upgrades</h2><p>Samus obtains various upgrades throughout the course of her adventure. These take many forms, and harken back to the original Metroid games.</p><h3>Varia Suit</h3><p>The Varia Suit is the first suit upgrade Samus receives, and the one she is most often associated with. This upgrade also provides a reduction in damage, as well as the ability to visit environments with extreme temperatures without being hurt. It is obtained by defeating Flaahgra in the Chozo Ruins.</p><h3>Gravity Suit</h3><figure data-align=\"left\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/6828/451485-gravity_suit.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-451485\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.75\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:75.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/6828/451485-gravity_suit.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-451485\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/6828/451485-gravity_suit.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/6828/451485-gravity_suit.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Samus in her Gravity Suit.</figcaption></figure><p>This suit upgrade allows Samus to move fluidly underwater, as well as increasing underwater visibility and providing additional damage reduction. It also recolours her suit with an indigo accent in place of the orange palette most associated with her. It is acquired in the Gravity Chamber in Phendrana Drifts.</p><h3>Phazon Suit</h3><p>The result of an overload of pure Phazon, the Phazon Suit is shades of black, silver, and crimson. It protects Samus from the effects of blue phazon (though not orange phazon), and provides the most damage reduction of any suit. It also allows her to use the powerful Phazon beam, only available during her final battle. This upgrade is obtained after the battle with the Omega Pirate, in the Phazon Mines.</p><h3>Visors</h3><p>Samus' visor has many different capabilities. The standard types are the combat and scan visors. There are also two others:</p><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/14945/894719-metroidprimewii08.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-894719\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.56281407035176\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:56.3%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/14945/894719-metroidprimewii08.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-894719\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/1/14945/894719-metroidprimewii08.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/1/14945/894719-metroidprimewii08.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>An example of the Thermal Visor in action.</figcaption></figure><p><b>Thermal Visor </b>- This visor allows Samus to see the heat signatures of everything around her. It is used to find Shadow Pirates in camoflauge and disabled energy conduits.</p><p><b>X-Ray Viso</b>r - This visor is used to see beyond the visible light spectrum. It allows her to see enemies that are invisible to even thermal imaging, and to see through flesh, most notably seen through Samus' arm cannon, instead only showing her bones.</p><h3>Missile Launcher</h3><p>The missile launcher allows Samus to fire missiles. At first, only five missiles are available to be stored onhand, but this is upgradeable by finding one of many missile expansions throughout the world. They are more powerful than a standard beam shot, and can hone in on targets, as well as opening doors and destroying certain materials.</p><h3>Morph Ball</h3><figure data-align=\"left\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/1675/273893-mprime_47.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-273893\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.75\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:75.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/1675/273893-mprime_47.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-273893\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/1675/273893-mprime_47.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/1675/273893-mprime_47.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>The Spider Ball in use.</figcaption></figure><p>In morph ball mode, Samus becomes a ball of pure energy, encased in her power suit, and can roll around, allowing access to areas previously out of reach. It is gotten once the Plated Beetle in the Chozo Ruins has been defeated. It has various upgrades:</p><p><b>Bombs</b> - Getting this upgrade allows Samus to drop small bombs while in Morph Ball form. These can destroy certain materials, are effective against many enemies, and can even serve a purpose in some boss fights. They can also be dropped into bomb slots to activate certain things. It is gotten once the Incinerator Drone in the Chozo Ruins has been beaten.</p><p><b>Power Bombs</b> - Able to destroy Bendezium objects and stronger enemies, the Power Bomb is one of Samus' strongest weapons. The number available can be expanded. This upgrade is obtained by defeating the Beta Drone and passing through the maze in the Phazon Mines.</p><p><b>Boost Bal</b>l - This upgrade affords Samus a short burst of speed while in Morph Ball mode. Useful for traversing half-pipes and defeating smaller enemies. Acquired in Phendrana Canyon in Phendrana Drifts.</p><p><b>Spider Ball</b> - This upgrade allows Samus to stick to and roll along the magnetic tracks that wind around Tallon IV. Bombs provide a small jump off the track. This is gotten by defeating Thardus in Phendrana Drifts.</p><h3>Space Jump Boots</h3><p>These boots give Samus the ability to double jump. They are equipped with boosters to give Samus that extra jump she needs. They are found in the Alcove in Tallon Overworld. They are unique to the <i>Prime</i> series.</p><h3>Grapple Beam</h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/4231/1017875-metroidprimegrap.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1017875\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.75\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:75.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/4231/1017875-metroidprimegrap.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1017875\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/4231/1017875-metroidprimegrap.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/4231/1017875-metroidprimegrap.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Samus using the Grapple Beam to swing across a gap.</figcaption></figure><p>Different from other beams in that it can't be used to attack, the Grapple Beam is used to attach to grapple points and cross large distances. It is found in the Storage Depot in Phazon Mines.</p><h2>Bonuses and Secrets</h2><h3>Unlocking the fusion suit</h3><p>This can be unlocked by connecting Metroid Fusion to the GameCube after completion of Metroid Prime. The fusion suit will then be selectable from the start menu of Prime. It is solely cosmetic, however. In the <a href=\"/metroid-prime-trilogy/3030-26559\" data-ref-id=\"3030-26559\">Metroid Prime Trilogy</a> version for <a href=\"/wii/3045-36\" data-ref-id=\"3045-36\">Wii</a>, it is unlocked by beating the game once and purchasing it from the Extras store.</p><h3>Play the original Metroid (NES)</h3><p>Upon completion of <i>Metroid Fusion</i>, connecting the completed game to a copy of Metroid Prime will unlock a playable version of the first Metroid game.</p><h3>Unlocking Hard Mode</h3><p>Completing the game once unlocks hard mode.</p><h3>Unlocking the art galleries</h3><ul><li>Image Gallery 1: Compile 50% of the Log Book scans.</li><li>Image Gallery 2: Compile 100% of the Log Book scans.</li><li>Image Gallery 3: Complete Hard Mode.</li><li>Image Gallery 4: Complete Hard Mode with 100% of the Items collected.</li></ul><h2>Music</h2><p>The music found in the game was composed primarily by <a href=\"/kenji-yamamoto/3040-20628\" data-ref-id=\"3040-20628\">Kenji Yamamoto</a>, along with Kouichi Kyuma. A CD release came in June 16, 2003 in Japan and contained both Metroid Prime and Metroid Fusion soundtrack, named \"Metroid Prime &amp; Fusion Original Soundtracks\", The track listing for the Metroid Prime part is the following:</p><ol><li>Title</li><li>Menu Select</li><li>Prologue</li><li>Frigate Orpheon</li><li>VS. Parasite Queen</li><li>Escape from Frigate Orpheon</li><li>Planet Tallon IV</li><li>Ancient Chozo Ruins</li><li>VS. Hive Totem</li><li>VS. Giant Beetle</li><li>Chozo Ruins</li><li>Energy core</li><li>VS. Flaahgra</li><li>Lava Caverns (Burning Trail)</li><li>Lava Caverns</li><li>Ice Valley</li><li>Ice Chapel</li><li>Space Pirates (Laboratory Gate)</li><li>VS. Space Pirates</li><li>VS. Thardus</li><li>Tallon Overworld</li><li>Chozo Chapel of the Elders</li><li>VS. Chozo Ghosts</li><li>Ice Valley (Phendrana Deep Lake Area)</li><li>The Downed Frigate Orpheon</li><li>Phazon Mines</li><li>Phazon Area</li><li>VS. Omega Pirates</li><li>Artifact Shrine</li><li>VS. Meta Ridley</li><li>Artifact Shrine (Chozo no Huin Kaijyo)</li><li>Impact Crater</li><li>VS. Metroid Prime (Spider)</li><li>VS. Metroid Prime (Head)</li><li>Shrine Collapsing Epilogue</li><li>Ending Staff Roll</li><li>End Jingle</li><li>Record of Samus</li><li>Samus Aran Appears</li><li>Get Item Jingle</li><li>Get Artifact Jingle</li></ol><h2>Reception</h2><p>At first, many fans of the Metroid series were furious that Metroid Prime, the first Metroid game in a generation, was going to be in first person. This led Nintendo to clarify that the game is a \"First Person Adventure\" and not a first-person shooter. Once the game was released, however, many critics and former detractors praised the game's level design and incredible graphics. It was stated as being a great reinvention of the Metroid franchise into 3D. Many stated that the gameplay was well done and that the lock-on feature was a welcome addition as it allowed easy strafing. Still, some stated that the controls were difficult and that a traditional first-person control scheme, where the left analog stick controls movement and the right controls direction, should have been included. </p>", "deck": "Take control of Samus Aran in her first 3D adventure as she battles the Space Pirates on Tallon IV while uncovering the mysterious disappearance of its inhabitants.", "aliases": "mp", "image": {"icon_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/square_avatar/8/82063/2550128-primeclean.jpg", "medium_url":
