It was developed by Nintendo's in-house development studio, <a data-ref-id=\"3010-3433\" href=\"/nintendo-software-technology-corporation/3010-3433\">NST</a>. The gameplay is mostly racing oriented, and unlike <a data-ref-id=\"3025-564\" href=\"/ssx/3025-564\">SSX</a> focuses very little on tricks. Even when tricks are possible to do in the game, the player is not rewarded for doing them, and therefore the player is discouraged to do them. The tricks in the game are very similar to SSX, but the user controls them with the bumpers, and not button combination. The game also features 2 player play. In addition, the game was one of the only games that the Gamecube ever supported to go online.</p><h2>Long Development</h2><p>The game suffered from a long development time, being firstly announced in 1998, and was originally announced to the Nintendo 64 platform. {"duration": "1:00:00", "runner": "pok3monrocks", "data": {"site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/harry-potter-and-the-chamber-of-secrets/3030-8370/", "expected_release_quarter": null, "description": "<h2>Overview</h2><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets is a game made by EA based on J. K. Rowling's Harry Potter franchise. The game is based on the second book and film in the series of the same name. The game follows the plot of the book for the most part, although random missions were thought up to add length to the game, like multiple missions where you have to save or help other pupils.</p><h2>Gameplay</h2><figure style=\"width: 320px\" data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/4938/417169-185169.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-417169\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.74037089871612\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:74.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/4938/417169-185169.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-417169\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/4938/417169-185169.jpg\"/></a><figcaption>Inside Hogwarts.</figcaption></figure><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">The game starts out at <a href=\"/ron-weasley/3005-4554\" data-ref-id=\"3005-4554\">Ron Weasley's</a> house, where some chores must be taken care of in which the player will play some mini-games.</p><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">After that, the player gets sent to <a href=\"/diagon-alley/3035-2173\" data-ref-id=\"3035-2173\">Diagon Alley</a>. Here, the game actually adds the first additional gameplay sequence by expanding on the little side trip Harry makes.</p><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">After this sequence, the player gets taken to <a href=\"/hogwarts-castle/3035-569\" data-ref-id=\"3035-569\">Hogwarts</a>, where the game begins in earnest.</p><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets' gameplay is somewhat similar to that of <a href=\"/bully/3030-10281\" data-ref-id=\"3030-10281\">Bully</a> (<a href=\"/bully/3030-10281\" data-ref-id=\"3030-10281\">Canis Canem Edit</a> or <a href=\"/bully-scholarship-edition/3030-5092\" data-ref-id=\"3030-5092\">Bully: Scholarship Edition</a>), <a href=\"/rockstar-games/3010-1194\" data-ref-id=\"3010-1194\">Rockstar</a>'s over-the-top highschool simulator.</p><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">The player will need to take classes to advance the story. Upon taking one of the classes, the player will be sent into a backroom of the classroom in order to retrieve a spellbook associated with that class. The player will come across a spell that turns giant blue eggs into birds if the \"Transfiguration\" class is taken, while the \"Incendio\" spell that sets object aflame will be learned in the \"Defence against the Dark Arts\" class.</p><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">In between classes, players can also take missions from pupils. The game has a day/night cycle, and some missions must be done during nighttime. When it's dark, prefects will roam the halls of Hogwarts, as well as the grounds outside. Like in the books, there is always a contest going on between the houses in points, which are gained by doing things well in the classes. If the player is caught by a prefect or Filch however, some points will be lost. Magical trick items like dungbombs and certain spells to distract these watchmen can be purchased.</p><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">While missions are not being done, Hogwarts castle and the grounds surrounding it can be freely explored.</p><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">There are some odd jobs that can be done as well. the player can become champion of the dueling club, trade stuff with fellow pupils, attempt to make other houses lose points and run people over with a broom.</p><h2>Additional Information</h2><figure style=\"width: 320px\" data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/4938/417166-185163.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-417166\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.75072886297376\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:75.1%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/4938/417166-185163.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-417166\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/4938/417166-185163.jpg\"/></a><figcaption>The Lumos spell reveals more than you might imagine</figcaption></figure><ul><li>The player will eventually receive a broomstick, the Nimbus 2000. This broom can be obtained at any time while outside, though not in missions where the player has to go to the Forbidden Forest. This can actually be used to make certain missions easier, for instance; in one mission, school prefects must be avoided while trying to get across the school grounds in order to get to <a href=\"/rubeus-hagrid/3005-11628\" data-ref-id=\"3005-11628\">Hagrid's</a> house. The broom can be used to fly across the school grounds, avoiding that part of the mission entirely. The broomstick can also be used to reach otherwise inaccessible part of the castle, like certain rooftops.</li></ul><ul><li>There are huge differences between the PlayStation and PlayStation 2/Xbox versions of the game. For instance, while Harry travels to Diagon Alley with flu powder, things go wrong. On PlayStation, the player must attempt to keep Harry on the middle of the slide with the analog stick. On PlayStation 2 however, this sequence is not present at all, and the player simply gets dropped off in a cutscene. This is one of the few examples of the PlayStation game having more content in a gameplay sequence. For the rest of the game, this tends to be the other way around.</li></ul>", "deck": "Harry's second year at Hogwarts is marked with whispers about his parentage, snakes, and strange spells causing students to nearly be killed.", "aliases": null, "image": {"icon_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/square_avatar/0/4938/609950-cover.jpg", "medium_url": {"duration": "0:21:00", "runner": "DarkTerrex", "data": {"site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/the-incredible-crash-dummies/3030-20029/", "expected_release_quarter": null, "description": "<h2>Overview</h2><p>The Incredible Crash Dummies (known as \"The Incredible Crash Dummies: Slick Bouya no Daichousen\" in Japan. The subtitle roughly translates as \"Slick's Great Challenge\") is an action platformer game based on the Incredible Crash Dummies license, a toy series that became an animated TV show. The player controls Slick, one of the titular Incredible Crash Dummies, and must rescue Dr Zub from the evil Junkman before he can use the good Doctor's knowledge to create an army of robots.</p><p>The game was released on many home systems of the era, some of which varied slightly in their presentation and gameplay. </p><h2>Game Boy Version</h2><p>The Game Boy version of The Incredible Crash Dummies featured many different forms of gameplay, resembling more of a mini-game collection than its Super Nintendo counterpart. Players must either successfully crash the playable dummy, or successfully pass the Dummy through various levels.</p><h3>Levels (Dummy Stunts)</h3><p>Five separate stunts await the Dummy for testing. The <strong>Roof Jump</strong> comprises of a vertical drop off the edge of a burning building. Players receive more points for each awning they are able to break, and for each fire hazard they are able to avoid. A target is painted on the sidewalk, which the Dummy must hit in order to progress to the next stage of testing.</p><p>The <strong>Air Bumper</strong> stage puts the Dummy behind the wheel of a new car model, with improved air bumper safety features. The player must steer the car over air cans in order to inflate the bumper, while avoiding large pits on the test track, along with oil slicks that cause the Dummy's vehicle to spin out.</p><p>The <strong>Ski Slope</strong> tests the Dummy's agility and reflexes, as trees must be avoided, and points are awarded for any jumps completed.</p><p>The Dummy proceeds to enter the <strong>Bomb Factory</strong>, where the player must ensure the quality of bombs created by blowing out any lit fuses. Failing to do so on any three bombs will result in the stunt starting over. Conveyor belts move the bombs from the top of the screen to the bottom, with other various items. The Dummy is instructed to smash all of the other items with a mallet, ensuring that only quality tested bombs make it through the factory.</p><p>The <strong>Cruise Missle</strong> stunt is an arcade style level, where the player navigates a space ship in an extremely low gravity environment. Changing the ship's trajectory requires rotating the vehicle and igniting the engine, creating a delicate balance between speed and maneuverability as the player is timed. The Dummy must crash the ship on yet another bulls eye, ending the stunt.</p><p>After the end of each stunt, the Dummy's boss will critique the player's work. The Dummy receives cash if the stunt went as planned, and a small bonus if the boss was impressed. Three levels of difficulty are presented, with easy, normal, and hard, encouraging the player to revisit each stunt for more cash.</p><h2>Critical Reception</h2><p>Electronic Gaming Monthly gave the SNES version a review score of 4 out of 10. Mike Weigand wrote, \"...This side-scrolling, survive the levels-type game is cute at times, but the poor control and mandatory cheap hits by enemies ruin things\".</p>", "deck": "The Incredible Crash Dummies capitalizes on the early '90s popularity of the Crash Dummy characters. {"duration": "0:20:00", "runner": "Dragondarch, Darkwing Duck", "data": {"site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/the-goonies-ii/3030-10395/", "expected_release_quarter": null, "description": "<h2>Overview</h2><p>The Goonies II is a platformer at heart with a dash of \"first person\" perspective in the vein of Shadowgate or Deja Vu. The bulk of the game plays out as the player runs around random maps (like volcanoes, icy mountains or the obligatory underwater level) using various doors, vines, and ladders as a means of getting from one area to the next. The main character that the player controls is <a data-ref-id=\"3005-2645\" href=\"/mikey/3005-2645\">Michael \"Mikey\" Walsh</a>, the character played by Sean Astin in the Goonies movie. The Goonies II was developed and published by Konami and released in Japan on March 18, 1987; in North America in November 1987; and in Europe on December 19, 1988.</p><h2>Plot</h2><p>The Fratelli gang has captured Annie the Mermaid and the six other Goonies and imprisoned them in their hideout. Mikey must search the Fratellis' expansive, labyrinth-like lair to find his friends and bring peace back to the town of Goon Docks.</p><h2>Gameplay</h2><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/5018/398543-goonies.gif\" data-ref-id=\"1300-398543\" data-size=\"small\" data-embed-type=\"image\" data-ratio=\"0.3575\" data-width=\"320\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:35.8%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/5018/398543-goonies.gif\" data-ref-id=\"1300-398543\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/5018/398543-goonies.gif\"/></a><figcaption>Mikey, The Goonies, and Annie The Mermaid</figcaption></figure><p>Most of the world is a sidescrolling platformer with pits to navigate and enemies to avoid or destory. Ladders, vines, and moving platforms allow for increased access to the various levels. When the player goes from place to place using a door, the game changes into the \"First Person\" style of play. The player can then select from several different ways of interacting with the environment, like \"Go\", \"Hit\", or \"Take\". Most of the rooms are empty; some have exit doors, or picture frames, safes, and sometimes other random characters. The player is also able to use an assortment of \"Tools\". The main rooms that Mikey needs to find are the ones that have his other friends, \"The Goonies\", held captive. Each \"Goonie\" that Mikey releases gives him an extra bar of health.</p><h2>Items</h2><p>Mikey has several different choices of weapons to use during the game. Starting off, he only has his trusty Yo-Yo. Mikey can also find others like the slingshot, boomerang, Molotov cocktails, and bombs. Mikey also can pick up other useful items that help him in his quest to save his friends:</p><ul><li>The hammer allows Mikey to reveal hidden doors, safes, and holes in the floor and ceiling.</li><li>The ladder can be used to climb through holes in the ceiling or floor.</li><li>The candle can be used to illuminate darkened rooms.</li><li>Keys will open prison cells and safes.</li><li>A helmet can protect Mikey from falling icicles and stalagmites.</li><li>Glasses reveal secret areas.</li><li>Two different types of shoes: one allows Mike to move faster, the other allows him to jump really high.</li><li>There is a raincoat to protect Mikey from waterfalls and geysers.</li><li>Scuba gear to give Mikey access to underwater areas.</li><li>A bulletproof vest will decrease the damage taken from projectiles, such as those fired by the Fratellis.</li><li>The radio, necessary for receiving special messages.</li><li>Transceiver boxes which are instrumental in locating the imprisoned Goonies.</li></ul><h2>Enemies</h2><p>Other than the normal throwaway enemies in the game (like ghostly armor, or dragons, killer eskimo kids, snakes, spiders and strange tigers), the Fratellis are the main bad guys (and girl). However, they cannot be beaten (with the exception of Pip-Squeak); they are simply dazed long enough that Mikey can get by them.</p><ul><li>Jake Fratelli - Large guy in blue suit. Attacks Mikey with a gun.</li><li>Francis Fratelli - Skinny version of Jake. Arrows being his weapon of choice.</li><li>Mama Fratelli - Old lady from the movie. Throws bombs that bounce along after Mikey.</li><li>Cousin \"Pip-Squeak\" Fratelli (Not actually in the movie at all) - Short, squatty guy. Jumps at Mikey. Because of his small size he is the only one of the Fratellis that can be beaten.</li></ul><h2>Characters</h2><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/5018/398385-characters.gif\" data-ref-id=\"1300-398385\" data-size=\"large\" data-embed-type=\"image\" data-ratio=\"0.25357142857143\" data-width=\"560\" style=\"width: 560px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:25.4%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/5018/398385-characters.gif\" data-ref-id=\"1300-398385\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_super/0/5018/398385-characters.gif\"/></a><figcaption>Some of the helpful people that can be encountered in the game.</figcaption></figure><p>In first-person mode, a bunch of characters will appear in some of the hallways and rooms including:</p><ul><li>Old Man - Old guy dressed in a white robe. Usually means there is a \"warp zone\" around.</li><li>Old Woman - Also wears a white robe like dress. Reminds the player \"It's fun to play the Goonies 2.\" Also will drop the candle if Mikey punches her 5 times.</li><li>Konami Man - Superman or Captain America fan apparently, wears a red and blue suit. Refills Mikey's health bar if the player finds his room, which is usually quite difficult.</li><li>Eskimo - He is an Eskimo. (\"I am ERROR\")</li><li>Fish Man - He's a man, no a fish. He will sometimes give out bonuses including the high jump shoes.</li><li>Goonies - They are Mikey's friends and are being held in locked prison cells.</li><li>Ambassador Konami - A yellow alien looking dude that says \"Rescue all 6 Goonies to help Annie.\"</li><li>Annie the Mermaid - Just like the other Goonies, she is being held captive by the Fratellis at the end of the second underwater zone. Once she is rescued the game ends.</li></ul><h2>Fun Facts</h2><ul><li>If anyone in the game is hit (with Mikey's fist or the hammer) they will say \"Ouch! What do you do?\" - an example of the game's occasionally ridiculous localization.</li><li>If Mikey punches Konami Man or hits him with the hammer, he won't help the player anymore, and tells them, \"I don't give energy because you hit me.\"</li><li>If the player uses their radio right before saving Annie, they get a message from Konami thanking them for their business.</li></ul>", "deck": "Mikey must save his friends, the Goonies, and Annie the Mermaid from the Fratelli family in this NES platformer.", "aliases": "The Goonies 2\nThe Goonies II: Fratelli Saigo no Chousen\n", "image": {"icon_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/square_avatar/9/93770/2361767-nes_goonies2.jpg", "medium_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_medium/9/93770/2361767-nes_goonies2.jpg", "tiny_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/square_mini/9/93770/2361767-nes_goonies2.jpg", "small_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/9/93770/2361767-nes_goonies2.jpg", "thumb_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_avatar/9/93770/2361767-nes_goonies2.jpg", "screen_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/screen_medium/9/93770/2361767-nes_goonies2.jpg", "super_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_large/9/93770/2361767-nes_goonies2.jpg"}, "date_last_updated": "2014-05-14 01:41:15", "expected_release_month": null, "api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/game/3030-10395/", "number_of_user_reviews": 0, "original_release_date": "1987-11-30 00:00:00", "original_game_rating": null, "date_added": "2008-04-01 15:54:52", "platforms": [{"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/platform/3045-21/", "abbreviation": "NES", "site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/nintendo-entertainment-system/3045-21/", "id": 21, "name": "Nintendo Entertainment System"}], "expected_release_day": null, "expected_release_year": null, "id": 10395, "resource_type": "game", "name": "The Goonies II"}, "platform": "NES", "title": "The Goonies II"}
{"duration": "0:45:00", "runner": "error72", "data": {"site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/claymates/3030-1607/", "expected_release_quarter": null, "description": "<h2>Overview</h2><p>Claymates is a platformer released in 1993. It is the sister game to <a href=\"/clayfighter/3030-489\" data-ref-id=\"3030-489\">Clay Fighter</a> although neither release shared any characters or plot points. The game has players assuming the role of Clayton, a scientist's son who is turned into a ball of clay by a nefarious looking fellow for unclear reasons. As a ball Clayton does not have very many skills but he can grab other colored balls to turn into different animals. The game is a standard platformer otherwise, only presented entirely in a claymation style.</p><h3>Forms</h3><p>Clayton can transform into various animal forms if he finds their specific colored ball. Each has their own abilities and means of attack, but can only take one hit before reverting back to Clayton's ball form. If the ball form gets hit, the player loses a life and must restart at the last checkpoint.</p><ul><li>Clayton: Clayton is, by default, a blue ball of clay. He can jump and has a standard punch attack, but is very vulnerable.</li><li>Muckster: A supercilious cat, Muckster has the highest vertical leap of the characters.</li><li>Oozy: A vicious mouse, Oozy is fast and can roar at enemies to stun them.</li><li>Globmeister: A large squirrel, Globmeister is the only claymate to have a ranged attack.</li><li>Doh-Doh: A green bird, Doh-Doh is able to fly.</li><li>Goopy: A purple fish, Goopy is needed for aquatic levels.</li></ul><p> </p>", "deck": "Released in 1993, Claymates is a platformer game where the hero Clayton (pun unfortunately intended) has been turned into a ball of clay. He has to save his dad and, using power ups, can turn into various animals.", "aliases": null, "image": {"icon_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/square_avatar/9/93770/2363705-snes_claymates.jpg", "medium_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_medium/9/93770/2363705-snes_claymates.jpg", "tiny_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/square_mini/9/93770/2363705-snes_claymates.jpg", "small_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/9/93770/2363705-snes_claymates.jpg", "thumb_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_avatar/9/93770/2363705-snes_claymates.jpg", "screen_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/screen_medium/9/93770/2363705-snes_claymates.jpg", "super_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_large/9/93770/2363705-snes_claymates.jpg"}, "date_last_updated": "2014-08-19 09:17:47", "expected_release_month": null, "api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/game/3030-1607/", "number_of_user_reviews": 0, "original_release_date": "1993-11-20 00:00:00", "original_game_rating": null, "date_added": "2008-04-01 01:39:53", "platforms": [{"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/platform/3045-9/", "abbreviation": "SNES", "site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/super-nintendo-entertainment-system/3045-9/", "id": 9, "name": "Super Nintendo Entertainment System"}], "expected_release_day": null, "expected_release_year": null, "id": 1607, "resource_type": "game", "name": "Claymates"}, "platform": "SNES", "title": "Claymates"}
{"duration": "0:32:00", "runner": "Straevaras", "data": {"site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/actraiser/3030-7274/", "expected_release_quarter": null, "description": "<h2>Overview</h2><figure data-align=\"right\" data-embed-type=\"image\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/6150/464818-title.gif\" data-ref-id=\"1300-464818\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.87109375\" data-width=\"256\" style=\"width: 256px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:87.1%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/6150/464818-title.gif\" data-ref-id=\"1300-464818\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/6150/464818-title.gif\"/></a><figcaption>The title screen of the Super Nintendo version</figcaption></figure><p>ActRaiser is a <a data-ref-id=\"3045-9\" href=\"/snes/3045-9\" slug=\"snes\">Super Nintendo Entertainment System</a> city-building simulation and action hybrid. The game was developed by <a data-ref-id=\"3010-3151\" href=\"/quintet-co-ltd/3010-3151\" slug=\"quintet-co-ltd\">Quintet</a> and published by <a data-ref-id=\"3010-6337\" href=\"/enix/3010-6337\" slug=\"enix\">Enix</a> (before their merge with <a data-ref-id=\"3010-6323\" href=\"/square-company-ltd/3010-6323\" slug=\"square-company-ltd\">Square</a>), and the game was released during November of 1991. Although there was a sequel for the game, <a data-ref-id=\"3030-17123\" href=\"/actraiser-2/3030-17123\" slug=\"actraiser-2\">ActRaiser 2</a>, it completely abandoned the simulation aspects of the original, which caused many fans to dislike it.</p><p>ActRaiser was also released in 2007 on the Wii <a data-ref-id=\"3015-2925\" href=\"/virtual-console/3015-2925\" slug=\"virtual-console\">Virtual Console</a> in Europe, North America, and Japan. European mobile phones got a version of the game with a 2004 release as well. The game was also part of the <a data-ref-id=\"3015-3204\" href=\"/nintendo-super-system/3015-3204\" slug=\"nintendo-super-system\">Nintendo Super System</a>, an arcade system that allowed gamers to preview upcoming releases.</p><p>ActRaiser is a relatively well-received game. It was accepted into GameSpot's <a href=\"http://www.gamespot.com/gamespot/features/all/greatestgames/p-30.html\">Greatest Games of All Time in 2003</a> and was rated the 150th best game on a <a data-ref-id=\"3010-90\" href=\"/nintendo/3010-90\" slug=\"nintendo\">Nintendo</a> system by <i>Nintendo Power</i>.</p><h2>Plot</h2><p>Not much of a plot exists in the actual game itself in ActRaiser. However, much is explained via the instruction booklet. The instruction booklet states that <a data-ref-id=\"3005-1239\" href=\"/tanzra/3005-1239\" slug=\"tanzra\">Tanzra</a> and his six guardians attacked the Master. The Master was injured after the long battle, so he retreated to his sky palace and proceeded to fall into a deep sleep.</p><p>While the Master was sleeping, Tanzra drove the world into ruins. He divided the world into six lands with each being ruled by one of the guardians. When the Master awakes, fully rejuvenated, he is ready to free the world from the oppression of Tanzra.</p><p>After defeating Tanzra, civilizations begin to stop worshiping the Master with many losing faith in him and turning to other things. The servant notes this, and says that people only appear to pray and trust to the Master in times of trouble.</p><h2>Gameplay</h2><p>In ActRaiser, the player takes control of an incredibly powerful being known only as the Master. The Master has been awakened from a deep sleep to find the world in ruin. He and his loyal servant (a small angelic creature) then set out to rebuild civilization.</p><figure data-align=\"left\" data-embed-type=\"image\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/2014/389799-actraiser_58.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-389799\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.875\" data-width=\"256\" style=\"width: 256px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:87.5%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/2014/389799-actraiser_58.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-389799\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/2014/389799-actraiser_58.png\"/></a><figcaption>The Master takes the form of a warrior; here he is battling a boss</figcaption></figure><p>To begin this rebuilding process, the Master positions his sky palace above an area filled with enemies and demons. Then, the Master takes on the form of a strong warrior wielding a large sword. In these side-scrolling areas, the warrior uses his sword to dispatch many hazards, such as environmental hazards or monsters. The warrior can pick up power-ups by destroying statues situated in certain places around the level. The power-ups have a variety of effects, from healing the warrior, to bonus points. After defeating the boss of the level, the warrior moves onto the next section of the city-building portion.</p><p>The life bar that the Master has in his warrior form can also be extended as the Master gains levels. Leveling up is done through an experience system, in which the combined population of the Master's rebuilt towns amasses into experience. Also gained in leveling up is more SP, which can then be used to preform miraculous events in the city-building part of the game. Magical spells can also be granted to the Master through his followers that he can use in his warrior form. These spells deal significantly more damage than regular attacks, making them essential to the completion of the game.</p><p>In the city-building portion of the game, the player takes control of the Master's servant, a small cupid-like creature. Each town begins with only two humans, who then follow the Master's commands and aid him in rebuilding his world. They must be guided (the direction they are guided in is where they will build), and in turn will build houses, roads, and farms. The villagers eventually gain use of other skills, such as composing music or creating bridges.</p><figure data-align=\"right\" data-embed-type=\"image\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/6150/464816-oversee.gif\" data-ref-id=\"1300-464816\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.87109375\" data-width=\"256\" style=\"width: 256px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:87.1%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/6150/464816-oversee.gif\" data-ref-id=\"1300-464816\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/6150/464816-oversee.gif\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/6150/464816-oversee.gif\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Building a city</figcaption></figure><p>The Master also has the use of several magical powers in the city-building portion. He can summon lightning, rain, sun, wind, or earthquakes. Using these abilities, trees, rocks, snow, monsters, and much more can be cleared. In a few sections of the game, the abilities must be used to assist the villagers, starting windmills or putting out fires, for example.</p><p>However, the city-building isn't calm. There are several Monster Lairs scattered around the map. Monsters are spawned out of these lairs. The people have the ability to seal these lairs, making it a necessity to guide the population to the lairs. The cupid can attack the monsters using his arrows, but once he loses all of his life, he cannot attack until the people increase in population. Once all of the Monster Lairs are sealed, the people can gain even more advanced technology and techniques.</p><h2>Soundtrack</h2><figure data-align=\"right\" data-embed-type=\"image\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/3661/1712890-cover_l.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1712890\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"1\" data-width=\"320\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:100.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/3661/1712890-cover_l.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1712890\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/3661/1712890-cover_l.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/3661/1712890-cover_l.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Symphonic Suite from ActRasier</figcaption></figure><p>The critically acclaimed 16-bit soundtrack was composed by <a data-ref-id=\"3040-5461\" href=\"/yuzo-koshiro/3040-5461\" slug=\"yuzo-koshiro\">Yuzo Koshiro</a>. Brad Shoemaker <a href=\"http://www.gamespot.com/gamespot/features/all/greatestgames/p-30.html\">described it as</a>:</p><blockquote><p>Orchestral video game soundtracks are the norm these days, but back then, the realistic instrument samples really brought out the beauty of Koshiro's aural backdrop. Even though it was a first-generation SNES game, ActRaiser's score remains one of the finest on the system</p></blockquote><p>On Sep. 21, 1991, Koshiro released a 'Symphonic Suite From ActRaiser' CD that used a full orchestral arrangement for the soundtrack. It contained the following 10 tracks:</p><table class=\"t-editor full-width with-out-border\"><thead><tr><th><p>#</p></th><th><p>Track Name</p></th><th><p>Duration (30:40)</p></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><p>1</p></td><td><p><b>Opening ~ Tenkujo ~ Blood Pool ~ Casandora</b></p></td><td><p>4:20</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>2</p></td><td><p><b>Intermezzo I</b></p></td><td><p>0:18</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>3</p></td><td><p><b>Filmoa</b></p></td><td><p>2:53</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>4</p></td><td><p><b>Intermezzo II</b></p></td><td><p>0:31</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>5</p></td><td><p><b>Aitos ~ Temple ~ Korin ~ Sekaiju</b></p></td><td><p>5:19</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>6</p></td><td><p><b>Intermezzo III</b></p></td><td><p>0:20</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>7</p></td><td><p><b>Pyramid ~ Marana ~ Seijyaku ~ North Wall</b></p></td><td><p>5:56</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>8</p></td><td><p><b>Hitobito no Tanjyo ~ Sasagemono</b></p></td><td><p>3:06</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>9</p></td><td><p><b>Maju Arawaro ~ Kyoteki ~ Satan</b></p></td><td><p>3:18</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>10</p></td><td><p><b>Heiwa na Sekai ~ Ending</b></p></td><td><p>4:39</p></td></tr></tbody></table>", "deck": "ActRaiser is a hybrid of two genres: city-building and action platformer. The player takes control of the powerful entity known as the Master in his quest to rebuild civilization.", "aliases": null, "image": {"icon_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/square_avatar/9/93770/2363111-snes_actraiser.jpg", "medium_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_medium/9/93770/2363111-snes_actraiser.jpg", "tiny_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/square_mini/9/93770/2363111-snes_actraiser.jpg", "small_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/9/93770/2363111-snes_actraiser.jpg", "thumb_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_avatar/9/93770/2363111-snes_actraiser.jpg", "screen_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/screen_medium/9/93770/2363111-snes_actraiser.jpg", "super_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_large/9/93770/2363111-snes_actraiser.jpg"}, "date_last_updated": "2015-10-31 16:10:10", "expected_release_month": null, "api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/game/3030-7274/", "number_of_user_reviews": 5, "original_release_date": "1991-11-01 00:00:00", "original_game_rating": [{"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/game_rating/3065-29/", "id": 29, "name": "ESRB: E10+"}], "date_added": "2008-04-01 15:41:27", "platforms": [{"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/platform/3045-9/", "abbreviation": "SNES", "site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/super-nintendo-entertainment-system/3045-9/", "id": 9, "name": "Super Nintendo Entertainment System"}, {"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/platform/3045-87/", "abbreviation": "WSHP", "site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/wii-shop/3045-87/", "id": 87, "name": "Wii Shop"}], "expected_release_day": null, "expected_release_year": null, "id": 7274, "resource_type": "game", "name": "ActRaiser"}, "platform": "SNES", "title": "ActRaiser"}
{"duration": "0:30:00", "runner": "Ivan", "data": {"site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/sparkster/3030-19920/", "expected_release_quarter": null, "description": "<h2>Overview</h2><p>Sparkster and its prequel, <a href=\"/rocket-knight-adventures/3030-6339\" data-ref-id=\"3030-6339\"> Rocket Knight Adventures</a>, were released at that time in the nineties when tons of mascot based platformer games were being released. Like many of those competitors, Sparkster is a 2D platformer starring an anthropomorphic animal. The twist in this game is Sparkster's rocket pack, which can be used to fly around the level in eight directions for short bursts. Sparkster's quality and pedigree as a Konami game helped ensure it would be more memorable than <a href=\"/bubsy/3005-334\" data-ref-id=\"3005-334\"> Bubsy</a> or <a href=\"/aero-the-acro-bat/3030-19337\" data-ref-id=\"3030-19337\"> Aero the Acro-Bat</a> ever were.</p><p>Sparkster is not to be confused with <a href=\"/sparkster-rocket-knight-adventures-2/3030-21235\" data-ref-id=\"3030-21235\">Sparkster: Rocket Knight Adventures 2</a>, which was a direct sequel to the original Rocket Knight Adventures exclusive to the Genesis/Mega Drive. The US/EU version of Rocket Knight Adventures 2 is known as just Sparkster, making it easy to confuse with this SNES spin-off.</p><h2>Gameplay</h2><p>Sparkster controls like a typical 2D platformer. Many areas feature thin ledges that can be grabbed by Sparkster's prehensile tail and climbed around on. A regular attack with the sword also launches a projectile across the screen, and holding down the button after attacking will charge the rocket pack, which takes about a second. Once charged, holding a direction and releasing the button will send Sparkster shooting away. While dashing with the rocket pack Sparkster will ricochet wildly off walls, floors and ceilings, which is sometimes the only way to reach a certain area. Sparkster can also use a flip move by pressing the R and L buttons, which will cause Sparkster to quickly flip right or left. This can be done in mid air and is a great way to get around, but using it too many times in a row makes Sparkster dizzy and unable to move for a while.</p><p>In addition, Sparkster has a few unique levels that switch up the gameplay. There's a level where Sparkster pilots giant mechanical ostriches, which run automatically. He can fire ripple laser shots from the bird's mouth and make it go up and down to grab crystals as it speeds by. Towards the end of the game, there is a section where the player controls the game as a top-down shooter. That level's boss fight involves piloting a fighting mech, which is controlled by pressing the R and L buttons to punch with the respective hand.</p>", "deck": "Sort of a spin-off game to the Genesis game known as Rocket Knight Adventures. A Genesis game was released at the same time but was a more direct sequel.", "aliases": null, "image": {"icon_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/square_avatar/9/93770/2364768-snes_sparkster_2.jpg", "medium_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_medium/9/93770/2364768-snes_sparkster_2.jpg", "tiny_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/square_mini/9/93770/2364768-snes_sparkster_2.jpg", "small_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/9/93770/2364768-snes_sparkster_2.jpg", "thumb_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_avatar/9/93770/2364768-snes_sparkster_2.jpg", "screen_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/screen_medium/9/93770/2364768-snes_sparkster_2.jpg", "super_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_large/9/93770/2364768-snes_sparkster_2.jpg"}, "date_last_updated": "2014-12-29 18:24:42", "expected_release_month": null, "api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/game/3030-19920/", "number_of_user_reviews": 0, "original_release_date": "1994-09-15 00:00:00", "original_game_rating": null, "date_added": "2008-04-01 16:50:46", "platforms": [{"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/platform/3045-9/", "abbreviation": "SNES", "site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/super-nintendo-entertainment-system/3045-9/", "id": 9, "name": "Super Nintendo Entertainment System"}], "expected_release_day": null, "expected_release_year": null, "id": 19920, "resource_type": "game", "name": "Sparkster"}, "platform": "SNES", "title": "Sparkster"}
{"duration": "0:20:00", "runner": "Omnigamer", "data": {"site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/hagane-the-final-conflict/3030-11438/", "expected_release_quarter": null, "description": "<h2>Overview</h2><p>Hagane (\"Steel\" in Japanese) was created by CAProduction and published by Hudson Soft. The game is a sidescrolling platformer, using ninja weapons to attack all foes and even acrobatic skills to reach areas of the game. Because of this, the game feel familiar to the original <a href=\"/ninja-gaiden/3025-472\" data-ref-id=\"3025-472\">Ninja Gaiden</a> or <a href=\"/strider/3025-321\" data-ref-id=\"3025-321\">Strider</a> games. The character designs are the work of Keita Amemiya who also worked on the Japan-only <a href=\"/rudra-no-hihou/3030-564\" data-ref-id=\"3030-564\">Rudra no Hihou</a> as well as the <a href=\"/onimusha/3025-467\" data-ref-id=\"3025-467\">Onimusha</a> series.</p><h2>Story</h2><p>There were two clans who learned ninjutsu and black magic known as the Fuma and Koma clans. It was the job of the Fuma clan to protect a Holy Grail, whereas the Koma Clan wanted to use this Grail for ultimate power and conquer the world. They attacked the Fuma Clan and stole the Holy Grail from their hands. All members were killed except for one person, Hagane. He was then revived by Momochi by transforming him into an advanced android where his body was all robotics and his mind was still human. He then pursued forward into destroying the Koma clan and claiming back the power before it is used to conquer the world.</p><h2>Gameplay</h2><p>The games play similar to the old Ninja Gaiden games where the player can move left and right, can jump on platforms and kill enemies with his sword as well has a vast range of weapons in his disposal.</p><h3>Weapons</h3><h4><b>Sword</b></h4><figure data-align=\"left\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/13/137417/2304530-2304529-hagane__e__00000.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2304530\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.38235294117647\" data-width=\"68\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 68px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:38.2%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/13/137417/2304530-2304529-hagane__e__00000.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2304530\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/13/137417/2304530-2304529-hagane__e__00000.png\"/></a></figure><p>A good all round weapon. Used for close ranged enemies and deals a good amount of damage. It doesn't require to refill when using the sword and the sword comes out very quickly upon pressing the button.</p><h4><b>Kunai</b></h4><figure data-align=\"left\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/13/137417/2304536-2304535-hagane__e__00006.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2304536\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.32835820895522\" data-width=\"67\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 67px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:32.8%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/13/137417/2304536-2304535-hagane__e__00006.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2304536\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/13/137417/2304536-2304535-hagane__e__00006.png\"/></a></figure><p>While it deals slightly less damage than the sword, it's good for picking enemies off from a distance. They fire at a straight line and have a limited stock. The player can collect extra in packs of 10.</p><h4><b>Bombs</b></h4><figure data-align=\"left\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/13/137417/2304532-2304531-hagane__e__00004.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2304532\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.32352941176471\" data-width=\"68\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 68px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:32.4%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/13/137417/2304532-2304531-hagane__e__00004.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2304532\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/13/137417/2304532-2304531-hagane__e__00004.png\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/13/137417/2304532-2304531-hagane__e__00004.png\"/></noscript></a></figure><p>These bombs are used in a short range but can deliver extra splash damage to surrounding enemies as well. These too have a limited stock and can collect extra bombs in packs of 10.</p><h4><b>Grappling Hook</b></h4><figure data-align=\"left\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/13/137417/2304534-2304533-hagane__e__00005.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2304534\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.32352941176471\" data-width=\"68\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 68px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:32.4%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/13/137417/2304534-2304533-hagane__e__00005.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2304534\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/13/137417/2304534-2304533-hagane__e__00005.png\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/13/137417/2304534-2304533-hagane__e__00005.png\"/></noscript></a></figure><p>While the hook can also damage enemies, its main primary use would be for latching onto ceilings or any high ground above the player. Very useful for the difficult stages.</p><h3>Techniques and Combat</h3><p>Few things that Hagane has to offer is his agility in movement and also in combat. He can pull off many types of jumps and his attacks in combination with his movement can produce different abilities.</p><ul><li><b>Jump</b> - Player jumps in the air.</li><li><b>Mid-Air Roll -</b> Does this by rolling forward in mid air. Must time the jump perfectly to perform action.</li><li><b>Slide</b> - Can slide on the ground for a short amount of distance.</li><li><b>Foot Stomp</b> - Whilst in the air, he can bounce on enemies with his foot causing extra damage.</li><li><b>Latch -</b> He can latch onto ceilings or platforms above him to grab onto. Very useful for the later levels.</li><li><b>Wall Jump</b> - Whilst doing the Mid-Air Roll near a wall, he can wall jump and if there are 2 narrow walls, he can also wall climb to the top. However if there isn't a wall, he will slowly float back down.</li></ul><h4><b>Somersault Attacks</b></h4><p>Not only is the somersault good for evading attacks, but can also be used to attack. These types of attacks are used with the somersault buttons and pressing the attack button. Upon holding either of the shoulder buttons, with the character facing in the appropriate direction, the character produces 3 types of somersaults, with the distance shortening each time. Pressing either the attack or jump button will result in a new technique.</p><table><thead><tr><th>Number of Somersaults</th><th>After pressing Attack</th><th>After pressing Jump</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>1 - Normal somersault</td><td>Dashing Forward Punch</td><td>Flying Kick</td></tr><tr><td>2 - Partially charged with green aura</td><td>Spin Kick</td><td>Spinning Dragon Flame</td></tr><tr><td>3 - Fully charged with yellow aura</td><td>Ground Dragon Smash</td><td>Vertical Upwards Kick</td></tr></tbody></table><h2>Items</h2><ul><li>Kunai Blades - Adds 10 additional blades to stock.</li><li>Extra Bombs - Adds 10 bombs to stock.</li><li>Health - Heals one bar of health.</li><li>Extra Health - Add one additional health bar to life. Maximum amount of bars can be stacked to 5 bars.</li></ul><p>The levels themselves do have a strict learning curve due to the perfect timings on platforms as well as distinct boss patterns that they have.</p><h2>Bosses</h2><table><tbody><tr><td><figure data-align=\"left\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/13/137417/2371628-hagane__e__00003.png\" {"duration": "0:30:00", "runner": "Omnigamer", "data": {"site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/skyblazer/3030-6763/", "expected_release_quarter": null, "description": "<h2>Overview &amp; Gameplay</h2><p>The player controls the hero Sky (<a href=\"/garuda/3005-17497\" data-ref-id=\"3005-17497\">Garuda</a> in <a href=\"/japan/3035-37\" data-ref-id=\"3035-37\">Japanese </a>original) on his quest to defeat the Warlord Ashura and rescue the sorceress Ariana (<a href=\"/vishnu/3005-12514\" data-ref-id=\"3005-12514\">Vishnu</a> in Japanese original).</p><p>Skyblazer's basic structure is similar to many platformers of the era: he must pass through and conquer a series of stages, defeating the bosses along the way, on his quest to gain power and reach the last stage where Ashura and the dark god Raglan await. There is the occasional branching path as well, which allows the player try a different stage if they're having trouble with the current one. As well as jumping and attacking, Sky can also climb walls and leap off them as well as use several offensive and defensive spells, many of which also increase his ability to traverse a stage as well. Some aerial stages require that Sky take to the air with his wings, a few of which use the Super Nintendo's Mode 7 functionality - these stages play a lot more like a shoot 'em up.</p><p>Sky has several methods of attack which he gains by finding them spread around the levels. Sky's basic attack, a punch and kick combo, costs no magic points and he can perform it as often as he likes. He can also use the Dragon Slash from the offset, which is a powerful finishing attack that uses a little magic.</p><p>Additionally, by defeating certain bosses/stages he can acquire:</p><ul><li>The Comet Flash, which sends Sky flying horizontally. This is invaluable for passing by floor obstacles like spikes and lava.</li><li>Lightning Strike, which clears the screen of enemies. It's a move best left for emergencies, when enemies threaten to overcome the hero.</li><li>Star Fire, which fires bullets in eight directions away from Sky.</li><li>Heal, which gives Sky some health back.</li><li>Warrior Force, a helpful buff that turns Sky invincible and increases his attack power.</li><li>Time Stop, a power that freezes all enemies. It can be used on one boss.</li><li>Fiery Phoenix, the only magic that can destroy Ashura's shield.</li></ul><p>All these attacks require magic power, which can be found throughout the stages and after defeating enemies. Along with magic power (represented as red potions) and health (represented as green potions), Sky can also collect diamonds. These diamonds will give Sky an extra life should he find 100 of the smaller ones or ten of the larger ones (which count as ten small diamonds each).</p>", "deck": "Skyblazer is an action platformer from Sony Imagesoft, released exclusively on the Super Nintendo.", "aliases": null, "image": {"icon_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/square_avatar/9/93770/2364760-snes_skyblazer_2.jpg", "medium_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_medium/9/93770/2364760-snes_skyblazer_2.jpg", "tiny_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/square_mini/9/93770/2364760-snes_skyblazer_2.jpg", "small_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/9/93770/2364760-snes_skyblazer_2.jpg", "thumb_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_avatar/9/93770/2364760-snes_skyblazer_2.jpg", "screen_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/screen_medium/9/93770/2364760-snes_skyblazer_2.jpg", "super_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_large/9/93770/2364760-snes_skyblazer_2.jpg"}, "date_last_updated": "2015-03-04 05:09:57", "expected_release_month": null, "api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/game/3030-6763/", "number_of_user_reviews": 0, "original_release_date": "1994-01-31 00:00:00", "original_game_rating": null, "date_added": "2008-04-01 01:58:45", "platforms": [{"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/platform/3045-9/", "abbreviation": "SNES", "site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/super-nintendo-entertainment-system/3045-9/", "id": 9, "name": "Super Nintendo Entertainment System"}], "expected_release_day": null, "expected_release_year": null, "id": 6763, "resource_type": "game", "name": "Skyblazer"}, "platform": "SNES", "title": "Skyblazer"}
{"duration": "0:55:00", "runner": "soothingplumtea", "data": {"site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/mega-man-8-anniversary-edition/3030-19393/", "expected_release_quarter": null, "description": "<h2>Overview</h2><figure data-ref-id=\"1300-2589174\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/8/87790/2589174-mm8_jpbox.png\" data-size=\"small\" data-align=\"right\" style=\"width: 320px\" data-ratio=\"1.0996015936255\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:110.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/8/87790/2589174-mm8_jpbox.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2589174\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/8/87790/2589174-mm8_jpbox.png\"/></a></figure><p>Mega Man 8: Anniversary Edition (more known as Mega Man 8, known in Japan as <em>Rockman 8: Metal Heroes</em>) is a side-scrolling action platformer developed and published by <a href=\"http://www.giantbomb.com/capcom/3010-367\" data-ref-id=\"3010-367\">Capcom</a> for the <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/saturn/3045-42\" data-ref-id=\"3045-42\">Sega Saturn</a> and <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/playstation/3045-22\" data-ref-id=\"3045-22\">PlayStation</a> on January 1997.</p><p>It is the eighth installment of the original <a href=\"http://www.giantbomb.com/mega-man/3025-523\" data-ref-id=\"3025-523\">Mega Man</a> series (and the sequel to <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/mega-man-7/3030-7391\" data-ref-id=\"3030-7391\">Mega Man 7</a>). The only official installment of the series for 32-bit consoles, Mega Man 8 introduces a brand new art style (the second complete change in the series) and cutscenes detailed in animated <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/full-motion-video/3015-604\" data-ref-id=\"3015-604\">full-motion video</a>. The game commemorates the 10th anniversary of the series and is the last titled game in the franchise for 11 years (before <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/mega-man-9/3030-20975\" data-ref-id=\"3030-20975\">Mega Man 9</a>).</p><p>Set in the year <a href=\"http://www.giantbomb.com/year-x/3015-7424\" data-ref-id=\"3015-7424\">20XX</a>, the game takes place shortly after the events of Mega Man 7 (in which the <a href=\"http://www.giantbomb.com/android/3015-692\" data-ref-id=\"3015-692\">humanoid robot</a> hero <a href=\"/mega-man/3005-344\" data-ref-id=\"3005-344\">Mega Man</a> defeats both the evil roboticist <a href=\"http://www.giantbomb.com/dr-wily/3005-291\" data-ref-id=\"3005-291\">Dr. Wily</a>, for the seventh time, and new-found rival <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/bass/3005-1594\" data-ref-id=\"3005-1594\">Bass</a>). Two mysterious forces battle in outer space before crash-landing down to Earth, causing Mega Man (who was battling Bass at the time) to investigate. When he reaches the crater, he sees Dr. Wily (flying away with a mysterious purple orb) and a <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/duo/3005-10569\" data-ref-id=\"3005-10569\">mysterious damaged robot</a> to send back to <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/dr-light/3005-292\" data-ref-id=\"3005-292\">Dr. Light</a> for repair. When Dr. Wily sends a new group of <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/robot-masters/3015-154\" data-ref-id=\"3015-154\">Robot Masters</a> to combat Mega Man, our hero must battle Dr. Wily's forces while investigating the connection between the purple orbs and the damaged robot.</p><p>Because the PlayStation version was rushed to be released a month before the Sega Saturn version, the Sega Saturn version received some bonus additions, most notably access to special material (such as official artwork and <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/sound-test/3015-634\" data-ref-id=\"3015-634\">sound test</a> mode) and two new mini-boss battles (<a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/cut-man/3005-894\" data-ref-id=\"3005-894\">Cut Man</a> from the original <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/mega-man/3030-5251\" data-ref-id=\"3030-5251\">Mega Man</a> and <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/wood-man/3005-1185\" data-ref-id=\"3005-1185\">Wood Man</a> from <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/mega-man-2/3030-14026\" data-ref-id=\"3030-14026\">Mega Man 2</a>).</p><p>The PlayStation version of the game was later released (in North America only) as part of the <a href=\"http://www.giantbomb.com/mega-man-anniversary-collection/3030-6141\" data-ref-id=\"3030-6141\">Mega Man Anniversary Collection</a> compilation for the <a href=\"http://www.giantbomb.com/playstation-2/3045-19\" data-ref-id=\"3045-19\">PlayStation 2</a> and <a href=\"http://www.giantbomb.com/gamecube/3045-23\" data-ref-id=\"3045-23\">GameCube</a> on June 23, 2004 and the <a href=\"http://www.giantbomb.com/xbox/3045-32\" data-ref-id=\"3045-32\">Xbox</a> on March 15, 2005. An unofficial 8-bit <a href=\"http://www.giantbomb.com/demake/3015-7736\" data-ref-id=\"3015-7736\">\"demake\"</a> of Mega Man 8 was finished in 2010, coinciding with the release of the <a href=\"http://www.giantbomb.com/deliberately-retro/3015-996\" data-ref-id=\"3015-996\">deliberately-retro</a> <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/mega-man-10/3030-29413\" data-ref-id=\"3030-29413\">Mega Man 10</a>. More information can be found <a href=\"http://megaman.wikia.com/wiki/Rockman_8_Famicom\" rel=\"nofollow\" data-ref-id=\"false\">here</a>.</p><p>Shortly after the game was released, Capcom began porting the game for the <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/super-nintendo-entertainment-system/3045-9\" data-ref-id=\"3045-9\">Super Nintendo Entertainment System</a>, with the intent of selling it to those who have not purchased one of the two 32-bit consoles. Not wanting to make a half-hearted attempt, they ended up making an original Mega Man game (exclusively for Japan in its original run) using most of the assets from Mega Man 8 (including two of the game's bosses, <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/tengu-man/3005-1549\" data-ref-id=\"3005-1549\">Tengu Man</a> and <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/astro-man/3005-1440\" data-ref-id=\"3005-1440\">Astro Man</a>), titled <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/mega-man-bass/3030-13218\" data-ref-id=\"3030-13218\">Rockman &amp; Forte</a>.</p><h2>Gameplay</h2><p>The gameplay is similar to the previous games, but with some additions. The main priority is the player picks a level and fights the end boss; Mega Man will earn a weapon for defeating the boss. Rush also returns with some special abilities. Also returning from <a href=\"/mega-man-7/3030-7391\" data-ref-id=\"3030-7391\">Mega Man 7</a> is the item store.</p><p>Like <i>Mega Man 7</i>, only four robot masters are available at the start. After the player beats the first four, the other four will appear. The weapons earned from the first four robot masters play a big role in the other four levels; for example, in <a href=\"/search-man/3005-10196\" data-ref-id=\"3005-10196\">Search Man</a>'s stage, the thunder claw that was earned from <a href=\"/clown-man/3005-1609\" data-ref-id=\"3005-1609\">Clown Man</a>, is used to get through spiked gaps by using the thunder claw to grab on to metal poles and swing to the other side.</p><p>Rush returns in <i>Mega Man 8</i>, this time with new abilities. Old abilities like Rush Marine and Rush Coil have been retired, but new abilities are introduced. Each new ability can be earned by defeating the mid bosses in some of the game's levels. The first new ability is Rush can transform into a motorcycle - Mega Man can hop on, shoot projectiles, and run at high speed. The other is Rush will drop a random item for Mega Man, which can be a health item or ammunition for Mega Man's weapon. Rush can also fly up in the air and drop health or ammunition items for Mega Man. The last new ability is Rush can fly up in the air and aid Mega Man in battle by dropping missiles on enemies.</p><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/2/29889/1116076-untitled.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1116076\" data-size=\"small\" style=\"width: 320px\" data-ratio=\"0.74423480083857\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:74.4%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/2/29889/1116076-untitled.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1116076\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/2/29889/1116076-untitled.jpg\"/></a><figcaption>The item store.</figcaption></figure><p>Also returning from <i>Mega Man 7</i> is the item store. Items that were available in <i>Mega Man 7</i> were purchased by collecting bolts that were dropped by enemies. In <i>Mega Man 8</i>, bolts are hidden throughout the level, the player must carefully spent the bolts to purchase upgrades for Mega Man. Certain upgrades can improve Mega Man's Mega Buster, or affect other abilities such as sliding or climbing up a ladder. The upgrades include the following:</p><ul><li>Power Shield - Won't be pushed back when received a hit.</li></ul><ul><li>Spare Extra - Four lives will be giving to Mega Man instead of three at the start of a level.</li></ul><ul><li>Shooting Part - Five Mega Busters can be shot all together when charged.</li></ul><ul><li>Energy Balancer- The weapon with the least amount of energy will be refiled when an energy icon is received.</li></ul><ul><li>Exit - When a boss is defeated, Mega Man can exit a stage at any time.</li></ul><ul><li>Laser Shot - A piercing laser will be shot when the Mega Man Buster is charged.</li><li>Arrow Shot - A arrow will be shot out when the Mega Buster is charged.</li><li>Auto Shoot -When the Mega Buster is charged, the Mega Buster will be fired automatically.</li><li>Step Booster - Mega Man can climb a ladder faster than before.</li><li>Energy Saver - Will save the amount of energy required for a special weapon.</li><li>Super Recover - Increase the health or weapon energy Mega Man recovers.</li><li>Spare Charger - Weapons will be refilled when exited from a stage.</li><li>Hyper Slider - The power slide will increase in distance.</li><li>High Speed Charge - Shortens the time for the charge shot.</li><li>Rapid Part - Three Mega Man Busters will be fire each time the fire button is press.</li><li>Boost Part - The Mega Buster's charge time will be decrease.</li><li>Exchanger - When life energy is obtained while the life gauge is full, it will be transfer to the special weapons that's low on energy.</li></ul><h2>Stages</h2><h3><u><b>Tengu Man</b>'s Stage</u></h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/2/29889/1113180-gfs_50347_2_1_mid.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1113180\" data-size=\"small\" style=\"width: 320px\" data-ratio=\"0.75\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:75.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/2/29889/1113180-gfs_50347_2_1_mid.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1113180\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/2/29889/1113180-gfs_50347_2_1_mid.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/2/29889/1113180-gfs_50347_2_1_mid.jpg\"/></noscript></a></figure><p>Tengu Man's stage takes place high up in the air. Some section of the stage has the wind's current blowing directly towards the right, which affects Mega Man's movements by pushing him back. The stage also features a section Mega Man encased in a bubble floating upwards while dodging spiked balls suspended in mid-air. A Rush Jet section is feature in the stage; Mega Man and Rush go through hoards of enemies like a 2-D shooter. <a href=\"/auto/3005-11985\" data-ref-id=\"3005-11985\">Auto</a>, <a href=\"/eddie/3005-12032\" data-ref-id=\"3005-12032\">Eddie</a>, and <a href=\"/beat/3005-2361\" data-ref-id=\"3005-2361\">Beat</a> can aid Mega Man and Rush through the Rush Jet sections of the game.</p><h3><u><b>Frost Man</b>'s Stage</u></h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/2/29889/1113233-gfs_50347_2_14.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1113233\" data-size=\"small\" style=\"width: 320px\" data-ratio=\"0.75\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:75.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/2/29889/1113233-gfs_50347_2_14.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1113233\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/2/29889/1113233-gfs_50347_2_14.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/2/29889/1113233-gfs_50347_2_14.jpg\"/></noscript></a></figure><p>Most of this stage has Mega Man going through the stage on a rocket board. While going through it, waring sighs will appear - telling Mega Man to jump or slide. Enemies such as Big Telly will appear to drop bombs on Mega Man, the other enemy is Rabbiton - a skiing robotic rabbit, and the last is Penpen EV - a robotic pigeon that gets on its belly and does a jet boost.</p><h3><u><b>Clown Man</b>'s Stage</u></h3><p>An amusement park that has been taken over. Clown Man's stage contains platforms with a</p><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/2/29889/1115090-foto_mega_man_8__anniversary_collectors_edition.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1115090\" data-size=\"small\" style=\"width: 320px\" data-ratio=\"0.74\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:74.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/2/29889/1115090-foto_mega_man_8__anniversary_collectors_edition.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1115090\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/2/29889/1115090-foto_mega_man_8__anniversary_collectors_edition.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/2/29889/1115090-foto_mega_man_8__anniversary_collectors_edition.jpg\"/></noscript></a></figure><p>symbol on them. In the background a robot will appear and ring a bell, which will activate the symbols on each platform. If Mega Man where to be standing on one of them, the effect of one of the symbols will go off. The symbols include \"X,\" which means a piece of debre will fall on Mega Man, or a boxing glove will pop out of the platform, a skull symbol will drop Mega Man below the platform, a arrow symbol will bring Mega Man back to the beginning of the section of the stage, a question mark symbol will transport Mega Man to a random location, and a circle symbol means the safe zone - nothing will occur.</p><h3><u><b>Grenade Man</b>'s Stage</u></h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/2/29889/1115095-mmh_megaman8b.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1115095\" data-size=\"small\" style=\"width: 320px\" data-ratio=\"0.75\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:75.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/2/29889/1115095-mmh_megaman8b.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1115095\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/2/29889/1115095-mmh_megaman8b.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/2/29889/1115095-mmh_megaman8b.jpg\"/></noscript></a></figure><p>Returning from Mega Man 7 is Count Bomb CD - a platform that will self-destruct in three seconds. The enemy originally appear in <a href=\"/burst-man/3005-1461\" data-ref-id=\"3005-1461\">Brust Man's</a> Stage. Another version of Count Bomb is introduce, Count Bomb GEO - a walking time bomb. Sections of the stage contains explosive platforms, one of them is built with a fuse and the entire platform will go off if the fuse is lit. Fire Met will appear and lit the fuse; casing the entire platform to explode. Mega Man will fall to his death unless he makes it out in time.</p><h3><u><b>Sword Man</b>'s Stage</u></h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/2/29889/1115895-untitled.gif\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1115895\" data-size=\"small\" style=\"width: 320px\" data-ratio=\"0.73430962343096\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:73.4%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/2/29889/1115895-untitled.gif\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1115895\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/2/29889/1115895-untitled.gif\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/2/29889/1115895-untitled.gif\"/></noscript></a></figure><p>At the start of this stage, Mega Man has to open up four walls by performing various tasks in four different sections of the stage. The second half has Mega Man on a paddle boat going through molten hot lava. But Mega Man must be careful as the lava will shoot up. Mega Man can use it as a boost up to the next section. Mega Man will also go through platform sections that has a giant robotic hammer known as Kao go Meh da. What he'll do is follow Mega Man to the platform he's on, and slams the platform into the lava with Mega Man on it.</p><h3><u><b>Aqua Man</b>'s Stage</u></h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/2/29889/1115098-untitled.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1115098\" data-size=\"small\" style=\"width: 320px\" data-ratio=\"0.73903966597077\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:73.9%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/2/29889/1115098-untitled.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1115098\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/2/29889/1115098-untitled.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/2/29889/1115098-untitled.jpg\"/></noscript></a></figure><p>An underwater adventure that is filled with Surumaker that will dash towards the direction that Mega Man is in, and the Shellens will use the same attacks method as the <a href=\"/met/3015-3742\" data-ref-id=\"3015-3742\">Mets</a>. Underwater levels in previous Mega Man games acted in the same way as it would be on land, the only differences is it will affect Mega Man's jumping. In Mega Man 8, Mega Man can swim instead of doing an actual jump. Aqua Man's stage has areas of spikes on the top and bottom, Mega Man has to carefully remain in the middle by swimming in order to get through.</p><h3><u><b>Astro Man</b>'s Stage</u></h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/2/29889/1115097-untitled.gif\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1115097\" data-size=\"small\" style=\"width: 320px\" data-ratio=\"0.74267782426778\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:74.3%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/2/29889/1115097-untitled.gif\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1115097\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/2/29889/1115097-untitled.gif\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/2/29889/1115097-untitled.gif\"/></noscript></a></figure><p>The main part of Astro Man's stage is Mega Man going through a maze The maze is one big circle - as Mega Man moves forwards, hell head back where he started. certain walls will block some passage, they can be moved up or down to alter the route. Mega Man's priority is to carefully think about which walls to move around in order to get to the exit.</p><h3><u><b>Search Man</b>'s Stage</u></h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/2/29889/1116060-untitled.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1116060\" data-size=\"small\" style=\"width: 320px\" data-ratio=\"0.7489539748954\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:74.9%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/2/29889/1116060-untitled.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1116060\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/2/29889/1116060-untitled.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/2/29889/1116060-untitled.jpg\"/></noscript></a></figure><p>In this stage, the thunder claw and the flame sword weapons play a big role. Swarms of enemies will be running or flying around to give Mega Man a hard time. There's also an extensive amount of Thorn Vines planted throughout the stage, they can only be destroy by using the flame sword. There's also a section with multiple metal poles that Mega Man can use by swinging around with use of the thunder claw to get through obstacle.</p><h2>Robot Masters</h2><table><thead><tr><th>Name and Portrait</th><th>Attack/Weakness</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><figure data-align=\"left\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/2/29889/1116265-mm8frostman.jpg\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/2/29889/1116265-mm8frostman.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1116265\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/2/29889/1116265-mm8frostman.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img Wave</li><li><b>Weakness</b>: Flash Bomb</li></ul></td></tr><tr><td><figure data-align=\"left\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/125/197936-300px_mm8tenguman.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-197936\" data-size=\"small\" style=\"width: 300px\" data-ratio=\"1.1366666666667\" data-width=\"300\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/125/197936-300px_mm8tenguman.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img Hold</li><li><b>Weakness</b>: Ice Wave</li></ul></td></tr><tr><td><figure data-align=\"left\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/125/198018-mm8clownman.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-198018\" data-size=\"small\" style=\"width: 129px\" data-ratio=\"1.3178294573643\" data-width=\"129\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" The game is the sequel to the original <a href=\"/mega-man/3030-30993\" data-ref-id=\"3030-30993\">Mega Man</a> DOS game, not the NES titles. Confusingly, this was the second Mega Man title released for DOS, despite it being titled Mega Man 3. The console release had progressed to <a href=\"/mega-man-5/3030-1223\" data-ref-id=\"3030-1223\">Mega Man 5</a> when this game was released. </p><p>The subtitle The Robots are Revolting is only mentioned on the back of the box. {"duration": "0:39:00", "runner": "almondcity", "data": {"site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/mega-man-5/3030-1223/", "expected_release_quarter": null, "description": "<h2>Overview</h2><figure data-ref-id=\"1300-2589171\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/8/87790/2589171-mm5_jpbox.png\" data-size=\"small\" data-align=\"right\" data-ratio=\"0.93436293436293\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:93.4%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/8/87790/2589171-mm5_jpbox.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2589171\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/8/87790/2589171-mm5_jpbox.png\"/></a></figure><p>Mega Man 5 (also known as Mega Man V, known in Japan as Rockman 5: The Trap of Blues?!, and not to be confused with the Game Boy game <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/mega-man-v/3030-15447\" data-ref-id=\"3030-15447\">Mega Man V</a>) is a side-scrolling action platformer developed and published by <a href=\"http://www.giantbomb.com/capcom/3010-367\" data-ref-id=\"3010-367\">Capcom</a> for the <a href=\"http://www.giantbomb.com/nintendo-entertainment-system/3045-21\" data-ref-id=\"3045-21\">Nintendo Entertainment System</a> on December 1992.</p><p>It is the fifth installment of the original <a href=\"http://www.giantbomb.com/mega-man/3025-523\" data-ref-id=\"3025-523\">Mega Man</a> series (and the sequel to <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/mega-man-4/3030-8141\" data-ref-id=\"3030-8141\">Mega Man 4</a>). Along with an improved <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/mega-buster/3055-518\" data-ref-id=\"3055-518\">Mega Buster</a>, protagonist <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/mega-man/3005-344\" data-ref-id=\"3005-344\">Mega Man</a> can now collect eight circuit chips to help assemble <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/beat/3005-2361\" data-ref-id=\"3005-2361\">Beat</a>, a robotic <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/bird/3015-3105\" data-ref-id=\"3015-3105\">bird</a> (created by both his creator <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/dr-light/3005-292\" data-ref-id=\"3005-292\">Dr. Light</a> and his new ally <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/dr-mikhail-sergeyevich-cossack/3005-2335\" data-ref-id=\"3005-2335\">Dr. Cossack</a>) that can automatically attack enemies around him.</p><p>Set in the year <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/year-x/3015-7424\" data-ref-id=\"3015-7424\">20XX</a>, the game takes place months after the events of Mega Man 4 (in which the <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/android/3015-692\" data-ref-id=\"3015-692\">humanoid robot</a> hero <a href=\"/mega-man/3005-344\" data-ref-id=\"3005-344\">Mega Man</a> defeats the evil roboticist <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/dr-wily/3005-291\" data-ref-id=\"3005-291\">Dr. Wily</a> a fourth time). <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/proto-man/3005-1559\" data-ref-id=\"3005-1559\">Proto Man</a>, brother and ally to Mega Man, goes rogue and creates <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/robot-masters/3015-154\" data-ref-id=\"3015-154\">an army of robots</a> to set out destructive attacks all over the world. When Proto Man kidnaps Dr. Light, Mega Man (now with upgrades by his new ally, Dr. Cossack) sets out to rescue him and deliver justice to Proto Man's army.</p><h2>Bosses</h2><h3><a href=\"/gravity-man/3005-1391\" data-ref-id=\"3005-1391\">Gravity Man</a></h3><figure data-align=\"left\" Wave</li><li><b>Weakness:</b> Charge Kick</li></ul><h3><a href=\"/stone-man/3005-1505\" data-ref-id=\"3005-1505\">Stone Man</a></h3><figure data-align=\"left\"
