{"duration": "1:45:00", "runner": "Blood_Thunder", "data": {"site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/wolfenstein-the-new-order/3030-42581/", "expected_release_quarter": null, "description": "<h2>Overview</h2><p>Wolfenstein: The New Order was developed by <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/machinegames/3010-7331\" data-ref-id=\"3010-7331\">MachineGames</a>, a studio formed in 2009 by many of the people who founded <a href=\"/starbreeze-studios-ab/3010-1768\" data-ref-id=\"3010-1768\">Starbreeze</a>.</p><p>The game takes place in 1960, and is set in an alternate historical timeline in which the <a href=\"/nazis/3015-113\" data-ref-id=\"3015-113\">Nazis</a> developed <a href=\"/nuclear-bomb/3055-231\" data-ref-id=\"3055-231\">nuclear weapons</a> before the United States and won <a href=\"/world-war-ii/3015-471\" data-ref-id=\"3015-471\">World War II</a>, allowing them to achieve world domination. Now, their technological advancements far exceed what would have otherwise existed in the '60s or even today, ranging from <a href=\"/energy-weapons/3015-6658\" data-ref-id=\"3015-6658\">energy weapons</a> to heavily-armed <a href=\"/robots/3015-278\" data-ref-id=\"3015-278\">robots</a> and <a href=\"/mech/3055-21\" data-ref-id=\"3055-21\">mechs</a>.</p><p> </p><h2>Gameplay</h2><p>Wolfenstein: The New Order is a fast-paced first-person shooter that takes inspiration from earlier Wolfenstein games in a few aspects. It has a limited health regeneration system, meaning the player must rely on picking up <a href=\"/health-pack/3055-255\" data-ref-id=\"3055-255\">health</a> and <a href=\"/armor-points/3015-8323\" data-ref-id=\"3015-8323\">armor</a> packs to survive. All of the weapons can be dual-wielded and the amount of carried ammo is relatively limited, encouraging scavenging and exploration of the levels. There are a number of <a href=\"/collectibles/3015-375\" data-ref-id=\"3015-375\">collectables</a>, many of which are hidden in <a href=\"/hidden-room/3015-3078\" data-ref-id=\"3015-3078\">secret rooms</a> which require basic <a href=\"/puzzles/3015-932\" data-ref-id=\"3015-932\">puzzle</a> solving to access.</p><p> </p><h2>Story</h2><figure data-ref-id=\"1300-2634732\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/329/2634732-wolfenstein%C2%AE_+the+new+order_20140520113850.jpg\" data-size=\"small\" data-align=\"right\" data-embed-type=\"image\" data-ratio=\"0.5625\" data-width=\"320\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:56.3%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/329/2634732-wolfenstein%C2%AE_+the+new+order_20140520113850.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2634732\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/329/2634732-wolfenstein%C2%AE_+the+new+order_20140520113850.jpg\"/></a><figcaption>Fergus Reid</figcaption></figure><p>Wolfenstein: The New Order opens in 1946 as the Allies attempt a desperate assault on the sea-side compound of General <a href=\"/wilhelm-strasse/3005-11687\" data-ref-id=\"3005-11687\">Wilhelm 'Deathshead' Strasse</a>, a scientist whose technological advances have allowed the Nazis to turn the tide of the war. <a href=\"/bj-blazkowicz/3005-753\" data-ref-id=\"3005-753\">B.J. Blazkowicz</a>, along with his squadmates <a href=\"/fergus-reid/3005-29500\" data-ref-id=\"3005-29500\">Fergus Reid </a>and <a href=\"/probst-wyatt-iii/3005-29501\" data-ref-id=\"3005-29501\">Probst Wyatt</a> manage to breach the compound but are captured by General Deathshead.</p><p>Deathshead forces Blazkowicz to choose which of his squadmates will live. Deathshead says that he will take the other's eyes for use in a medical experiment. After being forced to witness the dissection of the squadmate the player has condemned to death, Deathshead attempts to kill them both as well using the room's incinerator. However, both characters escape. In their escape Blazkowicz is wounded by a piece of shrapnel in the skull, falling into the ocean unconscious.</p><p>Blazkowicz is pulled from the sea by Polish fishermen, and based on the fact he is unable to speak or move, he is sent to an asylum run by the Oliwa family. As the Nazis grow in power, defeating other nations, their visits to the asylum for 'specimens' become more frequent, as shown in the game's introductory cutscene. The game begins when a group arrive in 1960, proclaiming that the asylum is to be liquidated. The Nazis begin to shoot the inmates; when the staff resist, they too are shot. This moment sparks Blazkowicz's 'reactivation', for he becomes aware of his surroundings again and kills his way out of the asylum, saving <a href=\"/anya-oliwa/3005-29499\" data-ref-id=\"3005-29499\">Anya Oliwa</a> in the process. Together, they are the only survivors from the asylum.</p><p>Blazkowicz spends time with Anya's grandparents in Poland, learning that the Nazis rule the world and the United States, as Fergus had predicted, would surrender. In the game's timeline, the USA surrendered in 1948 after the Nazis dropped atomic bombs. Resistance has been all but crushed, and the few who have resisted the regime are held in Berlin's Eisenwald Prison: built in the late 1940s, it is notable as there have been no escapees in its history. Anya and Blazkowicz, with the aid of her grandparents, make it to a train bound for Berlin.</p><p>Aboard the train Blazkowicz is confronted by <a href=\"/frau-engel/3005-29498\" data-ref-id=\"3005-29498\">Frau Engel</a> and Hans Winkle, whom is referred to throughout the game as 'Bubi'. Engel forces Blazkowicz to engage in a Rorschach-esque test, choosing pictures linked to feelings of sadness and other emotions. She claims that, through this test, she is able to spot a true Aryan, and informs Blazkowicz that failing the test will result in him being shot. He manages to survive the encounter, and arrives in Berlin with Anya.</p><p>Upon arriving in Berlin, Blazkowicz breaches Eisenwald's perimeter by climbing onto the roof of the prison bus and accessing the roof. He is reunited with the squadmate who the player chose to spare in the opening mission, and subsequently introduced to the resistance movement headed by his old ally <a href=\"/caroline-becker/3005-29503\" data-ref-id=\"3005-29503\">Caroline Becker</a>.</p><p>Blazkowicz's first action with the resistance is the theft of three stealth helicopters in London, with the aid of resistance member Bobby Bram, who acts as a <a href=\"/suicide/3015-1408\" data-ref-id=\"3015-1408\">suicide bomber</a>. During the attack on the research facility, Blazkowicz steals files relating to the secret Da'at Yichud organization. These files explain how the Nazis managed to build the monolithic concrete structures that dominate their cities: a substance Anya dubs \u00dcberconcrete. They discover that a member of the group, Set Roth, is being helped at the Belica concentration camp.</p><p>Blazkowicz is sent in to find Roth and extract him from the camp. It transpires that <a href=\"/frau-engel/3005-29498\" data-ref-id=\"3005-29498\">Frau Engel</a> runs the camp, with Bubi as her second in command. While undercover in the camp Blazkowicz kills a sadistic guard known as 'The Knife', having been captured and tortured. He recovers valuable technology that Roth requires to engineer their escape, but when Engel learns of The Knife's death, she demands the immediate execution of all prisoners in Block 6. Seconds before their execution, Roth seizes control of one of the prison guard robots, known as \"Herr Faust\". Using Faust, he kills the executioners and seriously disfigures Engel.</p><p>Once the prisoners are safely secured from Belica, they hide with the resistance movement under the Reich's capital city, Berlin. Roth helps the group secure knowledge from Da'at Yichud held in a storehouse in the Atlantic Ocean. To gain this valuable knowledge, Blazkowicz steals a Nazi <a href=\"/submarine/3055-828\" data-ref-id=\"3055-828\">U-Boat</a> and the group finds the storehouse. Here they discover a type of armor with a neural interface that enables <a href=\"/caroline-becker/3005-29503\" data-ref-id=\"3005-29503\">Caroline </a>to walk despite being disabled. The submarine stolen was one of the nuclear variants; according to Fergus 'Eva's Hammer' the \"pride of the Reich's fleet\". With the commander having been killed the group cannot fire any of the nuclear missiles in its cargo: the Nazis store the codes in the lunar based opened on the moon.</p><p>In order to gain access to the lunar base, the resistance attacks a train carrying Deathshead's chief scientist. With his identity, Blazkowicz is able to gain access to the lunar base, where he is welcomed by the Nazis. They congratulate him on his success and make reference to the previous head, but Blazkowicz acquires weapons and systematically makes his way through the base and across the moon's surface in order to acquire the nuclear codes.</p><p>Upon returning to earth in a stolen cargo-ship, Blazkowicz is shot down by the London Nautica, from which he had previously stolen the stealth helicopters. While fighting his way out of Berlin, Fergus informs him that the resistance hideout has been found and Deathshead has sent one of his elite units to eliminate them all. After destroying the monolithic London Monitor robot, Blazkowicz escapes Nazi-controlled England and returns to Berlin, where he fights alongside the remaining members of the resistance to eliminate the Nazi attackers.</p><p>In an act targeted at Blazkowicz in particular, Deathshead has taken <a href=\"/anya-oliwa/3005-29499\" data-ref-id=\"3005-29499\">Anya </a>and Set Roth to his own compound, near the Baltic Sea. With the hideout having been destroyed and their numbers drastically cut down, the resistance launches a last-ditch attack on Deathshead's own compound. The captured members are freed and told to escape the compound aboard one of the resistance stealth helicopters. Blazkowicz is not able to escape, and chooses to face Deathshead and settle an old debt.</p><p>Before Deathshead opts to fight Blazkowicz, he informs him of what he did with the dead squadmate's brain - he used it as the basis for one of his robots, claiming it to have the \"intelligence of the human brain and the obedience of machinery\". Despite trying to fight with Blazkowicz, the robot pleads with him to kill it, which he does by removing the brain both from the robot and from Deathshead's containment chamber.</p><p>Seeing the prototype robot has been destroyed, Deathshead attacks aboard his own robot. While the prototype may have been the latest and greatest weapon in the Nazi arsenal, Deathshead's personal robot has been made even more deadly, featuring a shield as well as more guns. Blazkowicz ultimately destroys this robotic creation, pulling the stricken General from its wreckage and stabbing him repeatedly. In one last act of desperation, Deathshead pulls the pin on a grenade, killing himself and seriously wounding Blazkowicz.</p><p>Though seriously wounded Blazkowicz ensures all of the freed resistance members have escaped before he calls in the nuclear missile aboard Eva's Hammer. His act is one of sacrifice; without the helicopter it is not clear how he could escape Deathshead's compound himself. The game fades to black and the credits roll.</p><p>However, at the end of the credits the sound of a helicopter becomes louder, potentially implying that the nuclear missile was never launched and Blazkowicz was saved.</p><p> </p><h2>German Censorship</h2><p>Under German law it is illegal to display the swastika for non-historical purposes, meaning that German copies of the game do not contain swastikas or the 'Sig' runes adopted by the SS. The swastika is replaced by the Wolfenstein logo, while the Sig runes are replaced with a triangle. Surprisingly, the gore in-game remains intact despite players being able to - among other things - decapitate Nazis, sever their limbs, and (should they so desire) blow dogs up with grenades.</p><p> </p><h2>Collectables</h2><p>The game contains a wide variety of collectibles, some unlock new game modes or increased health and armor pools, while others are merely for completion. With the 'scout' perk, silently killing an enemy officer marks the location of all the collectibles hidden in the chapter.</p><h3>Enigma Codes</h3><p>Every level has a series of Enigma codebooks, gathering all of the pieces of a codebook unlocks a cypher which, when solved, unlocks a new game mode.</p><h3>Nazi Gold</h3><p>Each level contains a number of pieces of gold in the shape of various objects from the franchise, they serve no purpose other than to be collected.</p><h3>Records</h3><p>Each of the three chapters which take place in the resistance HQ (chapters 5,7,and 9) have a hidden record; each unlocks a re-imagined song written in the style of a classic 60's band or musician.</p><h3>Health / Armor Powerups</h3><p>Choosing Fergus in the first level of the game will branch the story along the 'Fergus Timeline', while choosing Wyatt will branch the story along the 'Wyatt Timeline'. Depending on the timeline the pick-ups found will vary: health power-ups appear along the Fergus Timeline. When they are collected, player health is increased by 10. Choosing the Wyatt Timeline will replace these health pick-ups with armor pick-ups, increasing the amount of damage negated per armor point.</p><h3>Letters</h3><p>There are a number of letters hidden throughout the game which provide details and lore on the dark alternate timeline of the game. These letters are written by various individuals inhabiting the world under Nazi control.</p><h3>Journal Recordings</h3><p>Throughout the game <a href=\"/anya-oliwa/3005-29499\" data-ref-id=\"3005-29499\">Anya </a>will automatically give you recorded readings of her cousin Ramona's diary, where she chronicles her vigilante attacks against the Nazi soldiers occupying her town. According to Anya, the diary was originally written in Polish. Dates on the entries refer to the early years of the Second World War, when the <a href=\"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polish_resistance_movement_in_World_War_II\" rel=\"nofollow\" data-ref-id=\"false\">Polish resistance movement</a> would have been operating effectively. The final record is dated to 1960.</p><p>Ramona's diary entries discuss her acts against the Nazis and her efforts to kill soldiers in a clandestine manner as well as the growing support for the Nazis among her own family and friends. The first entry justifies her attacks, as the Nazi soldiers killed a friend of hers. Her first kill is dated to June 25, 1940, when she stabs a soldier to death and records how he whimpered for his mother.</p><p> </p><h2>Promotional Methods</h2><h3>Records</h3><p>All cultural landmarks following the Nazi conquest of earth have been reshaped or suppressed to suit the Nazi ideology, as can be seen in the game's collectible records. Three records can be found in-game, and are recordings of real-world music in German.</p><p>The tracks are found on the fictional \"Neumond Recordings\" label (New Moon Recordings) and can be bought through iTunes.</p><p>The tracks are as follows, and were used for pre-release promotion. The tracks by Ralph Becker and Die Partei Fraue are also not included among the Neumond Recordings. Curiously one of the tracks collected in-game - Die K\u00e4fer's track \"Das blaue U-Boat\" - is not among those available on iTunes either.</p><p>None of the tracks feature any obvious Nazi symbols. Where these would be otherwise present they have been replaced by the Wolfenstein logo, with the most obvious example being The Bunkers' track \"Toe the Line\".</p><table data-max-width=\"true\"><thead><tr><th scope=\"col\">Track Name (German)</th><th scope=\"col\">Track Name (English)</th><th scope=\"col\">Album Covers</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>\"Mond Mond, Ja Ja\" - Die K\u00e4fer</td><td>\"Moon Moon, Yes, Yes\" - The Beatles (lit. Die Partei Damen</td><td>\"Nowhere to Run\" - The Party Girls ('Partei' indicating the Nazi Party)</td><td><figure data-align=\"left\" data-size=\"medium\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/3/32849/2637791-nowheretorun.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2637791\" data-embed-type=\"image\" data-ratio=\"1\" data-width=\"461\" style=\"width: 461px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:100.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/3/32849/2637791-nowheretorun.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2637791\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_medium/3/32849/2637791-nowheretorun.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_medium/3/32849/2637791-nowheretorun.jpg\"/></noscript></a></figure></td></tr></tbody></table><h2>System Requirements</h2><ul><li><strong>OS:</strong> 64-bit Windows 7/Windows 8</li><li><strong>Processor:</strong> Intel Core i7 or equivalent AMD</li><li><strong>Memory:</strong> 4 GB RAM</li><li><strong>Graphics:</strong> GeForce 460, ATI Radeon HD 6850</li><li><strong>Hard Drive:</strong> 50 GB available space</li></ul>", "deck": "The latest entry in the venerable shooter franchise takes place in a version of the 1960s in which the Nazis have established a global empire after winning World War II. {"duration": "1:00:00", "runner": "SavageDreamLord", "data": {"site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/amnesia-the-dark-descent/3030-30087/", "expected_release_quarter": null, "description": "<h2>Overview</h2><p>In this horror adventure, the player is cast as <a href=\"/daniel/3005-16475\" data-ref-id=\"3005-16475\">Daniel</a>, who, as suggested by the game's title, awakens with <a href=\"/amnesia/3015-286\" data-ref-id=\"3015-286\">amnesia</a>. He finds himself in a castle in 1840s Brennenburg, and all that he seems to be able to remember is his name, the fact that he lives in London and that something called a shadow is hunting him down. The game has three different endings that are largely chosen by the player in the final moments of the game.</p><p>Amnesia: The Dark Descent can be purchased from <a href=\"/gogcom/3015-2379\" data-ref-id=\"3015-2379\">GOG</a>, <a href=\"/steam/3015-718\" data-ref-id=\"3015-718\">Steam</a>, and <a href=\"/humble-bundle/3015-6612\" data-ref-id=\"3015-6612\">Humble Bundle</a>.</p><h2>Gameplay</h2><figure style=\"width: 480px\" data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/10/106662/1542228-amnesia02.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1542228\" data-size=\"medium\" data-ratio=\"0.5625\" data-width=\"480\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:56.3%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/10/106662/1542228-amnesia02.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1542228\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_medium/10/106662/1542228-amnesia02.jpg\"/></a><figcaption>Sanity stops draining whilst in lit areas. </figcaption></figure><p>Amnesia: The Dark Descent is a first-person <a href=\"/survival-horror/3015-4801\" data-ref-id=\"3015-4801\">survival horror</a> game which focuses the player on exploring a centuries-old Prussian castle whilst avoiding elements of danger and being careful of the supernatural.</p><p>The game has a health system that includes Daniel's psychological health (sanity) as well as his physical health. Seeing and being involved in disturbing events in the game will drain his sanity, eventually leaving him with hallucinations and impaired movement and vision. Dips in Daniel's sanity allow the supernatural to spot him quickly. Sanity stops draining when in lit areas, and it regenerates to a healthy state if Daniel solves a puzzle. The sanity system can be considered similar to the one found in <a href=\"/eternal-darkness-sanitys-requiem/3030-7512\" data-ref-id=\"3030-7512\">Eternal Darkness: Sanity's Requiem.</a> However sanity cannot explicitly lead to killing the player, unlike physical health.</p><p>The game utilizes a lighting system which affects the sanity of a character (darkness being detrimental to Daniel's sanity). The player collects and refills their <a href=\"/lantern/3055-1978\" data-ref-id=\"3055-1978\">lantern</a>, which helps light the way, but also collects tinderboxes to light <a href=\"/torch/3055-484\" data-ref-id=\"3055-484\">torches</a> or <a href=\"/candle/3055-814\" data-ref-id=\"3055-814\">candles</a>. The lighting system creates a balance between maintaining sanity and hiding from elements of danger.</p><figure style=\"width: 480px\" data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/5/57879/1638154-screen_shot_2010_11_22_at_4.03.25_am.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1638154\" data-size=\"medium\" data-ratio=\"0.625\" data-width=\"480\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:62.5%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/5/57879/1638154-screen_shot_2010_11_22_at_4.03.25_am.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1638154\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_medium/5/57879/1638154-screen_shot_2010_11_22_at_4.03.25_am.jpg\"/></a><figcaption>The inventory screen.</figcaption></figure><p>Additionally, the lighting ties heavily into the <a href=\"/stealth/3015-24\" data-ref-id=\"3015-24\">stealth</a> aspect of the game. Daniel has no means of defence, so the game explicitly states to the player at the start of the game that they should use their wits instead. This can include staying in the dark and moving carefully at the cost of his sanity, or using the environment to create distractions (such as by throwing a bottle to make a noise), and running away when spotted. This is the style typical of the developer <a href=\"/frictional-games/3010-2417\" data-ref-id=\"3010-2417\">Frictional Games</a>' <a href=\"/penumbra/3025-1219\" data-ref-id=\"3025-1219\">Penumbra</a> franchise.</p><p>Along the journey, the player can collect notes that offer insight into the story but also help solve puzzles. Puzzles range from simply combining items to puzzles that span of numerous rooms.</p><h2>Story</h2><figure style=\"width: 480px\" data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/10/101494/1703848-a12.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1703848\" data-size=\"medium\" data-ratio=\"0.5625\" data-width=\"480\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:56.3%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/10/101494/1703848-a12.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1703848\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_medium/10/101494/1703848-a12.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_medium/10/101494/1703848-a12.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>The gloomy wine cellar.</figcaption></figure><p>In an effort to recover his lost memory, Daniel proceeds through the halls of Castle Brennenburg. He finds a page from his own journal that explains that he must find and kill the Baron <a href=\"/alexander-of-brennenburg/3005-17785\" data-ref-id=\"3005-17785\">Alexander of Brennenburg</a>. The note also explains that Daniel is being pursued by what can only be described as a sentient nightmare that cannot be harmed in any meaningful way.</p><p>As Daniel makes progress into the Castle's entrance hall, he is greeted with a flashback that details a tidbit of a conversation between what appears to be himself and another individual. It becomes clear that Daniel is to follow the red rose petals that litter the ground. Just as he begins to do so, a large fleshy wall impedes his progress.</p><p>Daniel then decides to explore the laboratory. Once there, he discovers a note that explains that someone has locked a party of men in the wine cellar. Daniel decides that this is to be his next stop. After obtaining the key to enter the cellar from the archive room, he enters the incredibly gloomy wine cellar. The aforementioned party of men has, as expected, long since expired, and their remains litter the floor. Among them, a note is found explaining that they delivered hundreds of innocent men, women, and children to the Baron in exchange for political advancement.</p><p>Daniel returns to the laboratory to create a chemical compound using the components he discovered in the cellar. With this acidic compound in hand, he returns to the entrance hall to splash it on the flesh wall. Sure enough, he evaporates the wall opening a path.</p><p>This path takes Daniel to the refinery where he encounters his first monster. After it passes, he proceeds through a trap door into the cellar archives where he discovers that a water demon now inhabits the flooded area. After leaping from box to box in an effort to confuse the monster, he narrowly escapes through the door to the back hall where he is greeted with a calming fountain and a brightly lit room.</p><p>Daniel continues to follow his <a href=\"/flashback/3015-226\" data-ref-id=\"3015-226\">flashbacks</a> to an elevator lever that no longer functions. Upon learning this, Daniel explores Baron Alexander's study. Daniel makes a grizzly discovery upon arriving in the Baron's office. He has been attempting to harness some primal breed of energy from animals. In a note left on his desk, he explains that the energy is only released when the creature is about to experience death so being able to harness it with any sort of regularity will prove difficult.</p><p>The next stop is the guest bedroom where Daniel is quick to recall that he stayed here fairly recently. A journal page left here details an orb that he pulled out of a tomb on a recent excavation. The orb he explains contained a wondrous power but just as he felt it in his grasp, it shattered into pieces that he could not reassemble. Daniel then recalls that he left the key to the machine room behind a painting in his room. That in hand and a quick trip to a nearby storage room, he proceeds into the machine room to repair the elevator.</p><p>Another collection of Daniel's journal entries explains why he came to the castle in the first place. Apparently, he found himself haunted by horrid dreams after his incident with the orb. He requested the aid of three specialists as a means of getting to the source of his new affliction. Much to his dismay, all of the men ended up brutally murdered. Daniel then attempted to contact others who may know something more about the orb. He received varying responses but the urgency of the Baron's return letter piqued his interest. Baron Alexander requested that Daniel come to his castle right away before it is too late. Orb pieces in hand, he went straight to the Baron's castle.</p><figure style=\"width: 480px\" data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/5/57879/1638152-screen_shot_2010_11_22_at_4.00.15_am.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1638152\" data-size=\"medium\" data-ratio=\"0.625\" data-width=\"480\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:62.5%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/5/57879/1638152-screen_shot_2010_11_22_at_4.00.15_am.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1638152\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_medium/5/57879/1638152-screen_shot_2010_11_22_at_4.00.15_am.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_medium/5/57879/1638152-screen_shot_2010_11_22_at_4.00.15_am.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>The fountain in The Great Hall.</figcaption></figure><p>Once inside the elevator, it lowers him partway before malfunctioning and sending him into free fall. He crawls from the wreckage into a prison block that is shrouded in total darkness. A flashback explains that the Baron also carries the responsibility of a prison warden. After some careful traversing, he procures a hammer and chipper which he uses to widen a tunnel within a previous inmate's cell. Again more perilous trekking leads Daniel out of the prison and into the cistern. A flashback explains that the Baron uses this area as a secret underground passage. As is Daniel's luck, the route his former self used has been entirely blocked. This time a flood impedes his progress.</p><p>Daniel finds that the flood water can be drained from a nearby room. In this room he also finds a journal entry that details a warding ritual performed by the Baron. Daniel willingly had this ritual performed in an effort to slow the impeding doom of this shadow beast. The ritual involved killing a man the Baron claimed was a murderer.</p><p>Daniel then discovers that a poisonous fungi now inhabits the no longer flooded route into the sewer. He proceeds into the morgue which contains numerous bodies as one might expect. Daniel locates a note that details a toxin that wiped out most of Alexander's servants. The note goes on to explain that he has indeed developed an antidote that will surely stop the outbreak. Daniel observes that the Baron has made this antidote using the body of an infected servant. Daniel extracts the antidote and enters the sewers.</p><p>After evading yet more monsters in the sewers, Daniel arrives at the nave. This is a much more visibly depraved area of the Baron's castle as it functioned as an area for prisoner's who awaited torture. Upon entering the center of this area, Daniel is introduced to <a href=\"/heinrich-cornelius-agrippa/3005-19409\" data-ref-id=\"3005-19409\">Agrippa</a>, a shattered husk of a man who claims to be able to aid Daniel. He explains that Alexander has been using destroyed pieces of another orb in torture as they seem to produce intense anxiety in his victims. If Daniel can reunite those pieces, he may be able to stop Alexander from using the new restored orb that past Daniel had inadvertently handed him. Agrippa also requests that he create a tonic for him that would free him from the shattered husk he currently resides in.</p><p>Daniel then enters the various torture chambers in an effort to locate the old orb chunks. He also begins to suffer horrible flashbacks as he begins to realize what he has become. Daniel had been aiding the Baron in the torture of the countless innocents the Baron had delivered to his castle. He did so as the Baron claimed their suffering and sacrifice would surely slow the advancement of the shadow demon. As his grief overtakes him, Daniel recalls that the Baron and he raided a small farm home killing the husband and kidnapping the wife and her three daughters for sacrifices. A journal entry explains that Daniel no longer feels justified in the killing to keep back the beast. In this entry, he curses the Baron for making him do these horrid things and claims his revenge.</p><p>As Daniel returns to Agrippa to ask what he is to do next, he is swarmed by monsters who lock him in a nearby cell. Daniel's escape is quick but the Baron's voice fills his head taunting him. Suddenly, something terrible begins to chase Daniel. He narrowly escape back to the nave. Once there, he creates the tonic that supposedly will free Agrippa. Agrippa drinks it and requests that Daniel remove his head.</p><p>Daniel now enters the chancel to reunite the orb. A path opens leading to Alexander's hollowed inner sanctum. To enter the orb chamber where Alexander is surely awaiting Daniel makes a blood sacrifice and enters. A naked floating Baron greets Daniel there. He explains that he is hardly evil and that Daniel is to share blame in much of what has transpired. Alexander goes on to say that he is going to harness the power of the shadow which has grown tremendously with all the sacrifices to warp himself into another world. The three endings are as follows.</p><h3>Endings</h3><ul><li><b>Good Ending</b>: Daniel throws Agrippa's head into the newly opened portal. Daniel and the Baron are consumed by the shadow but Agrippa calls upon a man named Johann Weyer to free Daniel from the abyss.</li><li><b>Revenge Ending</b>: Daniel destroys the portal before it can open, and the shadow consumes the Baron but spares Daniel. Daniel leaves the castle with a guilt-free conscience.</li><li><b>Bad Ending</b>: The Baron escapes to the other world. The shadow consumes Daniel.</li></ul><h2>Development</h2><p>Amnesia: The Dark Descent started off a very different game than the final product; it contained a more traditional structure, with the main character running around several hub worlds that could be completed in any order, collecting money that he could then give to NPCs to help solve puzzles or advance the story. The story itself was very different as well; according to an early pitch document, it would involve the main character traveling to a Castle (much like Brennenberg) in order to prevent an evil \"Nobleman\" (much like Alexander) from orchestrating an unspecified evil plan. Killing enemies was originally a larger part of the game, even though the document states that \"combat is not a large part of the gameplay\"; the main character was to be given various weapons, including melee weapons and a bow &amp; arrow. The player could even trick monsters into walking into pools of <a href=\"/electrified-water/3015-8088\" data-ref-id=\"3015-8088\">electrified water</a> and other such environmental hazards.</p><p>While the game that Frictional originally had in mind was vastly different, there were some very distinct similarities. First there are \"Visions\", which were the predecessor of the flashbacks, and act as such. The puzzles, as outlined in the document, are identical to those found in the finished product: the team talks about balancing the slow, thinking puzzles against the \"action\" puzzles, such as when the player need to clear the debris during the encounter with the water monster. The interplay between light and darkness was still there, though it differed in the sense that light would restore strength, and that lighting a corridor would also make it <i>easier</i> to pass the monster. Also, they kept the diary entries, though they were written by other characters instead of the protagonist.</p><p>So, some things changed and others stayed the same. In the end, the team found restraint, choosing not to include the \"gamey-er\" elements and instead going for a so-called \"purer\" horror experience.</p><h2>Justine Expansion</h2><p>In conjunction with the <a href=\"/portal-2/3030-21662\" data-ref-id=\"3030-21662\">Portal 2</a> Potato Sack ARG, in which <a href=\"/valve-corporation/3010-1374\" data-ref-id=\"3010-1374\">Valve</a> held a sale of 13 indie games on <a href=\"/steam/3015-718\" data-ref-id=\"3015-718\">Steam</a> which were then subsequently 'invaded' by various forms of <a href=\"/glados/3005-722\" data-ref-id=\"3005-722\">GLaDOS</a>, Frictional Games released a short expansion to the main game, titled \"<a href=\"/justine-florebelle/3005-18629\" data-ref-id=\"3005-18629\">Justine</a>\". The expansion is more puzzle-oriented than the base game and features an omniscient narrator (not unlike <a href=\"/portal/3025-588\" data-ref-id=\"3025-588\">Portal</a>). It is loosely tied to the main game, with a collectible note from Daniel.</p><p>Players control an unnamed female protagonist who wakes up in a dungeon, at the bottom of a castle, with a monster at her doorstep. Like Daniel, she doesn't know who she is or why she's here, and so is led along by the voice of Justine, a twisted and mysterious woman, emitting from various phonographs around the dungeon. She has kidnapped three people who were important in her life, and she asks the player to spare them or kill them. The aforementioned monster comes in three forms (though they are the same visual model), each a different suitor for Justine. Players travel through the dungeon and slowly unravel who they are and who Justine is.</p><p>The game does not allow players to save, upon dying, players are taken back to the desktop. The developers have said that this is a deliberate choice made to \"ratchet up the tension\". The Justine expansion is currently unavailable if not bought through Steam, though Frictional has promised to bring it to other <a href=\"/digital-distribution/3015-2329\" data-ref-id=\"3015-2329\">digital distribution</a> services.</p><h2>Additional Information</h2><ul><li>According to the original pitch document, the game was at first called \"Unknown\".</li><li>Inside the game installation one can find a locked archive file called supersecret.rar. Inside the file one can find a variety of media which relate to the games development such as level progress flowcharts, concept art, early videos etc. The password to this file is <b>lke271tyr299odn314</b> and is obtained by piecing together the supplied string of characters found at the bottom of the screen in each of the 3 endings.</li><li>It is speculated that the passwords one receives at the end of the game represent the three Norse gods <a href=\"/loki/3005-1993\" data-ref-id=\"3005-1993\">Loki</a> (spelled \"Loke\" in Scandinavia), <a href=\"/tyr/3005-5443\" data-ref-id=\"3005-5443\">Tyr</a> and <a href=\"/odin/3005-1778\" data-ref-id=\"3005-1778\">Odin</a>, each shortened to three letters.</li><li>Much of the game is based on historical figures and organizations, such as <a href=\"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heinrich_Cornelius_Agrippa\" rel=\"nofollow\">Heinrich Cornelius Agrippa</a>, <a href=\"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Johann_Weyer\" rel=\"nofollow\">Johann Weyer</a> and the <a href=\"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Order_of_the_Black_Eagle\" rel=\"nofollow\">Order of the Black Eagle</a>.</li><li>Brennenburg might be a reference to <a href=\"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brandenburg\" rel=\"nofollow\">Brandenburg</a>, since they both translate from German to \"<i>Burning Castle</i>\" <i>\u2014</i> Brandenburg was considered the heart of Prussia, which is where the game takes place.</li><li>The screams of the monsters were made by combining a long metal pipe with a large metal funnel, and then moaning loudly into the end of the pipe.</li></ul><h2>Soundtrack</h2><p>The <a href=\"/original-soundtrack-release/3015-189\" data-ref-id=\"3015-189\">original soundtrack</a> for Amnesia: the Dark Descent was composed by <a href=\"/mikko-tarmia/3040-77827\" data-ref-id=\"3040-77827\">Mikko Tarmia</a>.</p><table><thead><tr><th>Track #</th><th>Track Title</th><th>Running Time</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>01</td><td>Menu Appearance</td><td>01.14</td></tr><tr><td>11</td><td>Back Hall</td><td>01.22</td></tr><tr><td>12</td><td>Ending Agrippa</td><td>01.56</td></tr><tr><td>13</td><td>Suitor Attacks</td><td>01.14</td></tr><tr><td>14</td><td>Basement Storage</td><td>02.12</td></tr><tr><td>15</td><td>Brennenburg version)</td><td>02.12</td></tr><tr><td>18</td><td>Bridges</td><td>01.05</td></tr><tr><td>19</td><td>The End</td><td>02.04</td></tr></tbody></table><h2>System Requirements</h2><h3>PC</h3><h4>Minimum</h4><ul><li><b>OS</b>: Windows XP / Vista / 7 / 8 / 10</li><li><strong>Processor</strong>: High Range Intel Core i3 / AMD A6 CPU or equivalent</li><li><b>Memory</b>: 2 GB RAM</li><li><b>Graphics</b>: Mid-range NVIDIA GeForce 200 / AMD Radeon HD 5000</li><li><strong>Hard Drive</strong>: 5 GB available space</li></ul><h4>Recommended</h4><ul><li><b>OS</b>: Windows XP / Vista / 7 / 8 / 10</li><li><b>Processor</b>: High Range Intel Core i5 / AMD FX CPU or equivalent</li><li><b>Memory</b>: 4 GB RAM</li><li><b>Graphics</b>: High-range NVIDIA GeForce 400 / AMD Radeon HD 6000</li><li><strong>Hard Drive</strong>: 5 GB available space</li></ul><h3>Mac</h3><h4>Minimum</h4><ul><li><b>OS</b>: OS X 10.7 or newer</li><li><b>Processor</b>: High Range Intel Core i3 / AMD A6 CPU or equivalent</li><li><b>Memory</b>: 2 GB RAM</li><li><b>Graphics</b>: Mid-range NVIDIA GeForce 200 / AMD Radeon HD 5000</li><li><b>Hard Drive</b>: 5 GB available space</li></ul><h4>Recommended</h4><ul><li><b>OS</b>: OS X 10.7.5 or newer</li><li><b>Processor</b>: High Range Intel Core i5 / AMD FX CPU or equivalent</li><li><b>Memory:</b> 4 GB RAM</li><li><b>Graphics</b>: High-range NVIDIA GeForce 400 / AMD Radeon HD 6000</li><li><strong>Hard Drive</strong>: 5 GB available equivalent</li><li><strong>Memory</strong>: 2 GB RAM</li><li><strong>Graphics</strong>: Mid-range NVIDIA GeForce 200 / AMD Radeon HD 5000</li><li><strong>Hard Drive</strong>: 5 GB available space</li></ul><h4>Recommended</h4><ul><li><strong>OS</strong>: Ubuntu 14.04 / Mint 17</li><li><strong>Processor</strong>: High Range Intel Core i5 / AMD FX CPU or equivalent</li><li><strong>Memory</strong>: 4 GB RAM</li><li><strong>Graphics</strong>: High-range NVIDIA GeForce 400 / AMD Radeon HD 6000</li><li><b>Hard Drive</b>: 5 GB available space</li></ul><h2>External Link</h2><ul><li><a href=\"https://www.frictionalgames.com/site/\" rel=\"nofollow\">Frictional Games</a></li></ul>", "deck": "A first-person survival horror game with advanced physics-based puzzles from Frictional Games, the creators of the Penumbra series. Its dynamic of light and darkness and focus on avoidance of enemies rather than combat have been highly influential in recent horror games.", "aliases": null, "image": {"icon_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/square_avatar/9/93770/2299522-amnesia.png", "medium_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_medium/9/93770/2299522-amnesia.png", "tiny_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/square_mini/9/93770/2299522-amnesia.png", "small_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/9/93770/2299522-amnesia.png", "thumb_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_avatar/9/93770/2299522-amnesia.png", "screen_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/screen_medium/9/93770/2299522-amnesia.png", "super_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_large/9/93770/2299522-amnesia.png"}, "date_last_updated": "2015-10-28 00:45:36", "expected_release_month": null, "api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/game/3030-30087/", "number_of_user_reviews": 22, "original_release_date": "2010-09-08 00:00:00", "original_game_rating": null, "date_added": "2010-02-21 07:32:44", "platforms": [{"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/platform/3045-17/", "abbreviation": "MAC", "site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/mac/3045-17/", "id": 17, "name": "Mac"}, {"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/platform/3045-94/", "abbreviation": "PC", "site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/pc/3045-94/", "id": 94, "name": "PC"}, {"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/platform/3045-152/", "abbreviation": "LIN", "site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/linux/3045-152/", "id": 152, "name": "Linux"}], "expected_release_day": null, "expected_release_year": null, "id": 30087, "resource_type": "game", "name": "Amnesia: The Dark Descent"}, "platform": "PC", "title": "Amnesia: The Dark Descent"}
{"duration": "2:15:00", "runner": "Bonesaw577", "data": {"site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/jak-and-daxter/3025-366/", "description": "<figure data-align=\"right\" data-size=\"small\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/4340/777133-516509_front.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-777133\" data-embed-type=\"image\" data-ratio=\"1.41875\" data-width=\"320\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:141.9%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/4340/777133-516509_front.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-777133\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/4340/777133-516509_front.jpg\"/></a></figure><p><strong><a href=\"/jak-and-daxter-the-precursor-legacy/3030-14623\" data-ref-id=\"3030-14623\">JAK &amp; DAXTER: THE PRECURSOR LEGACY</a> (2001)</strong></p><p><a href=\"/jak/3005-548\" data-ref-id=\"3005-548\">Jak</a> and his pal <a href=\"/daxter/3005-549\" data-ref-id=\"3005-549\"> Daxter</a> set out on a trip to <a href=\"/misty-island/3035-2869\" data-ref-id=\"3035-2869\"> Misty Island</a>, when things take a turn for the worst and Daxter falls into a pit of Dark <a href=\"/eco/3015-1621\" data-ref-id=\"3015-1621\"> Eco</a>, transforming him into an Ottsel. Jak and Daxter begin their journey to find the <a href=\"/gol-acheron/3005-9820\" data-ref-id=\"3005-9820\"> Dark Eco Sage</a>, in hopes that they can change Daxter back to his human form. It turns out, though, the person they are trying to find is also the person standing in their way.</p><p> </p><p> </p><p> </p><p> </p><p> </p><p> </p><figure data-align=\"left\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/4340/776467-914535_75542_front.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-776467\" data-size=\"small\" data-embed-type=\"image\" data-ratio=\"1.4109375\" data-width=\"320\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:141.1%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/4340/776467-914535_75542_front.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-776467\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/4340/776467-914535_75542_front.jpg\"/></a></figure><p><strong><a href=\"/jak-ii/3030-10384\" data-ref-id=\"3030-10384\">JAK II </a>(2003)</strong></p><p>After finding a mysterious Precursor artifact, Jak and company are thrust into a dark new world. Immediatly, Jak is taken by guards and seperated from Daxter. Two years pass, and eventually Daxter finds Jak, but he is changed from countless Dark Eco experiments done on him. In an effort to explain what has happened, Jak and Daxter travel this new land in hopes for more answers, and of course, payback.</p><p> </p><p> </p><p> </p><p> </p><p> </p><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/9253/1332961-jak3gh_us_ps2_front.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1332961\" data-size=\"small\" data-embed-type=\"image\" data-ratio=\"1.4125\" data-width=\"320\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:141.3%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/9253/1332961-jak3gh_us_ps2_front.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1332961\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/9253/1332961-jak3gh_us_ps2_front.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/9253/1332961-jak3gh_us_ps2_front.jpg\"/></noscript></a></figure><p><strong><a href=\"/jak-3/3030-9669\" data-ref-id=\"3030-9669\">Jak 3</a> (2004)</strong></p><p>After crimes committed against the people, Jak and Daxter are left to die in the Wasteland. Almost close to death, they are found by other Wastelanders, and brought into the city. Now they must fight for their lives, and prove to the city that they are useful. Meanwhile, the world is in danger of the Darkmakers. The planet doesn't have much time, unless Jak and Daxter can prevent it.</p><p> </p><p> </p><p> </p><p> </p><p> </p><p> </p><figure data-align=\"left\" data-size=\"small\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/5/59593/2605002-5297140057-Jak_X.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2605002\" data-embed-type=\"image\" data-ratio=\"1.4140625\" data-width=\"256\" style=\"width: 256px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:141.4%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/5/59593/2605002-5297140057-Jak_X.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2605002\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/5/59593/2605002-5297140057-Jak_X.png\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/5/59593/2605002-5297140057-Jak_X.png\"/></noscript></a></figure><p><strong><a href=\"/jak-x-combat-racing/3030-689\" data-ref-id=\"3030-689\"><b>JAK X: COMBAT RACING</b></a> (2005)</strong></p><p>A spin-off that expands on the racing elements seen in previous games, Jak X sees Jak and friends racing for their lives. After the whole crew had been poisoned, Jak must win the racing championship for the antidote.</p><p>This game features online multiplayer via the <a href=\"/playstation-2-network-adaptor/3000-69\" data-ref-id=\"3000-69\">PlayStation 2 Network Adaptor</a>.</p><p> </p><p> </p><p> </p><p> </p><p> </p><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/4340/777115-927355_91640_front.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-777115\" data-size=\"small\" data-embed-type=\"image\" data-ratio=\"1.7182130584192\" data-width=\"291\" style=\"width: 291px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:171.8%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/4340/777115-927355_91640_front.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-777115\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/4340/777115-927355_91640_front.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/4340/777115-927355_91640_front.jpg\"/></noscript></a></figure><p><strong><a href=\"/daxter/3030-14604\" data-ref-id=\"3030-14604\">DAXTER</a> (2006)</strong></p><p>In the two years Jak was kidnapped at the beginning of <a href=\"/jak-ii/3030-10384\" data-ref-id=\"3030-10384\"> Jak II</a>, Daxter sets out to find him. This installment tells his tale of becoming a pest exterminator, and his journey to save his best friend.</p><p> </p><p> </p><p> </p><p> </p><p> </p><p> </p><p> </p><p> </p><p> </p><p> </p><figure data-align=\"left\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/9253/1166904-j_dtlf_us_psp_front.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1166904\" data-size=\"small\" data-embed-type=\"image\" data-ratio=\"1.7268128161889\" data-width=\"320\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:172.7%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/9253/1166904-j_dtlf_us_psp_front.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1166904\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/9253/1166904-j_dtlf_us_psp_front.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/9253/1166904-j_dtlf_us_psp_front.jpg\"/></noscript></a></figure><p><strong><a href=\"/jak-and-daxter-the-lost-frontier/3030-25720\" data-ref-id=\"3030-25720\"><b>JAK AND DAXTER: THE LOST FRONTIER </b></a>(2009)</strong></p><p>A PSP entry developed by <a href=\"/high-impact-games/3010-4124\" data-ref-id=\"3010-4124\"> High Impact Games</a>, later ported to the PS2. Jak and Daxter travel to the edge of the world, known as <a href=\"/the-brink/3035-2799\" data-ref-id=\"3035-2799\"> The Brink</a>. There is an Eco shortage, and therefore the world isn't complete. Jak, Daxter, and <a href=\"/keira/3005-3416\" data-ref-id=\"3005-3416\"> Keira</a> are in search for more Eco to help restabilize the world.</p>", "deck": "From innocent boy hero to edgy action movie hero, Jak, along with his wise-cracking friend Daxter, save the world from various perils and troubles all while trying to uncover the secrets of the mysterious Precursors.", "image": {"icon_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/square_avatar/0/8169/1154683-250px_jakanddaxter_logo.jpg", "medium_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_medium/0/8169/1154683-250px_jakanddaxter_logo.jpg", "tiny_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/square_mini/0/8169/1154683-250px_jakanddaxter_logo.jpg", "small_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/8169/1154683-250px_jakanddaxter_logo.jpg", "thumb_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_avatar/0/8169/1154683-250px_jakanddaxter_logo.jpg", "screen_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/screen_medium/0/8169/1154683-250px_jakanddaxter_logo.jpg", "super_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_large/0/8169/1154683-250px_jakanddaxter_logo.jpg"}, "date_last_updated": "2014-02-28 22:08:48", "api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/franchise/3025-366/", "date_added": "2008-04-28 17:14:42", "aliases": "Jak & Daxter", "id": 366, "resource_type": "franchise", "name": "Jak and Daxter"}, "platform": "PS2", "title": "Jak and Daxter"}
{"duration": "0:55:00", "runner": "CavemanDCJ", "data": {"site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/klonoa-door-to-phantomile/3030-9546/", "expected_release_quarter": null, "description": "<h2>Overview</h2><p>Klonoa: Door to Phantomile is a <a href=\"/playstation/3045-22\" data-ref-id=\"3045-22\">PlayStation</a> game released in 1997 to large amounts of critical acclaim. The game revolves around the protagonist <a href=\"/klonoa/3005-685\" data-ref-id=\"3005-685\">Klonoa</a> and his sidekick <a href=\"/huepow/3005-1051\" data-ref-id=\"3005-1051\">Huepow</a>. The game also spawned a sequel <a href=\"/klonoa-2-lunateas-veil/3030-7212\" data-ref-id=\"3030-7212\">Klonoa 2: Lunatea's Veil</a>. A remake of the game, simply titled <a href=\"/klonoa/3030-49398\" data-ref-id=\"3030-49398\">Klonoa </a>for the West, for <a href=\"/wii/3045-36\" data-ref-id=\"3045-36\">Wii</a> was released in <a href=\"/japan/3035-37\" data-ref-id=\"3035-37\">Japan </a>on December 4th 2008 and in <a href=\"/north-america/3035-1664\" data-ref-id=\"3035-1664\">North America</a> on May 5th 2009 and in <a href=\"/europe/3035-289\" data-ref-id=\"3035-289\">Europe</a> on May 22nd of the same year.</p><h2>Gameplay</h2><p>Throughout the game you take control of Klonoa, a cat-like creature with wings as ears, and his trusty sidekick Huepow, a spirit enchanted inside of a ring. The gameplay in Klonoa is rather unique as the game is played in 2.5D, this means the majority of the game is a 2D sidescrolling platformer but at certain points the player will need to interact with objects outside of the 2D dimensions. Klonoa can fire Huepow from his ring to interact with objects and enemies. Once Klonoa has hit an enemy he can use it to double jump or fire it at another enemy causing them to collide and explode. Other core elements of the gameplay include running, jumping and solving puzzles to progress through the games next set of levels which are called Visions. The game consists of 6 Visions each with two sections in which the second section contains a Boss fight at the end. Bosses are an integral part of the gameplay in Klonoa, however they have been criticized for their difficulty.</p><h2>Plot</h2><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/1699/207239-picture_9.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-207239\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.74686192468619\" data-width=\"478\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 478px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:74.7%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/1699/207239-picture_9.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-207239\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_super/0/1699/207239-picture_9.png\"/></a><figcaption>Klonoa's nightmare</figcaption></figure><p>The games plot starts in the Town of Breezegale which is fueled by its inhabitants dreams, though no one can clearly remember them. However, Klonoa is able to remember one dream, specifically vivid of an object falling from the sky and crashing into the nearby mountain. One day Klonoa awakes to a find that an object has infact crashed into the mountain and he sets off with his best friend Huepow to find out what happened. When they reach the top of the mountain they find two strange men, Ghadius and Joka who are searching for a pendant with magical properties. They then kidnap the Legendary Diva Lephise which spurs Klonoa and Huepow to chase after them.</p><h2>Locations and Bosses</h2><h3>Breezegale: The Wind Village</h3><figure data-align=\"left\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/1699/207227-picture_2.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-207227\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.74739039665971\" data-width=\"479\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 479px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:74.7%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/1699/207227-picture_2.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-207227\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_super/0/1699/207227-picture_2.png\"/></a><figcaption>Baladium</figcaption></figure><p>Breezegale is the wind village of Phantomile. The villagers of Breezegale all resemble anthropomorphic rabbits, with long furry ears and catlike faces. As can be expected, it is the village that our hero Klonoa calls home. Among the many outstanding features of this town is the Bell of Wind, a giant golden bell placed at the top of the aptly named Bell Hill with the Moon Pendant of Lephise is hidden inside. Besides the Bell, another landmark of Breezegale is the gigantic Windmill near the town's center. This windmill is shown as being the source of the Wind Spirit's power during the second game cinematic. Last but not least, Balue's Tower is also located in Breezegale. Although construction on this tower was only beginning as the game started, by the end of the story it has been completed. Upon unlocking the Tower as a bonus level, it is revealed to be several stories high... one of the largest structures in all of Phantomile. The boss of this stage is the Rongo Lango, one of Joka's pets. When returning to a corrupted Breezgale later in the game, the boss you fight will be Baladium, a winged cobra with various unusual abilities.</p><h3>Forlock: The Tree Village</h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/1699/446257-picture_36.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-446257\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.74213836477987\" data-width=\"477\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 477px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:74.2%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/1699/446257-picture_36.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-446257\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_super/0/1699/446257-picture_36.png\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_super/0/1699/446257-picture_36.png\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>The Cog</figcaption></figure><p>Forlock is the ancient wood village of Phantomile. The entire village consists solely of a colossal tree-house, the home of many jungle citizens. The most ancient and well-known citizen in all of Forlock is Granny, who knows large amounts of old legends, myths, and other forgotten stories. She lives at the very top of Forlock in a gigantic mansion of wooden machinery. Located on the very side of Granny's house is a huge cog, which if stops turning stops the flow of water to Jugpot. It is also interesting to note that the Wood Spirit of Phantomile gives its energy from this very contraption during the second game cinematic. The boss of this stage is Gelg Bolm, a bizarre bomb-like creature that is only defenseless to attacks from above.</p><h3>Jugpot: The Kingdom of Water</h3><figure data-align=\"left\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/1699/207235-picture_6.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-207235\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.74423480083857\" data-width=\"477\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 477px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:74.4%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/1699/207235-picture_6.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-207235\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_super/0/1699/207235-picture_6.png\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_super/0/1699/207235-picture_6.png\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Boss fight against Pamela</figcaption></figure><p>Jugpot is the large Phantomilian kingdom of Water that connects directly to Forlock. In the very center of Jugpot is a giant seashell with a cog in the center. Besides holding the power of Phantomile's Water Spirit, this structure is also the source of all water for the three Kingdoms and the Castle of King Seadoph himself. He rules alongside his \"servant\" Pamela: a fishlike creature with the ability to fly. Pamela has a son named Karal who befriends Klonoa during the game's story. During the story Ghadius possesses both Seadoph and Pamela in an attempt to destroy Jugpot. It is only due to Karal's help that Klonoa meets and confronts the distressed King, ultimately freeing him from the Ghadius' powers. Once freed, Seadoph directs our two heroes to Forlock, the Tree Village in order to stop Ghadius. The boss of this stage is Pamela. She can only be defeated by throwing Seadoph at her.</p><h3>Coronia: The Temple of the Sun</h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/1699/447068-picture_9.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-447068\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.74213836477987\" data-width=\"477\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 477px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:74.2%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/1699/447068-picture_9.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-447068\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_super/0/1699/447068-picture_9.png\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_super/0/1699/447068-picture_9.png\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Joka</figcaption></figure><p>Coronia, the Temple of the Sun, is a floating Kingdom located high above Phantomile. Klonoa and Huepow are brought to there after defeating Gelg Bolm in the Forlock. The only inhabitants of Coronia that the player meets are the priests Solare, Soleil and Coronia's High Priest Moire. These three are dedicated to guarding their Kingdom at all costs. At the very top of Coronia floats some sort of circular altar. It is at this very place that Klonoa must defeat Ghadius' servant, Joka. Unlike the past three Kingdoms, Coronia does not seem to have a related Spirit. Instead, this Temple appears to be the key which summons the ancient Moon Kingdom of Cress. How exactly this was achieved is unclear, but seems to be related to the large blue Crystal at the arena's center. Once Joka has been defeated, it explodes in a burst of energy, triggering the similar reactions of the other Three Kingdoms. The boss of this stage is Joka .</p><h3>Cress: The Moon Kingdom</h3><figure data-align=\"left\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/1699/466641-picture_1.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-466641\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.74841437632135\" data-width=\"473\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 473px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:74.8%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/1699/466641-picture_1.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-466641\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_super/0/1699/466641-picture_1.png\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_super/0/1699/466641-picture_1.png\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Klonoa and Pamela flying to the Moon Kingdom</figcaption></figure><p>The Legendary Moon Kingdom of Cress was long considered a legend until it is returned during the game's epic second cinematic. This h kingdom consists solely of a huge golden Castle, which is in turn seated upon an array of crystals. Once released from its underground captivity, Cress ascends high into the night skies of Phantomile. Living in the Moon Kingdom is the Queen of Cress and her Prince. The Moon Kingdom is also where the Diva Lephise sings her Song of Rebith. The boss of this stage is Ghadius.</p><h2>Wii Release</h2><p><a href=\"http://www.giantbomb.com/namco-bandai-games-inc/3010-382\" data-ref-id=\"3010-382\">Namco-Bandai</a> announced that Klonoa: Door to Phantomile would be remade on the <a href=\"http://www.giantbomb.com/wii/3045-36\" data-ref-id=\"3045-36\">Wii</a> via Famitsu and the first gameplay videos were shown during Nintendo's press conference in August 2008. The game includes improved graphics and can be controlled with the <a href=\"http://www.giantbomb.com/wii-remote/3055-1304\" data-ref-id=\"3055-1304\">Wii Remote</a> held sideways (also includes support for multiple other controllers). The remake features no CG cut-scenes and uses an in engine cut-scenes instead. Players are able to select between Japanese audio and the original Klonoa gibberish. The game also features a more finely tuned difficulty, new levels and bonuses, unlockable outfits for Klonoa among other things.</p><h3>Reception</h3><p>The game was released in Japan to high critical acclaim. Japanese magazine Famitsu gave the game 36 out of 40 praising its enjoyable gameplay and wide color palette. The game was however criticized for being too easy by many other critics. Klonoa was also praised for staying true to the original and evolving the graphics significantly.</p><p>The game was subsequently released in <a href=\"http://www.giantbomb.com/north-america/3035-1664\" data-ref-id=\"3035-1664\">North America</a> on May 5 2009 and in <a href=\"http://www.giantbomb.com/europe/3035-289\" data-ref-id=\"3035-289\">Europe</a> on May 22 2009.</p><h2>Soundtrack Release</h2><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/2/28533/1077818-klonoa_door_to_phantomile_packaging01.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1077818\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"1\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:100.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/2/28533/1077818-klonoa_door_to_phantomile_packaging01.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1077818\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/2/28533/1077818-klonoa_door_to_phantomile_packaging01.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/2/28533/1077818-klonoa_door_to_phantomile_packaging01.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Klonoa: Door to Phantomile Soundtrack Cover</figcaption></figure><p>There are two CDs packed inside one package that was released based on this game, and it features over a whopping 68 soundtracks. It was released on February 25, 1998, and was published by Nippon Crown.</p><p><strong>Disc One</strong></p><ol><li>And I Begin to Wonder</li><li>Inquisitive Waltz</li><li>Darken</li><li>The Windmill Song</li><li>Balue &amp; Lephise</li><li>Mine of Lights</li><li>Spiral Truck</li><li>Ghadius Appears</li><li>The Rongo Lango</li><li>A Pendant</li><li>Grandpa's Chair</li><li>Sad Forest Drum</li><li>Melancholy Soldier</li><li>Jugpot Falls</li><li>Weeping Karal</li><li>Mad Seadoph Blues</li><li>Cursed Pamela</li><li>Joker Mood</li><li>Jugpot King Speaks</li><li>Forlock Twist</li><li>Truck a Go Go</li><li>Count Three</li><li>Beats from Above</li><li>Granny's Word</li><li>I See</li><li>The Ruin's Air</li><li>Blue Cave Echo</li><li>When the Wind Stood Still</li><li>Joker's Move</li><li>Baladium's Drive</li><li>For the Time We've Spent</li><li>Fry Over the Wind</li></ol><p><strong>Disc Two</strong></p><ol><li>Red Heat Coronia</li><li>Nevertheless</li><li>Dawn Over Dawn &amp; Dark into Dark</li><li>Out of Time</li><li>No Jokes Around</li><li>Facade &amp; Blade</li><li>Cress</li><li>Untamed Heart</li><li>Difficult to Say</li><li>The Closing Encounter</li><li>Ghadius Laughs</li><li>Wheel of Woe</li><li>Quiet Choir</li><li>Nightmare's On</li><li>The Instrumentality</li><li>Rapid Eyes Inside</li><li>The Ring</li><li>Advent</li><li>Peaceful Moment</li><li>I'm On Your Side</li><li>Farewell</li><li>Resurrection</li><li>Staff Roll</li><li>Good Night</li><li>Continue</li><li>Title</li><li>Let's Go For a While</li><li>The Tower of Balue</li><li>Thankful Suite</li><li>3-2 Prototype</li><li>Demo Prototype</li><li>Opening (Movie)</li><li>Cress (Movie)</li><li>Ending (Movie)</li><li>Thankful Suite (Instrumental)</li><li>S.E.
