{"duration": "0:45:00", "runner": "Maxylobes", "data": {"site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/jet-set-radio/3025-376/", "description": "<h2>History</h2><p>Jet Grind Radio was announced at Tokyo Game Show 1999 and gained much attention due to a revolutionary style of graphics called \"cel-shading\". Jet Grind Radio was the first video game to feature this cartoon-like graphical style. Jet Grind Radio was released o the Sega Dreamcast in Japan on June 29, 2000, and was released on November 1 in the United States. The game did not sell well in the United States, but was critically acclaimed and gained a cult following. The sequel, Jet Set Radio Future, was released on February 25, 2002 for the Xbox. The game once again met with poor sales but critical acclaim. In 2003, a port of the original Jet Grind Radio was released on the Game Boy Advance. At Comic-Con 2008, rumors surfaced of a new Jet Grind Radio for the Wii. However, the rumors were silenced when comic book artist Cory \"Rey\" Lewis announced that Jet Grind Radio was proposed to Sega by Kuju Entertainment, though Sega turned them down. Lewis had created concept art for the proposed title.</p><h2>Gameplay</h2><p>The basic concept of Jet Grind Radio is simple. Each level has a time limit, a life meter and spots which you need to tag. The player must spray graffiti on designated locations. However, while the player tries to do this, the player will be met with resistance from law enforcement, at first just police officers with nightsticks but eventually helicopters with heat seeking missiles. There is also rival gangs to worry about as well.</p><h3>Jet Set Radio</h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-embed-type=\"image\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/5709/699152-143957_full.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-699152\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.69375\" data-width=\"320\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:69.4%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/5709/699152-143957_full.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-699152\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/5709/699152-143957_full.jpg\"/></a><figcaption>Jet Set Radio.</figcaption></figure><p>In this game, the player is given a set amount of time in which they must tag a number of designated spotsl. A trick system is featured - if the player jumps with enough speed, or lands on a grindable rail, a trick is automatically activated. The player may also to skate backwards by flicking the analog stick up and down. The tagging system is based around quick time events triggered when the player activates a tag location. When they do so, a quick time event occurs - the quick time consist of rotating the analog stick in certain directions that the game tells the player.</p><h3>Jet Set Radio Future</h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-embed-type=\"image\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/4356/421703-pic_jsrf_008.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-421703\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.75\" data-width=\"320\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:75.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/4356/421703-pic_jsrf_008.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-421703\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/4356/421703-pic_jsrf_008.jpg\"/></a><figcaption>Jet Set Radio Future.</figcaption></figure><p>The second game features a number of improvements from its predecessor. The game features an improved trick system. Tricks are activated by pressing the X button while grinding at a certain pace, and the way skating backwards is done is by pressing the Y button instead of flicking the analog stick up and down. The quick time tagging is removed - the player only has to activate a location to spray their tag. The timer from the original game is also removed. The player gains the ability to boost through the usage of 10 paint cans.</p><h2>Story</h2><p>The story of the Jet Set Radio series is about of group of <i>\"Rudies,\"</i> who are also graffiti artists. They skate around the city of Tokyo-to, tagging their art work as a means of expressing themselves. The story centers around a gang that is known as the GGs. The leader of the gang in the original story is Beat, and in the second game is Corn (Known as Tab in the original). At first they go around and tag their art work while battling rival gangs like the Love Shockers, Poison Jam, and Noise Tank while trying not to get hunted down by the police. The ploat thickens when they find a mysterious record that can summon an ancient demon. A corporation known as the Rokkaku group are hunting for the record, and are kidnapping members of rival street gangs in an effort to discover this record.</p><p>The Story of the second game is basically a retelling of the story of Jet Set Radio. It's partly due to the fact that the developers of the game have stated that it's a re imagining and not a true sequel). Certain points of the story is told a bit differently - the game takes place in the future, more rival gangs are introduced in the story, and the Japanese police is led by different characters.</p><h2>Jet Set Radio Re-Releases and Future Sequels</h2><p>On July 24th, 2008, Sega filed a trademark for their Jet Grind Radio series, separate from the Dreamcast trademark. This, coupled with rumblings from \"industry-insiders\" in Comic-Con, opened speculation for a Wii sequel to the game. A post by Corey Lewis indicated that there was a pitch made to Sega from developer Kuju - now known as Headstrong Games - that was turned down by Sega.</p><p>Jet Set Radio was re-released for a number of digital platforms in 2012. Including consoles, handhelds and mobile devices. The hint for it's re-release first surfaced in a Kotaku article posted on April 25, 2010. The article showed a photo of a game called <i>\"Jet Set Radio\"</i> sitting in someone's game library on an <a data-ref-id=\"3045-20\" href=\"/xbox-360/3045-20\" slug=\"xbox-360\">Xbox 360</a> dashboard.</p>", "deck": "Jet Set Radio is an unconventional platforming roller-skating series that involves the player in creating graffiti on key locations throughout a futuristic and lavishly designed Tokyo. It is also the first video game to feature cel-shaded graphics. ", "image": {"icon_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/square_avatar/2/29889/1097043-jet_set_radio.ashx.jpeg", "medium_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_medium/2/29889/1097043-jet_set_radio.ashx.jpeg", "tiny_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/square_mini/2/29889/1097043-jet_set_radio.ashx.jpeg", "small_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/2/29889/1097043-jet_set_radio.ashx.jpeg", "thumb_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_avatar/2/29889/1097043-jet_set_radio.ashx.jpeg", "screen_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/screen_medium/2/29889/1097043-jet_set_radio.ashx.jpeg", "super_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_large/2/29889/1097043-jet_set_radio.ashx.jpeg"}, "date_last_updated": "2012-11-29 21:59:37", "api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/franchise/3025-376/", "date_added": "2008-04-28 17:40:50", "aliases": null, "id": 376, "resource_type": "franchise", "name": "Jet Set Radio"}, "platform": "PC", "title": "Jet Set Radio"}
{"duration": "1:15:00", "runner": "Starwin", "data": {"site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/oddworld-abes-oddysee-new-n-tasty/3030-39928/", "expected_release_quarter": null, "description": "<h2>Overview</h2><p>Abe's Oddysee New 'n' Tasty is a complete remake of the first <a href=\"/oddworld/3025-470\" data-ref-id=\"3025-470\">Oddworld</a> game, <a href=\"/oddworld-abes-oddysee/3030-5269\" data-ref-id=\"3030-5269\">Abe's Oddysee</a>. While boasting updated graphics, it maintains a similar art style to that of the original. With the game removing the individual screens which was the format of the original game, some puzzles have changed and this has meant that some levels and puzzles have been reworked to fit in better with the new structure. The game also introduces new mechanics which were previously not available during Abe's Oddysee, although used in it's sequels, including a <a href=\"http://www.giantbomb.com/quicksaving/3015-2127\" data-ref-id=\"3015-2127\">quick save</a> feature and improved gamespeak. Improved gamespeak allows the player to talk to more than one Mudokon at once, which also changes some of the puzzles, making them far easier than before. Because of this, some puzzles have been slightly reworked as to balance this feature, as in Abe's Oddysee, Abe could only have the attention of one Mudokon at a time.</p><p>The <a href=\"/playstation-4/3045-146\" data-ref-id=\"3045-146\">PlayStation 4</a> version of the game was originally released on July 22, 2014. The <a href=\"/pc/3045-94\" data-ref-id=\"3045-94\">PC</a>, <a href=\"/mac/3045-17\" data-ref-id=\"3045-17\">Mac</a>, and <a href=\"/linux/3045-152\" data-ref-id=\"3045-152\">Linux</a> versions of the game are set to be released on February 25, 2015. The <a href=\"/playstation-3/3045-35\" data-ref-id=\"3045-35\">PlayStation 3</a> and <a href=\"/xbox-one/3045-145\" data-ref-id=\"3045-145\">Xbox One</a> versions of the game are slated for release sometime in March of 2015. The Wii U version of the game was initially developed internally and then later handed off to port house Olde Sk\u00fc\u00fcl. It's set for a Fall 2015 release.</p><h2>Story</h2><p>The game takes place in the continent of Mudos, in the land of <a href=\"http://www.giantbomb.com/oddworld/3035-288\" data-ref-id=\"3035-288\">Oddworld</a>. Home to <a href=\"http://www.giantbomb.com/mudokons/3015-1122\" data-ref-id=\"3015-1122\">Mudokons</a>, <a href=\"http://www.giantbomb.com/glukkon/3015-1567\" data-ref-id=\"3015-1567\">Glukkons</a> and various wildlife such as <a href=\"http://www.giantbomb.com/scrab/3015-1322\" data-ref-id=\"3015-1322\">Scrabs</a>, <a href=\"http://www.giantbomb.com/paramite/3015-1573\" data-ref-id=\"3015-1573\">Paramites</a> and the now extinct Meeches, in it lies the biggest meat processing plant in Oddworld: <a href=\"http://www.giantbomb.com/rupturefarms/3035-802\" data-ref-id=\"3035-802\">Rupturefarms</a>. Administrated by the high ranking Glukkon of the Magog Cartel, known as <a href=\"http://www.giantbomb.com/molluck-the-glukkon/3005-3805\" data-ref-id=\"3005-3805\">Molluck</a>, he was faced with a huge dilemma, with profits beginning to fall and the future of Rupturefarms was looking grim. The creatures of Oddworld were running scarce, thanks to the extinction of Meeches and the high in-take of Scrabs and Paramites. Molluck had to come up with a new and daring plan, to help save the future of Rupturefarms. A new kind of meat that would boost sales and create a profit once again. A meat made from their very own 'employees', the Mudokons called Mudokon Pops.</p><p>We follow the story of <a href=\"http://www.giantbomb.com/abe/3005-729\" data-ref-id=\"3005-729\">Abe</a>, a slave of Rupturefarms who is working late one night. Spotting a light through a gap, he sneaks over and listens into board meeting with the Glukkons and overhears Molluck's bold new plan. With a screen showcasing the falling profits, Molluck is confident and reveals their new product to the other Glukkons. Upon the discovery of what New 'N' Tasty really is, Abe flees the scene and is spotted by a camera, which causes <a href=\"http://www.giantbomb.com/slig/3015-644\" data-ref-id=\"3015-644\">Sligs</a> to take chase. Abe must escape and save as many of his other 299 fellow employees in the process, whilst utilizing his power to possess Sligs and guide other Mudokons to safety.</p><p>After escaping RuptureFarms and unaware that he has a destiny, Abe spots a moon in the sky with the paw of his people. Being enchanted by the moon, Abe slips off of a cliff and hits his head. Whilst knocked out, he is confronted by the mysterious tribesman wearing a large mask, known as <a href=\"http://www.giantbomb.com/big-face/3005-14569\" data-ref-id=\"3005-14569\">Big Face</a>. Big Face shows Abe a vision and explains that he must save the remaining workers at RuptureFarms in order to restore the lost land. To do so, he must complete a number of trials in the dark forests of Paramonia and the scorching hot deserts of Scrabania. Upon completed the trials, Big Face bestows a scar on each of Abe's hands, resembling a Paramite and a Scrab. Combined, they allow one to become the mighty and powerful demi-God, known as <a href=\"http://www.giantbomb.com/shrykull/3005-5347\" data-ref-id=\"3005-5347\">Shrykull</a>. Once in possession of this power, Abe can return to RuptureFarms and rescue his remaining friends until finally shutting the factory down for good!</p><p>After shutting down all the power, Abe finds himself caught in the board room, where he is knocked out and captured. Taken away by Sligs, he is tied up above a meat grinder, preventing him from chanting and bestowing the power of Shrykull or possessing any Sligs. Meanwhile, Big Face and the freed Mukokons discuss Abe's actions and whether or not he should be saved. It is at this point the game splits into two different endings. Abe's life, in the hands of the Mudokons is determined by how many are saved during the game. Whether or not he lives, is down to them...</p><p>Should Abe save enough Mudokons for them to even consider saving him, they combine their power, causing electricity to form from the sky, striking Molluck and his loyal Slig, either killing them or incapacitating them. With both of them down, Big Face appears and teleports Abe to a ceremony, celebrating his success, where all 99 Mudokons are cheering his name.</p><p>If Abe does not save enough of the Mudokons, he is ultimately left behind by the few who made it back safely. Disgusted with his behaviour, they refuse to help Big Face and leave Abe for dead. Molluck then gives the order for his execution and a Slig pulls a lever, releasing Abe into the meat grinder, killing him.</p>", "deck": "Oddworld: Abe's Oddysee New 'n' Tasty is a remake of the original Oddworld game, Abe's Oddysee.", "aliases": "Oddworld: Abe's Oddysee New n' Tasty\r\nOddworld: Abe's Oddysee New 'n Tasty\r\nOddworld: Abe's Oddysee New and Tasty\r\nOddworld: Abe's Oddysee {"duration": "0:55:00", "runner": "Vaati", "data": {"site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/oddworld-strangers-wrath/3030-21431/", "expected_release_quarter": null, "description": "<h2>Plot</h2><figure data-align=\"left\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/11847/445117-untitled8.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-445117\" data-size=\"small\" style=\"width: 160px\" data-ratio=\"1\" data-width=\"160\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:100.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/11847/445117-untitled8.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-445117\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/1/11847/445117-untitled8.jpg\"/></a><figcaption>Howdy Stranger</figcaption></figure><p><i>Oddworld: Stranger's Wrath</i> follows a bounty hunter named simply <a data-ref-id=\"3005-3814\" href=\"/stranger/3005-3814\">Stranger</a>. In the beginning of the game, Stranger captures numerous criminals to pay for a mysterious operation. As Stranger returns the criminals for their retrospective bounties, Stranger hears of a town of creatures called Grubbs. The Grubbs have been besieged by a <a data-ref-id=\"3015-557\" href=\"/demons/3015-557\">demonic</a> creature, and his army of minions. The Grubbs were once protected by a race called the Steef, now extinct, leaving them unprotected.</p><p>As Stranger continues to collect bounties, he finds that a man named Sekto has been drying up a river in the Grubbs town. When Stranger confronts him, Sekto offers him a bounty for the remaining Steef that he believes that are still around. The Stranger refuses this offer, leaving Sekto upset. Sekto hires a criminal, D. Caste Raider, to capture and interrogate Stranger.</p><p>As D interrogates Stranger, he discovers that Stranger himself is a Steef. Stranger escapes from the raiders, killing all of them in a large <a data-ref-id=\"3015-309\" href=\"/explosion/3015-309\">explosion</a>, and runs back to the Grubbs town. As he returns to the town, he realizes that the demon that he first heard about is Sekto. Stranger kills Sekto, and the remaining raiders, as well as destroying the dam that was drying the town of it\u2019s water. But as Sekto lies dying, the Stranger sees that the demon was possessing Sekto, who was also really a Steef. The demon escapes, as it goes into the now flowing river.</p><h2>Gameplay</h2><p>The game is split between third-person platforming and first-person shooting. The player progresses through the game by taking bounty missions that</p><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/5709/657835-straxb054.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-657835\" data-size=\"small\" style=\"width: 320px\" data-ratio=\"0.75\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:75.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/5709/657835-straxb054.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-657835\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/5709/657835-straxb054.jpg\"/></a></figure><p>consist of trekking though waves of enemies to fight unique bosses. All enemies can be \"bountied,\" which allows the <a data-ref-id=\"3005-3814\" href=\"/stranger/3005-3814\">Stranger</a> to cash them in at the bounty store. Moolah, the currency in this region of <a data-ref-id=\"3025-470\" href=\"/oddworld/3025-470\">Oddworld</a>, is received for the Stranger's help in cleaning up the area. Moolah can be spent on upgrades and ammo in the store. Enemies are worth more alive than dead.</p><h3>Combat</h3><p>Most of the combat centers around Stranger's <a data-ref-id=\"3055-107\" href=\"/crossbow/3055-107\">crossbow</a>, which can be loaded with special creatures from the world. This concept is known as \"live ammo\". The live ammo types all have their own personalities, not to mention their own unique functionality. Each type of live ammo has an upgraded, more powerful version:</p><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/5709/657837-straxb060.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-657837\" data-size=\"small\" style=\"width: 320px\" data-ratio=\"0.75\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:75.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/5709/657837-straxb060.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-657837\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/5709/657837-straxb060.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/5709/657837-straxb060.jpg\"/></noscript></a></figure><ul><li><b>Chippunks</b> - used to lure enemies to them by shouting taunts in a radius shown to the player as a spherical distortion effect</li><li><b>Bolamites</b> - spider-like creatures used to immobilize, but not kill, enemies; this allows them to be bountied for more Moolah than if they were killed</li><li><b>Fuzzles</b> - living mines; when enemies come close, Fuzzles leap onto them and begin chewing</li><li><b>Thudslugs</b> - armored balls which can hit enemies with great force, knocking them over</li><li><b>Zappflies</b> - bugs that can be shot rapidly or charged to stun enemies</li><li><b>Stingbees</b> - bugs that function like an automatic machine gun</li><li><b>Stunks</b> - creatures that can immobilize enemies; this one causes them to vomit uncontrollably</li><li><b>Boombats</b> - function as a sort of grenade / rocket launcher. If an enemy is hit directly, it will explode immediately; otherwise, a three-second timer is engaged</li></ul><h2>PC version</h2><p>In an interview with <a data-ref-id=\"3040-15879\" href=\"/lorne-lanning/3040-15879\">Lorne Lanning</a>, creator of Oddworld, it was announced that all Oddworld games including the previously <a data-ref-id=\"3045-32\" href=\"/xbox/3045-32\">Xbox</a> exclusive <a data-ref-id=\"3030-3684\" href=\"/oddworld-munchs-oddysee/3030-3684\">Munch</a> and Strangers Wrath will be released on <a data-ref-id=\"3045-94\" href=\"/pc/3045-94\">PC</a> via <a data-ref-id=\"3015-718\" href=\"/steam/3015-718\">Steam</a> and other <a data-ref-id=\"3015-2329\" href=\"/digital-distribution/3015-2329\">digital distribution</a> outlets. It was later released on PC via Steam and other digital distribution outlets on December 21, 2010 along with its predecessor Oddworld Munch's Oddysee. The game is available on it's own or as part of a compilation package known as \"The Oddboxx\" which includes all four released Oddworld titles.</p><h2>Enhanced PS3 Version</h2><p>On September 3rd 2010, the UK-based studio Just Add Water announced it was working on an enhanced remake of the game to be released for download on the PS3. It was planned to be released around Easter 2011, but was delayed until December 27, 2011.</p><p>The game will run at 720p and 60 FPS with added detail and graphical effects. It also features remastered dialogue, <a data-ref-id=\"3000-36\" href=\"/playstation-move/3000-36\">PlayStation Move</a> support, 37 Trophies and brand new content.</p><p>The launch price was $14.99.</p><p>Here's the list of improvements as mentioned on the <a href=\"http://blog.us.playstation.com/2011/12/07/oddworld-strangers-wrath-hd-comes-to-psn-december-27th/\" rel=\"nofollow\">US Playstation Blog</a>.</p><p><strong>Characters</strong></p><ul><li>All 84 character models have been updated with increased polygon counts and higher resolution textures.</li><li>Wolvark Sloghandlers now release Slogs instead of Slegs.</li><li>Professor Dimble now has glasses and an academic tome.</li><li>New female voices have been recorded for two characters.</li><li>Made Blisterz Booty unkillable.</li></ul><p><strong>Environments</strong></p><ul><li>All environments have been given higher resolution textures.</li><li>Most vegetation has been updated with increased polygon counts and/or higher resolution textures.</li><li>A lot of environment now reflects in water where it didn\u2019t before.</li><li>Many, many pipes and barrels were rounded.</li><li>New Easter Eggs added to the game.</li><li>Added Blisterz Booty\u2019s broken crud gun to the floor by his bola\u2019d body.</li><li>Sekto\u2019s Office has been changed to more closely resemble that seen in the FMV.</li></ul><p><strong>Audio</strong></p><ul><li>All game audio (voice, sound effects and music) have been upgraded to 16-bit 44KHz from 8-bit 11KHz or less!</li><li>Support for 5.1, Dolby Digitial and DTS.</li></ul><p><strong>Display</strong></p><ul><li>Everything now runs at 720p, 60 FPS, and in widescreen.</li><li>All menus have been updated with a new design based on original unused concepts.</li><li>New posters now occupy the inventory menu when no bounty is accepted.</li></ul><p><strong>Difficulty</strong></p><ul><li>All armour upgrades now actually increase Stranger\u2019s health.</li><li>Added difficulty levels to the game: Easy, Medium and Hard.</li><li>In Easy mode: Stranger has twice the health, Enemies have half the health and stamina, Enemies\u2019 stamina recovers half as fast.<ul><li>In Normal Mode: Stranger\u2019s health and armour for later in the game have been re-balanced.</li><li>In Hard mode: Stranger has a third less health, Enemies stamina recovers a third quicker.</li></ul></li></ul><p><strong>Unlockables</strong></p><ul><li>37 Trophies: 23 bronze, 8 silver, 5 gold, 1 platinum</li><li>37 pieces of unlockable concept art</li><li>Five unlockable movies</li></ul><h2>PS Vita Version</h2><p>On June 7th 2011, Just Add Water also announced a version of the game for the PlayStation Vita via twitter. Saves are set to be cross-platform with the PS3 using the cloud.</p>", "deck": "A spin-off of the Oddworld series, Oddworld: Stranger's Wrath attaches an unrelated shooter to the beloved franchise as Hard as nails, like the old classic games.", "aliases": null, "image": {"icon_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/square_avatar/27/272706/2808946-curse_of_issyos.jpg", "medium_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_medium/27/272706/2808946-curse_of_issyos.jpg", "tiny_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/square_mini/27/272706/2808946-curse_of_issyos.jpg", "small_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/27/272706/2808946-curse_of_issyos.jpg", "thumb_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_avatar/27/272706/2808946-curse_of_issyos.jpg", "screen_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/screen_medium/27/272706/2808946-curse_of_issyos.jpg", "super_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_large/27/272706/2808946-curse_of_issyos.jpg"}, "date_last_updated": "2016-04-29 19:26:23", "expected_release_month": null, "api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/game/3030-52056/", "number_of_user_reviews": 0, "original_release_date": "2015-10-15 00:00:00", "original_game_rating": null, "date_added": "2015-12-28 16:48:57", "platforms": [{"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/platform/3045-94/", "abbreviation": "PC", "site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/pc/3045-94/", "id": 94, "name": "PC"}], "expected_release_day": null, "expected_release_year": null, "id": 52056, "resource_type": "game", "name": "The Curse of Issyos"}, "platform": "PC", "title": "Curse of Issyos"}
{"duration": "0:55:00", "runner": "ty2358", "data": {"site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/castlevania/3030-22950/", "expected_release_quarter": null, "description": "<h2>Overview</h2><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/16396/542164-cv64_offart38.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-542164\" data-size=\"small\" style=\"width: 320px\" data-ratio=\"1.2480499219969\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:124.8%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/16396/542164-cv64_offart38.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-542164\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/1/16396/542164-cv64_offart38.jpg\"/></a><figcaption>Reinhardt Schneider, one of the game's main protagonists.</figcaption></figure><p>Castlevania (known in Japan as Akumaj\u014d Dracula Mokushiroku, translated to Devil's Castle Dracula Apocalypse) is a 3D action-adventure horror platformer developed by <a data-ref-id=\"3010-844\" href=\"/konami-computer-entertainment-kobe-inc/3010-844\">KCE Kobe</a> and published by <a data-ref-id=\"3010-87\" href=\"/konami-corporation/3010-87\">Konami</a> for the <a data-ref-id=\"3045-43\" href=\"/nintendo-64/3045-43\">Nintendo 64</a> on January 26, 1999. Often known as Castlevania 64 (to prevent confusion with the original <a data-ref-id=\"3030-6673\" href=\"/castlevania/3030-6673\">Castlevania</a>), Castlevania is the first game in the <a data-ref-id=\"3025-86\" href=\"/castlevania/3025-86\">Castlevania</a> franchise to include 3D gameplay. The game was remade (along with a new prequel story) later in the year as <a data-ref-id=\"3030-6467\" href=\"/castlevania-legacy-of-darkness/3030-6467\">Castlevania: Legacy of Darkness</a>.</p><h2>Plot</h2><p>Castlevania 64 starts out with players choosing between two different characters to play as. The first, Carrie Fernandez, is a young orphan who possesses the ability to use and create magic. She wears magic like armlets that serve as the players main attack weapon. The other selectable protagonist is Reinhardt Schneider, whom derives from the series infamous Belmont clan. Reinhardt is equipped with both a Whip for primary attacks, as well as, a sword for close encounters. Both of these characters share the common goal of stopping Lord Count Dracula who's returned to throne and crown the forces of darkness after a century of dormancy. The Plot has some back story that isn't directly in line with past games in the series. In Castlevania 64's universe, Dracula awakes in 1852 due to human beings rancor and vein, this has some how awaken the monster from his eternal slumber. Of the entire population on earth, only two very special gifted youths sense Count Dracula's presence. Carrie Fernandez, a young gypsy who has no family, and the latest Belmont Clan Vampire hunter, Reinhardt Schneider, also feels Dracula's arrival. The two set out to Castlevania to destroy the forces of darkness, and end the reign of Count Dracula.</p><p>As the two progress, and make their way through the gardens and pass the castle walls, an aristocratic vampire materializes to deliver a warning message to Carrie and Reinhardt that all those who oppose the Dark Lord will parish. Regardless of the creatures threats, the duo proceed on. The players soon come across a mansion where they meet Charles Vincent, an older vampire hunter who has also set sail to destroy the lord of darkness. Carrie and Reinhardt also stumble into Rosa, a young girl that is also a vampire. After meeting either of these characters, players discover the route to Dracula's castle, but they must first go through the terrace, a maze, and then the underground area and catacombs to reach the castle itself. Players meet the game's item seller, and everyone's favorite demon merchant, Renon. Renon is used to buy recovery items, more sub weapons and also gives info, since he's on nobody's side, but money. As the young hunters make way into the garden maze, they are met by a Frankenstein look-a-like wielding a chainsaw, who is also chasing a little kid. This is one of the game's many boss encounters and set's up a sub character, Malus. The heroes proceed underground and beyond, and this is when Count Dracula begins to feel the pressure. He's sends his main generals or servants Actrise and Death, to stop the pair once and for all. Carrie Fernandez is pitted against one of her only known family members, who is under the control of the generals of darkness. Reinhardt Schneider is put against his love interest Rosa, who he beats, but does not kill.</p><p>After the heroes best these lines of defense, they find themselves asending the Clock tower that will lead them to The castle keep. There, Actrise will be awaiting as well as the one and only Death. After these titans are vanquished, players have arrived at the castle keep and set foot in Count Draculas door step. Once players have penetrated Castlevania, the heroes battle any number of people depending on several factors. If you took sixteen or more in game days, you receive the bad ending in which Charles Vincent has already arrived and been beaten. You must then fight Vincent, not matter what. You discover that it was not the aristocratic vampire that was Dracula, but rather the boy Malus, however, in the bad ending, the heroes are unaware of this and therefore are damned. In Reinhardt Schnieder's ending, he's thinks by killing Vincent and the aristocratic vampire, that he's killed Count Dracula, still unaware that Malus is the lord of Darkness. He and Malus ride off into the sunset. In carries ending, she is taken by Malus or Count Dracula and forced to marry him and therefore is condemned to a life of agony. The Good endings play out if you beat the game in fifteen in game days or less, and they are; The hero reaches the castle before Vincent and defeats the aristocratic Vampire. Then, Malus appears as an adult possessed by a demon and attacks. You must then defeat him. After the battle he returns to the state of a child, but before Carrie or Reinhardt go to rescue him, Vincent arrives and pours Holy water all over him, destroying his incarnate of a child. Players must then battle the incarnate of Count Dracula as a dragon named Drago. After players defeat the spawn of Count Dracula himself, they will receive the good endings. For Carrie's ending she places a necklace on her step-mother's grave and finds inner peace. In Reinhardt's ending, Rosa the love of his life, who sacrificed herself for Reinhardt atop the Room of Clocks during the story, is resurrected and is a pure blood human once again. The heroes live on, but Dracula's return is ever growing.</p><p>Upon finishing the game, players unlocked costumes for both characters that were old outfits from past games in the series.</p><h2>Playable Characters</h2><p>There are two characters which are playable in Castlevania, down from the developers' original intention to have four. They each have very different storylines and attack styles.</p><h3>Reinhardt Schneider</h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/5/59247/1307440-schneider1.gif\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1307440\" data-size=\"small\" style=\"width: 160px\" data-ratio=\"1.875\" data-width=\"160\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:187.5%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/5/59247/1307440-schneider1.gif\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1307440\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/5/59247/1307440-schneider1.gif\"/></a></figure><p>Like his brethren, <a data-ref-id=\"3005-33\" href=\"/trevor-belmont/3005-33\">Ralph</a>, <a data-ref-id=\"3005-86\" href=\"/simon-belmont/3005-86\">Simon</a> and <a data-ref-id=\"3005-116\" href=\"/richter-belmont/3005-116\">Richter</a>, <a data-ref-id=\"3005-118\" href=\"/reinhardt-schneider/3005-118\">Reinhardt</a> (originally named Schneider Belmont) is a vampire killer descended by blood and ancestry from the infamous Belmont clan of vampire hunters. The past acts of legend, valor and life-saving are now long forgotten among the Schneider's peers. Schneider vows to renew his family's honor. \"Some day, the time will come when I have to fight the dark again!\" he mutters.</p><p>When Reinhardt's father, Michael, decides to become a vampire hunter to honor the family tradition, Reinhardt spends his time training in a forest near to his hometown of Wallachia. After his father's retirement ten years later, a rumor surfaces that Dracula has been resurrected, and Reinhardt begins his journey to the castle holding the whip of the Belmonts... According to those villagers who know him, Reinhardt has an unapproachable atmosphere around him. This is due to his revered but mysterious background. An intrepid figure, he is a gentle yet highly combative young man with a righteous mind.</p><h3>Carrie Fernandez</h3><figure data-align=\"left\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/5/59247/1307418-carry.gif\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1307418\" data-size=\"small\" style=\"width: 161px\" data-ratio=\"1.8633540372671\" data-width=\"161\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:186.3%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/5/59247/1307418-carry.gif\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1307418\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/5/59247/1307418-carry.gif\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/5/59247/1307418-carry.gif\"/></noscript></a></figure><p>The family of Fernandez, Spanish immigrants travelling throughout Eastern Europe, chanced upon Dracula's castle many moons ago, and utilizing a sacred family power of the orb, managed to repel both bandits, demonic intrusions and all manner of evil from their wagon train. However, after a particularly vicious attack by a form of Dracula himself, the patriarchal figure of the Fernandez family (a great warrior known as <a data-ref-id=\"3005-8466\" href=\"/sypha-belnades/3005-8466\">Sypha</a>) fell under dark trickery.</p><p>The family, although wracked with despair, did not cease to be. A small orphan called <a data-ref-id=\"3005-5688\" href=\"/carrie-fernandez/3005-5688\">Carrie</a> (originally named Carrie Eastfield), exhibited strange talents of light summoning and was traced back to the family after a lengthy search through records by her foster mother. A gentle child, Carrie watched with horror as a band of devils descended upon their Romanian village and attempted to attack her. Diving to save her child, Carrie's mother was killed and at that moment, a great orb of light was instantly summoned by the screaming Carrie and directed at the demons, which promptly writhed in agony and vanished. Her destiny has called, and Carrie realizes she must fight the demonic intrusions.</p><p>Carrie's parents exhibited the same power and were condemned and burnt as witches by a suspicious judiciary, fearful of anything that could be likened to the resurrection of Dracula. Only recently realizing this fact, Carrie halts her beliefs in an uncaring God and closes her mind to adults, disliking them. Hearing of Dracula's most recent resurrection, Carrie decides to investigate the castle...</p><h2>Other Notable Characters</h2><h3>Malus</h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/5/59247/1307433-malus.gif\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1307433\" data-size=\"small\" style=\"width: 193px\" data-ratio=\"1.5544041450777\" data-width=\"193\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:155.4%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/5/59247/1307433-malus.gif\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1307433\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/5/59247/1307433-malus.gif\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/5/59247/1307433-malus.gif\"/></noscript></a></figure><p>In a tiny hamlet to the south of Wallachia, Malus lived a a happy life with his parents. However, when the resurrection of Dracula occurred, a messenger rode into his village with the news that dark flying figures had been seen in the nearby moors. Surely enough, the hamlet was subsequently attacked and burned to the ground by devils. Amid the ashes, Malus is plucked from the smoldering ruins of his home, borne on the back of a devil, and flown to Dracula's citadel where he remains a prisoner in a dungeon cell. Obviously, the ingenuity of the child knows no bounds, and he seems to have broken free of his prison.</p><p>He has no clue to why Dracula kidnapped him, indeed he appears startlingly calm for one so young...</p><h3>Rosa</h3><figure data-align=\"left\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/5/59247/1307438-rosa.gif\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1307438\" data-size=\"small\" style=\"width: 101px\" data-ratio=\"2.970297029703\" data-width=\"101\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:297.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/5/59247/1307438-rosa.gif\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1307438\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/5/59247/1307438-rosa.gif\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/5/59247/1307438-rosa.gif\"/></noscript></a></figure><p>A beautiful, yet luckless woman who has recently been infected by a vampire. Once a servant girl in the castle's rose-garden, tending to many bouquets of white satin roses. Alas, since the bit infected her nervous system, she no longer feels like the Rosa of old, but continues to water her roses... although she has found a new liquid fertilizer. Despite her vampirec appearance, her soul has been fighting this state, and she has been known to shout \"I curse my own rotting body\" and \"do not let my unsaved soul die!\"</p><p>Somewhere deep in her thoughts lies the promise of salvation, she sees a brave man striding in to save her and the world from the terrible fate that awaits...</p><h3>Vincent the Vampire Killer</h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/5/59247/1307446-vincent.gif\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1307446\" data-size=\"small\" style=\"width: 167px\" data-ratio=\"1.7964071856287\" data-width=\"167\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:179.6%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/5/59247/1307446-vincent.gif\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1307446\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/5/59247/1307446-vincent.gif\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/5/59247/1307446-vincent.gif\"/></noscript></a></figure><p>A rather boastful and arrogant, yet slightly jolly fellow, especially for a Vampire Hunter, Vincent calls himself \"the strongest vampire Killer\". He is a scholar who has spent his entire life studying vampires and lycanthropy, and well-known in literary circles as an authority on these dreaded beings, publishing his results of \"field study\" in hugely detailed tomes.</p><p>His clothing comes complete with a number of additional extras, including holy water, garlic, a wooden stake and a crucifix. Although he loves to sleep, he provides vitally important information in regard to the quest.</p><h3>Heinrich Meyer</h3><figure data-align=\"left\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/16396/542145-cv64_offart35.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-542145\" data-size=\"small\" style=\"width: 320px\" data-ratio=\"1.2345679012346\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:123.5%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/16396/542145-cv64_offart35.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-542145\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/1/16396/542145-cv64_offart35.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/1/16396/542145-cv64_offart35.jpg\"/></noscript></a></figure><p>Heinrich Meyer, a nearby merchant, visited the castle of Dracula five years prior to ply his trade of wooden artifacts, aware of the presence of evil, but not letting that get in the way of a sale. Once inside the castle, he was offered some tea buy a rather pale looking butler... Waking up three days later, he discovered to his horror that he was tied to a huge wooden operating bench, and a small mad scientist was working furiously on inserting a number of needles into his arm. The rest of his body covered in leeches, Heinrich let out an awful scream and then realized the true terror of his predicament. A thick rasping noise sounded from his lips... As he looked down, he saw blue scales covering his torso and legs. He was changing...</p><p>The fearful and quite mad Heinrich, now completely transformed into a lizard man, is kept in a castle bedroom. He keeps a key for company, and runs from the slightest aggression.</p><h3>Renon the Salesman</h3><figure data-align=\"left\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/5/59247/1307437-renon_salesm.gif\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1307437\" data-size=\"small\" style=\"width: 120px\" data-ratio=\"2.5\" data-width=\"120\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:250.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/5/59247/1307437-renon_salesm.gif\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1307437\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/5/59247/1307437-renon_salesm.gif\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/5/59247/1307437-renon_salesm.gif\"/></noscript></a></figure><p>Masquerading as a salesman (complete with an old suit, a rather dapper bowler hat and an ornate hand watch), <a data-ref-id=\"3005-5359\" href=\"/renon/3005-5359\">Renon's</a> pointed tail gives his true nature away, he is a devil.</p><p>His chosen profession however, is to sell items to adventures or brave souls who visit the castle, before watching their demise with amused glee. A mysterious man who is initially very friendly and cooperative, though his contract comes with some fine print that is not to be ignored.</p><h3>Actrise</h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/5/59247/1307412-actrise1.gif\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1307412\" data-size=\"small\" style=\"width: 204px\" data-ratio=\"1.4705882352941\" data-width=\"204\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:147.1%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/5/59247/1307412-actrise1.gif\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1307412\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/5/59247/1307412-actrise1.gif\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/5/59247/1307412-actrise1.gif\"/></noscript></a></figure><p><a data-ref-id=\"3005-13352\" href=\"/actrise/3005-13352\">Actrise</a> was a stage actress who wished for eternal beauty and fame. To this end, she bargained with the Devil himself, and her soul was thus sold. Now completely deranged after years of creeping madness, she shows her willingness to become a vampire by journeying to the Count's castle and proclaiming her foul deed: She slays one hundred children a year in praise of Dracula, and collects their souls in a number of gems. To make matters worse for this hated hag, she sacrificed her own doughter to the Devil when her contract with him suddenly ended, and was restored to eternal life shortly thereafter.</p><p>Sensing the power present in Carrie, Dracula orders Actrise to win over the girl to the cause of evil, or die trying.</p><h3>The Fernandez Warrior</h3><figure data-align=\"left\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/5/59247/1307417-camilla.gif\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1307417\" data-size=\"small\" style=\"width: 169px\" data-ratio=\"1.7751479289941\" data-width=\"169\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:177.5%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/5/59247/1307417-camilla.gif\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1307417\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/5/59247/1307417-camilla.gif\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/5/59247/1307417-camilla.gif\"/></noscript></a></figure><p>One of Actrise's brood and Carrie's blood-relation, the Fernandez warrior only appears briefly during Carrie's journey, tormenting and taunting her to return to her family roots and become a witch herself. She can summon in spirits by a simple smile (she calls it her \" death grin\"), and physical attacks are difficult to land as she lives in the Astral plane, and her earthly body is completely ethereal. Recently vampiric, she strikes with force against her will, as she would never intentionally harm her family.</p><h3>Death</h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/5/59247/1307420-death.gif\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1307420\" data-size=\"small\" style=\"width: 229px\" data-ratio=\"1.3100436681223\" data-width=\"229\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:131.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/5/59247/1307420-death.gif\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1307420\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/5/59247/1307420-death.gif\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/5/59247/1307420-death.gif\"/></noscript></a></figure><p>The confrere of Dracula himself, this lesser God has descended from another world to pursue a perverse set of goals, to confront Reinhardt, blood-relations of the Belmonts, Dracula's arch rivals. Previously, <a data-ref-id=\"3005-5581\" href=\"/death/3005-5581\">Death</a> controlled the soul of Rosa and sent her to defeat Reinhardt when he realized that Reinhardt could not be swayed to the path of Vampirism. Of course, the pure heart of Rosa allows her to protect Reinhardt, although she herself dies. A now furious Reinhardt faces this flying scythe-wielding fiend, who can summon both sickles and huge green fish to aid him.</p><h3>Gilles de Rais</h3><figure data-align=\"left\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/5/59247/1307425-dracula.gif\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1307425\" data-size=\"small\" style=\"width: 135px\" data-ratio=\"2.2222222222222\" data-width=\"135\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:222.2%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/5/59247/1307425-dracula.gif\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1307425\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/5/59247/1307425-dracula.gif\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/5/59247/1307425-dracula.gif\"/></noscript></a></figure><p>A faithful servant who has worked for Dracula since ancient times. His great age makes him the closest to a complete vampire in all facets, but he serves his darker lord all the same. Gilles de Rais knows that Dracula was born again as a human child. In order to locate his master and control the power, he commences a mass kidnapping of all the children from nearby hamlets, using both his devils and the help of Actrise to help his cause. He gathers the children in the castle, and locates the resurrected power of Dracula in a small boy called Malus. However, before the complete transformation and rebirth can be completed, he hears that two vampire hunters have infiltrated his castle. To deceive them, he changes his appearance and behaves as if he is Dracula himself.</p><h3>Dracula</h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/5/59247/1307424-dracula1.gif\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1307424\" data-size=\"small\" style=\"width: 98px\" data-ratio=\"3.0612244897959\" data-width=\"98\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:306.1%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/5/59247/1307424-dracula1.gif\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1307424\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/5/59247/1307424-dracula1.gif\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/5/59247/1307424-dracula1.gif\"/></noscript></a></figure><p>After being defeated be the Belmonts, <a data-ref-id=\"3005-348\" href=\"/dracula/3005-348\">Dracula's</a> material body vanished, and his soul was banished for one hundred years, only to be resurrected in the form of Malus. Malus does not have any memories of his previous life, but the devils notice their evil leader's traits in the immense dark power that Malus wields.</p><p>One devil was even honored enough to transform into a demonic steed for the boy. However, another even more frightening power he wields appears to be being summoned by Malus. By the ritual sacrificing of the children captured by the devils, Malus' powers of transformation begin to surface as he remembers his true vicious nature. Malus is only the initial stage of ultimate evil, as Dracula's true form reveals.</p><h2>Beta Characters</h2><p>A large number of characters and enemies did not make it into the final version of Castlevania.</p><h3>Cornell</h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/5/59247/1307845-corny01.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1307845\" data-size=\"small\" style=\"width: 320px\" data-ratio=\"2.4901960784314\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:249.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/5/59247/1307845-corny01.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1307845\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/5/59247/1307845-corny01.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/5/59247/1307845-corny01.jpg\"/></noscript></a></figure><p><a data-ref-id=\"3005-8531\" href=\"/cornell/3005-8531\">Cornell</a> (initially named \"Cornell Reinhardt\") was the first of two playable protagonist characters that were scrapped during the game's development. He did, however, make the cut for the followup edition of the game, Castlevania: Legacy of Darkness, though his backstory was a bit darker in it's original conception.</p><p>Rather than being a member of the man-beast tribe, Cornell's werewolf transformation ability was actually a curse placed by Dracula on his ancestors. The curse was revived when Dracula reawakened and the dark lord's minions proceeded to attack Cornell's village.</p><p>In their panic and desperation, Cornell and his sister, Ada Reinhardt, regressed into lycanthropes in their attempt to save a child from nearby a monster. Having witnessed the frightening transformations, the people of the village feared what might happen if the Reinhardts would turn against them, and both captured and executed Ada. Filled with rage, Cornell abandoned his village and made his way to Dracula's castle, with the intent of ending the curse of his blood once and for all.</p><h3>Coller</h3><figure data-align=\"left\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/5/59247/1307426-gardener.gif\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1307426\" data-size=\"small\" style=\"width: 155px\" data-ratio=\"1.9354838709677\" data-width=\"155\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:193.5%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/5/59247/1307426-gardener.gif\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1307426\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/5/59247/1307426-gardener.gif\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/5/59247/1307426-gardener.gif\"/></noscript></a></figure><p>Coller is the second of two playable protagonist characters which were scrapped from the game's development. Little is known of his backstory, though the developers have stated that he was an artificial human and could not become vampirized.</p><p>Bits of Coller's concept and design did make it into the game as a chainsaw-equipped Frankenstein's monster, which acts as the gardener in the Villa's hedge maze.</p><h3>Coller 2</h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/5/59247/1307455-kora2.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1307455\" data-size=\"small\" style=\"width: 150px\" data-ratio=\"2\" data-width=\"150\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:200.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/5/59247/1307455-kora2.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1307455\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/5/59247/1307455-kora2.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/5/59247/1307455-kora2.jpg\"/></noscript></a></figure><p>An artificial human, Coller2 was designed to be the main antagonist of Coller during his quest through Dracula's castle. Whereas the original Coller was quite primitive in construction, his rival's design was sleek and advanced.</p><p>When Coller was scrapped from the game, Coller2 went with him. The \"2\" represents the model number by which she was manufactured.</p><h3>Majo (Witch)</h3><figure data-align=\"left\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/5/59247/1307569-castle3.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1307569\" data-size=\"small\" style=\"width: 320px\" data-ratio=\"0.79142300194932\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:79.1%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/5/59247/1307569-castle3.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1307569\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/5/59247/1307569-castle3.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/5/59247/1307569-castle3.jpg\"/></noscript></a></figure><p>In volume 3 of Konami Magazine (July 1997), this enemy was introduced and labeled \"Majo\" (\u9b54\u5973), though it is possible that her true name was <a data-ref-id=\"3005-8461\" href=\"/camilla/3005-8461\">Carmilla</a>, as she bears a striking resemblance to the recurring Castlevania villainess. <a data-ref-id=\"3010-844\" href=\"/konami-computer-entertainment-kobe-inc/3010-844\">KCEK</a>, the development team behind the game, would later feature Carmilla in their future handheld entry, <a data-ref-id=\"3030-13197\" href=\"/castlevania-circle-of-the-moon/3030-13197\">\"Castlevania: Circle of the Moon\"</a>.</p><p>Majo was described as being extremely dangerous. After preparing an attack via a high incantation, she would call out \u300c\u6b7b\u3092\u547c\u3076\u300d (\"Death has called!\") and cast a spell which could cause instant-death to the castle intruder. An early tech demo trailer of Castlevania showed heroine Carrie briefly battling Majo; it is possible that the enemy was replaced by Actrise as the girl's main rival.</p><h3>Mummy-chan</h3><p>Mummy-chan (<b>\u30de\u30df\u3061\u3083\u3093</b>) was set to be a regular enemy in the game, who attacked with a Taekwondo fighting style. Her special attack was the \"Nerichagi,\" which could take down the player in one hit. It is highly likely that she would have been an enemy encountered during Cornell's quest, suggested both by the accompanying concept art and that the lycanthrope would have also used martial arts moves to attack.</p><h2>Soundtrack</h2><p>The soundtrack of the game was composed by <a href=\"../../masahiko-kimura/72-67256/\" rel=\"nofollow\">Masahiko Kimura</a>, <a href=\"../../motoaki-furukawa/72-63416/\" rel=\"nofollow\">Motoaki Furukawa</a> and Mariko Egawa. It was released on March 26th, 1999 in Japan and May 1999 in Europe.</p><h3>Track Listing</h3><p>01. Introduction</p><p>02. Setting</p><p>03. Prologue</p><p>04. Shudder</p><p>05. Intrusion</p><p>06. Watchtower</p><p>07. Annex. Silent Madness</p><p>08. Hamlet People</p><p>09. Rose</p><p>10. Maze Garden</p><p>11. Mysterious Coffin</p><p>12. First Struggle</p><p>13. Underground Waterway</p><p>14. Ungerground Tunnel. Invisible Sorrow</p><p>15. Lamented Rose</p><p>16. Dungeon ~ Main Theme</p><p>17. Malus Reappears</p><p>18. Actrise</p><p>19. Sypha</p><p>20. Planetarium</p><p>21. Unexpected Encounter</p><p>22. Duel Tower</p><p>23. Tower of Science</p><p>24. Tower of Execution</p><p>25. Tower of Sorcery</p><p>26. Second Struggle</p><p>27. Toothed Wheel</p><p>28. Carrie's Good Ending</p><p>34. Bad Ending</p><p>35. Schneider's Good Ending</p><p>36. Credits</p><p>37. Melodies of Castlevania</p><p>38. Invisible Sorrow</p><p>39. A Night in Peace and Quiet</p>", "deck": "Castlevania 64 brings the horror franchise to 3D, as players control either the whip-bearing Reinhardt Schneider or the magical Carrie Fernandez.", "aliases": "Castlevania 64\nAkumaj\u014d Dracula Mokushiroku\nDevil's Castle Dracula Apocalypse", "image": {"icon_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/square_avatar/8/87790/1773380-box_cv64.png", "medium_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_medium/8/87790/1773380-box_cv64.png", "tiny_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/square_mini/8/87790/1773380-box_cv64.png", "small_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/8/87790/1773380-box_cv64.png", "thumb_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_avatar/8/87790/1773380-box_cv64.png", "screen_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/screen_medium/8/87790/1773380-box_cv64.png", "super_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_large/8/87790/1773380-box_cv64.png"}, "date_last_updated": "2014-10-14 20:29:46", "expected_release_month": null, "api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/game/3030-22950/", "number_of_user_reviews": 0, "original_release_date": "1999-01-26 00:00:00", "original_game_rating": [{"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/game_rating/3065-1/", "id": 1, "name": "ESRB: T"}, {"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/game_rating/3065-36/", "id": 36, "name": "PEGI: 12+"}], "date_added": "2008-08-04 00:47:57", "platforms": [{"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/platform/3045-43/", "abbreviation": "N64", "site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/nintendo-64/3045-43/", "id": 43, "name": "Nintendo 64"}], "expected_release_day": null, "expected_release_year": null, "id": 22950, "resource_type": "game", "name": "Castlevania"}, "platform": "N64", "title": "Castlevania 64"}
{"duration": "0:30:00", "runner": "_VB", "data": {"site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/castlevania-aria-of-sorrow/3030-12036/", "expected_release_quarter": null, "description": "<h2>Overview</h2><figure data-ref-id=\"1300-238655\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/3693/238655-somacruz2.jpg\" data-size=\"small\" data-align=\"right\" data-embed-type=\"image\" data-ratio=\"0.97402597402597\" data-width=\"320\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:97.4%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/3693/238655-somacruz2.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-238655\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/3693/238655-somacruz2.jpg\"/></a><figcaption>Soma Cruz, the game's main protagonist.</figcaption></figure><p>Castlevania: Aria Of Sorrow (known in Japan as <em>Castlevania: Minuet of Dawn</em>) is an action-adventure horror platformer developed by <a href=\"/konami-computer-entertainment-tokyo/3010-817\" data-ref-id=\"3010-817\">KCE Tokyo</a> and published by <a href=\"/konami-corporation/3010-87\" data-ref-id=\"3010-87\">Konami</a> for the <a href=\"/game-boy-advance/3045-4\" data-ref-id=\"3045-4\">Game Boy Advance</a> on May 6, 2003.</p><p>It is the spiritual sequel to <a href=\"/castlevania-harmony-of-dissonance/3030-18040\" data-ref-id=\"3030-18040\">Castlevania: Harmony of Dissonance</a> (which also shared the same game engine) and the fourth <a href=\"/castlevania/3025-86\" data-ref-id=\"3025-86\">Castlevania</a> platformer to use the modern <a href=\"/metroidvania/3015-2440\" data-ref-id=\"3015-2440\">Metroidvania</a> structure of platforming based on free-roaming exploration. It is the first game to take place in the 21st century and the first game to <em>not</em> take place in Europe. It is also the first game to abandon the traditional sub-weapon system for a unique \"Tactical Soul\" system, where the player character can absorb (at random) the <a href=\"/souls/3015-1449\" data-ref-id=\"3015-1449\">souls</a> of fallen enemies to use in both combat and utility.</p><p>The story takes place in the year 2035, 36 years after the final defeat of <a href=\"/dracula/3005-348\" data-ref-id=\"3005-348\">Count Dracula</a>. The main protagonist is <a href=\"/soma-cruz/3005-1537\" data-ref-id=\"3005-1537\">Soma Cruz</a>, a seemingly-normal 18-year-old student who visits <a href=\"/japan/3035-37\" data-ref-id=\"3035-37\">Japan</a> as a transfer student. While visiting the Hakuba shrine to witness a solar eclipse with his childhood friend <a href=\"/mina-hakuba/3005-8681\" data-ref-id=\"3005-8681\">Mina Hakuba</a>, both Soma and Mina are drawn into a mysterious castle inside the eclipse, where they learn from <a href=\"/alucard/3005-646\" data-ref-id=\"3005-646\">Genya Arikado</a>, a member of a mysterious Japanese organization, that they are in Dracula's castle. Players control Soma as he explores the castle, unlocking new abilities while unsheathing a prophecy about the reincarnation of Dracula.</p><p>The game received a sequel in 2005 for the <a href=\"/nintendo-ds/3045-52\" data-ref-id=\"3045-52\">Nintendo DS</a>, dubbed <a href=\"/castlevania-dawn-of-sorrow/3030-11321\" data-ref-id=\"3030-11321\">Castlevania: Dawn of Sorrow</a>, which abandons the dark, gothic, painting-like art style for an anime-inspired look. In 2006, the game was bundled together with Castlevania: Harmony of Dissonance in one cartridge as Castlevania: Double Pack.</p><h2>Gameplay</h2><figure data-align=\"left\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/7539/501373-castlevania___aria_of_sorrow___gba_67.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-501373\" data-size=\"small\" data-embed-type=\"image\" data-ratio=\"0.66666666666667\" data-width=\"240\" style=\"width: 240px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:66.7%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/7539/501373-castlevania___aria_of_sorrow___gba_67.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-501373\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/7539/501373-castlevania___aria_of_sorrow___gba_67.png\"/></a></figure><p>Aria of Sorrow, much like all of its predecessors, is a 2D sidescrolling action platformer. The game incorporates a number of elements from console RPG games, such as the experience and levelling up systems. Soma, the main character, will gain experience points whenever he defeats an enemy. Once enough experience has been gained he will level up, increasing all of his stats, and improving his performance in combat. In addition, the game borrows inventory and loot systems from RPGs that allow Soma to collect upgrades for armor and weapons. Equippable items, along with hearts and money, are dropped by enemies, and can be found when destroying breakable light sources. </p><p>Being a post-Symphony of the Night Castlevania title, the game is non-linear in nature. Soma will explore the many quadrants of Dracula's castle, discovering new powers, secret passage, and solving puzzles to advance. He will need to search thoroughly, backtrack, and experiment in order to progress through the castle, and reach new areas. Each area houses different scenery, tougher enemies, and new puzzles and challenges for Soma to tackle.</p><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/7539/501350-castlevania___aria_of_sorrow___gba_45.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-501350\" data-size=\"small\" data-embed-type=\"image\" data-ratio=\"0.66666666666667\" data-width=\"240\" style=\"width: 240px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:66.7%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/7539/501350-castlevania___aria_of_sorrow___gba_45.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-501350\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/7539/501350-castlevania___aria_of_sorrow___gba_45.png\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/7539/501350-castlevania___aria_of_sorrow___gba_45.png\"/></noscript></a></figure><p>Unique to Aria of Sorrow is the tactical soul system, which allows Soma to absorb the souls of his enemies, granting him an expanded repertoire of special abilities. These souls are divided into four categories: Bullet, Guardian, Enchant, and Ability souls. Soma can equip one of each at any given point in the game. Bullet souls are generally offensive in nature, and will usually create a projectile attack. Guardian souls have an effect over time, and include summons and transformations. Enchant souls are continuously active when equipped, and will increase Soma's statistics, or grant him a number of abilities. Finally, the ability souls will give Soma additional skills, usually required for progress through the castle. Both bullet and guardian souls require magic points to use, while Enchant and ability souls do not.</p>", "deck": "Castlevania: Aria of Sorrow is the third Castlevania installment for the Game Boy Advance, bringing the tale of Castlevania to the 21st century and putting players in the shoes of Soma Cruz, a seemingly-normal guy who has the power to absorb souls of the castle's demons and equip them.", "aliases": "Castlevania: Minuet of Dawn\nCastlevania: Akatsuki no Menuett", "image": {"icon_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/square_avatar/8/87790/2582052-box_cvaos.png", "Castlevania: Aria of Sorrow"}
{"duration": "0:40:00", "runner": "romscout", "data": {"site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/castlevania-dawn-of-sorrow/3030-11321/", "expected_release_quarter": null, "description": "<h2>Overview</h2><figure data-ref-id=\"1300-187568\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/4344/187568-dsmain.jpg\" data-size=\"small\" data-align=\"right\" data-embed-type=\"image\" data-ratio=\"1.2425213675214\" data-width=\"320\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:124.3%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/4344/187568-dsmain.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-187568\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/4344/187568-dsmain.jpg\"/></a></figure><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">Castlevania: Dawn of Sorrow (known in Japan as <em>Devil's Castle Dracula: Cross of the Blue Moon</em>) is a 2D action-adventure horror platformer developed by <a href=\"/konami-computer-entertainment-tokyo/3010-817\" data-ref-id=\"3010-817\">KCE Tokyo</a> and published by <a href=\"/konami-corporation/3010-87\" data-ref-id=\"3010-87\">Konami</a> for the <a href=\"/nintendo-ds/3045-52\" data-ref-id=\"3045-52\">Nintendo DS</a> on October 4, 2005.</p><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">The sequel to <a href=\"/castlevania-aria-of-sorrow/3030-12036\" data-ref-id=\"3030-12036\">Castlevania: Aria of Sorrow</a>, Castlevania: Dawn of Sorrow is the first <a href=\"/castlevania/3025-86\" data-ref-id=\"3025-86\">Castlevania</a> game developed for the Nintendo DS and the fifth Castlevania game to use the modern <a href=\"/metroidvania/3015-2440\" data-ref-id=\"3015-2440\">Metroidvania</a> structure of platforming based on free-roaming exploration. It is also one of the few Castlevania games to use an anime-inspired art style.</p><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">Taking place in the year 2036, one year after the events in Castlevania: Aria of Sorrow, the game follows protagonist <a href=\"/soma-cruz/3005-1537\" data-ref-id=\"3005-1537\">Soma Cruz</a> (who is revealed in the last game to be the reincarnation of <a href=\"/dracula/3005-348\" data-ref-id=\"3005-348\">Dracula</a>), who must investigate an evil cult (headed by shadow priestess <a href=\"/celia-fortner/3005-8525\" data-ref-id=\"3005-8525\">Celia Fortner</a>) dedicated to the resurrection of a lord of darkness.</p><h2>Gameplay</h2><h4>Tactical Soul</h4><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/3693/210720-dawnofsorrow7.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-210720\" data-size=\"small\" data-embed-type=\"image\" data-ratio=\"0.744140625\" data-width=\"320\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:74.4%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/3693/210720-dawnofsorrow7.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-210720\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/3693/210720-dawnofsorrow7.jpg\"/></a><figcaption>Dawn of Sorrow's Magic Seal mechanic in action</figcaption></figure><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">First featured in <a href=\"/castlevania-aria-of-sorrow/3030-12036\" data-ref-id=\"3030-12036\">Castlevania: Aria of Sorrow</a>, the Tactical Soul mechanic allows Soma to absorb the souls of monsters and creatures he killed throughout the game. Each soul sports a unique power, and there are four categories: Bullet, Guardian, Enchant and Ability. Players can absorb a soul as much they want to except for the Ability souls that are unlocked through specific boss battles and plot points. Each specific soul has a different rarity; the better ones, like the Valkyrie soul, are much harder to get than an ordinary Zombie soul. At <a href=\"/yoko-belnades/3005-8680\" data-ref-id=\"3005-8680\">Yoko Belnades</a>' shop, you can use absorbed souls to make higher-powered weapons with the penultimate versions requiring the rarest ones to find. If two people have a cartridge for Dawn of Sorrow, an option to trade souls through wireless connectivity became available. Souls relating to the storyline or souls that allow access to later parts of the game are not available through trade.</p><h4>Magic Seal</h4><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">The Magic Seal mechanic first appeared in Castlevania: Dawn of Sorrow with no appearances in the Castlevania series since then. During large boss battles, players received a prompt to draw a predetermined symbol to finish the boss off; there were no other options when defeating bosses. The further into the game the player got, the more elaborate the symbols became.</p><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">Reception concerning the Magic Seal mechanic was generally negative and deemed as \"unnecessary\" or \"pace-breaking\" according to many players and reputable reviewers. This is Dawn of Sorrow's only use of the touch screen other than breaking crystal blocks or controlling familiars. The series has since abandoned extensive use of touch screen capabilities due to negative criticisms.</p><h2>Bosses &amp; Alternate Endings</h2><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">There are 16 boss fights in the game:</p><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/3693/210719-dawnofsorrow6.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-210719\" data-size=\"small\" data-embed-type=\"image\" data-ratio=\"0.744140625\" data-width=\"320\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:74.4%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/3693/210719-dawnofsorrow6.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-210719\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/3693/210719-dawnofsorrow6.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/3693/210719-dawnofsorrow6.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Boss fights are as gruesome as ever</figcaption></figure><ul><li>Flying Armor</li><li>Balore</li><li>Dmitrii</li><li>Malphas</li><li>Dario</li><li>Puppet Master</li><li>Gergoth</li><li>Zephyr</li><li>Rahab</li><li>Bat Company</li><li>Paranoia</li><li>Dario (again)</li><li>Aguni</li><li>Death</li><li>Abaddon</li><li>Menace</li></ul><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">Some boss fights are optional as the game can be completed at three different points during the main story progression. However, to reach the true ending you need to find a way to the final boss room and beat Menace.</p><h2>Game Modes</h2><h4>Enemy Set Mode</h4><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">Here, players can select the souls of any they've taken from adventure mode and create their own series of dungeons. The goal is to cut past all enemies on every screen and get to the end as soon as possible with the hero you have in adventure mode. Players can also challenge a friend to fight past their custom dungeons.</p><h4>Boss Rush Mode</h4><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">In this mode you have to defeat all of the game's bosses in order. You are given a Super Potion, a Mana Prism and a Rusty Food Tin. The objective is to defeat the bosses as fast as possible. Depending on how fast you defeat them, you are given different prizes at the end.</p><h4>Julius Mode</h4><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">In Julius mode you start off as Julius Belmont, and are later joined by Yoko Belnades and Alucard. You are able to swap between the three characters by pressing the X-button. You fight through the castle as in Normal Mode, except with a different story and a different final boss. The character swap system was later reused in <a href=\"/castlevania-portrait-of-ruin/3030-14357\" data-ref-id=\"3030-14357\">Castlevania: Portrait of Ruin</a>.</p>", "deck": "Castlevania: Dawn of Sorrow is the first Castlevania game for the Nintendo DS, continuing the tale of Soma Cruz and his ability to absorb the souls of fallen enemies for use in combat and utility.", "aliases": "Demon Castle Dracula: Cross of the Blue Moon\nAkumaj\u014d Dracula: Sougetsu no J\u016bjika\nDevil's Castle Dracula: Cross of the Blue Moon", "image": {"icon_url":
