{"duration": "0:20:00", "runner": "lildingus", "data": {"site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/castlevania-dracula-x/3030-10975/", "expected_release_quarter": null, "description": "<h2>Overview</h2><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/6494/240499-62728_9_2.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-240499\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"1.1953352769679\" data-embed-type=\"image\" data-width=\"320\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:119.5%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/6494/240499-62728_9_2.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-240499\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/6494/240499-62728_9_2.jpg\"/></a><figcaption> Richter Belmont, the game's main protagonist</figcaption></figure><p>Castlevania: Dracula X (known in Europe as <em>Castlevania: Vampire's Kiss</em> and in Japan as <em>Devil's Castle Dracula XX</em>) is an action horror platformer developed and published by <a href=\"/konami-corporation/3010-87\" data-ref-id=\"3010-87\">Konami</a> for the <a href=\"/snes/3045-9\" data-ref-id=\"3045-9\">Super Nintendo Entertainment System</a> in September 1995.</p><p>Based on the <a href=\"/turbografx-cd/3045-53\" data-ref-id=\"3045-53\">PC-Engine Super CD-ROM\u00b2</a> game <a href=\"/akumajo-dracula-x-chi-no-rondo/3030-12673\" data-ref-id=\"3030-12673\">Castlevania: Rondo of Blood</a> (originally Japanese-exclusive), the game shares most of its graphics, gameplay, storyline, and music. However, some components (such as the levels) were completely redesigned.</p><p>Taking place sometime in 1792 (one hundred years after the events of the original <a href=\"/castlevania/3030-6673\" data-ref-id=\"3030-6673\">Castlevania</a>, the player controls <a href=\"/richter-belmont/3005-116\" data-ref-id=\"3005-116\">Richter Belmont</a>, descendant of <a href=\"/simon-belmont/3005-86\" data-ref-id=\"3005-86\">Simon Belmont</a>, as he sets out to seal the fate of <a href=\"/dracula/3005-348\" data-ref-id=\"3005-348\">Count Dracula</a> while rescuing his beloved <a href=\"/anette-renard/3005-8703\" data-ref-id=\"3005-8703\">Annette Renard</a> (along with her sister, <a href=\"/maria-renard/3005-179\" data-ref-id=\"3005-179\">Maria</a>).</p><h2>Gameplay</h2><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/3693/345775-ss_07.27.2008_08.16.05am.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-345775\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.86758893280632\" data-embed-type=\"image\" data-width=\"320\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:86.8%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/3693/345775-ss_07.27.2008_08.16.05am.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-345775\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/3693/345775-ss_07.27.2008_08.16.05am.jpg\"/></a></figure><p>Castlevania: Dracula X plays like a traditional <a href=\"/castlevania/3025-86\" data-ref-id=\"3025-86\">Castlevania</a> game. Players guide Richter through seven stages, increasing their score by defeating enemies and collecting bags of money (dropped by enemies or destroying scenery). Players will also find <a href=\"/heart/3055-142\" data-ref-id=\"3055-142\">heart</a>-shaped <a href=\"/jewel/3055-1737\" data-ref-id=\"3055-1737\">jewels</a>, which serve as ammunition for Richter's sub-weapons and super attacks (known as \"Item Crashes\"). Unlike <a href=\"/super-castlevania-iv/3030-11443\" data-ref-id=\"3030-11443\">Super Castlevania IV</a>, released four years earlier, the player cannot do any special tricks with his <a href=\"/vampire-killer/3055-284\" data-ref-id=\"3055-284\">Vampire Killer</a> whip (such as whip in eight directions, hold out the whip freely to block projectiles, and use the whip to grapple onto special points). However, Richter can perform a backflip dodge (by double-tapping the jump button). Richter can also maintain his position while getting hit simply by crouching (preventing him from being knocked back), and can jump on and off stairs (by holding up or down on the d-pad and pressing the jump button).</p><p>Other than jewels and bags of money, players can also find pendants (which clears the screen of all enemies), transparency <a href=\"/potion/3055-79\" data-ref-id=\"3055-79\">elixirs</a> (which grant Richter <a href=\"/temporary-invincibility/3015-266\" data-ref-id=\"3015-266\">temporary invulnerability</a>), and food (which restores some of Richter's <a href=\"/health/3015-130\" data-ref-id=\"3015-130\">health</a>). Defeating a boss causes a Mystic Sphere to drop from the sky, refilling Richter's health completely and clearing the stage. Players earn extra lives by finding 1-Up items scattered throughout the game and clearing stages without getting hit, as well as for every time the player earns 20,000 points.</p><h3>Sub-Weapons/Item Crashes</h3><p>Along the way, Richter can pick up unique sub-weapons that consume the jewel meter for a special attack (performed by holding up on the directional pad and pressing the attack button). Richter can also perform \"Item Crushes\", which sacrifice more jewels for a super attack (by pressing the special Item Crush button). All of the sub-weapons and Item Crushes perform like they did in <a href=\"/akumajo-dracula-x-chi-no-rondo/3030-12673\" data-ref-id=\"3030-12673\">Castlevania: Rondo of Blood</a>. However, this game is missing the Holy Bible sub-weapon.</p><ul><li><a href=\"/dagger/3055-1306\" data-ref-id=\"3055-1306\"> <b>Dagger</b></a> - At the cost of one jewel, Richter throws three very fast (but very weak) daggers. The Item Crush, at the cost of 10 jewels, produces a rapid stream of daggers.</li><li><a href=\"/axe/3055-437\" data-ref-id=\"3055-437\"> <b>Axe</b></a> - At the cost of one jewel, Richter tosses an axe in the air in an arced path (going through both walls and enemies). The Item Crash, at the cost of 10 jewels, causes Richter to float up in the air and produce a circle of axes that fan out around him.</li><li><a href=\"/cross/3055-671\" data-ref-id=\"3055-671\"> <b>Holy Cross</b></a> - At the cost of one jewel, Richter throws a cross-shaped object forward, which will return in the other direction like a <a href=\"/boomerang/3055-76\" data-ref-id=\"3055-76\"> boomerang</a>, damaging enemies along the way. The Item Crash, at the cost of 15 jewels, causes the screen to be bombarded with large crucifixes.<br /><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/8812/289559-gfs_45539_2_21.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-289559\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.75\" data-embed-type=\"image\" data-width=\"320\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:75.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/8812/289559-gfs_45539_2_21.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-289559\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/8812/289559-gfs_45539_2_21.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/8812/289559-gfs_45539_2_21.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Holy Water rain!</figcaption></figure></li><li><a href=\"/holy-water/3055-1207\" data-ref-id=\"3055-1207\"> <b>Holy Water</b></a> - At the cost of three jewels, Richter throws a bottle of holy water on the ground, creating a small area-of-effect attack with the flames it creates. Its Item Crash, at the cost of 20 jewels, causes holy water to rain from the sky all over the screen.</li><li><a href=\"/pocket-watch/3055-979\" data-ref-id=\"3055-979\"> <b>Pocket Watch</b></a> - At the cost of five jewels, Richter freezes most enemies in their place for five seconds. The Item Crash, at the cost of 30 jewels, grants Richter a temporary shield of pocket watches (causing a lot of damage when inflicted upon enemies).</li><li><a href=\"/key/3055-105\" data-ref-id=\"3055-105\"> <b>Key</b></a> - Found in Stage 3, it is used for unlocking certain doors (allowing the player to rescue Annette and Maria). The Item Crash, which can only be performed if Richter has 15 jewels or more (it does not consume any jewels), causes Richter to hold the key out in front of him, causing major damage at the cost of its close range.</li></ul><p>Pressing the Item Crush button without carrying a sub-weapon causes Richter to throw a giant flaming whip attack (at the cost of 15 jewels).</p>", "deck": "A Super Nintendo remake of the PC-Engine Super CD-ROM\u00b2 game Castlevania: Rondo of Blood, Dracula X details the original adventures of whip-bearing Richter Belmont, a century after the events of the {"duration": "0:50:00", "runner": "MickeyGnou", "data": {"site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/metroid-zero-mission/3030-17356/", "expected_release_quarter": null, "description": "<h2>Overview</h2><p>Metroid: Zero Mission is a GBA remake of the original NES <a href=\"/metroid/3030-21761\" data-ref-id=\"3030-21761\">Metroid</a>, using updated graphics and controls based on and inspired by the then-recent <a href=\"/metroid-fusion/3030-10323\" data-ref-id=\"3030-10323\">Metroid Fusion</a>. As well as a map function missing from the original, the game has a few updated features and bonus areas, including a unique <a href=\"/ridley/3005-1305\" data-ref-id=\"3005-1305\">Ridley</a> fight.</p><h2>Story</h2><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/5709/274948-29764_8_2.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-274948\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.66735966735967\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:66.7%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/5709/274948-29764_8_2.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-274948\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/5709/274948-29764_8_2.jpg\"/></a><figcaption>Samus Aran is the main protagonist of Zero Mission.</figcaption></figure><p>Metroid: Zero Mission follows the same basic plot as that of the original Metroid. On an emergency order from the Galactic Federation, bounty hunter <a href=\"/samus-aran/3005-99\" data-ref-id=\"3005-99\"> Samus Aran</a> travels to the planet Zebes in order to infiltrate a lair of space pirates, exterminate the metroids that they have in their possession, and destroy the space pirates' bio-mechanical computer, Mother Brain. The bosses Ridley and <a href=\"/kraid/3005-3010\" data-ref-id=\"3005-3010\"> Kraid</a> also return and are given appearances more in line with their redesigned forms that appeared in <a href=\"/super-metroid/3030-8292\" data-ref-id=\"3030-8292\"> Super Metroid</a>.</p><p>The plot is further expanded by cutscenes at key points to illustrate the story in more detail. It also works in key points of Samus's backstory that had been established in later games, depicting moments of her childhood as an orphan on Zebes, raised by the Chozo that once inhabited the planet. The biggest deviation from the original Metroid comes at the point where the first game ended. in Zero Mission, after Samus defeats Mother Brain and escapes to her ship, she is attacked by space pirates and forced to crash land, losing her power suit in the process. Armed with only an emergency pistol, she must sneak into the inner-most chamber of an old Chozo temple and complete a trial to acquire a newer, more powerful suit. Once done, she confronts a now cybernetic Ridley and uses a spare space pirate craft to escape.</p><h2>Gameplay </h2><p>Metroid Zero Mission controls similarly to Metroid Fusion. Players fire with B and jump with A. Zero Mission brings in power ups made famous by Super Metroid for this remake for a different take on the first game. Some effects also happen automatically such as the Speed Booster which turns off after walking for a while without getting obstructed. Players also have more control over some more advanced techniques in this game such as the Shinespark, which can now be cancelled by inclines while still allowing it to continue for a short while. An addition was made to the Shinespark, as it can now be used in Morph Ball mode, a technique which is necessary to get 100% of all items in the game. </p><p>Sequence Breaking was a big part in the design of Metroid Zero Mission. Some paths that exist in the game are solely there for the purpose of sequence breaking, and are otherwise unreachable without using techniques such as wall jumping, shinesparking or diagonal bomb jumping; all of which are techniques non-existent in the original Metroid. </p><p>After defeating Mother Brain and escaping Zebes, Samus is attacked by Space Pirates, leaving her marooned on Zebes without her Power Suit. This new part of the game which puts Samus in her Zero Suit, introduced first in this game. Samus is very weak in this segment, and only a few hits will result in a Game Over. Samus cannot kill enemies in this section, only stun them. This section of the game is a side-scrolling stealth segment which leads Samus getting the Gravity Suit as well as all the Unknown items she has picked up thus far. This will eventually lead to the final boss of the game as well as final escape sequence.</p><h2>Beam Upgrades</h2><h3>Long Beam</h3><p>An extension of Samus' Power Beam, allowing her to shoot farther to reach those annoying enemies at the corners of the screen and blow up all the rocks blocking Morph Ball tunnels.</p><h3>Charge Beam</h3><p>A fully charged blast has the same power as a missile, but it doesn't open red doors. Also if Samus somersaults into small enemies while holding a charge she will destroy them; a less powerful Screw Attack.</p><h3>Wave Beam</h3><p>The Wave Beam increases Samus's beam width and allows her to shoot through walls. It can also reveal destructible blocks.</p><h3>Ice Beam</h3><p>One shot of Ice Beam freezes some enemies in their tracks for a short period of time, making them easier to avoid. Since frozen enemies don't harm Samus, they can be used as platforms.</p><h3>Plasma Beam</h3><p>One of the unknown items Samus can collect early on which later becomes the Plasma Beam once Samus has fully upgraded her suit. Rather than stopping with one enemy Plasma Beam allows Samus's beam to keep flying to hit multiple enemies.</p><h2>Bomb Upgrades</h2><h3>Morph Ball Bomb</h3><p>Finally Samus's Morph Ball is no longer weak and defenseless. Morph Ball Bombs are used for opening new paths and she can use them to preform a bomb jump. Using Bombs on certain areas will reveal special blocks that require certain items to get past, such as Power Bombs and Missiles.</p><h3>Power Bomb</h3><p>This is the game's final upgrade. This bomb has a radius of about a screen and a half and destroys anything in its way.</p><h2>Missile Upgrades</h2><h3>Missile Tank</h3><p>A missile is more powerful than Samus's beam and can open red hatches, making it a great addition to her arsenal. In easy and normal difficulties the missile tank gives Samus five missiles, but on hard difficulty it gives her only two.</p><h3>Super Missile Tank</h3><p>A Super Missile is around five missiles combined into one huge explosion that opens green hatches and brings bosses to their knees. On easy and normal difficulty, the tank gives Samus two Super Missiles, where as it gives her one on hard difficulty.</p><h2>Suit Upgrades</h2><h3>Varia Suit</h3><p>The Varia Suit allows Samus to enter hot rooms that originally drained her health. She can even go in acid without fear of damage, but lava still zaps her health. Without a better suit upgrade, she will move at half speed while in these areas.</p><h3>Gravity Suit</h3><p>Another one of the unknown items; the Gravity Suit allows Samus to jump normally in acid, lava, or water and prevents damage from lava. The Gravity Suit also allows her to move freely in these areas without being slowed down.</p><h2>Miscellaneous Upgrades</h2><h3>Morph Ball</h3><p>Samus's first upgrade she get immediately after starting. Morph Ball allows her to enter small passages and evade enemies quicker.</p><h3>Power Grip</h3><p>Power Grip allows Samus to grab onto edges that she couldn't jump onto before. She can also fire her beam in five directions while hanging.</p><h3>High Jump</h3><p>This greatly increases how high Samus can jump, and even adds a jump to the Morph Ball. Using this allows her to reach areas that were once unreachable through jumping normally.</p><h3>Space Jump</h3><p>This allows Samus to continuously jump while in mid-air. When Samus acquires the Screw Attack, she can jump without fear of taking damage from enemies, which would cause her to lose her jump otherwise.</p><h3>Speed Booster</h3><p>This upgrade allows Samus to run faster through long corridors, destroying everything in her way, including blocks with an arrow on them. While activated, pressing down on the D-pad will allow her to perform the Shinespark technique which can be done by jumping twice and pressing a direction.</p><h3>Screw Attack</h3><p>This upgrade turns Samus's somersault into an upgrade that allows her to plow through all enemies (except for bosses), and destroys certain blocks by jumping into them.</p><h3>Energy Tanks</h3><p>These increase Samus's Health by 100 on every difficulty besides Hard. On Hard difficulty, Energy Tanks only increase her health by 50. </p><h2>Areas on Zebes</h2><p>Metroid Zero Mission takes all of the areas from the original Metroid and adds a couple of its' own. </p><h3>Brinstar </h3><p>This is the starting area of the game. Samus even starts in the exact same location as well. Most of the environments are rock and plant based. Here, she can obtain the Morph Ball, the Long Beam, the Varia Suit, Bombs and the Charge Beam; not necessarily in that order. She can also reach the areas Norfair, Tourian, Kraid and Crateria. Brinstar is basically the game's hub world since it connects to almost every other area in the game. </p><h3>Norfair </h3><p>The environment here is made up mostly of rocks and lava/acid. Some areas are not accessible if Samus do not have the Varia Suit due to the extreme temperatures, which will cause her to constantly take damage until she dies. In this area she can get the Ice Beam, the High Jump, the Wave Beam and the Speed Attack. In Norfair, she can access the areas Brinstar, Crateria, and Ridley. She can also access Kraid, but only through sequence breaking.</p><h3>Kraid </h3><p>This area is where Samus faces the first boss of the game, Kraid. Kraid is a giant lizard that is 2 screens tall. By defeating Kraid she obtains access to the Speed Booster. In Kraid, she can also get one of three unknown items, which are unlocked later in the game. Kraid, like Ridley is an area that existed in the original Metroid dedicated to confronting one of the game's main bosses. In Kraid, she can access Brinstar as well as Norfair, but the latter can only be reached through sequence breaking from this area.</p><h3>Ridley </h3><p>This area is where Samus faces the second boss of the game, Ridley. The area has a similar environmental breakdown as Norfair. Ridley is a giant, flying fire breathing dragon monster. By defeating Ridley, Samus obtains another unknown item. Along with Kraid, by defeating Ridley Samus opens up one of two paths that are required to be opened to reach the final area of the game, Tourian. </p><h3>Tourian </h3><p>This is the final area of the game, or at least the original game, and is only accessible through Brinstar. The area is very mechanical, but also contains lava. This area also introduces the player to Metroids, biological lifeforms that suck Samus's energy away at the slightest touch. They're also hard to shake off. At the end of Tourian, Samus will face Mother Brain. Mother Brain is somewhat different from the original Metroid in that it actually attacks Samus directly. After defeating Mother Brain, the game's first escape sequence, while similar to the original game takes Samus to Crateria and Samus' Ship, both of which were unseen in the first game. </p><h3>Crateria </h3><p>This new area of Zebes contains Samus' Ship as well as access to Tourian, Brinstar, Norfair and Chozodia. Samus can get the Power Grip early on in the game here. Samus will rarely visit Crateria throughout the game. Crateria is on the surface of Zebes, so it has no hazards outside of enemies. </p><h3>Chozodia and Pirate's Ship</h3><p>While Samus can access this area somewhat early on in the game, it is dominantly the final area of the game, containing the real final boss of the game. Here Samus can access Crateria, which is a short distance away from the other main areas of the game and she can get the Gravity Suit, and in turn unlock the 3 unknown items she has obtained throughout the game. Those items include the Plasma Beam among others. At the end Samus faces Meta Ridley, a giant mechanical version of Ridley. Defeating this boss will trigger the final escape sequence of the game, which forces Samus to hijack a Space Pirate Escape Pod.</p><h2>Other Features and Trivia</h2><ul><li>The game also allows the player to play a copy of the original <a href=\"/metroid/3030-21761\" data-ref-id=\"3030-21761\"> Metroid</a> for NES.</li><li>The game allows the player to view the Gallery, which contains all the wallpapers they've obtained from beating the game in various ways.</li><li>The player can unlock Hard Mode by beating the game on Normal.</li><li>The player can unlock Sound Test by beating the game on Hard once.</li><li>The player can use a Link Cable to link up with Metroid Fusion to unlock the Fusion Gallery.</li><li>By achieving a 100% item collection rate, the final boss will take longer to kill and will deal more damage.</li></ul>", "deck": "A GBA Metroid game and remake of the original Metroid for the NES. It also depicts what happens immediately after the self destruct sequence by Mother Brain.", "aliases": null, "image": {"icon_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/square_avatar/8/82063/2617564-mzm.jpg", "medium_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_medium/8/82063/2617564-mzm.jpg", "tiny_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/square_mini/8/82063/2617564-mzm.jpg", "small_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/8/82063/2617564-mzm.jpg", "thumb_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_avatar/8/82063/2617564-mzm.jpg", "screen_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/screen_medium/8/82063/2617564-mzm.jpg", "super_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_large/8/82063/2617564-mzm.jpg"}, "date_last_updated": "2016-01-13 09:50:35", "expected_release_month": null, "api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/game/3030-17356/", "number_of_user_reviews": 8, "original_release_date": "2004-02-09 00:00:00", "original_game_rating": [{"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/game_rating/3065-6/", "id": 6, "name": "ESRB: E"}, {"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/game_rating/3065-18/", "id": 18, "name": "PEGI: 7+"}], "date_added": "2008-04-01 16:33:22", "platforms": [{"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/platform/3045-4/", "abbreviation": "GBA", "site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/game-boy-advance/3045-4/", "id": 4, "name": "Game Boy Advance"}, {"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/platform/3045-139/", "abbreviation": "WIIU", "site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/wii-u/3045-139/", "id": 139, "name": "Wii U"}], "expected_release_day": null, "expected_release_year": null, "id": 17356, "resource_type": "game", "name": "Metroid: Zero Mission"}, "platform": "GBA", "title": "Metroid Zero Mission"}

[{"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/publisher/3010-7831/", "site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/hitbox-team/3010-7831/", "id": 7831, "name": "Hitbox Team"}, {"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/publisher/3010-367/", "site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/capcom/3010-367/", "id": 367, "name": "Capcom"}], "date_last_updated": "2016-05-25 07:54:04", "expected_release_quarter": null, "first_appearance_people": [{"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/person/3040-129193/", "site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/woodley-nye/3040-129193/", "id": 129193, "name": "Woodley Nye"}, {"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/person/3040-129194/", "site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/matt-bush/3040-129194/", "id": 129194, "name": "Matt Bush"}, {"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/person/3040-129195/", "site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/lexie-dostal/3040-129195/", "id": 129195, "name": "Lexie Dostal"}, {"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/person/3040-24955/", "site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/terence-lee/3040-24955/", "id": 24955, "name": "Terence Lee"}], "description": "<h2>Overview</h2><p>Dustforce is an action-platformer developed by Australian developer <a href=\"/hitbox-team/3010-7831\" data-ref-id=\"3010-7831\">Hitbox Team</a> depicting the adventures of a team of ninja janitors known as Dustforce. Rather than collect coins or destroy enemies, characters dust and sweep the environments, which are full of dirt, leaves, and other debris. Characters are able to double jump, wall run, and perform combos in their quest for clean.</p><p>A demo was released on August 1, 2010 for the <a href=\"/pc/3045-94\" data-ref-id=\"3045-94\">PC</a>. It includes a tutorial, two maps, and a level editor, allowing players to create their own maps.</p><p>On 24 October, 2014 Dustforce DX was released as a free update for the game. This update included 16 new easy levels, remade tutorial, a redesigned hub to smooth the progression and 109 community-made levels.</p><h2>Gameplay</h2><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/9/97921/2108991-dustforce_judgement.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2108991\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"1.3033932135729\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:130.3%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/9/97921/2108991-dustforce_judgement.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2108991\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/9/97921/2108991-dustforce_judgement.png\"/></a></figure><p>The main gameplay in Dustforce consists of navigating <a href=\"/super-meat-boy/3030-25114\" data-ref-id=\"3030-25114\">Super Meat Boy</a>-esque levels while avoiding hazards and cleaning debris off of the environment either by running over a dirty area or using attacks to knock the offending detritus off of wild animals; being covered in garbage has made the animals scared and hostile, and will attack Dustforce members until they are cleaned off.</p><p>Cleaning the level fills up a meter which, when full, lets players use a <a href=\"/full-screen-attack/3015-4886\" data-ref-id=\"3015-4886\">full-screen attack</a> that defeats all of the currently visible enemies. This is generally useful for large clusters of entities that require cleaning, but it resets the mid-air jumps so it be used to cross very wide gaps.</p><p>Upon completion of a stage, the player is given a rank in both Completion and Finesse. Completion measures the percentage of refuse cleaned in a level. Finesse reflects how high of a combo players are able to maintain. If both of these conditions are <a href=\"../../s-rank/92-2962/\" rel=\"nofollow\">S-Ranked</a>, the player is awarded with a key to unlock additional levels. Unfortunately, this means that levels must be perfected before the player can advance beyond a certain point.</p><p>Cleaning all of the debris in the level is usually as simple as working out the most fluid path to hit all of the dirty surfaces. Getting an S-Rank in Finesse means that the player must build up their combo by cleaning things with a less than five-second gap between, otherwise the combo resets to zero. A perfect run involves clearing all of a level's debris and defeating all the enemies while maintaining a single combo.</p><h2>Members of Dustforce</h2><ul><li><b>Dustman</b> (Blue): Wields a broom. The most balanced character.</li><li><b>Dustgirl</b> (Red): Wields a pushbroom. Has the biggest attack range but is the slowest character.</li><li><b>Dustkid</b> (Purple): Dual-wields <a href=\"/pom-poms/3055-1751\" data-ref-id=\"3055-1751\">pom-pom</a> dusters. Fastest and can triple jump but has a very small attack range and her jumps are quite low.</li><li><b>Dustworth</b> (Green): Wields a power vacuum cleaner. Has the highest jump and the furthest glide.</li></ul><h2>Multiplayer</h2><p>The game features a local-only multiplayer component. Up to 8 players containing teams of 4 can play (4v4). One team takes on the role of cleaning a stage as members of the Dustforce while the other team leaves dust everywhere they go and are tasked with making the stage as dirty as possible.</p><h2>Level Editor</h2><figure data-align=\"right\" data-size=\"small\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/6/69612/2436052-dustforce_leveleditor.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2436052\" data-ratio=\"0.57272727272727\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:57.3%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/6/69612/2436052-dustforce_leveleditor.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2436052\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/6/69612/2436052-dustforce_leveleditor.png\"/></a></figure><p>The level editor was released on May 1, 2012 as part of a large update which also brought the game to the Mac. Created levels can be uploaded and shared on Atlas, the official Dustforce level sharing community.</p><h2>Leaderboards</h2><p>There is an in game list of fastest runs for each stage sorted by rank and clear time. A replay of each entry in the list is able to be viewed in game, but only after players have completed the level once.</p><h2>Enemies</h2><figure data-align=\"right\" data-size=\"small\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/6/69612/2435778-airorb_forest.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2435778\" data-ratio=\"0.75\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:75.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/6/69612/2435778-airorb_forest.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2435778\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/6/69612/2435778-airorb_forest.png\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/6/69612/2435778-airorb_forest.png\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>An orb enemy in a Forest level.</figcaption></figure><p>Dustforce has a wide variety of enemies. Enemy type and behavior varies depending on a level's theme, though the 'orb' enemy is common to all.</p><p> </p><h2>Achievements</h2><p>Dustforce has only one <a href=\"/steam-achievements/3015-3280\" data-ref-id=\"3015-3280\">Steam Achievement</a> named \"Double S+\" with no accompanying description. This is obtained by achieving an S rank in Completion and Finesse on all levels.</p><p>It is assumed that this single achievement is only a placeholder and that more achievements are forthcoming.</p><h2>Fastfall (Dustforce OST) by Lifeformed (Terence Lee)</h2><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/9/99201/2122900-2122898-lifeformedjpg.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2122900\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"1\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:100.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/9/99201/2122900-2122898-lifeformedjpg.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2122900\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" {"duration": "0:25:00", "runner": "Hornlitz", "data": {"site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/jumper-two/3030-32957/", "expected_release_quarter": null, "description": "<h2>Story</h2><p><a data-ref-id=\"3005-16993\" href=\"/ogmo/3005-16993\" slug=\"ogmo\">Ogmo</a> was created in 1888 after lab experiments to create the ultimate soldier went wrong. The labs were abandoned during World War 1, but Ogmo escapes the labs only to be recaptured, but Ogmo jumped from the plane to escape once again.</p><h2>Gameplay</h2><p>In Jumper Two there are a total of 60 stages. There are 10 groups of 5 stages each and one group of 10. Each of these groups has a common theme to them. The goal of each level is just to jump the way to the end of the level, with secondary objectives to gather gems for skilled players. In addition to the main game mode there is also a time trial mode where the game will track how quickly each level is finished. The game also features both normal and easy difficulty settings. On the easy difficulty there will be checkpoints in the levels, while on normal mode there are not.</p><p>The different types of jumps you can perform:</p><ul><li><b>Normal Jump</b> - The basic jump that can be done by merely pressing the up key.</li><li><b>Double Jump</b> - This allows Ogmo to jump once already in the air, but only one double jump can be performed before touching the ground or collecting a power up.</li><li><b>Wall Jump</b> - Wall jumps are performed by holding the arrow in the direction of the wall and pressing up. Ogmo will jump off of the wall in the opposite direction. There is no limit to how many of these can be performed before touching ground again.</li><li><b>Skid Jump</b> - The skid jump is performed by running in one direction, then quickly pushing the other direction and jump. This jump will go much higher in the air than a normal jump.</li></ul>", "deck": "Sequel to Jumper. Adds new features and physics such as the wall jump and skid jump. Jumper Two features a new storyline as well as 10 worlds to jump through. Jumper Two also comes with the Jumper Two Editor for creating levels.", "aliases": null, "image": {"icon_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/square_avatar/10/103881/2316028-jumper_two.png", "medium_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_medium/10/103881/2316028-jumper_two.png", "tiny_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/square_mini/10/103881/2316028-jumper_two.png", "small_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/10/103881/2316028-jumper_two.png", "thumb_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_avatar/10/103881/2316028-jumper_two.png", "screen_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/screen_medium/10/103881/2316028-jumper_two.png", "super_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_large/10/103881/2316028-jumper_two.png"}, "date_last_updated": "2012-09-09 14:33:18", "expected_release_month": null, "api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/game/3030-32957/", "number_of_user_reviews": 0, "original_release_date": "2004-06-18 00:00:00", "original_game_rating": null, "date_added": "2010-10-22 18:06:30", "platforms": [{"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/platform/3045-94/", "abbreviation": "PC", "site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/pc/3045-94/", "id": 94, "name": "PC"}], "expected_release_day": null, "expected_release_year": null, "id": 32957, "resource_type": "game", "name": "Jumper Two"}, "platform": "PC", "title": "Jumper Two"}
{"duration": "0:05:00", "runner": "SecksWrecks", "data": {"site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/celeste/3030-53678/", "expected_release_quarter": null, "description": null, "deck": "Hardcore platformer on for the Pico-8", "aliases": null, "image": {"icon_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/square_avatar/8/84915/2849350-8488496843-COewB.jpg", "medium_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_medium/8/84915/2849350-8488496843-COewB.jpg", "tiny_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/square_mini/8/84915/2849350-8488496843-COewB.jpg", "small_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/8/84915/2849350-8488496843-COewB.jpg", "thumb_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_avatar/8/84915/2849350-8488496843-COewB.jpg", "screen_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/screen_medium/8/84915/2849350-8488496843-COewB.jpg", "super_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_large/8/84915/2849350-8488496843-COewB.jpg"}, "date_last_updated": "2016-05-09 18:24:00", "expected_release_month": null, "api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/game/3030-53678/", "number_of_user_reviews": 0, "original_release_date": null, "original_game_rating": null, "date_added": "2016-05-09 18:24:00", "platforms": null, "expected_release_day": null, "expected_release_year": null, "id": 53678, "resource_type": "game", "name": "Celeste"}, "platform": "PC", "title": "Celeste"}
{"duration": "0:15:00", "runner": "ChaosArtisan", "data": {"site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/prompt/3030-52844/", "expected_release_quarter": null, "description": null, "deck": "A minimalistic, hardcore platformer.", "aliases": null, "image": {"icon_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/square_avatar/30/309103/2830463-prompt.jpg", "medium_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_medium/30/309103/2830463-prompt.jpg", "tiny_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/square_mini/30/309103/2830463-prompt.jpg", "small_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/30/309103/2830463-prompt.jpg", "thumb_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_avatar/30/309103/2830463-prompt.jpg", "screen_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/screen_medium/30/309103/2830463-prompt.jpg", "super_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_large/30/309103/2830463-prompt.jpg"}, "date_last_updated": "2016-02-29 17:58:55", "expected_release_month": null, "api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/game/3030-52844/", "number_of_user_reviews": 0, "original_release_date": null, "original_game_rating": null, "date_added": "2016-02-29 17:58:55", "platforms": null, "expected_release_day": null, "expected_release_year": null, "id": 52844, "resource_type": "game", "name": "Prompt"}, "platform": "PC", "title": "Prompt"}
{"duration": "0:20:00", "runner": "Vulajin", "data": {"site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/escape-goat-2/3030-43376/", "expected_release_quarter": null, "description": "<h2>Overview</h2><p>Escape Goat 2 is a puzzle platformer developed by <a href=\"/magical-time-bean/3010-7455\" data-ref-id=\"3010-7455\">Magical Time Bean</a> and published by <a href=\"/double-fine-productions-inc/3010-2215\" data-ref-id=\"3010-2215\">Double Fine</a> for the <a href=\"/pc/3045-94\" data-ref-id=\"3045-94\">PC</a>, <a href=\"/mac/3045-17\" data-ref-id=\"3045-17\">Mac</a>, and <a href=\"/linux/3045-152\" data-ref-id=\"3045-152\">Linux</a> platforms. The player once again assumes the role of a goat trapped in the maze, that uses his natural athleticism and his magical mouse friend to reshape the labyrinth until an exit is revealed. Hitting buttons makes shifting changes to the current stage, and finding the right combination is key to getting past enemies and reaching the exit.</p><p>Escape Goat 2 follows the original <a href=\"/escape-goat/3030-37311\" data-ref-id=\"3030-37311\">Escape Goat</a> as a Steam release. Though the two play similarly, Escape Goat 2 has a distinctive hand-drawn style instead of the original's pixel art look and contains a more elaborate story, as well as multiple branching regions to explore and a new magic hat system. Escape Goat 2 also saw a PS4 \"<a href=\"/platform-exclusive/3015-5670\" data-ref-id=\"3015-5670\">console exclusive</a>\" release.</p>", "deck": "A hand-drawn, puzzle platformer about a goat imprisoned for witchcraft.", "aliases": null, "image": {"icon_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/square_avatar/0/1992/2521860-screen+shot+2013-07-29+at+8.09.59+pm.png", "medium_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_medium/0/1992/2521860-screen+shot+2013-07-29+at+8.09.59+pm.png", "tiny_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_avatar/0/1992/2521860-screen+shot+2013-07-29+at+8.09.59+pm.png", "screen_url": "api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/game/3030-43376/", "number_of_user_reviews": 0, "original_release_date": "2014-03-24 00:00:00", "original_game_rating": null, "date_added": "2013-07-29 16:58:29", "platforms": [{"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/platform/3045-17/", "abbreviation": "MAC", "site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/mac/3045-17/", "id": 17, "name": {"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/platform/3045-146/", "abbreviation": "PS4", "site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/playstation-4/3045-146/", "id": 146, "name": "PlayStation 4"}, {"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/platform/3045-152/", "abbreviation": "LIN", "site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/linux/3045-152/", "id": 152, "name": "Linux"}],
