Its effectiveness isn't especially great, however, though it may prove useful against crowds due to the charge passing through all within close vicinity.</p><ul><li>Maximum Ammo Count - 100%, with each charge representing 2%.</li><li>Ammunition - N/A.</li></ul><h3>Flamethrower</h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-size=\"small\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/5322/464685-re2flamethrower_lg.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-464685\" data-ratio=\"0.625\" data-width=\"200\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 200px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:62.5%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/5322/464685-re2flamethrower_lg.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-464685\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"/uploads/scale_small/0/5322/464685-re2flamethrower_lg.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"/uploads/scale_small/0/5322/464685-re2flamethrower_lg.jpg\"/></noscript></a></figure><p>A weapon of limited use, the flamethrower is exclusive to Leon and takes up two inventory slots. Its ammo is also represented by percentage. Its primary use is against the mutant plants the player will encounter amidst the Umbrella Lab, as they are extremely resistant against most other forms of damage. However beyond that it is weak and deals little damage -- its fuel also rapidly runs out, and like other two slot weapons has no additional ammo to spare.</p><ul><li>Maximum Ammo Count - 100%, with each second of flame output representing 1%.</li><li>Ammunition - N/A.</li></ul><h3>Gatling Gun</h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-size=\"small\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/10354/2633823-re2_3gatling_lg.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2633823\" data-ratio=\"0.69\" data-width=\"200\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 200px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:69.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/10354/2633823-re2_3gatling_lg.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2633823\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"/uploads/scale_small/1/10354/2633823-re2_3gatling_lg.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"/uploads/scale_small/1/10354/2633823-re2_3gatling_lg.jpg\"/></noscript></a></figure><p>A secret weapon that is only used by unlocking it with infinite ammo. It requires players to complete each set of a Scenario A &amp; B with at least an A rank, and will then reside within the Scenario A's item box as well the Scenario B's whence Scenario A has been completed again. Though while it has a bit of a build up, it can rip through everything with enough time.</p><ul><li>Maximum Ammo Count - Infinite.</li><li>Ammunition - N/A.</li></ul><h3>Rocket Launcher</h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-size=\"small\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/5322/464634-re2rocketlauncher_lg.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-464634\" data-ratio=\"0.65\" data-width=\"200\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 200px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:65.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/5322/464634-re2rocketlauncher_lg.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-464634\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"/uploads/scale_small/0/5322/464634-re2rocketlauncher_lg.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"/uploads/scale_small/0/5322/464634-re2rocketlauncher_lg.jpg\"/></noscript></a></figure><p>Within a narrative-context the rocket launcher is used to destroy the mutated T-103 tyrant during Scenario B, though like the gatling gun can be unlocked with infinite ammo under the same requirements. It can kill nearly every enemy and boss in the game besides William Birkin in his canine form and his shapeless blob form.</p><ul><li>Maximum Ammo Count - 2</li><li>Ammunition - N/A</li></ul><h2>Enemies</h2><h3>Zombies</h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-size=\"small\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/10354/2633825-re2-zombies.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2633825\" data-ratio=\"1.3559322033898\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:135.6%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/10354/2633825-re2-zombies.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2633825\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"/uploads/scale_small/1/10354/2633825-re2-zombies.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"/uploads/scale_small/1/10354/2633825-re2-zombies.jpg\"/></noscript></a></figure><p>Like the original, zombies function as the most common enemy encountered throughout Resident Evil 2. Though they have a more varied set of animations, and there is a greater variety of models now too -- which includes the series' debut of female zombies.</p><p>Slow and sluggish in movement, but dangerous up close, zombies are durable enough against gunfire that they can prove to be extremely dangerous even just in small numbers. When encountered on their own, however, zombies can be dispatched relatively easy so long as the player has enough ammunition to spare. As per usual, zombies are best dealt with the pistol or sometimes the shotgun, which can kill a zombie with a single shot if the player aims directly at its head once close enough, or can at least reduce the zombie to a literal crawl by destroying its legs.</p><p>Zombies attack by grabbing and biting the player when close, but will also puke out acid instead if they can't quite reach the player. Some zombies will be encountered lying on the ground, seemingly pretending to be dead, and will grab at a character's leg should the player get close enough. However, the leg bite does little damage and will always result in the character killing the zombie with a single stomp or kick. Zombies also have a slight chance of splitting in two after being shot with a shotgun. Their torso will collapse onto the ground and will then proceed to crawl towards the player, though if the player leaves the area the torso will be gone the next time the player returns.</p><h3>Zombie Dogs</h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-size=\"small\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/10354/2633826-re2-dog.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2633826\" data-ratio=\"1.0909090909091\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:109.1%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/10354/2633826-re2-dog.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2633826\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"/uploads/scale_small/1/10354/2633826-re2-dog.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"/uploads/scale_small/1/10354/2633826-re2-dog.jpg\"/></noscript></a></figure><p>Returning from the original game are zombie hounds, only these are of accidental infection and aren't the specifically designed Cerberus B.O.W.s. Though they otherwise function very much the same, and are likewise always encountered in packs. They contain the same agility and brutality as a standard dog, though are easy to stunlock as any shot from even a pistol will knock them off balance; continued shots will be able to keep them locked to the ground until death.</p><h3>Crows</h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-size=\"small\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/10354/2633827-2209272-enemies_crow.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2633827\" data-ratio=\"1.3333333333333\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:133.3%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/10354/2633827-2209272-enemies_crow.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2633827\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"/uploads/scale_small/1/10354/2633827-2209272-enemies_crow.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"/uploads/scale_small/1/10354/2633827-2209272-enemies_crow.jpg\"/></noscript></a></figure><p>Much like most Resident Evil iterations, Crows only act as more of a nuisance than a genuine threat. They are always found to be in a large number, however, and can be very hard to avoid.</p><p>They only have one attack by way of pecking at the player, which while does little damage will keep the player stuck in a short animation of trying to wave them off.</p><h3>Licker</h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-size=\"small\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/10354/2632846-20110929164051%21licker0.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2632846\" data-ratio=\"1.1428571428571\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:114.3%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/10354/2632846-20110929164051%21licker0.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2632846\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"/uploads/scale_small/1/10354/2632846-20110929164051%21licker0.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"/uploads/scale_small/1/10354/2632846-20110929164051%21licker0.jpg\"/></noscript></a></figure><p>An advanced mutation of zombies, mostly recognizable for their long tongue and claws. Lickers are extremely agile and fast, have an attack that can commit an instant-kill against the player, and can withstand more damage than the typical zombie. Lickers also have the added advantage of being able to climb up and rest upon flat surfaces, including ceilings. However they often tend to make a breathy growl of sorts, that along with the squishy noise of their movements makes them easy to pick up should one be close by.</p><p>A licker usually takes between 2-3 shotgun or crossbow attacks to kill one. Though because of their lack of sight, players can potentially avoid encounters with one should they walk past rather than run. However if a player gets close enough, a Licker will always catch on to their presence and give chase regardless of their movement speed. While they can sometimes be encountered alone, they will more often than not be found in groups of at least two.</p><p>Their attacks often involve their claws; they will swipe the player's leg when close, and when encountered at a distance will give off a loud shriek and then leap through the air in an attempt to maul the player. They will alternatively strike with their tongue and attempt to strangle the player; if the player's health is in the Caution state, there's a high chance the Licker will rip off the player's head completely.</p><h3>Evolved Licker</h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-size=\"small\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/10354/2633832-dsc_enemies-7.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2633832\" data-ratio=\"0.78412698412698\" data-width=\"315\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 315px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:78.4%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/10354/2633832-dsc_enemies-7.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2633832\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"/uploads/scale_small/1/10354/2633832-dsc_enemies-7.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"/uploads/scale_small/1/10354/2633832-dsc_enemies-7.jpg\"/></noscript></a></figure><p>This is a tougher variant of the Licker that'll be encountered later in the game. They are of a noticeably different shade of color from the regular red Lickers, with a more murky green color to them. They utilize the same attacks as a regular Licker, however they will deal--and can withstand--more damage.</p><h3>Web Spinners</h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-size=\"small\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/10354/2633830-spider.gif\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2633830\" data-ratio=\"0.55301455301455\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:55.3%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/10354/2633830-spider.gif\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2633830\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"/uploads/scale_small/1/10354/2633830-spider.gif\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"/uploads/scale_small/1/10354/2633830-spider.gif\"/></noscript></a></figure><p>Much like zombie hounds, these are to be found in nearly every Resident Evil game to date. They are primarily just spiders, though they all also have the ability to poison the player with a gush of poison spit.</p><p>Ordinarily should a giant spider die with its sack still intact, hundreds of miniature spiders would begin to seep out and attack the player. However for whatever reason this is not the case in Resident Evil 2.</p><h3>Plant 43</h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-size=\"small\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/10354/2633835-re2_plant43_art.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2633835\" data-ratio=\"1.3333333333333\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:133.3%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/10354/2633835-re2_plant43_art.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2633835\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"/uploads/scale_small/1/10354/2633835-re2_plant43_art.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"/uploads/scale_small/1/10354/2633835-re2_plant43_art.jpg\"/></noscript></a></figure><p>A smaller, smarter iteration off of Plant 42 from the original Resident Evil. Though while significantly smaller in size, they are still quite resistant to most forms of damage. However they are terribly weak against fire. They primarily attack by spewing a gob of acid at the player from their gaping mouth, though they especially dangerous up close as they will grapple and trap the player with their vines while pouring their acid all over them.</p><p>There is another variant of the creature that's acid will also poison the player should it hit. They are otherwise the same, and are visually distinctive by their 'head' being of a red color as opposed to green.</p><h3>Giant Moth</h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-size=\"small\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/10354/2633838-giant_moth.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2633838\" data-ratio=\"1.4157650695518\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:141.6%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/10354/2633838-giant_moth.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2633838\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"/uploads/scale_small/1/10354/2633838-giant_moth.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"/uploads/scale_small/1/10354/2633838-giant_moth.jpg\"/></noscript></a></figure><p>While there is only one to be found in the game, the giant moth isn't technically a boss battle. It is encountered within an Umbrella lab and has grown itself a nest. It attacks the player by charging towards them, or spitting poison. While it still has its wings, it is not strong enough to fly very efficiently and can only hover. It is nonetheless quite sturdy and requires around 4 shots from an upgraded desert eagle magnum to down.</p><p>It's also worth noting that it is completely optional to fight, and is only necessary should players desire to register their handprint to access the locked laboratory door.</p><h2>Boss Battles</h2><h3>G</h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-size=\"small\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/10354/2633899-gvirus_mutation.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2633899\" data-ratio=\"0.98901098901099\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:98.9%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/10354/2633899-gvirus_mutation.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2633899\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"/uploads/scale_small/1/10354/2633899-gvirus_mutation.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"/uploads/scale_small/1/10354/2633899-gvirus_mutation.jpg\"/></noscript></a></figure><p>The first boss encountered in Scenario A, G was once a small parasitic larvae that was implanted by the mutated William Birkin into either Ben Bertolucci or Brian Irons, depending on which character's story it is. After an allotted time, however, it grows into a much larger, more humanoid creature.</p><p>It is slow in speed, so its primary source of attack is to vomit out several small larvae to then seek out the player and attempt to force themselves down their throat. Otherwise it can punch the character when close enough, but the primary tactic is to keep a good distance and keep shooting at it, while also trying to shoot any of the swarming larvae on the ground. After enough damage it will ultimately disintegrate.</p><h3>Giant Alligator</h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-size=\"small\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/10354/2633849-re2_alligator.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2633849\" data-ratio=\"0.63821138211382\" data-width=\"246\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 246px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:63.8%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/10354/2633849-re2_alligator.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2633849\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"/uploads/scale_small/1/10354/2633849-re2_alligator.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"/uploads/scale_small/1/10354/2633849-re2_alligator.jpg\"/></noscript></a></figure><p>This aptly titled boss is encountered in the sewers. It will surprise attack the player from beneath the sewage water and slowly makes its way through the tunnel; its size means it is impossible to run past it. There are two methods to killing it: first is the basic path of simply unloading whatever the player has into the creature; alternatively the player could drop the gas canister that resides within the middle of the tunnel, and then shoot it once the alligator picks it up with its mouth killing it instantly. If players choose to kill it the old fashioned way, there will be a small stash of ammunition awaiting them next to the tram later in the game.</p><p>The alligator will always be fought in Scenario A, however if it is killed via the gas canister it will stay dead for the alternate character's Scenario B. Otherwise it must be fought again in much the same way, complete with the gas canister still available; it will also visually be shown wounded to account for the previous battle.</p><h3>T-103 'Mr. X'</h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-size=\"small\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/10354/2625818-20100430232542%21tyrant_t-103.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2625818\" data-ratio=\"2\" data-width=\"300\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 300px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:200.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/10354/2625818-20100430232542%21tyrant_t-103.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2625818\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"/uploads/scale_small/1/10354/2625818-20100430232542%21tyrant_t-103.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"/uploads/scale_small/1/10354/2625818-20100430232542%21tyrant_t-103.jpg\"/></noscript></a></figure><p>A mass-produced successor to the T-102 from Resident Evil, the T-103 is only encountered during Scenario B. It is encountered multiple times throughout at scripted moments in the story, often bursting through walls or ambushing from around a corner. A clear way to note if it is about to arrive is if the theme music for the area has stopped.</p><p>It is usually designed to block the player from progressing, forcing them to kill it before it reaches them. Though it will always walk, and when attacked with a powerful enough weapon such as a shotgun will slow down even further. If it gets close its attacks will do a noticeable amount of damage and can potentially kill the player with only about 4 attacks. It will only use its fists to attack, usually using a hook punch to knock the player back as a method of again forcing players to fight it. Though it will also sometimes do an overhead smash with both hands clasped together -- its most powerful attack.</p><p>After enough damage has been dealt it will begin to slightly sway before toppling to the floor. Searching its body afterwards will gift the player some ammunition.</p><h3>T-103 Mutated Form</h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-size=\"small\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/10354/2633856-re2-super-tyrant.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2633856\" data-ratio=\"1.3333333333333\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:133.3%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/10354/2633856-re2-super-tyrant.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2633856\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"/uploads/scale_small/1/10354/2633856-re2-super-tyrant.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"/uploads/scale_small/1/10354/2633856-re2-super-tyrant.jpg\"/></noscript></a></figure><p>Upon inadvertently falling into a vat of molten liquid, the tyrant will re-emerge now mutated and of a completely different boss design. It is only fought once nearing the end, again only during Scenario B, shortly after the player is powering up the escape train. Its trademark jacket has now completely burnt away, revealing a growth in mass, as has its hands formed into large claws.</p><p>It is now considerably faster and will frequently rush and slash at the player. Its attacks are thusly difficult to avoid, likely forcing most players to simply brute force their way through the fight and hope they have enough healing supplies. Upon enough damage, from around 4-5 upgraded magnum shots for reference, a silhouette of Ada Wong will arrive to drop the player--as either Leon or Claire--a rocket launcher.</p><p>The player must then quickly rush and equip it, and then fire at the tyrant -- one shot is all it will take to destroy it.</p><h3>William Birkin First Form</h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-size=\"small\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/10354/2633859-willbirkinfirstform.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2633859\" data-ratio=\"1.3333333333333\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:133.3%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/10354/2633859-willbirkinfirstform.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2633859\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"/uploads/scale_small/1/10354/2633859-willbirkinfirstform.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"/uploads/scale_small/1/10354/2633859-willbirkinfirstform.jpg\"/></noscript></a></figure><p>Upon injecting himself with the G-virus, William Birkin has now transformed into a horrible monstrosity -- one that grows more hideous as the game progresses. Similar to the T-103 he is thusly fought multiple times throughout the game, though each time is a different form, and unlike the T-103 is fought across both Scenarios. Though his first is only fought during Scenario B, in place of where players faced 'G' in Scenario A.</p><p>His first form is his most comparatively mundane, as he still retains many of his human physical qualities. Though he still has access to incredible strength, and will pull off a nearby pipe which will govern his attacks. He is slow moving, similar to G, and will primarily swing the pipe around randomly -- any attack that hits does a significant amount of damage, however. Similar to G, the primary strategy is to keep at a distance and fire whatever the player has. He can withstand a fair amount of damage, roughly taking about eight grenade rounds. Once enough damage has been inflicted, the boss theme will cut off and he will then seemingly accidentally fall over the edge into the sewers below.</p><h3>William Birkin Second Form</h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-size=\"small\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/10354/2633860-re2-g2.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2633860\" data-ratio=\"1.4363636363636\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:143.6%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/10354/2633860-re2-g2.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2633860\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"/uploads/scale_small/1/10354/2633860-re2-g2.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"/uploads/scale_small/1/10354/2633860-re2-g2.jpg\"/></noscript></a></figure><p>This form is the point where Birkin now literally begins to shed his human qualities in favor of something more monstrous, and is the first William boss for Scenario A. After discarding his pipe, his right arm has grown into an enormous claw, now making him somewhat resemble a tyrant.</p><p>The battleground is set on a tram platform descending down into Umbrella's underground laboratory. Birkin still only walks, but the arena is of a U shape, with the possibility of the player finding themselves at a dead end. Though area is also wide enough that players should be able to potentially rush past.</p><p>Birkin of course now attacks with his claw, which has a slightly greater reach than the pipe but roughly does the same amount of damage. He will also take about the same amount of damage to down as before, so as long as players again keep their distance he will eventually begin bleeding and ultimately slump to the floor after receiving enough damage.</p><h3>William Birkin Third Form</h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-size=\"small\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/10354/2633862-re2-g3.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2633862\" data-ratio=\"1.2923076923077\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:129.2%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/10354/2633862-re2-g3.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2633862\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"/uploads/scale_small/1/10354/2633862-re2-g3.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"/uploads/scale_small/1/10354/2633862-re2-g3.jpg\"/></noscript></a></figure><p>At this point William now resembles something more demonic than human, and has access to two equally large claws protruding from his shoulders along with what is now another pair of claws that were once his hands. This form is fought in the B Scenario on the same tram platform as his previous form was fought.</p><p>He still only walks but each step will now cover more distance, allowing him to more quickly catch up to the player. His attacks also now have a much larger reach than before, and he will periodically enter a stance with all four of his claws raised up. If attacked amidst this stance he will unleash a powerful combo with all four claws and can potentially kill the player outright with this attack. If he isn't able to strike the player with this attack, after so long he will revert back to his default stance</p><p>This form is naturally tougher than the last and can withstand even more damage. Though this time when the battle is over Birkin will leap away onto the wall rather than pass out.</p><h3>William Birkin Fourth Form</h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-size=\"small\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/10354/2633863-re2-g4.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2633863\" data-ratio=\"0.78666666666667\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:78.7%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/10354/2633863-re2-g4.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2633863\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"/uploads/scale_small/1/10354/2633863-re2-g4.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"/uploads/scale_small/1/10354/2633863-re2-g4.jpg\"/></noscript></a></figure><p>The final boss of Scenario A, Birkin has how transformed into some sort of monstrous canine. His shoulder claws have morphed into his front legs, and he has grown considerably in mass with a large maw for a mouth.</p><p>Now running on four 'legs', this form is his fastest by a great deal, and he will commonly rush at the player and grab them with its maw and shake the player around like a ragdoll. It won't kill the player outright but still does a high amount of damage.</p><p>The arena offers two tall series of tubes, to which Birkin will occasionally jump onto, potentially allowing players some temporary safety and to get in some extra shots. Though it will eventually jump off and may also attack the player simultaneously.</p><p>In traditional Resident Evil fashion, there is a 5 minute timer ticking down during the battle.</p><h3>William Birkin Final Form</h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-size=\"small\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/10354/2633864-william_birkin_%28g5%29.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2633864\" data-ratio=\"0.64375\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:64.4%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/10354/2633864-william_birkin_%28g5%29.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2633864\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"/uploads/scale_small/1/10354/2633864-william_birkin_%28g5%29.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"/uploads/scale_small/1/10354/2633864-william_birkin_%28g5%29.jpg\"/></noscript></a></figure><p>The final boss of Scenario B, William has ultimately become an amorphous blob of a creature, made up of a variety of eyes, teeth, claws, and assimilated corpses all over. Probably the simplest boss in the game, it exists more for spectacle than to serve as a challenge. Set on the cargo cart of the escape train, the player is trapped between a locked door and the slowly slithering horror that is now William Birkin.</p><p>The player is simply tasking with unloading whatever they have into it from their position. At this point players should have access to a single shot left for their rocket launcher which, while it won't kill Birkin, will deal a fair bit of damage. After so much punishment Birkin begins to decompose, while the door conveniently unlocks behind the player allowing them to escape. Upon opening the door the game will end, switching to a CG cutscene showcasing Birkin's ultimate demise due to the self-destruction of the train -- after the characters themselves have escaped.</p><h2>Unlockables</h2><p>Like most Resident Evil games, Resident Evil 2 is packed with unlockable content to help supply replay value and prolong the game's lifespan.</p><h3>Ranking &amp; Unlockable Weapons</h3><figure data-align=\"left\" data-size=\"small\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/10354/2633818-leon_cocking_his_desert_eagle.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2633818\" data-ratio=\"0.692\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:69.2%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/10354/2633818-leon_cocking_his_desert_eagle.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2633818\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"/uploads/scale_small/1/10354/2633818-leon_cocking_his_desert_eagle.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"/uploads/scale_small/1/10354/2633818-leon_cocking_his_desert_eagle.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Art from Leon's results screen</figcaption></figure><p>There is a ranking system dependent on how players finish the game. Ranks are determined by how fast the player finished the game, how many first aid sprays are used, and how often the player saved. The ranks range from D to S, with S being the best.</p><p>To attain an S rank the player must complete the game under 2 hours, without using any first aid sprays and only saving once. Upon achieving an S rank, or even A rank, for both scenarios, the player will be rewarded with a submachine gun, a gatling gun, and a rocket launcher, all with infinite ammo, but only for the completed scenario pair. They will be awaiting in the item box should the player decide to play through the completed scenarios once more.</p><h3>Costumes</h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-size=\"small\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/10354/2633624-867950c7a852.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2633624\" data-ratio=\"0.75\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:75.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/10354/2633624-867950c7a852.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2633624\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"/uploads/scale_small/1/10354/2633624-867950c7a852.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"/uploads/scale_small/1/10354/2633624-867950c7a852.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>One of Leon's alternate costumes.</figcaption></figure><p>S.T.A.R.S. Alpha team pilot <a href=\"/brad-vickers/3005-3135\" data-ref-id=\"3005-3135\">Brad Vickers</a> is killed by the B.O.W. monster <a href=\"/nemesis/3005-3189\" data-ref-id=\"3005-3189\">Nemesis </a>during Resident Evil 3. However because it is initially set before the events of Resident Evil 2, Brad is thusly given time to return in zombie form for Resident Evil 2.</p><p>To locate him, players must head from the beginning of Scenario A to the Police Station without collecting any items -- not even the shotgun/bowgun that drops from Robert Kendo. Upon successfully reaching the station, the Brad Vickers zombie will be wandering below in the underpass. He can withstand more punishment than a regular zombie, though an upward shot to the head with the shotgun will still kill him instantly as like any other. Whence killed, his corpse will yield a key that will unlock a locker in the station's darkroom. In it are costumes for Leon and Claire.</p><figure data-align=\"right\" data-size=\"small\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/10354/2633625-tumblr_lcmsptrh381qe1li6o1_1280.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2633625\" data-ratio=\"0.75\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:75.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/10354/2633625-tumblr_lcmsptrh381qe1li6o1_1280.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2633625\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"/uploads/scale_small/1/10354/2633625-tumblr_lcmsptrh381qe1li6o1_1280.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"/uploads/scale_small/1/10354/2633625-tumblr_lcmsptrh381qe1li6o1_1280.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Claire wearing her alternate biker outfit</figcaption></figure><p>Leon unlocks two different outfits, whereas Claire only unlocks one. However Claire is instead gifted a six-shot revolver exclusive to her, to tie in with the cowgirl theme of her alternate costume. Leon, while he doesn't obtain a new weapon, will now wield handguns sideways with one hand; this stance then gives Leon increased firing speed with handguns, though can be only be used while wearing one of the alternate costumes. Should players modify Leon's H&amp;K handgun, however, he will lose the stance in favor of the burst-fire.</p><p>The N64 version has one additional exclusive costume per character.</p><p>If players manage to trigger the appearance of zombie Brad in Scenario A, he will then show up once again in the same location in the alternate character's Scenario B without any other prerequisites.</p><h3>The 4th Survivor</h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-size=\"small\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/10354/2633629-the_4th_survivor.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2633629\" data-ratio=\"0.5625\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:56.3%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/10354/2633629-the_4th_survivor.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2633629\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"/uploads/scale_small/1/10354/2633629-the_4th_survivor.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"/uploads/scale_small/1/10354/2633629-the_4th_survivor.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>4th Survivor title screen</figcaption></figure><p>A small side-story starring <a href=\"/umbrella-security-service/3015-7100\" data-ref-id=\"3015-7100\">U.S.S.</a> agent <a href=\"/hunk/3005-3859\" data-ref-id=\"3005-3859\">H.U.N.K.</a>, after he was able to escape the clutches of the mutated William Birkin, can be unlocked via attaining at least a rank A for either set of an A &amp; B scenario.</p><p>Beginning at the entrance to the station's sewers, it tasks players as H.U.N.K. to make it to the RPD helipad for extraction. However H.U.N.K.s supplies are limited, and no more can be found amidst the story. Furthermore, all of the enemies from the main game make an appearance, including two appearances of the Mr. X tyrant.</p><p>H.U.N.K.s inventory is as such:</p><ul><li>H&amp;K Pistol.</li><li>150 spare 9mm bullets.</li><li>Remington Shotgun.</li><li>15 spare shells.</li><li>Desert Eagle Magnum.</li><li>8 spare magnum bullets.</li><li>Mixed herb made up of a single green &amp; blue</li><li>Mixed herb made up of a single green &amp; blue.</li><li>And in his unique inventory slot is the G-Virus vial he successfully stole from William Birkin.</li></ul><p>As such, players are to choose wisely as to what to use against what enemies, as there are many more enemies in the player's path than they have bullets. Upon reaching the helipad it shows H.U.N.K. signalling for his escape chopper and flying away. In all ports from the Dualshock version onward, a timer will tick up showing how long it took the player to finish.</p><p>The mini-story's title is somewhat inconsistent with the amount of characters whom actually survive, with Leon, Claire, Sherry, and Ada also eventually being revealed to have escaped making H.U.N.K. the technically 5th survivor of Resident Evil 2.</p><h3>The Tofu Survivor</h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-size=\"small\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/10354/2633631-tofu_inicio1.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2633631\" data-ratio=\"0.75\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:75.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/10354/2633631-tofu_inicio1.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2633631\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"/uploads/scale_small/1/10354/2633631-tofu_inicio1.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"/uploads/scale_small/1/10354/2633631-tofu_inicio1.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Tofu Survivor title screen; Tofu is unfortunately not shown to wear Jill's beret in-game</figcaption></figure><p>A parody of The 4th Survivor minigame, Tofu Survivor plays near identical, only instead of controlling H.U.N.K. players instead take control of a sentient piece of Japanese <a href=\"/tofu/3005-4061\" data-ref-id=\"3005-4061\">tofu</a>. This mode is unlocked upon attaining at least an A rank for all four scenarios.</p><p>The objective is the exact same as The 4th Survivor, as is the enemy placements, however the character of Tofu only but has a combat knife to defend itself with. It does also have some additional herbs, however, and it is noticeably sturdier than the other characters in the game. Nonetheless, The Tofu Survivor is arguably the toughest minigame in the main Resident Evil series.</p><p>Because of the lack of reliable weaponry on hand, players are to instead attempt to avoid most encounters, using such tactics as the fan-coined ''wall hug'' of running diagonally into a wall to attempt to pass enemies. Completing the minigame yields the same ending as The 4th Survivor, and this too features a timer to help clock how long it took players to complete from the Dualshock version onward.</p><p>The mode itself originated as a joke by the developers, after they would use the Tofu character model to help in designing collision detection.</p><h3>Extreme Battle</h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-size=\"small\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/10354/2633644-extreme_battle.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2633644\" data-ratio=\"0.75\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:75.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/10354/2633644-extreme_battle.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2633644\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"/uploads/scale_small/1/10354/2633644-extreme_battle.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"/uploads/scale_small/1/10354/2633644-extreme_battle.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Extreme Battle title screen</figcaption></figure><p>The third and final minigame of Resident Evil 2, Extreme Battle is something more of a score-focussed mode, complete with multiple characters and difficulty levels -- 3 in total. It is unlocked upon completing either set of A &amp; B scenarios. It is only available in certain ports of Resident Evil 2, however.</p><p>Players are tasked in trying to locate four ''anti-virus bombs'' within the Raccoon Police Station--the specific locations of the bombs are randomized--though they first begin at Umbrella's laboratory near the end of the story. Players are to choose from four different characters to determine their equipment, although only two are available at the outset; the other two must be unlocked by climbing up the difficulty levels. Unlike the previous modes, players can locate more supplies amidst their travels and can even save their progress with an ink ribbon &amp; typewriter like in the main game.</p><p>There are leaderboards available that'll track how long it took for the player to complete which level, and with which character. However players can only strive to beat the pre-entered scores or their own, as there is no online functionality across any of the ports.</p><h4>Characters</h4><figure data-align=\"right\" data-size=\"small\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/10354/2633636-extreme_battle_leon.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2633636\" data-ratio=\"0.75\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:75.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/10354/2633636-extreme_battle_leon.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2633636\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"/uploads/scale_small/1/10354/2633636-extreme_battle_leon.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"/uploads/scale_small/1/10354/2633636-extreme_battle_leon.jpg\"/></noscript></a></figure><p><strong>Leon S. Kennedy</strong></p><ul><li>H&amp;K Pistol</li><li>Remington Shotgun</li><li>Desert Eagle Magnum</li><li>Ink Ribbon</li><li>First Aid Spray</li><li>Blue Herb</li></ul><p> </p><p><strong>Claire Redfield</strong></p><figure data-align=\"right\" data-size=\"small\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/10354/2633637-extreme_battle_claire.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2633637\" data-ratio=\"0.75\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:75.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/10354/2633637-extreme_battle_claire.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2633637\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"/uploads/scale_small/1/10354/2633637-extreme_battle_claire.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"/uploads/scale_small/1/10354/2633637-extreme_battle_claire.jpg\"/></noscript></a></figure><ul><li>Grenade Launcher</li><li>Flame Rounds</li><li>Acid Rounds</li><li>Ink Ribbon</li><li>First Aid Spray</li><li>Blue Herb</li></ul><p> </p><p><strong>Ada Wong</strong></p><figure data-align=\"right\" data-size=\"small\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/10354/2633638-extreme_battle_ada+%281%29.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2633638\" data-ratio=\"0.75\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:75.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/10354/2633638-extreme_battle_ada+%281%29.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2633638\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"/uploads/scale_small/1/10354/2633638-extreme_battle_ada+%281%29.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"/uploads/scale_small/1/10354/2633638-extreme_battle_ada+%281%29.jpg\"/></noscript></a></figure><p>Is unlocked upon completing Level 1.</p><ul><li>Colt Pistol</li><li>Submachine gun</li><li>Bow Gun</li><li>Ink Ribbon</li><li>Mixed herb, made up of a green, red, and blue.</li></ul><p> </p><p><strong>Chris Redfield</strong></p><figure data-align=\"right\" data-size=\"small\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/10354/2633639-extreme_battle_chris.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2633639\" data-ratio=\"0.75\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:75.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/10354/2633639-extreme_battle_chris.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2633639\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"/uploads/scale_small/1/10354/2633639-extreme_battle_chris.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"/uploads/scale_small/1/10354/2633639-extreme_battle_chris.jpg\"/></noscript></a></figure><p>The original hero from Resident Evil, Chris is unlocked upon completing Level 2. His STARS beretta pistol is exclusive to him and has a chance to pop a zombie's head similar to the magnum. Because of Chris' experience, he can handle the recoil of the upgraded shotgun more so than Leon, giving it less kickback. The sound effects related to Chris receiving damage are recycled from the original Resident Evil.</p><ul><li>Beretta Pistol</li><li>Remington Shotgun (Upgraded Version)</li><li>Rocket Launcher</li><li>Ink Ribbon</li><li>First Aid Spray</li></ul><h4>Levels</h4><p>Each of the three levels gets progressively harder from one to the next, by introducing new enemies (including William Birkin in his canine form) and remixing old enemy placements, to decreasing the amount of available supplies to collect out in the world.</p><h2>Version Differences</h2><h3>Resident Evil 2 (<a href=\"/playstation/3045-22\" data-ref-id=\"3045-22\">Sony PlayStation</a>)</h3><p>The original version of Resident Evil 2 released on January 21, 1998 in North America. One week later, Biohazard 2 would be released in Japan. The content was spread across two discs and featured considerable improvements to the mechanics and graphics from the preceding <a href=\"/resident-evil/3030-5842\" data-ref-id=\"3030-5842\">Resident Evil</a> (see \"Gameplay\" section above).</p><p>Supposedly, the Japanese release was considerably easier than its North American counterpart, featuring different item placement, better firepower and auto-aim enabled by default. Additionally, the Japanese version did not include scenes of player characters being eaten by zombies after death and gore was diminished along with some violent depictions.</p><h3>Resident Evil 2: DualShock Version (Sony PlayStation)</h3><p>Virtually the same as the original PlayStation version, but with added functionality to accept the <a href=\"/dualshock-controller/3000-1\" data-ref-id=\"3000-1\">DualShock Controller</a> released after the game's original release date. The game featured vibration functions and analog controls. This release also saw the addition of Extreme Battle, an unlockable mini game where the player needs to reach the police station and find four anti-biohazard bombs. Also, a cheat code for unlimited ammo was added.</p><p>The Japanese DualShock version featured a \"USA Version\" mode, bringing the difficulty up to par with its overseas counterpart; this release also had feature parity with the North American version and sported the same add-ons and DualShock-only functions. The violence scenarios and gore, however, still remained censored, edited or omitted.</p><p>In 2009, the DualShock Version was released on the <a href=\"/playstation-network-ps3/3045-88\" data-ref-id=\"3045-88\">PlayStation Store</a> at a $5.99 price point and is compatible with both the PlayStation 3 and PSP.</p><h3>Resident Evil 2 Platinum (Windows '98 <a href=\"/pc/3045-94\" data-ref-id=\"3045-94\">PC</a>)</h3><p>Contained the same content as the PlayStation releases, except the Dualshock Version's mini games were unlocked from the start. The game was spread across two CD-ROMs.</p><h3>Resident Evil 2 (<a href=\"/nintendo-64/3045-43\" data-ref-id=\"3045-43\">Nintendo 64</a>)</h3><p>After commercial success on the PlayStation, Capcom commissioned <a href=\"/angel-studios/3010-1195\" data-ref-id=\"3010-1195\">Angel Studios</a> (later renamed to <a href=\"/rockstar-san-diego/3010-3339\" data-ref-id=\"3010-3339\">Rockstar San Diego</a>) to create an Nintendo 64 port. The PlayStation original, however, had over 700MB of data spread across its two discs and the highest capacity for a Nintendo 64 cartridge was a comparatively tiny 64MB (512 Mbit). Despite the software media limitations, the N64 port was comparable to the PlayStation version with the omission of the DualShock Version's Extreme Battle mini game. This version also added additional documents called EX files, which referenced numerous plot details and <a href=\"/resident-evil-zero/3030-10247\" data-ref-id=\"3030-10247\">Resident Evil Zero</a>, which at that time was still in development for the N64 before being moved over to the GameCube later on.</p><p>Thanks to the Nintendo 64's additional 4MB of RAM added by the (optional) Expansion Pak, the game displayed at a higher resolution at times, switching between 640x480 and 320x240 (the PlayStation version's native resolution) depending on how many enemies were in the area. If the player defeated the enemies, then the game would automatically switch to the higher resolution. Without the Expansion Pak, the game's visuals closely resembled the PlayStation original.</p><p>Audio from this version suffered the most compression despite the addition of surround sound (which was absent from previous releases). All content fit on one cartridge and did not force players to switch between two different pieces of media.</p><h3>Biohazard 2 Value Plus (<a href=\"/dreamcast/3045-37\" data-ref-id=\"3045-37\">Sega Dreamcast</a>)</h3><p>The Value Plus version is a Japanese-exclusive release that came out one year after the DualShock version and in the same year as the PC and N64 ports. It was bundled with a disc containing a demo of <a href=\"/resident-evil-code-veronica/3030-13940\" data-ref-id=\"3030-13940\">Resident Evil: Code Veronica</a> and assorted music from various games in the series. Since the Dreamcast ran on a Windows CE operating system, this version of Resident Evil 2 was identical to the PC release (see above). However, if the player had a <a href=\"/vmu-support/3015-6194\" data-ref-id=\"3015-6194\">VMU</a>, they could see their character's health on the display.</p><h3>Resident Evil 2 (Sega Dreamcast)</h3><p>Resident Evil 2 on Dreamcast in territories other than Japan is a two-GD ROM set with each disc being a campaign for the two characters, similar to the original PlayStation edition. The Dreamcast version is known for having no drops in the game's framerate and having higher resolution backgrounds than the Playstation, Nintendo 64 and GameCube versions. It also had an \"Extra\" option in the main menu that allowed the player to view concept art and in-game cutscenes. Like the Japanese version, if the player had a VMU, they were able to see their character's health status on the <a href=\"/vmu-support/3015-6194\" data-ref-id=\"3015-6194\">VMU</a> screen.</p><h3>Biohazard 2 PC (Windows XP PC)</h3><p>The same as the PC version released in 1998, except now compatible with Windows XP machines and on one DVD-ROM with uncompressed 640x480 CG scenes. This particular version is a Japanese exclusive released in 2006. It's often referred to as BioHazard 2 SourceNext, after after the company responsible for re-releasing this version</p><h3>Resident Evil 2 (<a href=\"/gamecube/3045-23\" data-ref-id=\"3045-23\">Nintendo Gamecube</a>)</h3><p>Some note this as the definitive version of Resident Evil 2, and while it does not feature any of the EX files on N64, it comes complete with the <em>Extreme</em> <i>Battle </i>minigame. Although it did sport slightly better graphics, background resolutions were worse than the Dreamcast and PC versions. Minor differences such as the voice on the main menu are present. All content is available on one disc.</p><p>Along with the release of <a href=\"/resident-evil-3-nemesis/3030-5587\" data-ref-id=\"3030-5587\">Resident Evil 3: Nemesis</a> on the Gamecube, this particular version is considered a rarity for the system because of low print run.</p><h2>Development</h2><h3>Resident Evil 1.5</h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-size=\"small\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/10354/2633616-51527784am6.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2633616\" data-ratio=\"0.76775956284153\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:76.8%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/10354/2633616-51527784am6.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2633616\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"/uploads/scale_small/1/10354/2633616-51527784am6.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"/uploads/scale_small/1/10354/2633616-51527784am6.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Image of Elza equipped with a shotgun</figcaption></figure><p>After the launch of Resident Evil, work immediately began on Resident Evil 2 and was scheduled for a 1997 release. Nearing the end of development, when the game was about 80-90% done, the creators felt the sequel was more of the same and was scrapped. The previous version of the game had a female protagonist named Elza Walker who was eventually replaced by Claire Redfield. She shared many of Claire\u2019s traits such as being an avid fan of <a href=\"/motorcycle/3055-366\" data-ref-id=\"3055-366\">motorbikes</a> and was a student. While Claire is the sister of the Chris Redfield, the Resident Evil 1.5 protagonist, Elza, was completely unrelated to any previous Resident Evil character. Leon Kennedy also had a radically different appearance initially, but that too was altered since Capcom believed it held too strong a resemblance to former Resident Evil hero <a href=\"/chris-redfield/3005-413\" data-ref-id=\"3005-413\">Chris Redfield</a>. Additionally, the policeman named Marvin who dies early on in Resident Evil 2 had a much bigger role in this incarnation; supposedly he would help the player escape the city similar to the role of <a href=\"/barry-burton/3005-987\" data-ref-id=\"3005-987\">Barry</a> in Resident Evil 3.</p><figure data-align=\"left\" data-size=\"small\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/10354/2633617-residentevil2halloweent.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2633617\" data-ratio=\"0.75\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:75.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/10354/2633617-residentevil2halloweent.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2633617\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"/uploads/scale_small/1/10354/2633617-residentevil2halloweent.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"/uploads/scale_small/1/10354/2633617-residentevil2halloweent.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Ada in her original researcher outfit</figcaption></figure><p>Furthermore, the design and layout of the police department was modern and resembled a typical police structure. It lacked the gothic elements of the final police station and used the color gray quite frequently; perhaps in a bid to make the area feel sterile. Finally, amongst other things, were the varieties of the monsters. Sketches and screenshots showcase zombies of different races, monsters that resembled the reapers from <a href=\"/resident-evil-5/3030-20569\" data-ref-id=\"3030-20569\">Resident Evil 5</a> and two bosses, which made the cutting room floor named Zeiram and Gorgoda. Zeiram and Gorgoda\u2019s elements of design ultimately were used to create <a href=\"/william-birkin/3005-3332\" data-ref-id=\"3005-3332\">William Birkin</a>\u2019s G-form.</p><p>The characters had unique and more professional animations for wielding weapons, such as Leon holding his gun up when standing still rather than continuing in his neutral stance.</p><p>A version of the game that looks to be almost complete is in the confines of a <a href=\"http://www.playstationmuseum.org/\" rel=\"nofollow\">private collection</a>, but other than a 10 minute video of previously unseen footage posted on Youtube, nothing else has been released, much to the dismay of fans.</p><p> </p><h2>Remake</h2><p>On August 12th, 2015, Capcom announced that they will be proceeding with a Resident Evil 2 Remake. No major details were provided, but it is presumed that the game will receive the same treatment as the Gamecube remake of <a href=\"/resident-evil/3030-27715\" data-ref-id=\"3030-27715\">Resident Evil</a>.</p><p> </p><h2>Trivia</h2><ul><li>Resident Evil 2 is the only mainline Resident Evil game that doesn't feature any <a href=\"/idle-animations/3015-1737\" data-ref-id=\"3015-1737\">idle animations</a>.</li><li>It was <a href=\"/hideki-kamiya/3040-60123\" data-ref-id=\"3040-60123\">Hideki Kamiya</a>'s idea specifically to reintroduce Brad Vickers as a zombie.</li><li>Ada Wong's CG character model wasn't finished, and is thusly the only character of the main four to not show up in any of the CG cutscenes.</li></ul><h2>Soundtrack</h2><p>There are two soundtrack CD releases for Resident Evil 2, the first release came out in January 29, 1998 and consisted of 31 tracks and one CD. But since not all music contained in the game was included, a new version was release in August 21, 1998 named Biohazard 2 Complete Track and with 50 tracks and two CDs. The soundtrack was composed by Masami Ueda, Shun Nishigaki and Shusaku Uchiyama.</p><table><tbody><tr><th>Biohazard 2 Original Soundtrack</th><th>Biohazard 2 Complete Track</th></tr><tr><td>CD {"duration": "1:05:00", "runner": "RbdJellyfish", "data": {"site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/littlebigplanet/3030-25422/", "expected_release_quarter": null, "description": "<h2>Overview</h2><p>LittleBigPlanet <a href=\"/psp/3045-18\" data-ref-id=\"3045-18\">PSP</a> is the portable version of the <a href=\"/playstation-3/3045-35\" data-ref-id=\"3045-35\">PlayStation 3</a> hit of the same name. It was first playable at <a href=\"/e3-2009/3015-3244\" data-ref-id=\"3015-3244\">E3 2009</a> showing off two <a href=\"/australia/3035-292\" data-ref-id=\"3035-292\">Australian</a>-themed levels with similar gameplay of the console counterpart.</p><p>The game is developed by <a href=\"/sce-studio-cambridge/3010-278\" data-ref-id=\"3010-278\">Sony Computer Entertainment Studio Cambridge</a> in conjunction with <a href=\"/media-molecule/3010-6318\" data-ref-id=\"3010-6318\">Media Molecule</a>, and was released November 17, 2009 in North America , November 20, 2009 in PAL regions, and December 3, 2009 in Japan.</p><h2>Gameplay</h2><p>The platforming style of the original console game returns in the portable version, although without multiplayer co-op. The travel around the <a href=\"/earth/3035-65\" data-ref-id=\"3035-65\">globe</a> level design also returns, with themes like the <a href=\"/australia/3035-292\" data-ref-id=\"3035-292\">Australia Outback</a>, <a href=\"/china/3035-343\" data-ref-id=\"3035-343\">China</a>, <a href=\"/egypt/3035-878\" data-ref-id=\"3035-878\">Egypt</a>, <a href=\"/saudi-arabia/3035-1612\" data-ref-id=\"3035-1612\">Arabia</a>, the Alpine, Tinsel Town (based on <a href=\"/hollywood/3035-642\" data-ref-id=\"3035-642\">Hollywood</a>), and <a href=\"/brazil/3035-720\" data-ref-id=\"3035-720\">Brazil</a>. Other returning elements are rotating platforms, switches, stickers, swinging, creating, and more.</p><p><a href=\"/stephen-fry/3040-89566\" data-ref-id=\"3040-89566\">Stephen Fry</a> reprises his voice over role for the English version of the game.</p><h3>Game Differences</h3><p>With the limiting controls of the <a href=\"/psp/3045-18\" data-ref-id=\"3045-18\">PlayStation Portable</a> as opposed to the <a href=\"/dualshock-3/3000-29\" data-ref-id=\"3000-29\">DualShock 3 Controller</a>, changes had to be made to help adapt the game to the device. Also, some tools and options were completely removed.</p><p>This game only used two walking layers and three thin layers compaired to the PS3 game's three walking layers and four thin layers.</p><p>Changing layers for an object is done by tapping L to toggle the object onto each layer until you get to the layer you want. Also, without a second analog stick to determine <a href=\"/sackboy/3005-663\" data-ref-id=\"3005-663\">Sackboy</a> movement from object movement, holding L and pressing Left/Right rotates the object and Up/Down scales the object.</p><p>Dark Matter (the material in LBP PS3 that stays in the air and isn't affected by gravity), is replaced with the ability to give any object a \"static\" property, thus making that object act like Dark Matter would.</p><p>There are graphical and process limitations due to the PSP's limited power. Corners are no longer well rounded, textures are not as detailed, explosions no longer destroy or partially destroy objects, small objects can no longer break when being crushed, and only the square or circle shape can be used to freehand.</p><p>Lighting tools are no longer present.</p><p>Stickers are limited as well. They can't wrap around objects or materials; meaning they can only be placed on the face of objects. Stickers also can't be placed on Sackboy, costumes, score bubbles, or the scoreboard.</p><p>There is no photo tool, thus no way to make custom stickers.</p><p>Also, decorations are completely gone.</p><p>There are no Interactive Music tracks (music that you could set the volume of each instrument). Even tracks that were made interactive for the PS3 version, and ported to the PSP version, are no longer interactive.</p><p>It is also important to note that community levels must be downloaded to the PSP before becoming playable.</p>", "deck": "A game based on LittleBigPlanet for the PS3, developed for the PSP. It features most of the same platforming gameplay, creation tools, and sharing abilities.", "aliases": "LBP PSP\nLittleBigPlanet PSP", "image": {"icon_url":
