{"duration": "0:40:00", "runner": "soothingplumtea", "data": {"site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/burning-rangers/3030-5765/", "expected_release_quarter": null, "description": "<h2>Overview</h2>Burning Rangers is a third-person action platformer developed by <a data-ref-id=\"3010-781\" href=\"/sonic-team/3010-781\" slug=\"sonic-team\">Sonic Team</a>\u00a0and\u00a0released in 1998 for the <a data-ref-id=\"3055-3134\" href=\"/sega-saturn/3055-3134\" slug=\"sega-saturn\">Sega Saturn</a>. Released at the end of the consoles lifespan, the game is considered to have the most advanced graphics for the Saturn platform, an improvement on what the development team learned from <a data-ref-id=\"3030-9676\" href=\"/nights-into-dreams/3030-9676\" slug=\"nights-into-dreams\">NiGHTS</a>,\u00a0two years earlier. In the game, the player takes control of one of several firefighters, who using advanced <a data-ref-id=\"3055-46\" href=\"/exoskeleton/3055-46\" slug=\"exoskeleton\">exo-suits</a> and fire-extinguishers, navigate burning structures, putting out and avoiding fire and teleporting survivors to safety.<h2>Gameplay</h2><figure data-align=\"right\" data-embed-type=\"image\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/5911/845720-br09.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-845720\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.63636363636364\" data-width=\"320\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:63.6%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/5911/845720-br09.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-845720\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/5911/845720-br09.png\"/></a><figcaption>Gameplay in Burning Rangers\u00a0</figcaption></figure>   In Burning Rangers, the main threat to the player is fire. While there are rogue security bots and aliens later in the game, neither are as prominent as fire. The player must navigate the burning structure, sometimes moving underwater and even zero gravity, using their jetpack to move through the area and using an <a data-ref-id=\"3015-739\" href=\"/arm-cannon/3015-739\" slug=\"arm-cannon\">arm-cannon</a> to extinguish flames. The player must do this quickly, as a limit meter slowly rises the more fire there is. As the meter hits certain amounts like 50%, the area will explode around the player, giving them just seconds to react. A chime is played just before an explosion triggers, if the player is quick and jumps, they will do a backflip and avoid the explosion. If the player is lost at any point in the game, they can press the Z button, where the Team Navigator, <a data-ref-id=\"3005-11982\" href=\"/chris-partn/3005-11982\" slug=\"chris-partn\">Chris</a>,\u00a0will give them directions on where to go.\u00a0At the end of the level, they face a boss which require a certain strategy to defeat. The player is given their score, with a <a data-ref-id=\"3015-2163\" href=\"/ranking-system/3015-2163\" slug=\"ranking-system\">rank</a> ranging from F to <a data-ref-id=\"3015-2962\" href=\"/s-rank/3015-2962\" slug=\"s-rank\">S</a> depending on their time, amount of survivors rescued and what the limit meter was at various points in the level.<br/>\u00a0<br/>Extinguishing fires earns the player crystals. Crystals have two uses: Similar to rings in\u00a0<a data-ref-id=\"3025-383\" href=\"/sonic-the-hedgehog/3025-383\" slug=\"sonic-the-hedgehog\">Sonic The Hedgehog</a>, these crystals protect the player from death. As long as the player has at least one crystal, they will be protected. Like the\u00a0aforementioned\u00a0game, contact with fire will cause the player's crystals to fly out from them, but can be recollected if the player is quick enough. If the player is burned without a crystal in their possession, they will die and lose a life, sending them back to the last checkpoint. The second use of the crystals is to rescue survivors from danger. Each survivor requires a certain amount of crystals in order to teleport them out of the building, if the player uses more crystals than the required amount they will earn additional lives. At the end of the mission, the player may\u00a0receive\u00a0fan-mail from survivors they have rescued. If the player manages to find and rescue a cameo member of the development team, they will\u00a0receive\u00a0a password to unlock some of the game's extras.<br/>\u00a0<br/>On completion of the game, the player unlocks a random level generator. In this mode, levels are generated randomly, adding to the game's longetivity.<br/><h2>Story</h2><h3>Mission 1: Fallen Memory</h3><br/><figure data-align=\"right\" data-embed-type=\"image\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/6036/212543-br8.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-212543\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.63636363636364\" data-width=\"320\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:63.6%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/6036/212543-br8.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-212543\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/6036/212543-br8.png\"/></a><figcaption>Mission 1 establishes the game's mechanics.</figcaption></figure>     The first mission takes place at a power plant, where fires have broken out due to a breach of the core reactor, trapping researchers and\u00a0personnel\u00a0inside. The team are tasked with containing the spread of the fire and rescuing survivors. After moving through the facility, they attempt to override the CPU of the reactor, only for it to be rejected. They discover\u00a0that the main reactor is being controlled by a giant plant, which has mutated due to genetic experiments performed by a lead researcher, whose intended to discover the cure to a disease that took the life of his wife. The team manage to stop the plant by traveling to the 99th floor and severing the plant's connection to the reactor, deeming the mission a success.\u00a0<br/><br/><h3>Mission 2: Silent Blue</h3>\u00a0<br/><figure data-align=\"left\" data-embed-type=\"image\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/2579/1659162-00000001.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1659162\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.63636363636364\" data-width=\"320\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:63.6%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/2579/1659162-00000001.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1659162\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/2579/1659162-00000001.png\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/2579/1659162-00000001.png\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Underwater gameplay...\u00a0</figcaption></figure>     The second mission takes place at an underwater aquatic theme park\u00a0called\u00a0Ocean Park, located in<a data-ref-id=\"3035-1098\" href=\"/new-zealand/3035-1098\" slug=\"new-zealand\"> New Zealand</a>. A fire of unknown origin has broken out and the automatic evacuation system has failed,\u00a0reportedly\u00a0trapping 30\u00a0maintenance\u00a0crew inside. The team investigate the maintenance area, but Big and Lead report they have just found over 200 children, apparent special visitors for the park. Without enough crystals to rescue them all and water levels rising, the rookies are sent to detach the upper part of the park where the children are located. With the help of a Dolphin, they manage to travel through water passages and get to the joint area, where they discover a large\u00a0aggressive\u00a0fish and a transmitting device. After managing to destroy the fish, the successfully detach the upper part of the park, saving the children. When they return to their transport vessel they scan the transmitting device, learning that it received a signal from quadrant RK404. They leave immediately to discover the origin of the signal.<br/><br/><h3>Mission 3: Gravity Zero</h3>\u00a0<br/><figure data-align=\"right\" data-embed-type=\"image\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/2579/1659204-00000001.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1659204\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.63636363636364\" data-width=\"320\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:63.6%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/2579/1659204-00000001.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1659204\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/2579/1659204-00000001.png\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/2579/1659204-00000001.png\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>...Space gameplay!\u00a0</figcaption></figure>     On arrival at quadrant they discover that a nearby space colony 'Firebird' has been hit by debris from a nearby spaceship, the origin of the signal. The Burning Rangers enter the colony to investigate and rescue any survivors. With some of the gravity control systems malfunctioning, they are forced to navigate some of the colony in zero gravity. They move through the colony extinguishing fires and\u00a0acquiring\u00a0<a data-ref-id=\"3055-600\" href=\"/keycard/3055-600\" slug=\"keycard\">keycards</a>\u00a0from survivors to access further areas. When one of the rookies finds a young boy, the colony starts to\u00a0deteriorate and due to a magnetic shield storm are the rookie and young boy are unable to be transported. The rookie carries the young boy on their back and without the use of their extinguishers, must escape the burning colony. They manage to find an escape pod, but when there is only room for one, the rookie puts the boy inside and promises they'll find another escape pod and give them their autograph when they get back,\u00a0secretly\u00a0unsure of whether they can keep their promise. The rookie sets off to find another escape pod when they stumble upon another transmitter. An unknown female voice warns them that the colony's defense system has been activated, summoning a hybrid robot forcing the rookie to deactivate it. When they think it's over, the nearby spaceship begins\u00a0absorbing\u00a0the colony and with the transporter still malfunctioning and communications cut, the rookie is trapped inside...<br/><br/><h3>Mission 4: Winged Cradle</h3><br/><figure data-align=\"left\" data-embed-type=\"image\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/2579/1659646-00000003.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1659646\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.63636363636364\" data-width=\"320\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:63.6%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/2579/1659646-00000003.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1659646\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/2579/1659646-00000003.png\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/2579/1659646-00000003.png\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>\u00a0The team head for the core.</figcaption></figure>  The rookie wakes up inside the derelict spaceship. With communications to the Burning Ship still blocked, they must employ the help from the mysterious voice to navigate the strange structure. When they manage to find and destroy the source of the magnetic shield, the mysterious voice reveals herself to be Iria Klein. At the age of 16, she developed an incurable desease, so her father put her into cryogenic statis aboard the space ship and programmed it to orbit around Earth, until a desease could be found. In order to protect her, he cloned his conciousness into the spaceship's main computer memory banks. After a while however, the computers artificial intelligence started to malfunction, obsorbing all floating material in space it came into contact with, creating a large shield. When the ship receieved a transmission that a cure had been found, it began carrying out it's final instructions to land back on earth. With it's vastly increased mass however, this would act a meteor on a collision with Earth. With it's outer shield nearly invincible, the only way to stop it is to destroy the main computer.<br/> <br/><figure data-align=\"right\" data-embed-type=\"image\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/2579/1659649-00000008.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1659649\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.63636363636364\" data-width=\"320\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:63.6%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/2579/1659649-00000008.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1659649\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/2579/1659649-00000008.png\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/2579/1659649-00000008.png\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Tillis faces the corrupt AI.\u00a0</figcaption></figure>     With the magnetic shield disabled, the Burning Man is able to enter the space ship and make contact with the rookie, transporting them onto the vessel. With their objective realised, they fly through the outside perimeter and head for the main computer at the core of the ship. There they are able to find Iria's statis pod and transport it to safety. The rookie then successfully destroys the main computer, \u00a0with the team managing to transport the rookie back to the Burning Man moments before the entire spaceship explodes. In the epilogue, the doctor is again busy working on a cure, the dolphin from Ocean Park has returned safely, the child who was rescued is already planning to become a Burning Ranger and Iria has just become the most recent addition to the team.<br/><h2>Characters</h2><figure data-align=\"right\" data-embed-type=\"image\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/2579/1625738-rangers.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1625738\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.71621621621622\" data-width=\"320\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:71.6%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/2579/1625738-rangers.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1625738\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/2579/1625738-rangers.png\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/2579/1625738-rangers.png\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>\u00a0The Burning Rangers.</figcaption></figure>     Burning Rangers features a futuristic team of firefighters. At the beginning of the game the player has access to two characters, the most recent additions to the team, rookies\u00a0<a data-ref-id=\"3005-11979\" href=\"/tillis/3005-11979\" slug=\"tillis\">Tillis</a> and <a data-ref-id=\"3005-11976\" href=\"/shou-amabane/3005-11976\" slug=\"shou-amabane\">Shou Amabane</a>, both whom\u00a0lost their family in a fire which aspired them to become Burning Rangers themselves.\u00a0Other members such as\u00a0<a data-ref-id=\"3005-11981\" href=\"/big-landman/3005-11981\" slug=\"big-landman\">Big Landman</a>\u00a0and\u00a0<a data-ref-id=\"3005-11980\" href=\"/lead-phoenix/3005-11980\" slug=\"lead-phoenix\">Lead Phoenix</a>\u00a0are unlockable via passwords. The team's navigator <a data-ref-id=\"3005-11982\" href=\"/chris-partn/3005-11982\" slug=\"chris-partn\">Chris Paron</a>\u00a0provides vital information to the team from 'Burning Ship', their transporter vessel.<br/><h2>Soundtrack</h2>Burning Ranger's soundtrack was released in 1998 and composed by <a data-ref-id=\"3040-33675\" href=\"/naofumi-hataya/3040-33675\" slug=\"naofumi-hataya\">Naofumi Hataya</a>, who has composed several other titles for <a data-ref-id=\"3010-62\" href=\"/sega/3010-62\" slug=\"sega\">Sega</a>.\u00a0Several songs feature vocal work from <a data-ref-id=\"3040-52399\" href=\"/takenobu-mitsuyoshi/3040-52399\" slug=\"takenobu-mitsuyoshi\">Takenobu Mitsuyoshi</a>, who also appeared on the soundtrack for\u00a0<a data-ref-id=\"3025-134\" href=\"/daytona-usa/3025-134\" slug=\"daytona-usa\">Daytona USA</a>.<br/>\u00a0<br/><h3>Burning Rangers Sound Track</h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-embed-type=\"image\" mini-games.<br />\u00a0<br />Bomberman 64 was the last official Nintendo 64 game to be released in Japan, though the <a data-ref-id=\"3030-5688\" href=\"/tony-hawks-pro-skater-3/3030-5688\">    last {"duration": "0:40:00", "runner": "2dos", "data": {"site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/donkey-kong-64/3030-15000/", "expected_release_quarter": null, "description": "<h2>Overview</h2><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/7784/556637-donkeykong64.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-556637\" data-size=\"medium\" data-ratio=\"0.75\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:75.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/7784/556637-donkeykong64.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-556637\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_medium/0/7784/556637-donkeykong64.jpg\"/></a><figcaption> Title screen</figcaption></figure><p>Donkey Kong 64 is a game by <a href=\"../../rare-ltd/65-174/\" rel=\"nofollow\">Rare </a>for the <a href=\"/nintendo-64/3045-43\" data-ref-id=\"3045-43\">Nintendo 64</a>. The first 3D platformer Rare created after <a href=\"../../banjo-kazooie/61-10920/\" rel=\"nofollow\">Banjo Kazooie</a>, Donkey Kong 64 featured higher resolution textures and graphics (thanks to the N64 dual ram \"Expansion Pack\" that was included with the game), but also featured more collection quests and more items to collect.</p><p>It is regarded as one of the biggest and longest single player video games ever created, due to it's very large amount of collectibles and missions for the player to complete.</p><h2>Gameplay</h2><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/17172/824094-dk4.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-824094\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.73226238286479\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:73.2%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/17172/824094-dk4.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-824094\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/1/17172/824094-dk4.png\"/></a><figcaption> Going out!</figcaption></figure><p>Donkey Kong 64 is a 3-D platformer where players guide all five members of the \"Kong family\" (including <a href=\"../../donkey-kong/94-299/\" rel=\"nofollow\">Donkey Kong </a>and <a href=\"../../diddy-kong/94-304/\" rel=\"nofollow\">Diddy Kong</a>) to recollect their horde of Golden Bananas. Each Kong has their own abilities and characteristics, as well as their own unique collectibles, meaning each world has five different sets of collectible items.</p><p>The Golden Bananas have been hidden across eight unique worlds. On each world there are five golden bananas for each Kong to collect and a boss to be defeated. In order to open the door that locks the boss the players need to gather as many regular bananas as possible and feed them to a hippopotamus that guards the door.</p><p>When defeating the boss the Kongs will get a golden key that will allow them to help a giant <a href=\"../../kremlings/92-3312/\" rel=\"nofollow\">Kremlin </a>\u2013 K. Lumsy \u2013 who has been locked up by <a href=\"../../king-k-rool/94-906/\" rel=\"nofollow\">King K. Rool</a>. When using the key to unlock part of his cage, K. Lumsy will jump with joy and cause an earthquake that will open the following world. When reaching the entrance to another world, the player will use the Golden Bananas to finally gain entrance to a new area.</p><figure data-align=\"left\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/601/235350-donkey_kong_64_.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-235350\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.74375\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:74.4%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/601/235350-donkey_kong_64_.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-235350\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/601/235350-donkey_kong_64_.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/601/235350-donkey_kong_64_.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption> Exploring the world.</figcaption></figure><p>The worlds are filled with different challenges that will make use of all of the Kongs' many abilities. Some mini-games can also be found within each world, the reward earned for beating them is usually a Golden Banana.</p><p>On their adventure, the players are aided by other famous members of the Kong family such as <a href=\"../../funky-kong/94-1647/\" rel=\"nofollow\">Funky </a>(who provides guns for all the five Kongs), <a href=\"../../candy-kong/94-4238/\" rel=\"nofollow\">Candy </a>(who teaches them how to play different instruments), and <a href=\"../../cranky-kong/94-311/\" rel=\"nofollow\">Cranky </a>(who will give potions that will make the Kongs learn new moves).</p><h2>Plot</h2><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/17172/824096-dk2.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-824096\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.73226238286479\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:73.2%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/17172/824096-dk2.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-824096\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/1/17172/824096-dk2.png\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/1/17172/824096-dk2.png\"/></noscript></a><figcaption> The Kremlings try to steer their oversized ship.</figcaption></figure><p>K. Rool has an evil plan to destroy all the Kongs, and their island, using a massive laser called the \"Blast-O-Matic.\" But, due to his clumsy Kremlins, his ship crashes on a big rock in the ocean, which causes his weapon to malfunction.</p><p>He sends his underlings to lock-away some of the Kongs, and steal Donkey Kong\u2019s banana hoard once again, in order to have time to fix his weapon and attain his goal.</p><h2>Characters</h2><h3>Playable Characters</h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/3/33306/1072361-wallpaper_800_600_dk64_n64.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1072361\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.745\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:74.5%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/3/33306/1072361-wallpaper_800_600_dk64_n64.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1072361\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/3/33306/1072361-wallpaper_800_600_dk64_n64.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/3/33306/1072361-wallpaper_800_600_dk64_n64.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>The D.K crew</figcaption></figure><p><strong><a href=\"../../donkey-kong/94-299/\" rel=\"nofollow\"> Donkey Kong</a></strong> \u2013 The initial character and the most balanced of all the Kongs, he uses a coconut gun as a weapon and plays the bongos.</p><p><strong><a href=\"../../diddy-kong/94-304/\" rel=\"nofollow\"> Diddy Kong</a></strong> \u2013 He is not very strong but he is fairly quick, and he can perform long jumps. He uses two peanut popguns and plays the guitar.</p><p><strong><a href=\"../../lanky-kong/94-3309/\" rel=\"nofollow\"> Lanky Kong</a></strong> \u2013 An orangutan with long arms that help him swim quickly and stay in the air for a while after jumping. He uses a grape shooter and plays the trombone.</p><p><strong><a href=\"../../tiny-kong/94-3308/\" rel=\"nofollow\"> Tiny Kong</a></strong> \u2013 The smallest Kong- she can use her ponytails to fly (similar to Dixie Kong in Donkey Kong Country 2). She uses a feather crossbow as a weapon and plays the saxophone.</p><p><strong><a href=\"../../chunky-kong/94-4395/\" rel=\"nofollow\"> Chunky Kong</a></strong> \u2013 He is very slow, but also extremely strong. He uses a pineapple launcher and plays the triangle.</p><h3>Supporting Characters</h3><ul><li><a href=\"../../cranky-kong/94-311/\" rel=\"nofollow\"> Cranky Kong</a></li><li><a href=\"../../king-k-rool/94-906/\" rel=\"nofollow\"> King K.Rool</a></li><li><a href=\"../../funky-kong/94-1647/\" rel=\"nofollow\"> Funky Kong</a></li><li><a href=\"../../candy-kong/94-4238/\" rel=\"nofollow\"> Candy Kong</a></li></ul><h2>Worlds</h2><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/3957/235524-dkisle.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-235524\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.75\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:75.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/3957/235524-dkisle.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-235524\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/3957/235524-dkisle.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/3957/235524-dkisle.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption> The DK Island, the hub to access the worlds.</figcaption></figure><p><strong>DK Isles </strong>\u2013 The over world of the game. It is composed of the main island (in the shape of Donkey Kong's head) and several smaller isles surrounding it.</p><p><b>Jungle Japes </b>\u2013 The first world of the game- a classic Donkey Kong jungle with some caves to be explored and vast areas of trees and green grass.</p><p><b>Angry Aztec </b>\u2013 An Egyptian level with lots of ancient ruins, pyramids, and dangerous quicksand.</p><p><b>Frantic Factory</b> \u2013 A strange and dangerous toy factory, this level has a variety of machines and development rooms where the Kongs will have to play with K. Rool\u2019s latest cruel inventions.</p><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/3/33306/1072365-dk64es7.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1072365\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.73244147157191\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:73.2%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/3/33306/1072365-dk64es7.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1072365\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/3/33306/1072365-dk64es7.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/3/33306/1072365-dk64es7.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Angry Aztec level</figcaption></figure><p><b>Gloomy Galleon </b>\u2013 A water level that is composed of two large lakes and a variety of dangerous sunken ships.</p><p><b>Fungi Forest </b>\u2013 A mysterious forest with a big clock at its center that controls time. (The Kongs must switch between night and day to unlock all of Fungi Forest's secrets.)</p><p><strong>Crystal Caves</strong> \u2013 An underground cavern that suffers from frequent earthquakes due to a particularly nasty Kremling.</p><p><b>Creepy Castle </b>\u2013 An old castle and its surrounding grounds- this level is chock full of ghosts and other ghouls.</p><p><b>Hideout Helm </b>\u2013 The headquarters of the Kremlings and the notorious Blast-O-Matic laser.</p><h2>Abilities</h2><p>Each of the five members of the Kong clan will learn unique moves to help them collect Golden Bananas. Each Kong has one special move that requires them to jump into a barrel with their face on it- these special moves use Crystal Coconuts, which can be found lying around the levels. These moves are marked below by a 'CC'.</p><h3>All Kongs</h3><ul><li>Simian Slam \u2013 The Kongs slam the ground to perform a powerful attack.</li><li>Super Duper Simian Slam \u2013 A stronger version of the Simian Slam.</li></ul><h3>Donkey Kong</h3><ul><li>Baboon Blast \u2013 Donkey Kong uses a Kong Pad and is shot into the sky where Barrel Blast challenges take place.</li><li>Gorilla Grab \u2013 DK gains the ability to move levers and activate events within the same world.</li><li>Strong Kong (CC)\u2013 DK can jump into a barrel to temporarily become invincible.</li></ul><h3>Diddy Kong</h3><ul><li>Chimpy Charge \u2013 Diddy uses a charge attack where he hits enemies or other objects with his head.</li><li>Rocketbarrel Boost (CC) \u2013 Diddy can jump into a barrel and he will use a jet pack to fly around (while wielding his peanut popguns). (Uses Crystal Coconuts)</li><li>Simian Spring \u2013 Diddy uses his tail to perform a high jump.</li></ul><h3>Lanky Kong</h3><ul><li>Orangstand \u2013 Lanky will be able to run using his hands instead of his feet, allowing him to climb steeper slopes.</li><li>Baboon Balloon \u2013 Lanky gains the ability to become a balloon and float in the air for a limited time.</li><li>Orangstand Sprint (CC)\u2013 A faster version of the Orangstand move that can only be activated when Lanky uses a Lanky Barrel.</li></ul><h3>Tiny Kong</h3><ul><li>Mini Monkey (CC) - Tiny becomes even smaller with this move and can enter tiny holes.</li><li>Ponytail Whirl \u2013 Tiny uses her ponytails as a helicopter.</li><li>Monkeyport \u2013 Tiny uses Tiny Pads to teleport.</li></ul><h3>Chunky Kong</h3><ul><li>Hunky Chunky (CC) \u2013 Chunky becomes gigantic by entering his barrel- in this state he can pick up larger objects and activate heavier switches.</li><li>Primate Punch \u2013 The Kong delivers a powerful blow that can break weak doors and destroy enemies.</li><li>Gorilla Gone \u2013 Chunky becomes invisible for a short time by using a Chunky Pad.</li></ul><h2>Items</h2><p><b>Golden Banana </b>- The main item of the game. There are 25 hidden on each world five for each Kong.</p><p><b>Regular Banana </b>- Collect them to battle the boss of the respective world. There are 100 of them for each Kong on each of the game\u2019s seven worlds.</p><p><b>Blue Print </b>- Blueprints of K. Rool\u2019s powerful laser, the Blast-O-Matic. Snide will give the Kongs a Golden Banana for each one of the forty blueprints they collect during the game.</p><p><b>Banana Medal </b>- There are five on each level, one for each one of the Kongs. They can be acquired after collecting 75 regular bananas.</p><p><b>Banana Fairy </b>- Hidden carefully throughout the game, there are twenty missing banana fairies to be found. They can be captured using the Banana Camera, which uses Banana Film.</p><p><b>Crown </b>- Earned after winning an arena battle against a group of Kremlings.</p><p><b>Key </b>- Used to unlock K. Lumsy\u2019s cage.</p><p><b>Nintendo Coin </b>- Beat the Donkey Kong arcade twice to get this coin. Required to finish the game.</p><p><b>Rareware Coin </b>- Get at least 5000 points in Jetpak \u2013 an old game that Cranky Kong lets the Kongs play after they've collected 15 banana medals. It is also needed to finish the game.</p><h2>Multiplayer</h2><p>The game featured a multiplayer mode where the player can play as any of the five Kongs and one bonus character, Krusha. It is played in the style of a 3rd person shooter. Each Kong uses his or her specific gun, that is also seen in the story mode, to dole out damage. The players travel around the arena picking up ammo, grenades, and pieces of watermelon that regain health. They must work to accomplish the objective at hand, which is determined by the game mode they have chosen.</p><h3>Arenas</h3><p>Arenas are Monkey Smash Arena's one through three. Each are enclosed spaces, often multi-layered, and usually divided into sections that are used as spawn points.</p><h3>Game Modes</h3><p>There are six different game modes the player can choose from, each with its own special set of rules and objectives.</p><h4>Survival</h4><p>A sort of death match. Each player is given a limited amount of lives, the game is played until players have lost all their lives and one Kong remains standing.</p><h4>Wins</h4><p>In this game a set amount of kills in put in place at the beginning of the match, when this number of kills is reached by a player, they are the winner.</p><h4>Time</h4><p>A time limit is set, and players battle to see who can achieve the most kills in the time limit provided.</p><h4>Coin Hoard<b> </b></h4><p>Players race to collect as many coins from the map as they can within the time limit.</p><h4>Capture</h4><p>A coin appears on the map, players must race to grab the coin, and hold it for as long as they can to earn as many points as they can before time runs out.</p><h4>Capture Pad</h4><p>Once again, players race to get the coin somewhere on the map. When a player has the coin, they must travel over pads in order to earn the most points they can before time runs out.</p><h2>Trivia</h2><ul><li>The level Fungi Forest was initially created for <a href=\"../../banjo-kazooie/61-10920/\" rel=\"nofollow\">Banjo-Kazooie </a>but since the game already had plenty of levels the producers decided to put it on Donkey Kong 64.</li><li>According to the Guinness World Records Games 2008 book this game holds the record for the largest amount of collectibles a game has ever had.</li></ul><h2>Reception</h2><p>Donkey Kong was well received among reviewers, but it fell short when compared to other Rare platformers like the <a href=\"../../banjo-kazooie/62-46/\" rel=\"nofollow\">Banjo-Kazooie </a>franchise. The main complaint was that the game presented too many things to collect and that it was simply too long.</p><p>However, many praised the amazing graphics which were generated with the help of the expansion pack. The game was also praised for it's large amount of content.</p><h2>DK Rap</h2><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/3/33306/1072367-gfs_41619_1_2.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1072367\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.75\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:75.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/3/33306/1072367-gfs_41619_1_2.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1072367\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/3/33306/1072367-gfs_41619_1_2.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/3/33306/1072367-gfs_41619_1_2.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Screen capture from the DK rap</figcaption></figure><p>The DK Rap was a rather long and catchy tune played at the beginning of the game before the menu screen. The rap featured brief descriptions of each character, and the use of the word \"hell\".While the rap and accompanying cutscene was almost assuredly meant as tongue in cheek the bizarre nature of it has nonetheless made the DK Rap somewhat of an injoke among fans of the series.</p><h3>Lyrics</h3><p>He-He-Here we go!</p><p>So they're finally here,</p><p>Performin' for you.</p><p>If you know the words</p><p>you can join in too.</p><p>Put your hands together,</p><p>If you want to clap,</p><p>As we take you through,</p><p>This Monkey Rap.</p><p>HUH!</p><p>D-K, Donkey Kong.</p><p>He's the leader of the bunch,</p><p>You know him well,</p><p>He's finally back,</p><p>To kick some tail.</p><p>His coconut gun,</p><p>Can fire in spurts,</p><p>If he shoots ya,</p><p>Its gonna hurt!</p><p>He's bigger, faster,</p><p>And stronger too.</p><p>He's the first member,</p><p>Of the D.K. oranges,</p><p>And coconut shells.</p><h2>Soundtrack</h2><ol><li>Angry Aztec -- Rare (2:26)</li><li>Angry Aztec Lobby -- Rare (1:39)</li><li>Character Select Barrel -- Rare (1:14)</li><li>Credits -- The game also has a hub area where you start, from which you can enter one of the four themed areas. These themed areas consist of a few stages each and all end with an epic boss confrontation. The goal of the game is to finally beat all four of those bosses in order to finally come face to face with the Black Jewel, a seemingly cursed object which spawned monsters all around Wario's newly built castle. <br/><br/>The game is very combat oriented, with small puzzle areas reachable by going through trap doors supplying most of the mental challenge. These areas are necessary in order to finish the level, as you need 4 gems which can only be obtained by successfully finishing the puzzles. The game also has a unique approach to death. When Wario runs out of health, you can simply pay a large sum of gold acquired through playing the game to revive yourself. <br/><br/>The game received overall decent reviews, but it's primary criticism was it's lack of variety and short length. "2008-04-01 01:55:09", "platforms": [{"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/platform/3045-23/", "abbreviation": "GCN", "site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/gamecube/3045-23/", "id": {"duration": "1:05:00", "runner": "HastyAether", "data": {"site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/super-mario-64-ds/3030-8942/", "expected_release_quarter": null, "description": "<h2>Overview</h2><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/7399/379252-mario_64_ds.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-379252\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.75\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:75.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/7399/379252-mario_64_ds.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-379252\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/7399/379252-mario_64_ds.jpg\"/></a><figcaption>Super Mario 64 DS</figcaption></figure><p>Much like <a href=\"/super-mario-64/3030-2931\" data-ref-id=\"3030-2931\">Super Mario 64</a>, the game opens with <a href=\"/princess-peach/3005-709\" data-ref-id=\"3005-709\">Peach</a> inviting <a href=\"/mario/3005-177\" data-ref-id=\"3005-177\">Mario</a> to her castle. Mario shows up, but he is not alone, <a href=\"/wario/3005-24\" data-ref-id=\"3005-24\">Wario</a> and <a href=\"/luigi/3005-370\" data-ref-id=\"3005-370\">Luigi</a> accompany him. All three enter the castle and disappear, along with the still kidnapped, Princess Peach. Instead of beginning your adventure as Mario, <a href=\"/yoshi/3005-700\" data-ref-id=\"3005-700\">Yoshi</a> is the first character you are able to play, who has woken up from his deep slumber. There is also a small event before you enter the castle in which you have to capture a rabbit with a key to the front door. Yoshi sets off into the castle in search of his friends, and you will soon be able to play as all four characters. Much of the rest of the main game is almost exactly like its predecessor, jumping into paintings, finding stars and defeating <a href=\"/bowser/3005-337\" data-ref-id=\"3005-337\">Bowser</a>.</p><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/4344/194865-super_mario_64_ds__2_.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-194865\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.75\" data-width=\"256\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 256px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:75.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/4344/194865-super_mario_64_ds__2_.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-194865\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/4344/194865-super_mario_64_ds__2_.jpg\"/></a><figcaption>Mario inflated</figcaption></figure><p>The control scheme was a big issue as it used to be played using a analogue stick on the N64, which does not exist on the DS. Nintendo came up with a solution of using the touch screen as an analog stick. The controls can be changed to suit both right and left-handed play styles. During gameplay, pressing select will immediately bring up the \"Control Modes\" screen which provide the three following options.</p><h4>Standard Mode</h4><p>This mode uses the D-pad for movement. Holding Y will cause the character to dash. You can also perform a charge dash by holding Y, then pressing a direction on the D-pad will cause the player character to move immediately in the desired direction.</p><h4>Touch Mode</h4><p>The original Nintendo DS models came with a wrist strap with a thumb piece used to simulate analog control on the touch screen. A circle will appear on the touch screen indicating the speed the player character will move in. The circle will move if you try to slide off of the circle's radius. Letting go allows you to set a new neutral point on the touch screen controls.</p><h4>Dual-Hand Mode</h4><p>This mode allows for the use of a stylus for analog control. A bigger circle will appear on the touch screen which indicates the player's speed. It functions similarly to how the circle behaves in Touch Mode, however you can also use the D-pad for functions similar to the face buttons. This is suited for those who use the NIntendo DS on a flat system.</p><p>Throughout the castle grounds you'll often notice small bunnies hopping around wildly. Though they may seem just for decoration, they're actually a small challenge for you. Each rabbit you catch unlocks a new mini-game in Princess Peach's Rec Room. Each of the four characters has seven rabbits to catch\u2014below is a list of their locations. The easiest way to catch the rabbits is to chase them into a corner and dive at them. They always run in a pattern, giving you a chance to predict where they go next.</p><h2>Characters</h2><h3>Yoshi</h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-size=\"medium\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/14097/791469-920758_20041007_screen009.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-791469\" data-ratio=\"1.4742647058824\" data-width=\"272\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 272px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:147.4%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/14097/791469-920758_20041007_screen009.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-791469\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_medium/1/14097/791469-920758_20041007_screen009.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_medium/1/14097/791469-920758_20041007_screen009.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Yoshi in Dry Dry Desert.</figcaption></figure><p>You begin the game as <a href=\"/yoshi/3005-700\" data-ref-id=\"3005-700\"> Yoshi</a>, and until you collect eight stars total he's the only character you can play as. Yoshi has a few unique abilities, including his \"floaty\" jump. If you jump and hold down the jump button in mid-air, Yoshi's legs will flutter underneath him, letting him float a little further than normal. Also, Yoshi can fire eggs as projectiles. To lay an egg you'll have to first grab an enemy with Yoshi's tongue and then press the crouch button. These eggs will ricochet off of multiple enemies if you line 'em up right, too!</p><p>The unique ability that lets Yoshi solve puzzles others can't is his ability to breathe fire. Break open a red \"?\" block and grab the power flower to Yoshi fire breath for a short period of time. His fire breath can be used to melt ice blocks, or to damage enemies.</p><p>He's also the only character that does not fight with his fists, therefore he is unable to fight ghosts, which also means you cannot enter Big Boo's Haunt as Yoshi.</p><p><b>How to Unlock: </b></p><p>You don't need to unlock Yoshi\u2014he's available at the very start of the game!</p><h3>Mario</h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/1851/203846-dm64_comparison.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-203846\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.55389221556886\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:55.4%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/1851/203846-dm64_comparison.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-203846\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/1851/203846-dm64_comparison.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/1851/203846-dm64_comparison.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Graphical comparison between SM64DS (left), and SM64 (right)</figcaption></figure><p><a href=\"/mario/3005-177\" data-ref-id=\"3005-177\"> Mario</a></p><p>is probably the most versatile character in the game, though Luigi runs a close second. Mario is very maneuverable and quick, and his most unique ability is his wall kick. Only Mario can jump off of walls to gain extra height, which will let you reach certain areas that other characters can't (or just take shortcuts that are beyond the reach of others).</p><p>When Mario grabs a power flower he'll inflate and float around. You can change Mario's altitude by rapidly tapping the jump button, letting Mario reach vertical platforms that are out of reach to others. Also, some red \"?\" boxes will give Mario a feather instead of a power flower. With this feather, Mario can glide through the air to reach new areas. You can start flying either by shooting out of a cannon or by performing a triple jump.</p><p><strong>How to Unlock:</strong></p><p>You first need eight power stars before you can unlock Mario. When you've got the first eight, go to the</p><p><em>Goomboss Battle</em></p><p>behind Princess Peach's room and defeat the Goomboss.</p><h3>Luigi</h3><p><a href=\"/luigi/3005-370\" data-ref-id=\"3005-370\"> Luigi</a>'s greatest strength is in his jumps. Like Yoshi, Luigi can sort of hover in mid-air for a second by holding the jump button. More importantly, Luigi has a very unique back flip technique. Luigi's back flip goes higher than anyone else's, and as Luigi falls from his back flip he slowly twirls down to the ground. You can use this back flip to reach high places, <em>or</em> to glide across large gaps that other characters can't jump across. To perform a back flip, just jump while crouching.</p><figure data-align=\"left\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/31/10599-luigi_mp.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-10599\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"1.2016129032258\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:120.2%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/31/10599-luigi_mp.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-10599\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/31/10599-luigi_mp.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/31/10599-luigi_mp.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Luigi </figcaption></figure><p>Have Luigi grab a power flower and he'll turn invisible. While invisible, Luigi has the special ability to pass through certain objects, including certain paintings, mirrors, and especially cages. Since the invisibility only lasts a short time, you'll have to be quick to get to your goal once you grab the power flower with Luigi.</p><p><strong>How to Unlock:</strong></p><p>Once you've collected the first eight power stars you can then access the</p><p><em>Big Boo's Haunt</em></p><p>course in the basement. After earning the first star in the course, a set of steps will appear in the main house that lead to the second level. Through the door to the east (upstairs) is a secret loft with a painting of Luigi. Complete the</p><p><em>Big Boo Challenge </em>to unlock Luigi.</p><h3>Wario</h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-size=\"medium\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/14097/791482-920758_20041119_screen011.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-791482\" data-ratio=\"1.3157894736842\" data-width=\"342\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 342px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:131.6%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/14097/791482-920758_20041119_screen011.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-791482\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_medium/1/14097/791482-920758_20041119_screen011.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_medium/1/14097/791482-920758_20041119_screen011.jpg\"/></noscript></a></figure><p><a href=\"/wario/3005-24\" data-ref-id=\"3005-24\"> Wario</a> is easily the most difficult character to play as. He's slower than everyone else, has shorter jumps, and is generally less wieldy. However, what he lacks in maneuverability he more than makes up for in raw power. Wario's strength is unique, and he's the only character in the game that is capable of busting open the black-brick blocks that are located in some of the courses.</p><p>Wario's special power flower ability will turn him into a giant hunk of metal. When Wario is in metal form he's nearly immovable\u2014strong winds won't be able to push him from cliffs, and even powerful water currents can't budge him. You can use this unique ability to get Wario into places that other characters just can't reach.</p><p><strong>How to Unlock:</strong> You won't be able to unlock Wario until after you've collected thirty power stars. When you unlock the second floor of the castle, head up there with Luigi. Grab the power flower in a nearby room and jump through the mirror to hop into the painting of Wario and complete the <em>Chief Chilly Challenge</em>.</p><h2>Recreational Room (Mini Games)</h2><p>In addition to the main game, Super Mario 64 DS also has a mini-game mode that utilizes much of the touch screen controls. Divided into four sections representing the four characters, each section hosts a different variety of mini-games. Yoshi's mini-games include Wanted, a game where you have to find a character in a sea of impostors, and a Luigi's Mansion mini-game with the objective of using your stylus as a flashlight to detect a <a href=\"/boo/3005-943\" data-ref-id=\"3005-943\">Boo</a>, among others. Mario's mini-games include a couple platforming-jumping games with the objective to squash the <a href=\"/shy-guy/3005-940\" data-ref-id=\"3005-940\">Shy Guys</a> and prevent Mario from falling, a couple of puzzle mini-games where you have to draw the path of a falling Mario head to keep it away from the piranha plants, and a turtle shell-bowling game with the objective to get as many points as possible. Luigi's mini-game section includes many casino-style gambling games like roulette and memory. Wario's mini-games include a missile-command style bomb-omb game, and a snow-ball game. Several of these games and more are unlockable as you play throughout the game.Several of these minigames were included as extas in <a href=\"/new-super-mario-bros/3025-1546\" data-ref-id=\"3025-1546\">New Super Mario Bros</a> when it was released two years later/</p><h2>Versus Mode</h2><p>The last additional feature Super Mario 64 DS has is a versus mode. In this mode, you can compete against your friends in levels such as Princess's Secret Slide, Castle Grounds, Sunshine Isles and Battle Fort. The main objective is to collect as many stars as you can.</p><h2>Reception</h2><p>As of March 31 2016, Super Mario 64 DS has sold 11.06 million copies worldwide.</p>", "deck": "A remake of the original Nintendo 64 classic, Super Mario 64 DS adds 30 new stars, three new playable characters and 36 mini-games utilizing the touch screen.", "aliases": null, "image": {"icon_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/vic-mignogna/3040-89834/", "id": 89834, "name": "Vic Mignogna"}, {"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/person/3040-34971/", "site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/quinton-flynn/3040-34971/", "id": 34971, "name": "Quinton Flynn"}, {"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/person/3040-88794/", "site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/colleen-oshaughnessey/3040-88794/", "id": 88794, "name": "Colleen O'Shaughnessey"}, {"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/person/3040-97384/", "site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/keith-silverstein/3040-97384/", "id": 97384, "name": "Keith Silverstein"}, {"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/person/3040-89891/", "site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/michelle-ruff/3040-89891/", "id": 89891, "name": "Michelle Ruff"}, {"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/person/3040-14105/", "site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/karen-strassman/3040-14105/", "id": 14105, "name": "Karen Strassman"}, {"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/person/3040-98590/", "site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/travis-willingham/3040-98590/", "id": 98590, "name": "Travis Willingham"}, {"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/person/3040-49569/", "site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/mitsuo-iwata/3040-49569/", "id": 49569, "name": "Mitsuo Iwata"}, {"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/person/3040-90551/", "site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/mike-pollock/3040-90551/", "id": 90551, "name": "Mike Pollock"}], "description": "<h2>Overview</h2><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/11512/1384169-4639658251_54f56822ec.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1384169\" data-size=\"small\" data-embed-type=\"image\" data-ratio=\"0.75\" data-width=\"320\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:75.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/11512/1384169-4639658251_54f56822ec.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1384169\"><img src=\"/uploads/scale_small/1/11512/1384169-4639658251_54f56822ec.jpg\"/></a></figure><p><i>Sonic Colors</i> (<i>Sonic Colours</i> in Europe) is either of two action platforming titles from <a data-ref-id=\"3010-62\" href=\"/sega/3010-62\">Sega</a>, <a data-ref-id=\"3010-781\" href=\"/sonic-team/3010-781\">Sonic Team</a> and <a data-ref-id=\"3010-119\" href=\"/dimps-corporation/3010-119\">Dimps</a> -- one for <a data-ref-id=\"3045-36\" href=\"/wii/3045-36\">Nintendo Wii</a>, the other an offshoot title for <a data-ref-id=\"3045-52\" href=\"/nintendo-ds/3045-52\">Nintendo DS</a>. It brings a distinct new setting to the Sonic series, going after the fantastical rather than realism, and takes inspiration from games like <a data-ref-id=\"3025-1347\" href=\"/super-mario-galaxy/3025-1347\">Mario Galaxy</a> to become an evolution of the <a data-ref-id=\"3030-7852\" href=\"/sonic-adventure/3030-7852\">3D Sonic games</a>, as opposed to the throwback to the 2D classics like <a data-ref-id=\"3030-28078\" href=\"/sonic-the-hedgehog-4-episode-1/3030-28078\">Sonic 4</a>.</p><p>There are two <i>Sonic Colors</i> games: a full 3D one for <a data-ref-id=\"3045-36\" href=\"/wii/3045-36\">Wii</a>, and a 2D one for <a data-ref-id=\"3045-52\" href=\"/nintendo-ds/3045-52\">Nintendo DS</a>, and both were released on November 16, 2010. Sega has stated that if <i>Sonic Colors</i> for Wii sells well enough, they might port the game to the <a data-ref-id=\"3045-35\" href=\"/playstation-3/3045-35\">Playstation 3</a> and <a data-ref-id=\"3045-20\" href=\"/xbox-360/3045-20\">Xbox 360</a>. However, a version for Playstation 3 or Xbox 360 has yet to be announced, even over a year after <i>Sonic Colors</i> for Wii was released.</p><h2>Sonic Colors for Wii</h2><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/2/27239/1403723-4701737511_b0a9a7957d_b.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1403723\" data-size=\"medium\" data-embed-type=\"image\" data-ratio=\"0.599609375\" data-width=\"480\" style=\"width: 480px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:60.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/2/27239/1403723-4701737511_b0a9a7957d_b.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1403723\"><img src=\"/uploads/scale_medium/2/27239/1403723-4701737511_b0a9a7957d_b.jpg\"/></a><figcaption>Sonic explores Tropical Resort.</figcaption></figure><p>The Wii game is a spiritual sequel to the ''daytime'' Sonic stages of <a data-ref-id=\"3030-20953\" href=\"/sonic-unleashed/3030-20953\">Sonic Unleashed</a>. The stages are in full 3D in which Sonic can run and jump in any direction, periodically changing to a fixed 2D perspective for gameplay along a 2D plane, reminiscent of the original <a data-ref-id=\"3045-6\" href=\"/genesis/3045-6\">Genesis/Megadrive</a> Sonic titles. The 2D part of the stages take up roughly half of the levels, with plenty of vertical level design for platforming. The 3D segments, however, are narrow, and encourage high speed acrobatics.</p><p>But unlike Sonic Unleashed's gameplay, Sonic Colors allows the speedy rodent to collect Wisps, colorful floating aliens that give him special abilities upon flicking the Wii remote. (Unless the player opts out of motion controls and uses a Wii Classic Controller, which the game supports.) These power-ups include abilities such turning into a drill that lets Sonic dig through rock or water, or increasing his speed while he bounces from the walls like a laser. Only one Wisp can be used at a time, and the power-ups have a guage that tell you how long they will last.</p><figure data-align=\"left\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/2/27239/1403725-4702369776_3b35f6a132_b.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1403725\" data-size=\"medium\" data-embed-type=\"image\" data-ratio=\"0.599609375\" data-width=\"480\" style=\"width: 480px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:60.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/2/27239/1403725-4702369776_3b35f6a132_b.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1403725\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"/uploads/scale_medium/2/27239/1403725-4702369776_3b35f6a132_b.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"/uploads/scale_medium/2/27239/1403725-4702369776_3b35f6a132_b.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Sonic rides the rail in Sweet Mountain Zone.</figcaption></figure><p>The levels are sizable and feature a very large amount of hidden paths and items, mostly accessible only with a specific power-up. For example, there are various pockets of air underground that contain hidden emblems and <a href=\"../../gold-rings/93-84/\" rel=\"nofollow\">rings</a> that require a drill to access, but if you don't keep an eye on your gauge, the power-rup will run out of juice before you can get there, causing Sonic to literally be buried in his grave.</p><p>Sonic is the only playable character in Sonic Colors for Wii. This is also the first game in the Sonic series, along with <a data-ref-id=\"3030-31719\" href=\"/sonic-free-riders/3030-31719\">Sonic Free Riders</a>, to use his new voice actor.</p><h2>Sonic Colors for DS</h2><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/1450/1453822-20570sweet_mountain_4.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1453822\" data-size=\"small\" data-embed-type=\"image\" data-ratio=\"1.5\" data-width=\"256\" style=\"width: 256px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:150.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/1450/1453822-20570sweet_mountain_4.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1453822\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"/uploads/scale_small/0/1450/1453822-20570sweet_mountain_4.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"/uploads/scale_small/0/1450/1453822-20570sweet_mountain_4.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Sweet Mountain Zone on the Nintendo DS</figcaption></figure><p>The DS game is a spiritual sequel to <a data-ref-id=\"3030-9479\" href=\"/sonic-rush/3030-9479\">Sonic Rush</a> and <a data-ref-id=\"3030-12778\" href=\"/sonic-rush-adventure/3030-12778\">Sonic Rush Adventure</a>. The stages are in full 2D, with the boss battles in full 3D, expanding to both screens of the handheld. It also incorporates the Boost Gauge from Dimps' previous games. However, like the Wii version, the Wisps also make an appearance and function as powerups, two of which are exclusive to the DS version. Each Wisp can also activate certain stage mechanisms, like igniting a rocket that allows Sonic to fly over a large segment of the stage.</p><p>The bosses from the DS game will not be available on the Wii game, and the Wii bosses will not appear on the DS game. However, the DS levels make a cameo appearance in the backgrounds of the Wii game, while the same goes for the Wii version of the DS levels, giving the impression that each version shows a different view of the same world.</p><h2>Story</h2><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/11512/1384178-4640469436_708c23f35c.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1384178\" data-size=\"small\" data-embed-type=\"image\" data-ratio=\"1.2165450121655\" data-width=\"320\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:121.7%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/11512/1384178-4640469436_708c23f35c.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1384178\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"/uploads/scale_small/1/11512/1384178-4640469436_708c23f35c.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"/uploads/scale_small/1/11512/1384178-4640469436_708c23f35c.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Poster for Eggman's amusement park.</figcaption></figure><p>Interested in the native Wisps, <a data-ref-id=\"3005-293\" href=\"/dr-robotnik/3005-293\">Dr. Egggman (aka Robotnik)</a> has pulled their home planets together using a large tractor beam, and converted each planet into a large amusement park. Each planet was given a theme, with one planet being a full Las Vegas casino, another filled by mountains of giant donuts and candy, and another converted into a tropical water park.</p><p>Dr. Robotnik controls the theme park and periodically speaks through the PA system to rant about his opinions on the world, the amusement park costumers, Sonic the Hedgehog, and someone leaving their car's lights on in the parking lot. Each Wisp Sonic finds will help him defeat the boss battle of the attractions, using their specific abilities to exploit the stage and their weaknesses.</p><p>The story is written by the writers of <a data-ref-id=\"3030-21173\" href=\"/madworld/3030-21173\">MadWorld</a>.</p><h2>Development</h2><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/5911/1459949-planet_wisp_1_1_6.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1459949\" data-size=\"small\" data-embed-type=\"image\" data-ratio=\"1.5390625\" data-width=\"256\" style=\"width: 256px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:153.9%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/5911/1459949-planet_wisp_1_1_6.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1459949\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"/uploads/scale_small/0/5911/1459949-planet_wisp_1_1_6.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"/uploads/scale_small/0/5911/1459949-planet_wisp_1_1_6.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Sonic Colors (DS)</figcaption></figure><p>Developed by the same team that created <a data-ref-id=\"3030-2512\" href=\"/sonic-and-the-secret-rings/3030-2512\">Sonic and the Secret Rings</a> and <a data-ref-id=\"3030-21247\" href=\"/sonic-and-the-black-knight/3030-21247\">Sonic and the Black Knight</a>, they wanted to again bring Sonic to play in a new world he has never gone to before, this time a very large and dangerous amusement park. Development began as a watered down Wii version of Sonic Generations, but SEGA executives wanted another Sonic game to roll out in holiday 2010, so the project became Sonic Colors. After the bad receptions of <a data-ref-id=\"3030-20584\" href=\"/sonic-the-hedgehog/3030-20584\">Sonic 2006</a>, Sonic Unleashed, and Black Knight, they decided to move away from getting the hedgehog to do realistic human things, and go back to the more imaginative and fantastical ideas that fit the character better.</p><blockquote><p><b>\"By adding game elements that didn't fit with Sonic's traditional sense of speed, I think the recent titles in the series have failed to play to Sonic's strengths.\"</b><br />-Takashi Iizuka, producer</p></blockquote><figure data-align=\"left\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/5911/1459920-sweet_factory___4_.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1459920\" data-size=\"medium\" data-embed-type=\"image\" data-ratio=\"0.59982638888889\" data-width=\"480\" style=\"width: 480px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:60.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/5911/1459920-sweet_factory___4_.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1459920\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"/uploads/scale_medium/0/5911/1459920-sweet_factory___4_.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"/uploads/scale_medium/0/5911/1459920-sweet_factory___4_.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Sonic Colors (Wii)</figcaption></figure><p>The producer for the game, <a data-ref-id=\"3040-33657\" href=\"/takashi-iizuka/3040-33657\">Takashi Iizuka</a>, began by bringing Sonic to a new, more cartoon-like sense of style, with brighter colors and more imaginative surroundings and characters. Described as a game primarily aimed for kids, the team decided to base each stage on a popular theme park attraction, and then blow it up to fit an entire planet.</p><p>This time they tried to let Sonic do something that made sense to his character, unlike their previous attempts at making him a were-hog or letting him handle a sword. When asked about Sonic, people always come up with speed, but the developers could not find any way to make Sonic's speed a main part of the gameplay, so they came up with a transformation system that gave him moves that fit with the nature of speed, like allowing him to pass through walls of rock or run over water. They made sure for those powerups to remain a temporary transformation so that they do not dominate the gameplay, and keep Sonic always in motion with his traditional abilities.</p><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/8/80248/1421710-sonic_colors_32_noscale.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1421710\" data-size=\"medium\" data-embed-type=\"image\" data-ratio=\"0.6\" data-width=\"480\" style=\"width: 480px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:60.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/8/80248/1421710-sonic_colors_32_noscale.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1421710\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"/uploads/scale_medium/8/80248/1421710-sonic_colors_32_noscale.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"/uploads/scale_medium/8/80248/1421710-sonic_colors_32_noscale.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Drilling on a 2D segment.</figcaption></figure><p>While <a data-ref-id=\"3030-28078\" href=\"/sonic-the-hedgehog-4-episode-1/3030-28078\">Sonic the Hedgehog 4</a> is meant for the Sonic crowd that prefers the older games, this game is made for the audience that prefers the 3D games. Aiming both games at different markets keep them from competing against each other. However, fans say that it is unavoidable, with classic Sonic fans complaining that speed is entirely the wrong way to go with the series, claiming that platforming was the basis for the character. However, bad press from the Sonic 4 leaks, and positive impressions from the E3 demos of this game brought more hype for Sonic Colors.</p>", "releases": [{"api_detail_url": {"duration": "0:18:00", "runner": "Celestics", "data": {"site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/sonic-riders/3030-15802/", "expected_release_quarter": null, "description": "<h2>Overview</h2><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/7465/872422-sonicriders1.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-872422\" data-size=\"small\" data-embed-type=\"image\" data-ratio=\"0.7998046875\" data-width=\"320\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:80.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/7465/872422-sonicriders1.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-872422\"><img src=\"/uploads/scale_small/0/7465/872422-sonicriders1.jpg\"/></a><figcaption>A wallpaper with many of the characters in the game.</figcaption></figure><p>Sonic Riders is a spin-off of the <a data-ref-id=\"3025-383\" href=\"/sonic-the-hedgehog/3025-383\">Sonic the Hedgehog</a> franchise in which <a data-ref-id=\"3005-73\" href=\"/sonic-the-hedgehog/3005-73\">Sonic</a> and his friends face off in a futuristic hoverboard racing setting. The game was developed by <a data-ref-id=\"3010-781\" href=\"/sonic-team/3010-781\">Sonic Team</a> and published by <a data-ref-id=\"3010-62\" href=\"/sega/3010-62\">Sega</a> for the Nintendo GameCube, PlayStation 2, Xbox, and PC. The game was originally released to kick off the 15th anniversary for the Sonic the Hedgehog franchise. As part of this celebration, the Xbox version (for a short while) shipped with a DVD containing the first five episodes of Sonic X. The game was released on February 21, 2006. Sonic Riders even had an Archie Comics adaptation of the game.</p><p>The game's reception was relatively mediocre. Reviews ranged from eights to fives. Game Rankings lists the GameCube version as the highest rated with a 63.1% rating, then the PlayStation 2 version with 59.7%, the Xbox version with 59%, and last the PC version with 43.3%.</p><h2>Gameplay</h2><p>Sonic Riders is a traditional racing game in the same vein as <a data-ref-id=\"3025-180\" href=\"/f-zero/3025-180\">F-Zero</a> and <a data-ref-id=\"3025-205\" href=\"/wipeout/3025-205\">Wipeout</a>. Players can choose a character, each with different stats that slightly alter their performance during the game. In addition, the player can select a board or even other vehicles to use as they are unlocked, and each affects the performance of the character during the race. There are a total of fourteen tracks to race on, seven of which must be unlocked through the game's story mode, and two that must be unlocked by winning Gold in the World Grand Prix. The key feature of the game is a small air gauge in the corner of the screen. Air is essentially the fuel for the Extreme Gear, and is depleted slowly as the race goes on. Air is also depleted when the player performs certain maneuvers, such as boosting. Air can be gained at some stations along the way (when out of air, the character runs along the track slowly while carrying their board), as well as by doing well in tricks. Rings on the track \"level up\" the player, allowing them to carry more air (at the start of each race, the player is restarted to Level 1).</p><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/3699/457731-48327_28_2.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-457731\" data-size=\"small\" data-embed-type=\"image\" data-ratio=\"0.69965277777778\" data-width=\"320\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:70.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/3699/457731-48327_28_2.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-457731\"><img src=\"/uploads/scale_small/0/3699/457731-48327_28_2.jpg\"/></a><figcaption>Performing a trick.</figcaption></figure><p>Each character has one of three attributes: Speed, Flight, or Power. The main benefit to these attributes is what it allows the character to do during a race. The Speed attribute allows characters to grind on rails along the track for a good shortcut. The Flight attribute allows characters to \"fly\" over certain portions of the track, triggered by rings. The Power attribute allows characters to destroy obstacles that make shortcuts for the character to go on. Each maneuver for these attributes will refill the air gauge as well. Because most characters' stats are similar, their attribute is a point of interest.</p><p>There are three types of Extreme Gear available in the game: Boards, Skates, and Bikes. Boards are the only gear unlocked at the beginning of the game, and is the all-around gear. The Skates have lower performance, but use up less air, and the Bikes have higher performance, but use up more air. Some characters can only use one of the three types, limiting options.</p><h3>Playable Characters</h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/16291/494722-chara_jet_1_.gif\" data-ref-id=\"1300-494722\" data-size=\"small\" data-embed-type=\"image\" data-ratio=\"1.1062271062271\" data-width=\"273\" style=\"width: 273px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:110.6%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/16291/494722-chara_jet_1_.gif\" Hawk</figcaption></figure><ul><li>Sonic the Hedgehog</li><li><a data-ref-id=\"3005-5697\" href=\"/jet-the-hawk/3005-5697\">Jet the Hawk</a></li><li><a data-ref-id=\"3005-45\" href=\"/dr-eggman/3005-293\">Dr. Eggman</a></li><li><a data-ref-id=\"3005-948\" href=\"/amy-rose/3005-948\">Amy Rose</a></li><li><a data-ref-id=\"3005-811\" href=\"/shadow-the-hedgehog/3005-811\">Shadow the Hedgehog</a></li><li><a data-ref-id=\"3005-2366\" href=\"/rouge-the-bat/3005-2366\">Rouge the Bat</a></li><li><a data-ref-id=\"3005-4691\" href=\"/cream-the-rabbit/3005-4691\">Cream the Rabbit</a></li><li><a data-ref-id=\"3005-690\" href=\"/aiai/3005-690\">AiAi</a></li><li><a data-ref-id=\"3005-31\" href=\"/ulala/3005-31\">Ulala</a></li><li>Omochao</li><li>E-10000G</li><li>E-10000R</li><li><a data-ref-id=\"3005-1319\" href=\"/nights/3005-1319\">Nights</a></li><li>Super Sonic</li></ul><h2>Plot</h2><p>The game opens with Sonic and Tails walking in Future City, again searching for the Chaos Emeralds. All of the sudden, Tails's radar goes off and three mysterious riders fly by. Sonic pursues them on foot (as the radar is detecting they are carrying a Chaos Emerald), and knocks one of the three off their board. He quickly catches up to the leader, but is outmaneuvered. The next day, Dr. Eggman announces that he will be hosting a World Grand Prix. The entrance fee is one Chaos Emerald, and the winner \"takes all!\" Sonic recognizes the three riders as a few of the entrants, and decides to enter himself. The race will be on Extreme Gear, a type of hoverboard that the three riders were using. The three riders are later revealed to be the Babylong Rogues, consisting of Jet the Hawk, Wave the Swallow, and Storm the Albatross.</p><h2>PC System Requirements</h2><ul><li>Windows 2000/XP</li><li>1GHz Pentium III/AMD Processor</li><li>128MB RAM</li><li>64MB VRAM DirectX 3D Compatible Video Card</li><li>3GB Hard Disk Space</li><li>640x480 16 Bit (High Color) Display</li><li>12X CD ROM Drive</li><li>DirectX 9.0C</li><li>DirectX Sound Card</li><li>RECOMMENDED</li><li>1.4GHz Pentium 4</li><li>256 MB RAM</li><li>640x480 24/32 Bit (True Color) Display</li></ul>", "deck": "Sonic Riders stars Sonic and his friends, and their quest to win in the World Grand Prix. Their new rivals are the Babylon Rogues, a mysterious group that has information about the Chaos Emeralds.", "aliases": null, "image": {"icon_url":
