{"duration": "0:45:00", "runner": "Talon2461", "data": {"site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/sonic-adventure-2-battle/3030-6845/", "expected_release_quarter": null, "description": "<h2>Summary</h2><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/8/83448/1370794-sonic_adventure_2_battle_title_screen.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1370794\" data-size=\"medium\" style=\"width: 480px\" data-ratio=\"0.75971223021583\" data-width=\"480\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:76.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/8/83448/1370794-sonic_adventure_2_battle_title_screen.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1370794\"><img src=\"/uploads/scale_medium/8/83448/1370794-sonic_adventure_2_battle_title_screen.jpg\"/></a><figcaption>The title screen to the game.</figcaption></figure><p><a data-ref-id=\"3030-19060\" href=\"/sonic-adventure-2/3030-19060\">Sonic Adventure 2</a> was one of the final Dreamcast releases to come directly from Sega before the system was discontinued in 2001; the game was slightly tweaked and ported to the GameCube shortly afterward, sporting new battle modes and Game Boy Advance connectivity, and furthered the precedent set by <a data-ref-id=\"3030-14191\" href=\"/sonic-advance/3030-14191\">Sonic Advance</a> of Sonic the Hedgehog appearing for the first time on a Nintendo system. The game most notably introduced two major characters: <a data-ref-id=\"3005-811\" href=\"/shadow-the-hedgehog/3005-811\">Shadow the Hedgehog</a>, a black hedgehog with upward-curled quills, amnesia problems, and a singular focus on finding out his reason for existence, and <a data-ref-id=\"3005-2366\" href=\"/rouge-the-bat/3005-2366\">Rouge the Bat</a>, a large-breasted treasure hunter who harbors a healthy obsession with jewels, both of whom appear in more subsequent games than any new character introduced afterward.</p><p>Where Sonic Adventure 2's predecessor was focused on telling a multilayered story with numerous protagonists, this game took a more refined approach; instead of selecting which individual character to play as when starting the adventure, the choice was only between which faction to play, \"Hero\" (featuring <a data-ref-id=\"3005-73\" href=\"/sonic-the-hedgehog/3005-73\">Sonic</a>, <a data-ref-id=\"3005-45\" href=\"/tails/3005-45\">Tails</a>, and <a data-ref-id=\"3005-204\" href=\"/knuckles/3005-204\">Knuckles</a>) or \"Dark\" (featuring Shadow, <a data-ref-id=\"3005-293\" href=\"/dr-eggman/3005-293\">Eggman</a>, and Rouge), and experiencing the same events from the perspective of either set of characters. In terms of gameplay, both sport similar styles (though Dark assumes that the Hero campaign has been completed first, and is noticeably more difficult in comparison); Sonic/Shadow stages focus on running through stages that have been streamlined for speed, Tails/Eggman stages feature their characters piloting mechanical walking units with ballistic/missile capabilities, and Knuckles/Rouge stages deal with their characters flying around enormous stages to find objects (usually shards of the Master Emerald) in groups of three, usually to eclectic and interesting music.</p><p>An additional feature of Sonic Adventure 2 was the inclusion of an improved Chao Garden from the original <a data-ref-id=\"3030-7852\" href=\"/sonic-adventure/3030-7852\">Sonic Adventure</a>. After levels, players are able to find Chao Boxes that contain a key to enter Chao World after completing the level. After unlocking Chao World, it can also be accessed from the mission selection screen. After hatching Chao, they can participate in Chao Races and Chao Karate. In order to do well, it is important to raise the Chao's skills. To do so, players can collect Chaos Drives, animals, or feed the Chao fruit. After some time, Chao can evolve to adult forms that depend on what type of character, Hero or Dark, was used to raise it and what stat is the highest.</p><h2>Plot</h2><p>Hoping to find some sort of weapon, Dr. Eggman unseals his grandfather's greatest invention, Project Shadow, for the first time in 50 years. What he finds instead is a black hedgehog, claiming his name is Shadow. Now free, Shadow promises to grant Doctor Eggman one wish - but first he must meet him at the Space Colony ARK.</p><figure data-align=\"left\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/18205/611779-son2dc002.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-611779\" data-size=\"small\" style=\"width: 320px\" data-ratio=\"0.74857142857143\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:74.9%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/18205/611779-son2dc002.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-611779\"><img src=\"/uploads/scale_small/1/18205/611779-son2dc002.jpg\"/></a><figcaption>\"I'm outta here!\"</figcaption></figure><p>A week later, Sonic the Hedgehog finds himself on the run from the Military Organization, G.U.N (Guardian Unit of Nations), who claim Sonic is a dangerous criminal. Unaware of what is going on, Sonic attempts to avoid capture when he encounters Shadow the Hedgehog, who is in the middle of stealing a Chaos Emerald. Putting two and two together, Sonic assumes the Military is mistaking Shadow for Sonic (and vice versa), and this \"fake\" Hedgehog is the reason Sonic is in so much trouble. Before Sonic can engage Shadow in battle, however, Shadow vanishes in to thin air using a power called \"Chaos Control\", leaving Sonic surrounded by dozens of fully-armed G.U.N soldiers.</p><h3>Rouge's Report</h3><p>After Sonic Adventure 2 hit retail, SonicTeam published the Official Sonic Adventure 2 Strategy Guide in Japan, which contained \"The Last Report on Project Shadow\", written by the in-game character Rouge the Bat, in an effort to uncover the mystery of who - or what Shadow is, and where he came from. A summary of the report follows:</p><blockquote><p>50 years ago, the current President of Nations contracted Professor Gerald Robotnik to research the possibility of immortality. Gerald initially refused, comparing it to to playing God. But when his niece, Maria Robotnik, contracted the terminal (and as-of-yet incurable) disease NIDS (Neuro-Immuno Deficiency Syndrome), Gerald reconsidered the project as a means to extend her life. The top-secret \"Project Shadow\" (as it became to be known due to the secrecy of the research) took place on the Space Colony known as ARK and began researching the effects of Chaos Emeralds on living tissue.<br /><br />One experiment, designed to accelerate the rate of cell regeneration seen in some species of lizards, turned disastrous - the \"Biolizard\" subject grew ten times its normal size and became violent, nearly killing several scientists before being contained. When Military Organization G.U.N learned of the disaster aboard the ARK, they sprung in to action in order to silence Project Shadow (violently, if necessary). When they arrived aboard the ARK, Professor Gerald was already putting the finishing touches on what he called the \"Ultimate Life-form\", an immortal black hedgehog, named after the project he was born from: Shadow. Not knowing what the military would do with something like Shadow, Gerald entrusted Maria to take him to an escape pod and head down to the planet below.<br /><br />They were intercepted by G.U.N soldiers, who, in an effort to kill Shadow, accidentally shoot Maria. With her last dying breath, she sealed Shadow in the escape pod and ejected him to earth. When Professor Gerald heard the news of his niece's death, he flew in to a rage; the very project he took part in to save her life ended up being the key to her death. Before being captured by G.U.N and sentenced to death for the \"accident\" on ARK, Professor Gerald gave Shadow strict instructions to carry out his revenge for what happened to Maria. Shadow was sealed in stasis to ensure that the truth about what happened on the ARK was never revealed.</p></blockquote><h2>Other Info</h2><p>2 players simultaneous</p><p>Memory blocks needed: <b>11</b></p><p>Game Boy Advance compatible</p><h2>Levels</h2><h3>Hero</h3><ul><li><b>SONIC</b>: City Escape</li><li><b>KNUCKLES</b>: Wild Canyon</li><li><b>TAILS</b>: Prison Hair Band music styles to the game's soundtrack, and he is backed up by <a data-ref-id=\"3040-74739\" href=\"/fumie-kumatani/3040-74739\">Fumie Kumatani</a>, <a data-ref-id=\"3040-54819\" href=\"/kenichi-tokoi/3040-54819\">Kenichi Tokoi</a> and <a data-ref-id=\"3040-40721\" href=\"/tomoya-ohtani/3040-40721\">Tomoya Ohtani</a>. The game contains thirteen vocal tracks, some of which are simply remixes of themes from the original game:</p><ul><li>\"It Doesn't Matter - Theme of Sonic\" by Jun Senoue and Tony Harnell</li><li>\"Believe in Myself - Theme of Tails\" by Jun Senoue and Kaz Silver</li><li>\"Unknown from M.E. - Theme of Knuckles\" by Kenichi Tokoi, Marlon Saunders, and Hunnid-P</li><li>\"Throw it all Away - Theme of Shadow\" by Fumie Kumatani, Heigo Tani, and Everett Bradley</li><li>\"E.G.G.M.A.N. - Theme of Doctor Eggman\" by Jun Senoue and Paul Shortino</li><li>\"Fly in the Freedom - Theme of Rouge\" by Fumie Kumatani, Tabitha Fair, and Todd Cooper</li><li>\"Live and Learn - Main theme of Sonic Adventure 2\" by Jun Senoue and Johnny Gioeli from the band Crush 40</li><li>\"Escape from the City - ...for City Escape\" by Jun Senoue, Tony Harnell, and Ted Poley</li><li>\"Kick the Rock! - ...for Wild Canyon\" by Tomoya Ohtani</li><li>\"A Ghost's Pumpkin Soup - ...for Pumpkin Hill\" by Tomoya Ohtani</li><li>\"That's the way I Like It!\" For Metal Harbour by Jun Senoue</li><li>\"Rhythm and Balance\" For White Jungle</li><li>\"Dive Into The Mellow - ...For Aquatic Mine\" by Tomoya Ohtani</li><li>\"Deeper - ...for Death Chamber\" by Tomoya Ohtani</li><li>\"Space Trip Steps - ...for Meteor Herd\" by Tomoya Ohtani</li><li>'On the Edge\" for Eternal Engine</li></ul>", "deck": "Sonic and Shadow clash once more in this Dreamcast's swan song now ported to Gamecube, featuring the same sprawling, fast-moving story told from both sides of the conflict. The multiplayer mode also returns, this time with the option to play as Amy Rose and Metal Sonic.", "aliases": "SA2B", "image": {"icon_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/square_avatar/8/87790/1803648-box_sonicad2b.png", "medium_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_medium/8/87790/1803648-box_sonicad2b.png", "tiny_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/square_mini/8/87790/1803648-box_sonicad2b.png", "small_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/8/87790/1803648-box_sonicad2b.png", "thumb_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_avatar/8/87790/1803648-box_sonicad2b.png", "screen_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/screen_medium/8/87790/1803648-box_sonicad2b.png", "super_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_large/8/87790/1803648-box_sonicad2b.png"}, "date_last_updated": "2015-01-15 04:37:24", "expected_release_month": null, "api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/game/3030-6845/", "number_of_user_reviews": 5, "original_release_date": "2002-02-12 00:00:00", "original_game_rating": [{"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/game_rating/3065-6/", "id": 6, "name": "ESRB: E"}, {"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/game_rating/3065-7/", "id": 7, "name": "PEGI: 3+"}, {"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/game_rating/3065-19/", "id": 19, "name": "CERO: All Ages"}], "date_added": "2008-04-01 01:59:01", "platforms": [{"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/platform/3045-23/", "abbreviation": "GCN", "site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/gamecube/3045-23/", "id": 23, "name": "GameCube"}, {"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/platform/3045-94/", "abbreviation": "PC", "site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/pc/3045-94/", "id": 94, "name": "PC"}], "expected_release_day": null, "expected_release_year": null, "id": 6845, "resource_type": "game", "name": "Sonic Adventure 2: Battle"}, "platform": "PC", "title": "Sonic Adventure 2: Battle"}

data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:56.3%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/270/374120-929717_20060804_screen026.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-374120\"><img src=\"/uploads/scale_small/0/270/374120-929717_20060804_screen026.jpg\"/></a><figcaption>A new beginning.</figcaption></figure><p>Sonic's first title for the <a href=\"/xbox-360/3045-20\" data-ref-id=\"3045-20\">Xbox 360</a> and <a href=\"/playstation-3/3045-35\" data-ref-id=\"3045-35\">Playstation 3 </a>was supposed to be a new beginning for the franchise. Originally billed as a reboot for the series, the primary design goal for the game was to create a \"realistic\" Sonic game -- complete with a full-on <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/daynight-cycle/3015-92\" data-ref-id=\"3015-92\">day/night cycle</a>, physics-centric gameplay, and a huge world to explore. The game that ended up on store shelves was radically different: essentially another game broken out of the <a href=\"/sonic-adventure/3030-7852\" data-ref-id=\"3030-7852\">Sonic Adventure</a> gameplay mold, it contained unaltered game elements and concepts largely dating all the way back to 1999.</p><p>As per the formula established by Sonic Adventure, Sonic the Hedgehog (2006) is broken up in to multiple storylines: one for hero <a href=\"/sonic-the-hedgehog/3005-73\" data-ref-id=\"3005-73\">Sonic the Hedgehog</a>, another for rival <a href=\"/shadow-the-hedgehog/3005-811\" data-ref-id=\"3005-811\">Shadow the Hedgehog</a>, and a third story for the newcomer <a href=\"/silver-the-hedgehog/3005-1969\" data-ref-id=\"3005-1969\">Silver the Hedgehog</a>. Though each character has their own plot threads, paths frequently cross and storylines intersect. Like <a href=\"/sonic-adventure-2/3030-19060\" data-ref-id=\"3030-19060\">Sonic Adventure 2</a>, each of the three characters' campaigns does not represent just a single playable character, but a team of characters. For example, throughout the course of Sonic's story, one can expect to play portions of certain stages as <a href=\"/tails/3005-45\" data-ref-id=\"3005-45\">Tails</a>, or <a href=\"/knuckles/3005-204\" data-ref-id=\"3005-204\">Knuckles</a>. Likewise, players who choose Silver will at times be required to play as <a href=\"/blaze-the-cat/3005-2200\" data-ref-id=\"3005-2200\">Blaze the Cat</a> and <a href=\"/amy-rose/3005-948\" data-ref-id=\"3005-948\">Amy Rose</a>, and lastly, Shadow teams up with <a href=\"/rouge-the-bat/3005-2366\" data-ref-id=\"3005-2366\">Rouge the Bat</a> and <a href=\"/e-123-omega/3005-4068\" data-ref-id=\"3005-4068\">E-123 Omega</a> from <a href=\"/sonic-heroes/3030-9523\" data-ref-id=\"3030-9523\">Sonic Heroes</a>. Each character has abilities unique to them and can differ greatly from Sonic in terms of play style.</p><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/12968/342686-scsh300223.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-342686\" data-size=\"medium\" style=\"width: 480px\" data-ratio=\"0.56338028169014\" data-width=\"480\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:56.3%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/12968/342686-scsh300223.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-342686\"><img src=\"/uploads/scale_medium/1/12968/342686-scsh300223.jpg\"/></a></figure><p>The game is broken up in to two major modes: free-roaming \"Town Stages\" and more goal-oriented \"Action Stages\". A typical scenario involves exploring a Town Stage in order to find a way to access the next Action Stage, and once the level is complete, you're taken back to the Town Stage to repeat the process. Town Stages contain human <a href=\"/non-player-character/3015-967\" data-ref-id=\"3015-967\">NPCs</a>, which can offer hints on how to find the next Action Stage, or offer side missions to complete for money. A handful of shops exist around the game world's as well, which will sell upgrades that unlock new abilities.</p><p>New to the game is the \"Action Gauge\": a meter that determines how much of a special ability each character can use. When the gauge depletes, the special ability is unavailable until it recharges. For example, Silver the Hedgehog can only use his psychokinesis until the action gauge is empty.</p><p>Although Sonic's action gauge is always on-screen (just as it is for other characters) he possesses no abilities that deplete the action gauge - except for when he is carrying <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/princess-elise/3005-15639\" data-ref-id=\"3005-15639\">Princess Elise</a>, where it's used for a protective shield ability.</p><h2>Story</h2><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/5892/219280-sonic_the_hedgehog_ps3screenshots2769sonic_movie03.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-219280\" data-size=\"medium\" style=\"width: 480px\" data-ratio=\"0.5625\" data-width=\"480\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:56.3%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/5892/219280-sonic_the_hedgehog_ps3screenshots2769sonic_movie03.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-219280\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"/uploads/scale_medium/0/5892/219280-sonic_the_hedgehog_ps3screenshots2769sonic_movie03.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"/uploads/scale_medium/0/5892/219280-sonic_the_hedgehog_ps3screenshots2769sonic_movie03.jpg\"/></noscript></a></figure><p>In Soleanna, the City of Water, its people are holding a celebration marked by the lighting of a giant torch called the \"Sun of Soleanna\". During a fireworks display right at the ceremony's crescendo, Doctor Eggman launches a missile attack on the celebration, and uses the ensuing commotion to swoop down and attempt to kidnap the only surviving member of royalty: <a href=\"../../princess-elise/94-15639/\" rel=\"nofollow\">Princess Elise</a>. Eggman knows that contained inside of Princess Elise is a dark power known as \"The Flames of Disaster\", and he wants to use this power combined with the energy of the Chaos Emeralds to fuel \"Solaris\", a time machine of his own invention. With time travel firmly in his grasp, nothing would be able to stop Eggman from ruling the world.</p><figure data-align=\"left\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/3/32127/2182517-sonic_carrying_hooman.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2182517\" data-size=\"medium\" style=\"width: 480px\" data-ratio=\"0.5625\" data-width=\"480\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:56.3%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/3/32127/2182517-sonic_carrying_hooman.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2182517\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"/bundles/phoenixsite/images/core/loose/img_broken.png\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"/bundles/phoenixsite/images/core/loose/img_broken.png\"/></noscript></a></figure><p>Right on cue, Sonic the Hedgehog shows up to rescue the Princess. Unfortunately, a second ambush catches Sonic off guard, and he ultimately loses the Princess to the Doctor.</p><p>Watching this spectacle from the shadows is Silver the Hedgehog, who was sent from the future to kill Sonic, believing him to be the \"Iblis Trigger\". In the future, the world is in ruins caused by a destructive, sentient flame called \"Iblis\". Silver was brought to the past by a mysterious being called \"<a href=\"/mephiles-the-dark/3005-6830\" data-ref-id=\"3005-6830\">Mephiles</a>\" who has the power to travel through time. Mephiles informed Silver that it was Sonic who unleashed Iblis and is therefore the one responsible for destroying the world. If Sonic is killed in the past, Iblis will never be unleashed, and the future will be saved.</p><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/5892/219306-sonic_the_hedgehog_ps3screenshots2770sonic_movie04.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-219306\" data-size=\"medium\" style=\"width: 480px\" data-ratio=\"0.5625\" data-width=\"480\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:56.3%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/5892/219306-sonic_the_hedgehog_ps3screenshots2770sonic_movie04.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-219306\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"/uploads/scale_medium/0/5892/219306-sonic_the_hedgehog_ps3screenshots2770sonic_movie04.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"/uploads/scale_medium/0/5892/219306-sonic_the_hedgehog_ps3screenshots2770sonic_movie04.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Silver the Hedgehog.</figcaption></figure><p>Unknown to Silver, Mephiles is actually an evil entity who was supposed to be sealed inside the Scepter of Darkness centuries before Silver's time. Mephiles was accidentally released by Shadow the Hedgehog when he and Rouge the Bat attempted to steal the scepter from Dr. Eggman. Much to Shadow's confusion, Mephiles somehow seems to know who Shadow is, as if they had a previous encounter - though this was Shadow's first meeting with Mephiles. After being freed, Mephiles banishes both Shadow and Rouge to the dystopian future from where Silver originates.</p><p>Now Sonic must save Elise, Silver must kill Sonic, and Shadow has to figure out a way back to his own time!</p><h2>Action Stages</h2><ul><li>Wave Ocean *</li><li>Dusty Desert *</li><li>White Acropolis *</li><li>Crisis City</li><li>Flame Core</li><li>Radical Train</li><li>Tropical Jungle</li><li>Kingdom Valley *</li><li>Aquatic Base *</li><li>End of the World</li></ul><p>* Available in Multiplayer.</p><h2>Soundtrack</h2><p>Sonic the Hedgehog's soundtrack was composed by <a href=\"/mariko-nanba/3040-91807\" data-ref-id=\"3040-91807\">Mariko Nanba</a>, <a href=\"/tomoya-ohtani/3040-40721\" data-ref-id=\"3040-40721\">Tomoya Ohtani</a>, Hideaki Kobayashi, Tai-Hey, and <a href=\"/jun-senoue/3040-38321\" data-ref-id=\"3040-38321\">Jun Senoue</a>, and was overseen by <a href=\"/masato-nakamura/3040-16805\" data-ref-id=\"3040-16805\">Masato Nakamura</a>, the original composer for the Sega Genesis games <a href=\"/sonic-the-hedgehog/3030-2465\" data-ref-id=\"3030-2465\">Sonic the Hedgehog</a> and <a href=\"/sonic-the-hedgehog-2/3030-1662\" data-ref-id=\"3030-1662\">Sonic the Hedgehog 2</a>. The game contains five vocal songs:</p><ul><li>\"His World - Theme of Sonic the Hedgehog\" by Tomoya Ohtani, Ali Tabatabaee, and <a href=\"/johnny-gioeli/3040-74749\" data-ref-id=\"3040-74749\">Johnny Gioeli</a> of the band <a href=\"/crush-40/3040-94941\" data-ref-id=\"3040-94941\">Crush 40</a></li><li>\"Dreams of Absolution - Theme of Silver the Hedgehog\" by Mariko Nanba, Lee Brotherton and The Remix Factory</li><li>\"All Hail Shadow - Theme of Shadow the Hedgehog\" by Jun Senoue, Mike Szuter and Johnny Gioeli of the band Crush 40</li><li>\"My Destiny - Theme of Princess Elise\" by Mariko Nanba, Candie Y, and Donna De Lory</li><li>\"Sweet Dream - AKON '06 Mix\" by Dreams Come True and AKON</li></ul><h2>Development History</h2><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/1486/752464-929717_20050908_screen001.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-752464\" data-size=\"medium\" style=\"width: 480px\" data-ratio=\"0.5625\" data-width=\"480\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:56.3%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/1486/752464-929717_20050908_screen001.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-752464\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"/uploads/scale_medium/0/1486/752464-929717_20050908_screen001.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"/uploads/scale_medium/0/1486/752464-929717_20050908_screen001.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>The first teaser trailer for ''Sonic the Hedgehog''.</figcaption></figure><p>The game was first unveiled behind closed doors to select members of the press at <a href=\"/e3-2005/3015-3437\" data-ref-id=\"3015-3437\">E3</a> in May 2005. Shown along side a number of other <a href=\"/tech-demo/3015-2305\" data-ref-id=\"3015-2305\">tech demos </a>Sega created for Microsoft's Xbox 360 console, the \"Hedgehog\" tech demo featured a real-time animated scene of Sonic racing through miles of forest as robots closed in around him. After easily outrunning the robots, Sonic found himself at the ruins of an old castle, where the demonstrator took control to showcase a real-time physics engine. By pressing a button, the demonstrator would throw out a container which would burst on impact, scattering golden rings around the dilapidated environment. The animation resumed, with Sonic being chased out of the castle by the squad of robots who had been hunting him. Now outside, an airship loomed overhead. The ship's cargo doors opened, and hundreds of hunter robots poured out, completely surrounding Sonic on all sides. Having nowhere to escape to, the robots all simultaneously open fire on the blue hedgehog, and the hail of gunfire presumably leaves Sonic for dead. However, from the smoke rose the now-transformed Super Sonic. Super Sonic flies forward at high speed to meet the robot army head on - the tech demo animation ending right before we see the final result.</p><figure data-align=\"left\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/1486/752462-929717_20050908_screen003.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-752462\" data-size=\"medium\" style=\"width: 480px\" data-ratio=\"0.5625\" data-width=\"480\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:56.3%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/1486/752462-929717_20050908_screen003.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-752462\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"/uploads/scale_medium/0/1486/752462-929717_20050908_screen003.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"/uploads/scale_medium/0/1486/752462-929717_20050908_screen003.jpg\"/></noscript></a></figure><p>Despite being played exclusively for the press in secret, cell phone video footage of the tech demo reel was leaked on to the internet within hours of being shown. The game was officially announced on September 9th, 2005 <a href=\"/sonic-team/3010-781\" data-ref-id=\"3010-781\">by current President of Sonic Team,</a> <a href=\"../../yuji-naka/72-33662/\" rel=\"nofollow\">Yuji Naka</a>, who stated that they would be treating this game as if it were the original <a href=\"/sonic-the-hedgehog/3030-2465\" data-ref-id=\"3030-2465\">Sonic the Hedgehog </a>on the Sega Genesis - fully committing themselves to rebooting Sonic's universe. The game was to be a new beginning for the franchise, with particular focus being paid to a specific goal: \"What if Sonic the Hedgehog existed in the real world?\" When officially announced, the same animated scene from the behind-closed-doors demonstration was shown, minus the interactive ring physics demo. Instead, a brief demonstration of the actual game itself was revealed, showing a very early version of the level known as \"Kingdom Valley\". The highlight of the gameplay demonstration was the game's lighting engine, which self-shadowed everything in the environment. This was to fuel the game's day/night cycle , a first for a Sonic title. All of this would be aimed to celebrate Sonic's 15th Anniversary in 2006.</p><p>Not long after that point, Yuji Naka announced his resignation from both Sonic Team and Sega, departing the company after nearly two decades of employment, in order to start an independent studio, <a href=\"/prope-ltd/3010-6481\" data-ref-id=\"3010-6481\">PROPE</a>. Meanwhile, Nintendo chose Sonic Team as one of the very first third party developers to get <a href=\"/wii/3045-36\" data-ref-id=\"3045-36\">Wii</a> Development kits - then still codenamed the \"Nintendo Revolution\". Previously, Sega had planned to release Sonic 2006 on all three platforms, expecting the \"Revolution\" to be comparable to the Xbox 360 and Playstation 3 in terms of technology. When shown the Wii Remote and the level of graphical horsepower in the Wii, Sonic 2006 Game Director <a href=\"/yojiro-ogawa/3040-40732\" data-ref-id=\"3040-40732\">Yojiro Ogawa </a>decided they would have to make a completely new Sonic game to specifically fit the Wii hardware. To accomplish this task, he split the Sonic 2006 development team, taking half with him to go create <a href=\"/sonic-and-the-secret-rings/3030-2512\" data-ref-id=\"3030-2512\">Sonic &amp; the Secret Rings </a>for Nintendo's platform. Now working at half-capacity on an ambitious game for unfamiliar next-generation hardware, Sonic Team struggled towards Sonic 2006's impending Holiday season deadline, and was reportedly so behind schedule that many Quality Assurance Tester bug reports had to be ignored in order to get the game out on time.</p><h2>Trivia</h2><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/1486/791564-sonic_arch02.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-791564\" data-size=\"small\" style=\"width: 320px\" data-ratio=\"0.5625\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:56.3%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/1486/791564-sonic_arch02.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-791564\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"/uploads/scale_small/0/1486/791564-sonic_arch02.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"/uploads/scale_small/0/1486/791564-sonic_arch02.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Kingdom Valley with the scrapped day/night cycle.</figcaption></figure><ul><li>Despite being a focal point of the original gameplay demonstration, the game's day/night cycle was removed shortly after the game was unveiled.</li><li>A number of online multiplayer modes were at one point planned; Time Trial, Ring Race, and most cryptically, \"Quiz\". The final version of the game has no online multiplayer.</li><li>Viewing the game's main executable in a hex editor reveals a bevvy of cut content and features, including planned (but never released) Downloadable Content like \"Super Hard Mode\", additional Xbox 360 icon sets, dashboard themes, a real-time version of the original tech demo animation, and music packs for every game spanning Sonic's 15 year history.</li><li><figure data-ref-id=\"1300-2474902\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/1486/2474902-1846219-items.jpg\" data-size=\"small\" data-align=\"right\" style=\"width: 256px\" data-ratio=\"1\" data-width=\"256\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:100.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/1486/2474902-1846219-items.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2474902\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"/uploads/scale_small/0/1486/2474902-1846219-items.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"/uploads/scale_small/0/1486/2474902-1846219-items.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Most of these items were intended to appear either on the map or in Sonic's inventory, but very few are used.</figcaption></figure> Also cut were items to buy from the shop: A \"Speed Booster\" item for Silver that increased his top speed, and for Sonic, a special \"Rainbow Gem\" equip that possibly allowed him to transform in to Super Sonic at will, like he could in the old Sega Genesis Sonic games. At one point, extra <a href=\"/1-up/3055-77\" data-ref-id=\"3055-77\">1ups</a> could also be purchased from shops.</li><li>Perhaps the biggest content cut came in the form of extra missions for each playable character in the game - Sonic, Tails, Knuckles, Silver, Amy, Blaze, Shadow, Omega, and Rouge. However, listed among these names was a heretofore unseen secret tenth playable character: <a href=\"/metal-sonic/3005-2273\" data-ref-id=\"3005-2273\">Metal Sonic</a>, Sonic's long-time robotic doppelganger which originally debuted in <a href=\"/sonic-cd/3030-14433\" data-ref-id=\"3030-14433\">Sonic CD</a>. Curiously, Metal Sonic is not referenced anywhere else in the game, and no data for him exists anywhere else on the disc - he is only referenced in this on-disc DLC listing.</li><li>In addition, the game was slated to feature alternate level objectives, similar to <a href=\"/sonic-adventure-2/3030-19060\" data-ref-id=\"3030-19060\">Sonic Adventure 2</a>. Unused mission description text exists tasking you to get to the goal ring within a specific time limit, finding a newly re-located goal ring, collecting a specific amount of rings, defeating all the enemies, and clearing the mini-game.</li><li>More Level Objective text exists, possibly relating to the game's cut multiplayer modes: \"Get to the goal ring before the ghost\" and \"Get to the goal ring before your rival\" - Ghost possibly a reference to time trial ghosts, a feature often seen in racing games. However, no such ghost feature or mode exists in the final release.</li><li>The Tokyo Game Show 2006 trailer for the game showcases a build of Sonic the Hedgehog (2006) that is somewhat different from the final release. There are a large number of additional visual effects and complex animations present in the TGS 2006 trailer that simply do not exist in the final retail version of the game.</li><li>Even though customizing Sonic's abilities was one of the game's selling points, the final retail game features almost no customization at all. Most ability upgrades are required in order to finish the game, and while the player can purchase special gems near the end of Sonic's story, they cannot be \"customized\" in any way shape or form - once equipped, you have them forever.</li><li>The instruction manual for Sonic the Hedgehog (2006) contains a number of inaccuracies that do not accurately reflect the final game. For example: It describes the possibility of leveling up abilities equipped to the action gauge up to three levels of \"maturity\". The action gauge is never used like this by any character in the game, and unless he's carrying Princess Elise, Sonic's action gauge is never used for anything.</li><li>The manual also makes reference to a green shield power-up (similar to one seen in past Sonic games). No shield power is ever acquired from item pickups, nor is any green shield power-up ever accessible.</li><li>In addition, the manual also mentions that Tails and Omega can only fly until their \"Flight Gauge\" depletes. No flight gauge is ever visible, and Omega cannot fly - only hover.</li><li>Even prior to attaining it, the text for the Xbox 360 <a href=\"/achievements/3015-29\" data-ref-id=\"3015-29\">achievement</a> \"<a href=\"../../achievements/nights-of-kronos/96045/\" rel=\"nofollow\">Nights of Kronos</a>\" suggests there is an alternate ending sequence to the game. (The achievement writes: \"Unlock the complete ending to the last hidden story.\") Meeting the requirements to get the achievement (S-Rank the entire Last Episode) does not actually change anything about the ending.</li><li>Early design documents state that Silver's original name was \"Venice\" and Princess Elise's name was at one point \"Oliga\".</li><li><figure data-ref-id=\"1300-732351\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/1486/732351-madonna.jpg\" data-size=\"small\" data-align=\"right\" style=\"width: 320px\" data-ratio=\"0.73613766730402\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:73.6%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/1486/732351-madonna.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-732351\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"/uploads/scale_small/0/1486/732351-madonna.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"/uploads/scale_small/0/1486/732351-madonna.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Early Sonic 1 concept art for the lost \"Madonna\" character. </figcaption></figure> Princess Elise and her role as a human \"damsel in distress\" is similar to a scrapped concept for the original <a href=\"/sonic-the-hedgehog/3030-2465\" data-ref-id=\"3030-2465\">Sonic the Hedgehog (1991)</a> on Sega Genesis, where Sonic was tasked with rescuing a love interest named Madonna.</li><li>During Shadow's story, the Scepter of Darkness is mistakenly referred to as the \"Book of Darkness\" in the subtitles.</li><li>One of the very first leaked images of this game purported it was set to release on the Xbox 360, Playstation 3, and <a href=\"/pc/3045-94\" data-ref-id=\"3045-94\">Personal Computer</a>. This port was even teased in the back of the manual for the PC version of <a href=\"/sonic-riders/3030-15802\" data-ref-id=\"3030-15802\">Sonic Riders</a>, and Amazon accepted pre-orders for it until eventually the listing was removed, presumably after the port was canceled.</li><li><figure data-ref-id=\"1300-2128817\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/1486/2128817-ozkurt_sonic.jpg\" data-size=\"small\" data-align=\"right\" style=\"width: 320px\" data-ratio=\"1.0291139240506\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:102.9%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/1486/2128817-ozkurt_sonic.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2128817\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"/uploads/scale_small/0/1486/2128817-ozkurt_sonic.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"/uploads/scale_small/0/1486/2128817-ozkurt_sonic.jpg\"/></noscript></a></figure> Early concept art released by Blur Studios depicts a fur shaded version of the Sonic the Hedgehog character, having a slightly more hairy appearance than normal. This was perhaps related to the vision of creating a more \"realistic\" Sonic title.</li><li>In August 2009, Sonic (2006) was made available as a downloadable title for Xbox 360, as one of the first titles available on <a href=\"/xbox-live-marketplace/3045-86\" data-ref-id=\"3045-86\">Xbox Live Marketplace</a>'s <a href=\"/games-on-demand/3015-3251\" data-ref-id=\"3015-3251\">Games on Demand </a>service. It was sold with a price of $19.99 US plus tax. The title was eventually de-listed from the service a year later, in an effort made by Sega to remove \"poorly rated Sonic titles\" from the marketplace.</li></ul>", "releases": [{"api_detail_url": {"duration": "0:44:00", "runner": "Fladervy", "data": {"site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/freedom-planet/3030-39276/", "expected_release_quarter": null, "description": "<h2>Overview</h2><p>Freedom Planet is a 2D side scrolling platformer developed and published by <a href=\"/galaxytrail-games/3010-8178\" data-ref-id=\"3010-8178\">GalaxyTrail Games</a>. It is heavily inspired by the classic <a href=\"/sonic-the-hedgehog/3025-383\" data-ref-id=\"3025-383\">Sonic the Hedgehog</a> games but is so is also reminiscent of other <a href=\"/genesis/3045-6\" data-ref-id=\"3045-6\">Sega Genesis/Mega Drive</a> games. The game features two modes of play, Adventure mode and Classic Mode. Adventure Mode offers the same gameplay as Classic Mode but includes a large amount of cutscenes and story that are fully voice acted and animated, Classic Mode is for players who strictly want to play the game. Freedom Planet stars three young ladies as playable characters, <a href=\"/sash-lilac/3005-32106\" data-ref-id=\"3005-32106\">Lilac</a> the dragon, <a href=\"/carol-tea/3005-32107\" data-ref-id=\"3005-32107\">Carol</a> the wildcat and <a href=\"/milla-basset/3005-32108\" data-ref-id=\"3005-32108\">Milla</a> the basset hound.</p><h2>Gameplay</h2><p>The player controls one of three characters, Lilac, Carol, or Milla, and must platform across levels and battle robot enemies that get in the way. The levels contain loop-the-loops, corkscrews, spring pads and other obstacles and mechanisms that help and hinder the player. Some levels have gates that require special actions in order to pass through, like destroying a crystal or finding a key. Each level has a mini-boss, located about half way through the level and a boss at the end of the level.</p><p>The player is allowed to take damage and it is gauged by petals that act as hit points, this meter is located in the upper left corner. Lilac has seven health petals, Carol also has seven health petals and Milla only has health four petals. If the player looses all health petals then a life is lost, lives are indicated in the upper left corner as well. Players can also get shield power-ups, these have different properties based on what color of crystal is smashed. Green is a wood shield, yellow is an earth shield, blue is a water shield, red is a fire shield, silver is a metal shield and rainbow grants invincibility.</p><p>Each character has some basic attacks as well as a special attack that is unique to them. The basic attacks change based on the direction being held when the attack button is pushed, they are similar between characters. The special attack is more powerful but depletes the special meter, the meter must refill in order to use the special again, it is located in the upper left corner. Lilac has an air dash, Carol has a rapid kick move and Milla throws a gelatinous energy cube. The characters also have other special characteristics differentiating their play style. Lilac has a double jump, Carol can cling to walls and ride a motorcycle and Milla can fly temporarily by flapping her ears.</p><h2>Story</h2><p>The ruthless Lord Brevon crash lands on the planet Avalice, he soon learns of a powerful gemstone, the Kingdom stone, that is powering the three local cities. In order to repair his spacecraft he devises a plan to trick the three cities into fighting with one another so he can steal the Kingdom Stone without there interference and repair his ship. Meanwhile another spacecraft crash lands on Avalice containing Torque the Shellduck. Torque is rescued from the crash by two young ladies, Lilac and Carol who are on there way to see the Kingdom Stone. Torque informs them of Lord Brevons evil ways and the group decides they must protect the Kingdom Stone and thwart Lord Brevon's plans.</p><h2>Development</h2><p>The project was conceived by game designer and programmer Steven DiDuro who founded GalaxyTrail games to create the project. It was originally designed to be a Sonic fan project and included Doctor Robotnik/Eggman as the villain and a ring based health system but it was decided it would only limit the project.</p><p>A demo for Freedom Planet was initially posted on <a href=\"http://galaxytrail.com/\" rel=\"nofollow\">GalaxyTrail's website</a> in 2012 as a proof of concept. The project was then <a href=\"https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/galaxytrail/freedom-planet-high-speed-platform-game\" rel=\"nofollow\" data-ref-id=\"false\">Kickstarted</a> on January 15, 2013 where it raised $25,472 from 1,105 backers. The title was also placed into Steam Greenlight a day later and was officially Greenlit in August of 2013. The project was officially released around a year later on July 21, 2014. Freedom Planet was announced to release on the Wii U on March, 8 2015, no official date has been scheduled for that release.</p>", "deck": "An independently developed 2D platformer that shares many similarities to the early Sonic games, as well as Ristar and Gunstar Heroes.", "aliases": null, "image": {"icon_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/square_avatar/9/97089/2465736-m.png", "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/9/97089/2465736-m.png", "thumb_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_avatar/9/97089/2465736-m.png", "screen_url": 02:49:07", "expected_release_month": null, "api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/game/3030-39276/", "number_of_user_reviews": 0, "original_release_date": "2014-07-21 00:00:00", {"duration": "0:55:00", "runner": "V0oid, Nocturne_, BluntBunny", "data": {"site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/donkey-kong-country-3-dixie-kongs-double-trouble/3030-4547/", "expected_release_quarter": null, "description": "<h2>Overview</h2><p>Donkey Kong Country 3: Dixie Kong's Double Trouble is the third and final instalment of the <a href=\"/donkey-kong-country/3025-155\" data-ref-id=\"3025-155\">DKC Trilogy</a>. It was developed once again by <a href=\"/rare-ltd/3010-174\" data-ref-id=\"3010-174\">Rare</a>. In this last edition, neither <a href=\"/donkey-kong/3005-299\" data-ref-id=\"3005-299\">Donkey Kong</a> nor <a href=\"/diddy-kong/3005-304\" data-ref-id=\"3005-304\">Diddy Kong</a> are playable. Instead, the playable characters <a href=\"/dixie-kong/3005-303\" data-ref-id=\"3005-303\">Dixie Kong</a> (from <a href=\"/donkey-kong-country-2-diddys-kong-quest/3030-16889\" data-ref-id=\"3030-16889\">DKC 2</a>) and her cousin <a href=\"/kiddy-kong/3005-1651\" data-ref-id=\"3005-1651\">Kiddy Kong</a>, who is a new playable character.</p><h2>Story</h2><p>Donkey Kong and Diddy Kong decide to take a <a href=\"/fishing/3015-510\" data-ref-id=\"3015-510\">fishing</a> vacation after their hard work on keeping DK Isles safe from the clutches of <a href=\"/king-k-rool/3005-906\" data-ref-id=\"3005-906\">K. Rool</a>. But they mysteriously go missing and it's up to Dixie Kong and her cousin, Kiddy, to find them. Meanwhile, in the northern Kremisphere, the <a href=\"/kremlings/3015-3312\" data-ref-id=\"3015-3312\">kremlings</a> are back once again but now under the leadership of KAOS, a mysterious robot that is secretly being controlled by one Baron K. Roolenstein. Its up to Dixie and Kiddy to rescue Donkey and Diddy Kong and thwart K. Roolenstein's evil plans.</p><h2>Gameplay</h2><figure data-align=\"left\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/12583/415770-ss_17.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-415770\" data-size=\"medium\" data-ratio=\"0.66666666666667\" data-width=\"240\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 240px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:66.7%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/12583/415770-ss_17.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-415770\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_medium/1/12583/415770-ss_17.jpg\"/></a><figcaption>Boss Time!</figcaption></figure><p>Donkey Kong Country 3 retains the same gameplay from the previous two installments but with some new additions. One of the new additions is the use of vehicles on the <a href=\"/world-map/3015-611\" data-ref-id=\"3015-611\">world map</a> screen. Unlike the <a href=\"/airplane/3055-910\" data-ref-id=\"3055-910\">plane</a> used in the previous games, these vehicles range from a motorboat to a <a href=\"/helicopter/3055-361\" data-ref-id=\"3055-361\">helicopter</a> and help Dixie and Kiddy Kong get to different locations throughout the northern Kremisphere, as well as secret places that would be unreachable otherwise.</p><p>The two kongs make their way through various levels like woodland areas and mechanical factories picking up all sorts of items along the way whether it be <a href=\"/banana/3055-217\" data-ref-id=\"3055-217\">bananas</a>, <a href=\"/coin/3055-219\" data-ref-id=\"3055-219\">coins</a> or <a href=\"/balloon/3055-720\" data-ref-id=\"3055-720\">balloons</a> representing <a href=\"/extra-life/3015-1806\" data-ref-id=\"3015-1806\">extra lives</a>. They are once again aided by animals to guide them in defeating the kremling krew and other enemies that are about.</p><p>In this edition, the Kong family are joined by the Brothers Bears who are situated all throughout the northern Kremisphere. They have their own dilemmas and will help Dixie and Kiddy in their adventures in exchange for bear coins and certain items found throughout the world.</p><p>Hidden throughout the northern Kremisphere are caves that contain an important part of the game, <a href=\"/banana-bird/3055-136\" data-ref-id=\"3055-136\">banana birds</a>. In order to free the birds from their crystallised cages, the Kongs have to match the sequence of sounds that play for them when they enter the cave. Some are given to them by the bears in exchange for helping them out. In order to unlock the true ending, the player must obtain all 13 banana birds throughout the land.</p><h2>Playable Characters</h2><p>Dixie Kong - Girlfriend of Diddy Kong who can use her <a href=\"/ponytail/3055-2545\" data-ref-id=\"3055-2545\">ponytail</a> to glide along and reach certain places throughout the land.</p><p>Kiddy Kong - Cousin of Dixie Kong who can use his weight to his advantage in certain scenarios.</p><h2>Supporting Characters</h2><h3>The Kong Family</h3><ul><li><a href=\"/wrinkly-kong/3005-13171\" data-ref-id=\"3005-13171\">Wrinkly Kong</a> - Having quit her job as a school teacher, Wrinkly now spends her time exercising, sleeping and playing games in her cave. She is always there to save the game's progress and keeps the rescued banana birds.</li><li><a href=\"/swanky-kong/3005-14642\" data-ref-id=\"3005-14642\">Swanky Kong</a> - Is the host of his own sideshow attraction where Dixie and Kiddy can play for prizes including bananas, bear coins and lives.</li><li><a href=\"/cranky-kong/3005-311\" data-ref-id=\"3005-311\">Cranky Kong</a> - Is the opponent in Swanky Kong\u2019s sideshow attraction. Does not give advice in this edition of the series.</li><li><a href=\"/funky-kong/3005-1647\" data-ref-id=\"3005-1647\">Funky Kong</a> - Owns Funky\u2019s Rentals and helps develop new vehicles for the Kongs in order to reach new areas of the northern Kremisphere.</li></ul><h3>The Brothers Bears</h3><ul><li>Bazaar - Runs his own general store on the world map and helps the Kongs in exchange for bear coins.</li><li>Barnacle - Found in Lake Orangatanga and wants the Kongs to help him complete his shell collection.</li><li>Brash - Found in Kremwood Forest and is proud of his record for the fastest playthrough of Riverside Race, until the Kongs beat it that is.</li><li>Blunder - Found beside Kremwood Forest. He tends to blab out important information like the location of the lost world, Krematoa.</li><li>Blue - Found in Cotton-Top Cove. Is quite unhappy, as he believes his brothers have forgotten his birthday.</li><li>Bazooka - Found in Mekanos. Is an old general who operates a cannon known as Big Bessie.</li><li>Bramble - Has a flower shop near Cotton-Top cove.</li><li>Blizzard - Found in K3. The only bear of the family that actually got Blue a present for his birthday but needs the Kongs to deliver it for him.</li><li>Benny &amp; Bj\u00f6rn - Found in Razor Ridge. They operate the chair lifts so that Dixie and Kiddy Kong can get through the area.</li><li>Barter - Like Bazaar, also runs a shop on the world map.</li><li>Baffle - Found in KAOS Kore. He specialises in cracking codes that help the Kongs on their adventure.</li><li>Boomer - Found in Krematoa. Will help the Kongs make their way through Krematoa by blasting the rocks blocking their path. He does this in exchange for bonus coins.</li><li>Bachelor - Found in the GBA version of DKC 3 in Lake Orangatanga. Wants Dixie and Kiddy to get chocolates and flowers for a date he is having.</li></ul><h3>Bosses (In Order)</h3><ul><li><a href=\"/belcha/3005-10128\" data-ref-id=\"3005-10128\"><b>Belcha</b></a>: Giant man eating barrel that resides in a mill at Lake Orangatanga.</li></ul><ul><li><b>Arich</b>: A large red spider faced at Kremwood Forest.</li></ul><ul><li><b>Squirt</b>: An odd looking face that squirts jets of water, encountered at Cotton-Top-Cove.</li></ul><ul><li><b>Bleak</b>: An evil living snowman met at K3, utilizes cannonballs in the form of snowballs.</li></ul><ul><li><b>Barbos</b>: Some sort of spiked...clam. It fires needles and nautilus (type of shelled fish) missiles at the Kongs, faced at Razor Ridge.</li></ul><figure data-align=\"left\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/2574/474880-381374_baron_k._roolenstein._thumb.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-474880\" data-size=\"large\" data-ratio=\"1.3636363636364\" data-width=\"110\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 110px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:136.4%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/2574/474880-381374_baron_k._roolenstein._thumb.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-474880\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_super/0/2574/474880-381374_baron_k._roolenstein._thumb.jpg\"/></a><figcaption>Baron K. Roolenstein</figcaption></figure><p>KAOS - Considered to be the new leader of the Kremling Krew. However, it is actually being controlled by the true leader, Baron K. Roolenstein otherwise known as K. Rool. It is first encountered at Makanos and then at KAOS Kore at the end of the game.</p><p>Baron K. Roolenstein (K.Rool) - Created and operated the mechanical robot known as KAOS in a bid to stop Dixie and Kiddy thwart his evil plans; The final boss, faced at KAOS Kore and at the lost world of Krematoa.</p><h2>Worlds</h2><p>In Donkey Kong Country 3, there are eight worlds altogether (nine in the GBA version) including the lost world of Krematoa. Each world has 5 stages and a boss at the end for the Kongs to defeat. The worlds are as follows: Lake Orangatanga, Kremwood Forest, Cotton-Top Cove, Mekanos, K3, Razor Ridge, Pacifica, KAOS Kore, Krematoa.</p><h4>Lake Orangatanga</h4><ol><li>Lakeside Limbo</li><li>Doorstop Dash</li><li>Tidal Trouble</li><li>Skidda's Row</li><li>Murky Mill</li><li>Boss: Belcha's Barn</li></ol><h4>Kremwood Forest</h4><ol><li>Barrel Shield Bust-Up (SNES version)/Springin' Spiders (GBA version)</li><li>Riverside Race</li><li>Squeals on Wheels</li><li>Springin' Spiders (SNES version)/Barrel Shield Bust-Up (GBA version)</li><li>Bobbing Barrel Brawl</li><li>Boss: Arich's Ambush</li></ol><h4>Cotton Top Cove</h4><ol><li>Bazza's Blockade</li><li>Rocket Barrel Ride</li><li>Kreeping Klasps</li><li>Tracker Barrel Trek</li><li>Fish Food Frenzy</li><li>Boss: Squirt's Showdown</li></ol><h4>Mekanos</h4><ol><li>Fire-Ball Frenzy</li><li>Demolition Drain-Pipe</li><li>Ripsaw Rage</li><li>Blazing Bazukas</li><li>Low-G Labyrinth</li><li>Boss: KAOS Karnage</li></ol><h4>K3</h4><ol><li>Krevice Kreepers</li><li>Tearaway Toboggan</li><li>Barrel Drop Bounce</li><li>Krack-Shot Kroc</li><li>Lemguin Lunge</li><li>Boss: Bleak's House</li></ol><h4>Razor Ridge</h4><ol><li>Buzzer Barrage</li><li>Kong-Fused Cliffs</li><li>Floodlit Fish</li><li>Pot Hole Panic</li><li>Ropey Rumpus</li><li>Boss: Barbos' Barrier (SNES version)/Kroctopus Krush (GBA version)</li></ol><p>Pacifica (GBA version only)</p><ol><li>Dingy Drain-Pipe</li><li>Stormy Seas</li><li>Sunken Spruce</li><li>Cliffside Blast</li><li>Ripcurl Reef</li><li>Surf's Up</li><li>Boss: Barbos' Barrier</li></ol><h4>KAOS Kore</h4><ol><li>Konveyor Rope Klash</li><li>Creepy Caverns</li><li>Lightning Lookout</li><li>Koindozer Klamber</li><li>Poisonous Pipeline</li><li>Boss: Kastle KAOS</li></ol><h4>Krematoa</h4><ol><li>Stampede Sprint</li><li>Criss Kross Cliffs</li><li>Tyrant Twin Tussle</li><li>Swoopy Salvo</li><li>Rocket Rush</li><li>Boss: Knautilus</li></ol><h2>Animals</h2><p>Once again, the animals aid the kongs on their adventure to rescue Donkey and Diddy and stop the kremling krew.</p><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/12583/415754-ss_2.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-415754\" data-size=\"medium\" data-ratio=\"0.66666666666667\" data-width=\"240\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 240px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:66.7%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/12583/415754-ss_2.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-415754\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_medium/1/12583/415754-ss_2.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_medium/1/12583/415754-ss_2.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Ellie The Elephant</figcaption></figure><ul><li><a href=\"/enguarde-the-swordfish/3005-11234\" data-ref-id=\"3005-11234\">Enguarde</a> - The swordfish returns once again to poke at any enemies wishing to hurt the heroes.</li><li>Squitter - The spider from the previous game is back to help the Kongs whack enemies with his webs and to reach certain places that can\u2019t be reached on their own.</li><li><a href=\"/squawks-the-parrot/3005-11311\" data-ref-id=\"3005-11311\">Squawks</a> - The parrot helps the Kongs reach places that couldn\u2019t be reached on foot and helps them defeat enemies by spitting out nuts.</li></ul><ul><li>Ellie - A new addition to the lineup. Ellie is an elephant who can pick up barrels using her trunk and can use them in various ways. Also, can suck water and shoot it from her trunk to defeat enemies. Is afraid of mice and runs when she sets her eyes on one.</li></ul><h3>Unplayable animals</h3><p>Parry - When released from the crate, Parry flies above Dixie and Kiddy Kong\u2019s heads and helps them reach certain treasures that couldn\u2019t be obtained otherwise.</p><p>Nibbla - Only appears in one level to feed. If the Kongs feed him the right food when going through the level, his mood will stay high but if he feeds on the wrong food or waits too long, the mood worsens and can become an enemy to the Kongs.</p><h2>Coins</h2><p>Bear Coins - These are situated throughout the northern Kremisphere and are used in exchange for items and helpful information. Can be considered the replacement to Banana coins from DKC 2.</p><p>Bonus Coins - Replacing the Kremcoins from DKC 2, these coins are obtained by successfully completing a bonus level. These are used to travel through Krematoa successfully.</p><figure data-align=\"left\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/5327/255554-donkey_kong_country_303.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-255554\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"1.0498046875\" data-width=\"960\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 960px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:105.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/5327/255554-donkey_kong_country_303.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-255554\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_super/0/5327/255554-donkey_kong_country_303.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_super/0/5327/255554-donkey_kong_country_303.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Koin</figcaption></figure><p>DK Coins - Like in DKC 2, one is hidden in each level but unlike DKC 2, it is guarded by an enemy known as Koin. The only way to obtain the DK coin is by hitting Koin with a metal barrel in his unprotected back, as he has a shield on his front.</p><h2>Game Boy Advance Version</h2><p>Released in November 2005, Donkey Kong Country 3 for the <a href=\"/game-boy-advance/3045-4\" data-ref-id=\"3045-4\">Game Boy Advance</a> is a port of the original game with a few changes. It features a brand new world, Pacifica, as well as a new boss, Kroctopus.</p><p>The game also sported a completely new soundtrack from <a href=\"/david-wise/3040-33306\" data-ref-id=\"3040-33306\">David Wise</a>, composer for Donkey Kong Country 2, although the music has been criticised for not holding up to that of the original by <a href=\"/eveline-novakovic/3040-50659\" data-ref-id=\"3040-50659\">Eveline Fischer</a> (now Novakovic).</p><p>The port has also replaced the original Swanky Sideshow <a href=\"/minigames/3015-116\" data-ref-id=\"3015-116\">minigames</a> with some new boat games from <a href=\"/funky-kong/3005-1647\" data-ref-id=\"3005-1647\">Funky</a>, a star-collection game set in a sewer tube with Swanky, and an echidna-blocking game with Cranky Kong. <a href=\"/wrinkly-kong/3005-13171\" data-ref-id=\"3005-13171\">Wrinkly</a>'s save caves have been replaced by Cranky's Dojo now that the game allows the player to save at any time on the world map by hitting the start button.</p><p>The port has slightly changed physics from the original game which may be noticeable when playing them side by side; most notably that characters will move at a much slower rate in the port, including in the toboggan levels. There are also a few levels which have had objects shifted to fit with these slower character speeds, but sometimes this affects the original puzzles of levels, such as platforms being lowered to be accessible from points unreachable before, and some DK coins being accessible without figuring out a puzzle and collecting them the way the game had originally intended.</p><h2>Soundtrack</h2><p>The soundtrack for Donkey Kong Country 3 was the first soundtrack in the Donkey Kong Country series to not be solely composed by <a href=\"/david-wise/3040-33306\" data-ref-id=\"3040-33306\">David Wise</a>. Instead, <a href=\"/eveline-novakovic/3040-50659\" data-ref-id=\"3040-50659\">Eveline Fischer</a> was responsible for most of the composition with some help by David Wise.</p><h3>Tracklist</h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/4527/1782583-1.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1782583\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.9758064516129\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:97.6%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/4527/1782583-1.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1782583\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/4527/1782583-1.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/4527/1782583-1.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Soundtrack cover</figcaption></figure><ol><li>Dixie Beat</li><li>Crazy Calypso</li><li>Northern Kremisphere</li><li>Hangin' at Funky's</li><li>Wrinkly's Save Cave</li><li>Get Fit A-Go-Go</li><li>Wrinkly 64</li><li>Brothers Bear</li><li>Sub-Map Shuffle</li><li>Swanky's Sideshow</li><li>Cranky's Showdown</li><li>Showdown Win</li><li>Showdown Lose</li><li>Bonus Time</li><li>Bonus Win</li><li>Bonus Lose</li><li>Stilt Village</li><li>Mill Fever</li><li>Jangle Bells</li><li>Frosty Frolics</li><li>Treetop Tumble</li><li>Enchanted Riverbank</li><li>Hot Pursuit</li><li>Water World</li><li>Nuts and Bolts</li><li>Pokey Pipes</li><li>Rockface Rumble</li><li>Jungle Jitter</li><li>Cavern Caprice</li><li>Rocket Run</li><li>Boss Boogie</li><li>Crystal Chasm</li><li>Krematoa Koncerto</li><li>Big Boss Blues</li><li>Mama Bird</li><li>Chase</li><li>Baddies on Parade</li><li>Game Over</li></ol>", "deck": "The final installment in the original Donkey Kong Country trilogy for the Super Nintendo. {"duration": "0:09:00", "runner": "johncarls", "data": {"site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/disneys-the-little-mermaid/3030-8958/", "expected_release_quarter": null, "description": "<h2>Overview</h2><p>Disney's The Little Mermaid is a Capcom developed and published side-scrolling action game for the <a href=\"/super-nintendo-entertainment-system/3045-9\" data-ref-id=\"3045-9\">NES</a> and <a href=\"/game-boy/3045-3\" data-ref-id=\"3045-3\">Game Boy</a>, released in 1991. The game's plot immediately follows the movie: shortly before marrying Prince Eric, Ariel meets Sebastian the crab who informs her that Ursula is back and is brainwashing all the fish in the ocean. She decides she must turn back into a mermaid and fight Ursula to release her friends from her spell. The game uses cutaway scenes to tell its story in-between action levels.</p><p>This game is not to be confused with <a href=\"/disneys-ariel-the-little-mermaid/3030-6251\" data-ref-id=\"3030-6251\">Disney's Ariel: The Little Mermaid</a>, which was exclusive to Sega systems and played similarly to <a href=\"/ecco-the-dolphin/3030-9286\" data-ref-id=\"3030-9286\">Ecco the Dolphin</a>.</p><h2>Gameplay</h2><p>The game largely takes place in the ocean, with Ariel swimming across a series of underwater stages. Similar to other Capcom licensed games like <a href=\"/chip-n-dale-rescue-rangers/3030-1994\" data-ref-id=\"3030-1994\">Chip 'N Dale: Rescue Rangers</a>, Ariel can stun her enemies with bubbles, then pick them up and throw them at others. Players can also dig for sea shells and find hidden treasure, eventually earning power-ups to the number and size of bubbles that Ariel can use as projectiles.</p><h2>Story</h2><p>The story of the game takes place after the events of the film. In the game, Ursula, the evil Witch of the Sea, has cast a spell on all watery creatures. In order to save her friends, Ariel dives into the sea, becoming a mermaid again. But the water is full of jellyfish, lobsters, eels, and blowfish.</p><h2>Stages</h2><p>The following stages, and their boss fights, are specific to the NES version of the game.</p><ol><li>The Sea of Coral. Boss: Great White Shark.</li><li>Sunken Ship. Boss: Eels.</li><li>Sea of Ice. Boss: Walrus.</li><li>Undersea Volcano. Boss: Captain Seahorse.</li><li>Ursula's Castle. Boss: Ursula. (and then Giant Ursula)</li></ol>", "deck": "A side-scrolling action game developed and published by Capcom in 1991, based on the hit Disney movie. {"duration": "0:17:00", "runner": "NME", "data": {"site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/ducktales-2/3030-14532/", "expected_release_quarter": null, "description": "<h2>Overview:</h2><figure data-align=\"left\" data-size=\"medium\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/2714/297653-duck_tales_2_nes_screenshot1.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-297653\" data-ratio=\"0.875\" data-width=\"256\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 256px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:87.5%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/2714/297653-duck_tales_2_nes_screenshot1.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-297653\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_medium/0/2714/297653-duck_tales_2_nes_screenshot1.jpg\"/></a></figure><p>A sequel to the original <a href=\"/ducktales/3030-15799\" data-ref-id=\"3030-15799\">DuckTales</a> NES game. Similar to the original, the player assumes the role of Scrooge McDuck once again, going through several platforming oriented levels and defeating enemies in hopes of collecting hidden treasure map pieces.</p><p>Unlike the original game this sold poorly. The game only saw a limited production run due to its late release in the NES's cycle. The actual gameplay was praised mainly because the game didn't change much from its predecessor. Due to its limited run the game has become somewhat of a rarity among collectors.</p><h2>Plot</h2><p>In DuckTales 2, <a href=\"/scrooge-mcduck/3005-5901\" data-ref-id=\"3005-5901\">Scrooge McDuck</a> has to find Fergus McDuck's treasure by finding the seven map pieces, which are scattered around the world.</p>", "deck": "Play as Scrooge McDuck travelling around the world in this sequel to the {"duration": "0:12:00", "runner": "CTConqueror", "data": {"site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/mickey-mousecapade/3030-17706/", "expected_release_quarter": null, "description": "<h2>Overview</h2><p>Mickey Mousecapade is a platformer developed by <a href=\"/hudson-entertainment-inc/3010-419\" data-ref-id=\"3010-419\">Hudson Soft</a>. It was published for the Famicom in Japan in 1987 by Hudson Soft, and published by <a href=\"/capcom/3010-367\" data-ref-id=\"3010-367\">Capcom</a> for the Nintendo Entertainment System in the United States in 1988. The game follows the adventures of Disney mascot <a href=\"/mickey-mouse/3005-2363\" data-ref-id=\"3005-2363\">Mickey Mouse</a>, and his girlfriend Minnie Mouse, as they attempt to rescue Alice from the Disney movie \"Alice in Wonderland\".</p><p> </p><h2>Gameplay</h2><p>The player guides Mickey through the Fun House, the Forest, the Pirate Ship, and finally the Castle. Combat includes Mickey tossing stars at enemies such as snakes and spiders. Mickey can refill portions of his health bar by collecting diamonds that are available throughout the levels.</p><p> </p><h2>Localization</h2><p>Capcom made a number of changes to the game before its sale to the American audience. The Japanese version dealt primarily with characters and elements taken from Alice in Wonderland; the US version of the game introduces more characters from the Disney universe, replacing Cheshire Cat with Witch Hazel as the game's first boss, and introducing enemies from The Jungle Book, Sleeping Beauty, the Country Bear Jamboree, and Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs. The Capcom-published game employs diamonds as a means of replenishing Mickey's life bar, whereas players of the original game would collect the head of Donald Duck to return back to full health. Also, Mickey shoots white balls in the Japanese version of the game, while our hero shoots stars in the US release.</p><p> </p><figure data-align=\"left\"
