{"duration": "0:30:00", "runner": "YellowKillerBee", "data": {"site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/quackshot-starring-donald-duck/3030-9412/", "expected_release_quarter": null, "description": "<h2>Overview</h2><p>Quackshot starring Donald Duck is a platformer adventure game starring the main protagonist himself <a href=\"/donald-duck/3005-1754\" data-ref-id=\"3005-1754\">Donald Duck</a> and his three nephews Huey, Dewey and Louie. Donald meets a lot of his old friends along the way who help him out in his adventures, including <a href=\"/goofy/3005-1810\" data-ref-id=\"3005-1810\">Goofy</a>, <a href=\"/daisy-duck/3005-5525\" data-ref-id=\"3005-5525\"> Daisy Duck</a>, <a href=\"/gyro-gearloose/3005-13152\" data-ref-id=\"3005-13152\"> Gyro Gearloose</a>, and even <a href=\"/mickey-mouse/3005-2363\" data-ref-id=\"3005-2363\"> Mickey Mouse</a>. But there are a lot of familiar faces who aren't trying to help Donald either like <a href=\"/pete/3005-7861\" data-ref-id=\"3005-7861\"> Pete</a>, even <a href=\"/shere-khan/3005-10093\" data-ref-id=\"3005-10093\"> Shere Khan</a> and <a href=\"/kaa/3005-10092\" data-ref-id=\"3005-10092\"> Kaa</a> who appeared in the Jungle Book.</p><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/3909/363803-1.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-363803\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.7\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:70.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/3909/363803-1.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-363803\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/3909/363803-1.png\"/></a></figure><p>Quackshot starring Donald Duck has a lot of references to the Indiana Jones films. Nods to the series include the telltale jacket and fedora, the title screen's font, and map transition screens. Elements from the finale of <em>Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade</em>, like the Path of God and the ancient Grail Knight, also find themselves in the game.</p><h2>Gameplay</h2><figure data-align=\"left\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/1317/488637-q5.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-488637\" data-size=\"medium\" data-ratio=\"0.7\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:70.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/1317/488637-q5.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-488637\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_medium/0/1317/488637-q5.png\"/></a></figure><p>Each level sees Donald Duck going from left to right like most 2D side-scrollers. Along the way are enemies like the underlings of Pete, birds, living statues and even cacti. Most levels have an overworld and a dungeon: these dungeons consist of puzzles and traps, but have a big reward at the end. The first the levels have upgrades for weapons while later levels have clues - like scrolls, jewels or keys - all of which are needed to find the location of King Garuzia's treasure.</p><p>Donald is equipped with a plunger gun. This has an unlimited supply of yellow plungers, which are used to stun enemies so Donald can walk past them. In Mexico, Goofy gives Donald the red plungers and these can stick to wall for a limited time and can be used to get to unreachable places. Lastly, the Viking Captain gives Donald the green plunger which can be attached to birds; holding onto them will bring Donald along for the ride. Donald is also equipped with another gun with limited ammo and this gun fires popcorn and bubble gum. He can find pieces of corn and gum to refill this weapon. Enemies hit with either will be permanently defeated, rather than just stunned temporarily.</p><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/1317/488640-q8.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-488640\" data-size=\"medium\" data-ratio=\"0.7\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:70.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/1317/488640-q8.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-488640\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_medium/0/1317/488640-q8.png\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_medium/0/1317/488640-q8.png\"/></noscript></a></figure><p>Along the way are different types of food, like burgers and chicken, and these give Donald health. Hats can be found to give Donald a 1-up. Finally, if Donald eats five chili peppers, he will get mad and become invulnerable for a short period. During this time he will move faster and jump higher and wipe out any enemy he comes in contact with.</p><h2>Plot</h2><figure data-align=\"left\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/1317/488639-q7.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-488639\" data-size=\"medium\" data-ratio=\"0.7\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:70.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/1317/488639-q7.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-488639\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_medium/0/1317/488639-q7.png\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_medium/0/1317/488639-q7.png\"/></noscript></a></figure><p>While Donald is looking through Scrooge McDuck's books, an old piece of paper slips out of one of them. Donald discovers that it is a map that leads to King Garuzia's greatest treasure. Donald is overjoyed and with the help of his three nephews he starts his quest for the legendary treasure.</p><p>Unfortunately, Big Bad Pete overheard Donald's plan and is trying to stop Donald and get the treasure for himself. He sets his minions on Donald and later steals the necessary clues for the treasure's location in exchange for his kidnapped nephews.</p><p>Throughout the game Donald must travel between several locations to get new weapons and to get parts of the treasure so he can advance further. This involves setting waypoints that allows his nephews to pick him up in their plane, and later returning to the set waypoint once the correct item has been found.</p><h2>Ending</h2><p>In the end, Donald manages to defeat Pete and get the treasure for himself, however it turns out to be a stone statue. Donald returns home crestfallen, worried about how his girlfriend Daisy will react, until his nephews accidentally break the statue while unloading it from the plane and reveal a priceless gold and jewel necklace within. Donald gives the necklace to Daisy Duck and they fly away into the sunset.</p>", "deck": "While Donald is looking through Uncle's Scrooge's books he finds a treasure map and knowing Donald he's going to want to find it. Travel with Donald through seven different locations to try and find all this treasure!", "aliases": "I Love Donald Duck: Guruzia Ou no Hihou", "image": {"icon_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/square_avatar/9/93770/2371372-genesis_quackshot_eu.jpg", "medium_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_medium/9/93770/2371372-genesis_quackshot_eu.jpg", "tiny_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/square_mini/9/93770/2371372-genesis_quackshot_eu.jpg", "small_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/9/93770/2371372-genesis_quackshot_eu.jpg", "thumb_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_avatar/9/93770/2371372-genesis_quackshot_eu.jpg", "screen_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/screen_medium/9/93770/2371372-genesis_quackshot_eu.jpg", "super_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_large/9/93770/2371372-genesis_quackshot_eu.jpg"}, "date_last_updated": "2015-10-20 16:43:17", "expected_release_month": null, "api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/game/3030-9412/", "number_of_user_reviews": 0, "original_release_date": "1991-12-19 00:00:00", "original_game_rating": null, "date_added": "2008-04-01 15:50:19", "platforms": [{"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/platform/3045-6/", "abbreviation": "GEN", "site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/genesis/3045-6/", "id": 6, "name": "Genesis"}], "expected_release_day": null, "expected_release_year": null, "id": 9412, "resource_type": "game", "name": "QuackShot: Starring Donald Duck"}, "platform": "Genesis", "title": "Quackshot Starring Donald Duck"}
{"duration": "0:15:00", "runner": "Darkwing Duck, FFR Pro 21, Edobean, CardsOfTheHeart, Bbforky", "data": {"site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/tetris-attack/3030-13130/", "expected_release_quarter": null, "description": "<h2>Overview</h2><figure style=\"width: 250px\" data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/7465/873557-panel_de_pon_boxart.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-873557\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"1.832\" data-width=\"250\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:183.2%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/7465/873557-panel_de_pon_boxart.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-873557\"><img src=\"/uploads/scale_small/0/7465/873557-panel_de_pon_boxart.png\"/></a><figcaption>Tetris Attack is the North American version of Panel de Pon</figcaption></figure><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">Tetris Attack is the North American version of Panel de Pon (Paneru de Pon), initially a Japanese game which was one of the founders of the now commonly found \"tile swapping\" mechanic of puzzle gameplay. The core gameplay consists of a well partially filled with either 5 or 6 distinct types of tiles, depending on the difficulty level. Adjacent tiles may be swapped horizontally with the cursor, and matching three or more tiles vertically or horizontally will result in the tiles clearing after a short delay animation, during which they become immovable. Additional points may be earned with either \"combos,\" which involve clearing more than 3 tiles simultaneously, or \"chains,\" which require that the tiles above a clearing set fall into another clear. During play, the stack of tiles will slowly rise to the top of the screen, though clearing tiles will pause this advance. After a grace period after the stack reaches the top of the well, the game will end.</p><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">The version of Panel de Pon included in the Japan-only Nintendo Puzzle Collection has more differences from the original game than any other game included on the disc. The game is essentially the same as <a href=\"../../pokemon-puzzle-league/61-8052/\" rel=\"nofollow\">Pok\u00e9mon Puzzle League</a>, as it is a version of the game skinned as \"Panel de Pon 64.\" Thus, it features many of the same things as Pok\u00e9mon Puzzle League (such as a 3D mode, new characters, updated graphics, and a new four-player mode, which wasn't in Pok\u00e9mon Puzzle League). Despite these changes, gameplay-wise it is nothing more than an enhanced version of Panel de Pon.</p><h2>Game Modes</h2><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">There are 5 major game modes in Tetris Attack. In most modes, a difficulty level may be selected, and in some modes an initial speed may be selected; this may be confusing to new players, but while the difficulty level affects the rate at which death occurs, the number of tile types in play, and the rate at which tiles fall upon finding themselves in mid-air, the initial speed merely controls the speed at which the stack rises.</p><h3>Endless</h3><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">This mode allows the player to select a difficulty level and speed, and allows nearly limitless play. The name of the mode is misleading, however, as gameplay will necessarily end: either the player will die, or reach 99,999 points, upon which the game will end. Should the player reach this maximum point score, credits will be rolled.</p><h3>Time Trial</h3><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">This mode provides a 2 minute length of time in which to earn as many points as possible. The difficulty and speed may be set prior to the game. This mode may be played with either 1 or 2 players.</p><h3>Stage Clear</h3><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">The Stage Clear mode requires that players clear the stack down to a particular \"clear line\" to pass each stage, of which there are several per character in the game. In addition, there are certain \"boss battles,\" in which the player must earn points as quickly as possible to reduce the boss's HP level to zero.</p><h3>Puzzle</h3><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">This mode involves a collection of designed puzzles, of which there are ten per character in the game, as well as many \"special\" levels, totaling 120 levels. Each involves a set of tiles that must be cleared completely within the predetermined number of tile swaps.</p><h3>VS</h3><figure style=\"width: 256px\" data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/7465/392219-tetris_attack042.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-392219\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.875\" data-width=\"256\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:87.5%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/7465/392219-tetris_attack042.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-392219\"><img src=\"/uploads/scale_small/0/7465/392219-tetris_attack042.png\"/></a><figcaption>A screenshot of gameplay</figcaption></figure><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">The VS mode is the only game mode to feature the Garbage mechanic, as well as the only mode which features a computer-controlled AI. In it, each player attempts to stay alive and force the other player to lose first. This may be done by dumping \"garbage blocks\" upon the other player, by creating either combos or chains. Increasingly large combos will result in larger-width as well as multiple single slabs of garbage to be dropped on the player's opponent, while increasingly large chains will result in thicker single blocks of garbage. Clearing garbage may be done by matching three or more tiles adjacent to the garbage, upon which all the garbage in contact in the stack will flash and begin transforming into normal tiles, starting from the very bottom and progressing to the top of the garbage stack. These tiles, though revealed, are not in play until the entire stack has transformed, upon which it will fall onto the existing stack; this lag time is in turn an excellent time to anticipate and create large combos and chains. However, garbage created with chains consists of single multilayer blocks; these blocks will not completely transform with each attempt - instead, only the bottom layer will become normal tiles, while the rest will transform back into a single block.</p><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">In addition, there are special tiles in the VS mode which are gray and marked with exclamation points. These appear only sporadically, and, when matched, create special \"steel\" garbage blocks to be dropped on the player's opponent. These are unique because they do not clear when in contact with regular clearing garbage - they must be cleared separately. This effectively limits the clearing ability of one's opponent, and is particularly useful when sandwiched between two large segments of regular garbage.</p><h2>Characters</h2><ul><li><a href=\"/yoshi/3005-700\" data-ref-id=\"3005-700\">Yoshi</a></li><li>Bumpty</li><li>Flutter</li><li>Gargantua Blargg</li><li>Lunge Fish</li><li><a href=\"/prince-froggy/3005-12897\" data-ref-id=\"3005-12897\">Prince Froggy</a></li><li><a href=\"/lakitu/3005-927\" data-ref-id=\"3005-927\">Lakitu</a></li><li><a href=\"/poochy/3005-826\" data-ref-id=\"3005-826\">Poochy</a></li><li><a href=\"/hookbill-the-koopa/3005-12900\" data-ref-id=\"3005-12900\">Hookbill the Koopa</a></li><li><a href=\"/naval-piranha/3005-12898\" data-ref-id=\"3005-12898\">Naval Piranha</a></li><li><a href=\"/kamek/3005-1227\" data-ref-id=\"3005-1227\">Kamek</a></li><li><a href=\"/bowser/3005-337\" data-ref-id=\"3005-337\">Bowser</a></li></ul><h2>Scoring</h2><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">As mentioned above, tiles may be cleared in either \"combos\" or \"chains\" for additional points.</p><h3>Combos</h3><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">Combos are achieved by clearing more than three tiles simultaneously. This can be done either through clever tile manipulation, or by matching tiles to inactive rows as they appear on screen. A more advanced method, called \"garbage chaining,\" involves matching tiles in play with clearing rows of garbage from above. This is particularly useful for dealing with single blocks of thick garbage.</p><h3>The scoring details of combos are as follows:</h3><ul><li><strong>4 tiles:</strong> 20 points</li><li><strong>5 tiles:</strong> 30 points</li><li><strong>6 tiles:</strong> 50 points</li><li><strong>7 tiles:</strong> 60 points</li><li><strong>8 tiles:</strong> 70 points</li><li><strong>9 tiles:</strong> 80 points</li><li><strong>10 tiles:</strong> 100 points</li><li><strong>11 tiles:</strong> 140 points</li><li><strong>12 tiles:</strong> 170 points</li></ul><h3>Chains</h3><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">Chains are much more difficult to plan and execute than combos, and are thus worth substantially more points. Tiles must fall from above a clear into another clear to create a chain; once this condition is failed, the chain ends and a new one must be initiated. There are several advanced techniques involving chains, many of which are detailed in <strong>Advanced Gameplay Mechanics</strong> below. Noteworthy, however, is the fact that Tetris Attack does <em>not</em> in fact recognize chains of longer than 13 - rather than the standard x14 or x15 icon which would be the expected result of further chaining, players are presented with a x? icon and rewarded no points whatsoever for their continued efforts.</p><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">Another nuance in the scoring system involving chains, however, is that of \"bonuses.\" When a normal clear is made alongside a chain, that clear is awarded the same number of points as the current chain clear, instead of the standard clear amount. Thus, a standard strategy when trying to score points quickly is to quickly build out to a x13 chain, then instantly initiating as many standard three tile clears on the side as possible to maximize the number of points earned on the chain.</p><h3>The scoring details of chains are as follows:</h3><ul><li><strong>x2 chain:</strong> 50 points</li><li><strong>x3 chain:</strong> 80 points</li><li><strong>x4 chain:</strong> 150 points</li><li><strong>x5 chain:</strong> 300 points</li><li><strong>x6 chain:</strong> 400 points</li><li><strong>x7 chain:</strong> 500 points</li><li><strong>x8 chain:</strong> 700 points</li><li><strong>x9 chain:</strong> 900 points</li><li><strong>x10 chain:</strong> 1100 points</li><li><strong>x11 chain:</strong> 1300 points</li><li><strong>x12 chain:</strong> 1500 points</li><li><strong>x13 chain:</strong> 1800 points</li><li><strong>x14 chain:</strong> 0 points</li></ul><h2>Advanced Gameplay Mechanics</h2><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">Several nuances in Tetris Attack's engine allow for unique techniques while playing Tetris Attack. Since most rules are calculated on a frame-by-frame basis, some of the basic physical rules of the game can be bent - others may be broken. For instance, it is possible for a single tile to very briefly, while in the process of shifting between two columns, support two sets of falling tiles above it, just long enough to register the above tiles as a clear should they be positioned as such. This is particularly useful as a last-resort when attempted to keep chains alive. It is also possible, though vastly more difficult, to swap tiles in midair as they fall, and to swap tiles \"through\" clear arrangements such as they do not trigger the clear.</p><h2>Story and Multiple Endings</h2><figure style=\"width: 256px\" data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/7465/392205-tetris_attack028.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-392205\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.875\" data-width=\"256\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:87.5%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/7465/392205-tetris_attack028.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-392205\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"/uploads/scale_small/0/7465/392205-tetris_attack028.png\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"/uploads/scale_small/0/7465/392205-tetris_attack028.png\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Choosing one of the friends to free.</figcaption></figure><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">Tetris Attack's story is rather loose: there appears to be some sort of curse which has befallen all the major characters (who were enemies from <a href=\"/super-mario-world-2-yoshis-island/3030-2866\" data-ref-id=\"3030-2866\">Super Mario World 2: Yoshi's Island</a>, but are apparently now friends) except for <a href=\"/yoshi/3005-700\" data-ref-id=\"3005-700\">Yoshi</a>, and Yoshi must therefore battle each character in a VS mode match to free them. Upon freeing <a href=\"/lakitu/3005-927\" data-ref-id=\"3005-927\">Lakitu</a>, Bumpty, <a href=\"/poochy/3005-826\" data-ref-id=\"3005-826\">Poochy</a>, Flying Wiggler, Froggy, Blargg, Lunge Fish, and Rafael the Raven, the gang continues on to defeat Hookbill the Koopa, Naval Piranha, <a href=\"/kamek/3005-1227\" data-ref-id=\"3005-1227\">Kamek</a>, and finally <a href=\"/bowser/3005-337\" data-ref-id=\"3005-337\">Bowser</a> (in difficulty levels above easy) in the Cave of Darkness to win the day. Upon completion on hard, a code is given to the player to unlock \"hardest\" mode, and upon completion of hardest mode without dying, another code is given which allows the selection of characters prior to each match rather than only matches in the Cave of Darkness; the point is to choose characters other than Yoshi, as hinted at in the dialogue. Each level of completion involves a different set of dialogue at the end. However, this final step to achieving the VS mode \"perfect\" ending is rather superfluous, as it is no more difficult than beating the game on hardest without dying without the character selection.</p>", "deck": "Tetris Attack, derived from Panel de Pon in Japan, is one of the founding members of the \"swap and match\" tile-based puzzle gameplay style.", "aliases": "Panel de Pon", Green"}, {"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/person/3040-9684/", "site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/sandy-petersen/3040-9684/", "id": 9684, "name": "Sandy Petersen"}, {"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/person/3040-4559/", "site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/michael-abrash/3040-4559/", "id": 4559, "name": "Michael Abrash"}, {"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/person/3040-224/", "site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/mark-lamia/3040-224/", "id": 224, "name": "Mark Lamia"}, {"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/person/3040-4261/", "site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/aubrey-hodges/3040-4261/", "id": 4261, "name": "Aubrey Hodges"}, {"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/person/3040-2/", "site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/john-romero/3040-2/", "id": 2, "name": "John Romero"}, {"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/person/3040-4218/", "site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/scott-patterson/3040-4218/", "id": 4218, "name": "Scott Patterson"}], "description": "<h2>Overview</h2><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/329/1134314-psogl2_002.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1134314\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.75\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:75.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/329/1134314-psogl2_002.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1134314\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/329/1134314-psogl2_002.jpg\"/></a><figcaption>The main menu</figcaption></figure><p>Final Doom was originally released in 1996 for the <a href=\"/pc/3045-94\" data-ref-id=\"3045-94\">PC</a> and widely considered to be the hardest of the original <a href=\"/doom/3025-156\" data-ref-id=\"3025-156\">Doom series</a>. Final Doom consists of two separate standalone games built on the <a href=\"/doom-ii-hell-on-earth/3030-621\" data-ref-id=\"3030-621\">Doom II</a> engine. TNT: Evilution was developed by TeamTNT and The Plutonia Experiment was developed by the Casali brothers also from TeamTNT. Although not developed by <a href=\"/id-software/3010-347\" data-ref-id=\"3010-347\">id Software</a> themselves, Final Doom is an official <a href=\"/id-software/3010-347\" data-ref-id=\"3010-347\">id Software</a> product. Each game has a massive 32 levels (30 official and 2 secret levels.)</p><p>The game was released as the definitive challenge for the Doom veterans wanting more, hence the high difficulty and the name <i>Final Doom</i>.</p><p>A <a href=\"/playstation/3045-22\" data-ref-id=\"3045-22\">Playstation</a> version was later released containing levels from Final Doom and the map pack \"Master Levels for Doom II.\"</p><h2>TNT: Evilution</h2><p>Evilution is a game containing entirely new sprites and music tracks made by the developers. Features a slightly easier difficulty level than Plutonia, which ramps up towards harder levels instead of starting out at the highest difficulty. Unlike the earlier Doom games, the stages in this episode are designed to more closely resemble the areas that their names suggest.</p><p>LevelsDesigned by: <a href=\"/team-tnt/3010-681\" data-ref-id=\"3010-681\">TeamTNT</a></p><ol><li>System Control</li><li>Human BBQ</li><li>Power Control</li><li>Wormhole</li><li>Hanger</li><li>Open Season</li><li>Prison</li><li>Metal</li><li>Stronghold</li><li>Redemption</li><li>Storage Facility</li><li>Crater</li><li>Nukage Processing</li><li>Steel Works</li><li>Dead Zone</li><li>Deepest Reaches</li><li>Processing Area</li><li>Mill</li><li>Shipping / Respawing</li><li>Central Processing</li><li>Administration Center</li><li>Habitat</li><li>Lunar Mining Project</li><li>Quarry</li><li>Baron's Den</li><li>Ballistyx</li><li>Mount Pain</li><li>Heck</li><li>River Styx</li><li>Last Call</li><li>Pharaoh (secret level)</li><li>Caribbean (secret level)</li></ol><h2>The Plutonia Experiment</h2><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/1156/284577-0000002474.800x600.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-284577\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.625\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:62.5%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/1156/284577-0000002474.800x600.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-284577\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/1156/284577-0000002474.800x600.jpg\"/></a><figcaption>Final Doom is considerably harder than both Doom and Doom 2</figcaption></figure><p>The Plutonia Experiment is the more difficult of the two episodes. The player is immediately confronted with many of the game's most dangerous enemies while not yet entirely prepared to meet them. It also features a loose jungle theme and sends the player to some unusual environments not normally seen in the Doom Universe such as Aztec ruins and an ancient Egyptian Pyramid. Most of the stages in this episode also follow a more abstract layout more in line with those in the earlier Doom games.</p><p>LevelsDesigned by: Milo Casali, Dario Casali.</p><ol><li>Congo</li><li>Well of Souls</li><li>Aztec</li><li>Caged</li><li>Ghost Town</li><li>Baron's Lair</li><li>Caughtyard</li><li>Realm</li><li>Abattoire</li><li>Onslaught</li><li>Hunted</li><li>Speed</li><li>The Crypt</li><li>Genesis</li><li>The Twilight</li><li>The Omen</li><li>Compound</li><li>Neurosphere</li><li>NME</li><li>The Death Domain</li><li>Slayer</li><li>Impossible Mission</li><li>Tombstone</li><li>The Final Frontier</li><li>The Temple of Darkness</li><li>Bunker</li><li>Anti-Christ</li><li>The Sewers</li><li>Odyssey of Noises</li><li>The Gateway of Hell</li><li>Cyberden (secret level)</li><li>Go 2 It (secret level)</li></ol><h2>Weapons</h2><p>Final Doom adds no new weapons to the arsenal; it contains the same as found in Doom II.</p><table><tbody><tr><td><h3><a href=\"/fist/3055-693\" data-ref-id=\"3055-693\"><b>Fists</b></a></h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/13692/1408575-gzdoom_2010_06_17_14_30_05_27.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1408575\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.75\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:75.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/13692/1408575-gzdoom_2010_06_17_14_30_05_27.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1408575\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/1/13692/1408575-gzdoom_2010_06_17_14_30_05_27.png\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/1/13692/1408575-gzdoom_2010_06_17_14_30_05_27.png\"/></noscript></a></figure> When entirely out of ammo , your fists is your last option of self defense. The damage and attack rate of the fists are very low, but with the <a href=\"/berserk-pack/3055-1282\" data-ref-id=\"3055-1282\">berserk power-up</a> the fists turn into a deadly weapon for a short period of time.</td></tr><tr><td><h3><a href=\"/chainsaw/3055-168\" data-ref-id=\"3055-168\"><b>Chainsaw</b></a></h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/13692/1408578-gzdoom_2010_06_17_14_30_08_26.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1408578\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.75\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:75.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/13692/1408578-gzdoom_2010_06_17_14_30_08_26.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1408578\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/1/13692/1408578-gzdoom_2010_06_17_14_30_08_26.png\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/1/13692/1408578-gzdoom_2010_06_17_14_30_08_26.png\"/></noscript></a></figure> The chainsaw nearly nullifies the fists' existence with its superior damage and attack speed. The chainsaw is particularly useful against a single enemy since it stuns the enemy for periods of time. However, the chainsaw should still be seen as a last resort when low on ammo.</td></tr><tr><td><h3><a href=\"/pistol/3055-59\" data-ref-id=\"3055-59\"><b>Pistol</b></a></h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/13692/1408579-gzdoom_2010_06_17_14_30_10_80.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1408579\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.75\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:75.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/13692/1408579-gzdoom_2010_06_17_14_30_10_80.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1408579\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/1/13692/1408579-gzdoom_2010_06_17_14_30_10_80.png\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/1/13692/1408579-gzdoom_2010_06_17_14_30_10_80.png\"/></noscript></a></figure> The starting weapon. Its damage and attack speed is low and once the player is in possession of the chaingun, which uses the same ammunition, the pistol can be entirely ignored.</td></tr><tr><td><h3><a href=\"/shotgun/3055-114\" data-ref-id=\"3055-114\"><b>Shotgun</b></a></h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/13692/1408580-gzdoom_2010_06_17_14_30_14_27.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1408580\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.75\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:75.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/13692/1408580-gzdoom_2010_06_17_14_30_14_27.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1408580\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/1/13692/1408580-gzdoom_2010_06_17_14_30_14_27.png\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/1/13692/1408580-gzdoom_2010_06_17_14_30_14_27.png\"/></noscript></a></figure> The shotgun was the \"go-to\" weapon of the original <a href=\"/doom/3030-7326\" data-ref-id=\"3030-7326\">Doom</a>, but since the introduction of the Super Shotgun in <a href=\"/doom-ii-hell-on-earth/3030-621\" data-ref-id=\"3030-621\">Doom II</a>, its existence is somewhat nullified. Its fire rate is slow, but the high damage output makes up for it. Many players remember the enemies HP by how many shots from the shotgun they require. In Final Doom, the Shotgun is acquired at the same time as the Super Shotgun, so it is up to the preference of the player which shotgun to use when.</td></tr><tr><td><h3><a href=\"/super-shotgun/3055-848\" data-ref-id=\"3055-848\"><b>Super Shotgun</b></a></h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/13692/1408582-gzdoom_2010_06_17_14_30_17_12.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1408582\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.75\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:75.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/13692/1408582-gzdoom_2010_06_17_14_30_17_12.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1408582\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/1/13692/1408582-gzdoom_2010_06_17_14_30_17_12.png\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/1/13692/1408582-gzdoom_2010_06_17_14_30_17_12.png\"/></noscript></a></figure> First introduced in <a href=\"/doom-ii-hell-on-earth/3030-621\" data-ref-id=\"3030-621\">Doom II</a>, the Super Shotgun became the favorite weapon for many players. The fire rate is even slower than the original Shotgun, but the damage output and spread is very high. It shares ammunition with the standard Shotgun and fires two shots at a time.</td></tr><tr><td><h3><a href=\"/gatling-gun/3055-288\" data-ref-id=\"3055-288\"><b>Chaingun</b></a></h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/13692/1408583-gzdoom_2010_06_17_14_30_18_76.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1408583\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.75\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:75.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/13692/1408583-gzdoom_2010_06_17_14_30_18_76.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1408583\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/1/13692/1408583-gzdoom_2010_06_17_14_30_18_76.png\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/1/13692/1408583-gzdoom_2010_06_17_14_30_18_76.png\"/></noscript></a></figure> The chaingun is the fastest firing weapon in the game. Its damage is at the same level of the pistol, but the high fire rate makes it into a deadly weapon. It shares ammunition with the pistol, which means the players can fully ignore the pistol once they get their hands on the chaingun since there are no disadvantages.</td></tr><tr><td><h3><a href=\"/rocket-launcher/3055-211\" data-ref-id=\"3055-211\"><b>Rocket Launcher</b></a></h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/13692/1408584-gzdoom_2010_06_17_14_30_20_48.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1408584\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.75\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:75.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/13692/1408584-gzdoom_2010_06_17_14_30_20_48.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1408584\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/1/13692/1408584-gzdoom_2010_06_17_14_30_20_48.png\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/1/13692/1408584-gzdoom_2010_06_17_14_30_20_48.png\"/></noscript></a></figure> This is a very deadly weapon - both to the enemies and the player himself. The rockets deal a very high amount of damage and have <a href=\"/splash-damage/3015-347\" data-ref-id=\"3015-347\">splash damage</a>. Furthermore, the Rocket Launcher's fire rate is high, which makes the player able to carpet bomb areas.</td></tr><tr><td><h3><a href=\"/plasma-gun/3055-974\" data-ref-id=\"3055-974\"><b>Plasma Gun</b></a></h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/13692/1408585-gzdoom_2010_06_17_14_30_23_07.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1408585\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.75\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:75.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/13692/1408585-gzdoom_2010_06_17_14_30_23_07.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1408585\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/1/13692/1408585-gzdoom_2010_06_17_14_30_23_07.png\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/1/13692/1408585-gzdoom_2010_06_17_14_30_23_07.png\"/></noscript></a></figure> The Plasma Gun is often compared to the Chaingun. They both have a high firing rate and are generally useful in the same situations. The main difference between them is the projectile speed. Whereas the Chaingun's bullets hit the target instantly, the Plasma Gun's shots have to travel through the air before hitting the target, making it possible for enemies to dodge incoming attacks. The trade-off for this inaccuracy is a much higher damage output. The Plasma Gun shares ammunition with the BFG9000, so many players rarely use the Plasma Gun after getting the BFG.</td></tr><tr><td><h3><a href=\"/bfg9000/3055-26\" data-ref-id=\"3055-26\"><b>BFG9000</b></a></h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/13692/1408586-gzdoom_2010_06_17_14_30_25_80.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1408586\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.75\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:75.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/13692/1408586-gzdoom_2010_06_17_14_30_25_80.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1408586\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/1/13692/1408586-gzdoom_2010_06_17_14_30_25_80.png\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/1/13692/1408586-gzdoom_2010_06_17_14_30_25_80.png\"/></noscript></a></figure> The acronym in the name stands for Big Fucking Gun, and one thing is certain: it <i>is</i> a big fucking gun. The BFG9000 fires a huge plasma ball which moves slowly through the air. Upon impact, the target it hits receives a huge amount of damage and hits additional nearby enemies for a high amount of damage as well. The player in unable to damage himself with the weapon, which makes it the best weapon of choice against large groups of enemies that are relatively close to the player.</td></tr></tbody></table>", {"duration": "0:25:00", "runner": "Cubeface", "data": {"site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/strife/3030-10565/", "expected_release_quarter": null, "description": "<h2>Overview</h2><figure style=\"width: 320px\" data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/11/118253/2093704-strife_title.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2093704\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.75\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:75.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/11/118253/2093704-strife_title.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2093704\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/11/118253/2093704-strife_title.png\"/></a><figcaption>The Strife Title Screen.</figcaption></figure><p>Strife is a <a href=\"/pc/3045-94\" data-ref-id=\"3045-94\">PC</a> <a href=\"/first-person-perspective/3015-330\" data-ref-id=\"3015-330\">first-person</a> shooter which utilizes a modified version of <a href=\"/id-software/3010-347\" data-ref-id=\"3010-347\">id Software</a>'s <a href=\"/id-tech-1/3015-3803\" data-ref-id=\"3015-3803\">Doom engine</a>; it was released in May of 1996 by <a href=\"/velocity-inc/3010-1037\" data-ref-id=\"3010-1037\">Velocity</a> after first being developed (and cancelled) by <a href=\"/mountain-king-studios-inc/3010-2214\" data-ref-id=\"3010-2214\">Cygnus Studios</a> and later picked up and completed by <a href=\"/rogue-entertainment/3010-2094\" data-ref-id=\"3010-2094\">Rogue Entertainment</a>. It is primarily an action game, however it also incorporates a number of elements which were not common to shooters at the time, including a large unified game world, a quest-like mission system, and a significant amount of <a href=\"/voice-acting/3015-1413\" data-ref-id=\"3015-1413\">voice-over</a> throughout. Some of the gameplay systems on display, such as Strife's use of a player <a href=\"/inventory/3015-513\" data-ref-id=\"3015-513\">inventory</a> system and a hub-like level structure, can be seen in <a href=\"/raven-software/3010-1841\" data-ref-id=\"3010-1841\">Raven Software</a>'s earlier <a href=\"/heretic/3025-302\" data-ref-id=\"3025-302\">Heretic games</a>, which were also based on id technology. Strife also introduces a number of changes not previously seen in a Doom derivative, and embraces in particular many of the trappings of the role-playing genre, as outside of missions players are able to freely explore settlements where they are free to converse with <a href=\"/non-player-character/3015-967\" data-ref-id=\"3015-967\">non-player characters</a>, purchase items from vendors, or search for additional side activities all without needing to engage in combat. Strife was the last of the major retail Doom engine games to be released, with the others being <a href=\"/heretic/3030-10469\" data-ref-id=\"3030-10469\">Heretic</a>, <a href=\"/hexen/3030-22548\" data-ref-id=\"3030-22548\">Hexen</a>, and, of course, <a href=\"/doom/3030-7326\" data-ref-id=\"3030-7326\">Doom</a> (and <a href=\"/doom-ii-hell-on-earth/3030-621\" data-ref-id=\"3030-621\">Doom II</a>).</p><p>Having been released several months after the arrival of the popular <a href=\"/duke-nukem-3d/3030-3407\" data-ref-id=\"3030-3407\">Duke Nukem 3D</a> and its more technologically advanced <a href=\"/build-engine/3015-1733\" data-ref-id=\"3015-1733\">Build engine</a>, and scarcely a month prior to the much-anticipated <a href=\"/quake/3030-8015\" data-ref-id=\"3030-8015\">Quake</a> and its fully <a href=\"/polygonal-3d/3015-1430\" data-ref-id=\"3015-1430\">polygonal</a> <a href=\"/quake-engine/3015-1278\" data-ref-id=\"3015-1278\">Quake engine</a>, Strife did not receive the same amount of attention that many of its Doom engine forebears did. Reviewers at the time often noted that the game's graphical presentation was simply behind the times when stacked up against other contemporary titles (or those just on the horizon), though at the same time it also received positive remarks for paying attention to certain game elements which were commonly neglected by many shooters of its day, such as story and a cohesive environment.</p><p>The game was rereleased as \"The Original Strife: Veteran Edition\". It was released for PC, Mac, and Linux via <a href=\"/steam/3015-718\" data-ref-id=\"3015-718\">Steam</a> on December 12, 2014.</p><h2>Story</h2><p>The events of Strife take place within a world stricken by disease and oppression. In a time before, the world had been peaceful, even idyllic, though this reality was abruptly shattered and replaced by one far more bleak the day a solitary comet collided with the planet. In droves, People mysteriously began to fall sick, and millions would soon perish in a massive viral outbreak which coincided with the comet's arrival. Not all that were afflicted by the plague would die, but those that didn't laid claim to hearing a voice within their heads, a voice which they were compelled to obey. Those who could hear the voice began to look down upon those who could not, and before long they formed The Order, an organization devoted to achieving the goals of The One God, no matter the cost. The unafflicted were forced to submit to The Order; all aspects of life would eventually come under Order control, even procreation, and The Order's violent and indiscriminate ways led the remaining survivors to hide what few healthy women and children that remained below ground, as far from The Order's reach as could be mustered.</p><figure style=\"width: 320px\" data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/11/118253/2093705-the_order.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2093705\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.75\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:75.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/11/118253/2093705-the_order.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2093705\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/11/118253/2093705-the_order.png\"/></a><figcaption>The Order quickly seizes control in the wake of the viral epidemic.</figcaption></figure><p>For a time, those who suffered under The Order's persecution thought of little else save survival or escape from their bonds. Unfortunately, it became ever more apparent with the passage of time that The Order's influence was all-pervasive, and that if left unchecked the last remnants of humanity would simply be hunted to extinction or converted into mindless servants. It was from this realization that the resistance movement known as The Front came to be, a desperate gathering of citizens hoping to wrest The Order's influence from the lives of the populace by force. With The Order's significant numbers, advanced weaponry, and zealous methods, The Front could not afford to openly combat their adversaries until the conditions were right, and so its operatives maintained the utmost secrecy, hiding in the shadows and gathering arms and recruits where they could be found while also gathering any information that could possibly give them an edge against their oppressors.</p><p>The player enters these circumstances under the guise of a wandering mercenary whose displeasure with The Order has led him to offer his services to The Front. After a brief test of loyalty, the resistance welcomes him into the fold, sending him on important missions against The Order. Over the course of the game, the mercenary encounters and defeats several important figures within the cult, including The Programmer, The Bishop, and The Loremaster. Toward the game's climax, the wanderer discovers that The Order is controlled by an otherworldly being known as The Entity, and that the comet that heralded the beginning of the troubles was presumably the vessel that the creature had arrived in. Defeating The Entity is the player's final task in Strife, and depending upon what actions were taken beforehand, one of two endings is possible after winning, as well as a third in which the player loses to The Entity. In the better of the two endings, both The Order and the plague are eradicated, while in the lesser ending, the plague persists despite The Order's demise, causing the survivors to lose hope.</p><h2>Gameplay</h2><p>At the game's outset, the player arrives in the town of Tarnhill hoping to contact The Front. Tarnhill represents one of several neutral \"hub\" zones within Strife in which the player will not be attacked unless they behave aggressively. These areas serve a number of gameplay purposes. Missions are typically accepted and turned in within them, and they also contain various shops from which players can purchase weapons, <a href=\"/ammo/3055-533\" data-ref-id=\"3055-533\">ammunition</a>, <a href=\"/armor/3055-574\" data-ref-id=\"3055-574\">armor</a>, <a href=\"/health-pack/3055-255\" data-ref-id=\"3055-255\">health packs</a>, and other items. Furthermore, certain characters here also have the ability to increase the player's weapon accuracy and maximum hit points. Both can be upgraded a total of ten times over the course of the game, though there are usually prerequisites for receiving said upgrades. Players are rewarded with currency upon completing most missions, and it is understood (and in some instances specifically verbalized) that the player is to use this money in order to prepare themselves for the coming missions. In this sense, the hub areas of Strife can be viewed as interludes in the midst of the game's main action, places free from danger in which players can recuperate and restock before heading back out into more hostile lands.</p><figure style=\"width: 320px\" data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/11/118253/2094783-tarnhill_bar.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2094783\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.75\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:75.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/11/118253/2094783-tarnhill_bar.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2094783\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/11/118253/2094783-tarnhill_bar.png\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/11/118253/2094783-tarnhill_bar.png\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>A glimpse of the Tarnhill tavern, a location within the game's starting area.</figcaption></figure><p>Connected to the more centralized neutral zones are a variety of additional levels which the player must travel to in order to complete their objectives. These levels typically (but not always) require the player to engage in large amounts of combat, and it is within them that the game most resembles a traditional Doom-era first-person shooter. Enemies behave in rather straightforward fashion, usually waiting at a fixed point until the player passes by, which triggers them to attack. Quest objectives often do not specifically require the player to kill enemies within mission-critical areas, nonetheless it is not uncommon for the player to end up subduing the larger part of the enemy presence there over the course of a mission. There are some exceptions to this, the most notable being several maps in which the player has the option to infiltrate an Order-controlled area rather than simply resorting to violence. In these instances the player is able to remain incognito in the presence of foes that might otherwise attack. Triggering an alarm or acting suspiciously will still cue enemies to attack, and furthermore certain foes will always recognize the player as a threat, however this stealth system, if used properly, can allow players to successfully avoid combat in a number of situations.</p><p>As the game progresses, the player gradually gains access to larger segments of the game world, and in a similar fashion to earlier instances of more open first-person games, such as <a href=\"/system-shock/3030-13948\" data-ref-id=\"3030-13948\">System Shock</a>, there are very few restrictions placed upon the player when it comes to revisiting previous areas. Level progression is similar to <a href=\"/hexen/3030-22548\" data-ref-id=\"3030-22548\">Hexen</a>, in which a central hub level branches out into a number of attached levels that the player can travel back and forth from at will. Unlike Hexen's hub system, however, which transports the player to a new hub after finishing the current one, Strife is composed of a single interconnected set of levels, and as a result toward the game's end the player will be able to travel to almost any prior point in the game if they so choose. Outside of the game's hub areas, though, there is very little necessity or incentive to revisit most environments, as the player's actions within the world are persistent throughout, meaning that enemies and items will not respawn upon returning to previous levels.</p><h2>Weapons</h2><p>The Strife arsenal consists of eight weapons, including some well-worn staples of the first-person action game, such as an <a href=\"/assault-rifle/3055-413\" data-ref-id=\"3055-413\">assault rifle</a>, a <a href=\"/rocket-launcher/3055-211\" data-ref-id=\"3055-211\">rocket launcher</a>, and a <a href=\"/shotgun/3055-114\" data-ref-id=\"3055-114\">shotgun</a> equivalent. The means of acquiring these weapons can vary. They may be given, found, purchased, or constructed, and the most powerful of them can only be completed after defeating five bosses. Several of these armaments have more than one firing mode or a second ammunition type, and in these cases the player can cycle to the alternate mode or ammo simply by pressing that weapon's selection button a second time. Weapon ammo can be found throughout most levels, but it is often wise to purchase additional ammunition for the weapons one expects to use when the opportunity to do so arises, especially in the case of rarer types of ammunition. The Ammo Satchel item is also worth investing in early on, as it double's the player's ammo capacity across all weapons.</p><table><thead><tr><th>Appearance</th><th>Icon</th><th>Description</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><figure style=\"width: 196px\" data-align=\"left\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/11/118253/2092689-punch_dagger.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2092689\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.55612244897959\" data-width=\"196\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:55.6%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/11/118253/2092689-punch_dagger.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2092689\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/11/118253/2092689-punch_dagger.png\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/11/118253/2092689-punch_dagger.png\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Punch Dagger</figcaption></figure></td><td><ul><li>None (Starting Weapon)</li></ul></td><td><h3>Punch Dagger</h3><ul><li><u>Ammunition Type</u>: None</li></ul> The token melee implement of Strife, the Punch Dagger is the player's only defense at the beginning of the game, and is unsurprisingly outclassed as soon as the player obtains a ranged weapon. Even against the game's weaker foes, the Punch Dagger is not a particularly efficacious device, and when tackling larger ones, it is tantamount to suicide. It does become somewhat more potent over time, however, as the player's stamina rating has a direct effect on its potential damage.</td></tr><tr><td><figure style=\"width: 193px\" data-align=\"left\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/11/118253/2092666-crossbow.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2092666\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.46113989637306\" data-width=\"193\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:46.1%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/11/118253/2092666-crossbow.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2092666\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/11/118253/2092666-crossbow.png\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/11/118253/2092666-crossbow.png\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Crossbow</figcaption></figure></td><td><figure style=\"width: 58px\" data-align=\"left\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/11/118253/2092667-crossbow_icon.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2092667\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.37931034482759\" data-width=\"58\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:37.9%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/11/118253/2092667-crossbow_icon.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2092667\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/11/118253/2092667-crossbow_icon.png\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/11/118253/2092667-crossbow_icon.png\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Crossbow Icon</figcaption></figure></td><td><h3>Crossbow</h3><ul><li><u>Ammunition Types</u>: Electric Bolts, Poison Bolts</li></ul> The Crossbow is a solid if unspectacular weapon that can be obtained very early on. Its two bolt types, electric and poison, are meant to be used against mechanical and biological targets respectively. While certainly a better option than the Punch Daggers, the default electric rounds suffer from poor damage output and a slow rate of fire. The rarer poison rounds are an instant kill against any Acolyte, but are unfortunately useless against the game's myriad of mechanized foes.</td></tr><tr><td><figure style=\"width: 210px\" data-align=\"left\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/11/118253/2092662-assault_gun.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2092662\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.35238095238095\" data-align=\"left\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/11/118253/2092663-assault_gun_icon.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2092663\" data-size=\"small\" Gun</h3><ul><li><u>Ammunition Type</u>: Bullets</li></ul> Fireable in quick three-shot bursts or a continuous stream, the Assault Gun is a moderately powerful automatic rifle which can unleash a large number of rounds in fairly short order. Along with the Mini-Missile Launcher, it is considered one of the game's core weapons, being that it is reasonably effective against almost all types of opponents. Its rapid ammo consumption is its biggest drawback, making it somewhat of an inefficient way to deal with larger and more durable enemies.</td></tr><tr><td><figure style=\"width: 163px\" data-align=\"left\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/11/118253/2092686-mm_launcher.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2092686\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.50920245398773\" data-width=\"163\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:50.9%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/11/118253/2092686-mm_launcher.png\" data-width=\"80\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:40.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/11/118253/2092687-mm_launcher_icon.png\" Launcher</h3><ul><li><u>Ammunition Type</u>: Mini-Missiles</li></ul> The second of Strife's core weapons, the Mini-Missile Launcher is somewhat underpowered when compared to rocket launchers in other first-person shooters, however the relative abundance of its ammo and its usefulness against a wide variety of foes make it one of the more important weapons in the player's arsenal. In addition, the splash damage radius created by the mini-missiles is small enough that it can be used comfortably on foes in fairly close proximity to the player.</td></tr><tr><td><figure style=\"width: 215px\" data-align=\"left\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/11/118253/2092675-grenade_launcher.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2092675\" data-size=\"small\" data-align=\"left\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/11/118253/2092676-grenade_launcher_icon.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2092676\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.35555555555556\" data-width=\"90\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:35.6%\"
