"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_large/0/8960/1996759-serious_sam_the_random_encounter.png"}, "date_last_updated": "2012-09-17 13:53:47", "expected_release_month": null, "api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/game/3030-34402/", "number_of_user_reviews": 0, "original_release_date": "2011-10-24 00:00:00", "original_game_rating": null, "date_added": "2011-03-09 10:01:04", "platforms": [{"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/platform/3045-94/", "abbreviation": "PC", "site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/pc/3045-94/", "id": 94, "name": "PC"}], "expected_release_day": null, "expected_release_year": null, "id": 34402, "resource_type": "game", "name": "Serious Sam: The Random Encounter"}, "platform": "PC", "title": "Serious Sam: The Random Encounter"}
{"duration": "0:50:00", "runner": "Mr_Shasta", "data": {"site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/star-fox-assault/3030-2727/", "expected_release_quarter": null, "description": "<h2>Overview</h2><figure data-ref-id=\"1300-1270959\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/17172/1270959-sfa_009.png\" data-size=\"small\" data-align=\"right\" data-ratio=\"0.5625\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:56.3%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/17172/1270959-sfa_009.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1270959\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/1/17172/1270959-sfa_009.png\"/></a></figure><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">Star Fox: Assault is a sci-fi third-person shooter developed by <a href=\"/namco/3010-7420\" data-ref-id=\"3010-7420\">Namco</a> and published by <a href=\"/nintendo/3010-90\" data-ref-id=\"3010-90\">Nintendo</a> for the <a href=\"/gamecube/3045-23\" data-ref-id=\"3045-23\">GameCube</a> on February 14, 2005.</p><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">The fourth game in the <a href=\"/star-fox/3025-329\" data-ref-id=\"3025-329\">Star Fox</a> franchise, Star Fox: Assault returns the main gameplay of the series back to its shooter roots (after the action-adventure <a href=\"/star-fox-adventures/3030-19026\" data-ref-id=\"3030-19026\">Star Fox Adventures</a>), allowing the player to pilot an updated <a href=\"/arwing/3055-197\" data-ref-id=\"3055-197\">Arwing</a> spacecraft (through either a fixed path or with full freedom of movement) and an updated <a href=\"/landmaster-tank/3055-472\" data-ref-id=\"3055-472\">Landmaster</a> tank (with full freedom of movement). Players can also perform certain tasks in the game on-foot (similar to the hidden multiplayer mode in <a href=\"/star-fox-64/3030-19203\" data-ref-id=\"3030-19203\">Star Fox 64</a>) and can enter/exit their vehicle at-will.</p><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">Set a year after the events of Star Fox Adventures, players resume the role of <a href=\"/fox-mccloud/3005-418\" data-ref-id=\"3005-418\">Fox McCloud</a> as he leads the elite Star Fox team (<a href=\"/falco-lombardi/3005-420\" data-ref-id=\"3005-420\">Falco Lombardi</a>, <a href=\"/krystal/3005-748\" data-ref-id=\"3005-748\">Krystal</a>, and <a href=\"/slippy-toad/3005-419\" data-ref-id=\"3005-419\">Slippy Toad</a>, with <a href=\"/peppy-hare/3005-1615\" data-ref-id=\"3005-1615\">Peppy Hare</a> and <a href=\"/rob-64/3005-5602\" data-ref-id=\"3005-5602\">R.O.B.</a> on the <a href=\"/great-fox/3055-924\" data-ref-id=\"3055-924\">Great Fox</a>) throughout the <a href=\"/lylat-system/3035-555\" data-ref-id=\"3035-555\">Lylat</a> star system to combat a new invasive threat (the Aparoids, a race of part-machine, part-insect creatures bent on <a href=\"/borg/3015-1902\" data-ref-id=\"3015-1902\">assimilating other life forms</a>). Along the way, they cross paths with current and former members of the rival Star Wolf team of mercenaries (including newcomer <a href=\"/panther-caruso/3005-3284\" data-ref-id=\"3005-3284\">Panther Caruso</a>).</p><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">As bonus Namco <a href=\"/unlockables/3015-1414\" data-ref-id=\"3015-1414\">unlockables</a>, players can play the <a href=\"/nintendo-entertainment-system/3045-21\" data-ref-id=\"3045-21\">NES</a> version of <a href=\"/xevious/3030-1487\" data-ref-id=\"3030-1487\">Xevious</a> and, in the Japanese version only, the Famicom version of <a href=\"/star-luster/3030-41204\" data-ref-id=\"3030-41204\">Star Luster</a>.</p><h2>Gameplay</h2><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">There are three different gameplay types in Star Fox Assault. These types place the player in either an <a href=\"/arwing/3055-197\" data-ref-id=\"3055-197\">Arwing</a>, a <a href=\"/landmaster-tank/3055-472\" data-ref-id=\"3055-472\">Landmaster</a>, or on foot. Many missions consist of only a single type, but some make use of all three. All three gameplay types are also available for <a href=\"/split-screen-multiplayer/3015-322\" data-ref-id=\"3015-322\">multiplayer</a>. Each mission is completely linear, not unlike previous Star Fox titles.</p><figure style=\"width: 320px\" data-align=\"left\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/1675/366869-00121143.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-366869\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.56666666666667\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:56.7%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/1675/366869-00121143.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-366869\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/1675/366869-00121143.jpg\"/></a><figcaption>Fox in one of the on-foot portions</figcaption></figure><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">Arwing missions follow the same gameplay type as previous Star Fox games. Some missions are on-rails, with players defeating enemies in a certain level with a mandatory boss fight at the end. Other missions are in a small area where the player has a full freedom of movement, usually with certain objectives such as destroying certain Aparoid spawning points. Occasionally during missions, Fox's wingmates will be chased by an enemy, causing them to call for help. In some levels, Fox even has the option to jump out of the Arwing to explore on-foot (and possibly even jumping into a Landmaster).</p><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">On-foot and Landmaster portions of the game are all portions that give the player full freedom of movement. When playing on-foot, the game is essentially a third-person shooter. The player can pick up weapons such as a <a href=\"/machine-gun/3055-608\" data-ref-id=\"3055-608\">Machine Gun</a> and a Homing Launcher, which can be switched on the fly. As with the Arwing missions, the player can aid their wingmates, but from the ground instead. In two levels, Fox is on the wings of an Arwing or Wolfen picking off enemies on the ground with a <a href=\"/plasma-cannon/3055-1062\" data-ref-id=\"3055-1062\">Plasma Cannon</a>.</p><h3>Multiplayer</h3><figure style=\"width: 320px\" data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/7465/875543-561297_20040511_screen021.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-875543\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.7\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:70.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/7465/875543-561297_20040511_screen021.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-875543\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/7465/875543-561297_20040511_screen021.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/7465/875543-561297_20040511_screen021.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Multiplayer can take place on many stages, including this one.</figcaption></figure><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">Star Fox Assault has multiplayer support for up to four players (2-4). The multiplayer mode is very similar to an open action mission in the single-player campaign. In multiplayer games, however, instead of battling enemy opponents, it is other players. Multiplayer starts out very limited, but there can be much more unlocked, such as playable characters, <a href=\"/maps/3015-1780\" data-ref-id=\"3015-1780\">maps</a>, items, weapons, and modes. Most maps allow the player to play on foot or in a vehicle (Arwing, Wolfen, or Landmaster), but some only allow the player to be in one. Every member of the Star Fox team (excluding <a href=\"/rob-64/3005-5602\" data-ref-id=\"3005-5602\">R.O.B.</a>) is playable, as is <a href=\"/wolf-odonnell/3005-915\" data-ref-id=\"3005-915\">Wolf O'Donnel</a> of Star Wolf -- team Star Fox's rival pilot group.</p><h2>Plot</h2><figure style=\"width: 320px\" data-align=\"left\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/1675/366818-00121138.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-366818\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.56666666666667\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:56.7%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/1675/366818-00121138.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-366818\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/1675/366818-00121138.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/1675/366818-00121138.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Flying through space, fighting Oikonny's forces</figcaption></figure><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">Star Fox Assault takes place one year after the events of Star Fox Adventures. <a href=\"/andrew-oikonny/3005-2736\" data-ref-id=\"3005-2736\">Andrew Oikonny</a> ( <a href=\"/andross/3005-1443\" data-ref-id=\"3005-1443\">Andross</a>'s nephew) has taken control of Andross's army, and is now leading an uprising against <a href=\"/corneria/3035-548\" data-ref-id=\"3035-548\">Corneria</a>. Right away, the Star Fox team (now consisting of <a href=\"/fox-mccloud/3005-418\" data-ref-id=\"3005-418\">Fox McCloud</a>, <a href=\"/slippy-toad/3005-419\" data-ref-id=\"3005-419\">Slippy Toad</a>, <a href=\"/falco-lombardi/3005-420\" data-ref-id=\"3005-420\">Falco Lombardi</a>, <a href=\"/krystal/3005-748\" data-ref-id=\"3005-748\">Krystal</a>, and <a href=\"/peppy-hare/3005-1615\" data-ref-id=\"3005-1615\">Peppy Hare</a>) is called in to deal with the threat. They battle their way through Oikonny's forces, but Oikonny escapes to Fortuna. The team follows him, and fights a mock form of Andross's final form (albeit much weaker). However, before the battle is over, Oikonny's ship is destroyed by a large insect-like creature, which proceeds to attack the team. They manage to defeat it and grab its partial \"core memory\" before many more identical creatures attack the group.</p><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">The team regroups on the <a href=\"/great-fox/3055-924\" data-ref-id=\"3055-924\">Great Fox</a>, where <a href=\"/beltino-toad/3005-3306\" data-ref-id=\"3005-3306\">Beltino Toad</a> (Slippy's father) reveals to the team that the insect-like creature they fought was an Aparoid, a creature so strong that it could destroy an entire Cornerian fleet with little effort. Before they can do anything else, they pick up a distress signal coming from Katina. Suspecting Aparoid involvement, the team goes to the planet to investigate. Fox inspects the planet on-foot, but is trapped inside of a base along with the Aparoids. With the aid of his team (and a Landmaster dropped in), he fights off the Aparoids, as well as a large disk-like Aparoid with four legs. Before taking the Core Memory, however, <a href=\"/pigma-dengar/3005-1806\" data-ref-id=\"3005-1806\">Pigma Dengar</a> (the original sender of the distress message) sweeps in and steals it, revealing that he hopes to sell it for a high price.</p><figure style=\"width: 320px\" data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/7465/868399-sargosso.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-868399\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.705\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:70.5%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/7465/868399-sargosso.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-868399\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/7465/868399-sargosso.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/7465/868399-sargosso.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Sargasso Space Zone</figcaption></figure><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">The team tracks down Pigma to the Sargasso Space Zone, a popular hideout for bandits such as Pigma. Upon reaching there, the team is encountered by the Star Wolf team (now consisting of <a href=\"/wolf-odonnell/3005-915\" data-ref-id=\"3005-915\">Wolf O'Donnell</a>, <a href=\"/leon-powalski/3005-2734\" data-ref-id=\"3005-2734\">Leon Powalski</a>, and new member <a href=\"/panther-caruso/3005-3284\" data-ref-id=\"3005-3284\">Panther Caruso</a>). After being defeated by the Star Fox team, Panther (in an attempt to flirt with Krystal) reveals that Pigma has gone to Fichina. The team reaches Fichina, where Pigma has deactivated the planet's climate control, turning it into a snowy wasteland. They manage to destroy the Aparoids threatening to destroy the control center, and follow Pigma through an asteroid belt. They catch up to him and find that he has been taken over by Aparoids and has no control over his actions. They fight and defeat him, to gain another Core Memory, this one with information that could lead to the Aparoid Homeworld.</p><figure style=\"width: 320px\" data-align=\"left\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/7465/869301-wingridingsfa.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-869301\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.78354978354978\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:78.4%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/7465/869301-wingridingsfa.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-869301\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/7465/869301-wingridingsfa.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/7465/869301-wingridingsfa.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Corneria, after being attacked.</figcaption></figure><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">Before the team can go defeat the Aparoid Queen, however, Krystal receives a distress call from the planet Sauria (the setting of Star Fox Adventures). The team goes to the planet and defeats the Aparoids before too much damage can be caused. Krystal and Fox reunite with <a href=\"/prince-tricky/3005-4010\" data-ref-id=\"3005-4010\">Tricky</a>, who is now a teenage EarthWalker. Tricky asks if they are coming back to Sauria for their honeymoon, to which Fox stutters and Krystal laughs. Again, the team is delayed before they can go to the Aparoid Homeworld. This time, <a href=\"/general-pepper/3005-3294\" data-ref-id=\"3005-3294\">General Pepper</a> calls in to the team and informs them that the Aparoids have done a full force attack on Corneria, easily wiping out nearly all of the Cornerian Defense Fleet. With the aid of the Star Wolf team (who have come to help defeat a common enemy), they defeat the Aparoids. However, they learn that General Pepper's ship (along with General Pepper himself) has been taken over by Aparoids. General Pepper insists that Fox destroy him, and Fox complies by shooting down his ship. However, Peppy catches the General on his ship before he hits the ground. After this battle, the team heads to the Orbital Gate, a place where they can warp to the Aparoid Homeworld. Before they can warp there, they are forced to defend it from several Aparoid missiles ranging in sizes. They finish just in time, as Beltino finishes creating a program to destroy all of the Aparoids.</p><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">The team manages to make it to the Aparoid Homeworld, but the core of the homeworld is blocked by a base and a large shield. Fox infiltrates the base and destroys a large number of Aparoids. However, according to Slippy, the shields cannot be destroyed by mere laser power. Suddenly, the Great Fox comes into view, piloted by Peppy and <a href=\"/rob-64/3005-5602\" data-ref-id=\"3005-5602\">R.O.B.</a> The Great Fox is covered in Aparoids, and thus severely damaged. All power in the Great Fox is diverted towards its lasers, and it crashes into the shields, opening them wide and long enough for the team to fly through. The Great Fox, however, is destroyed, leading the team to believe that Peppy and R.O.B. are dead.</p><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">The team makes it to the core to confront the Aparoid Queen. In an attempt to dissuade the team, she uses the voices of R.O.B., General Pepper, Peppy, Pigma, and <a href=\"/james-mccloud/3005-2021\" data-ref-id=\"3005-2021\">James McCloud</a> (Fox's father). Wolf encourages Fox, however, and he ignores the voices. They blast through the Queen's thick armor, giving Fox enough time to deliver the program. Unfortunately, the Queen suppresses it. Slippy informs Fox that if he does not destroy the Queen, she will create an antibody. The team manages to destroy the Queen, carrying out the self-destruct program in the process. They escape the core, and find that Peppy and R.O.B. survived as well (they used an escape pod before the ship was destroyed). This gives them hope that others who sacrificed to defeat the Aparoids also survived.</p><h2>Characters</h2><h3>Fox McCloud</h3><figure style=\"width: 320px\" data-align=\"left\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/7465/869327-561297_20040511_screen014.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-869327\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"1.2265625\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:122.7%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/7465/869327-561297_20040511_screen014.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-869327\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/7465/869327-561297_20040511_screen014.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/7465/869327-561297_20040511_screen014.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Fox McCloud</figcaption></figure><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">Fox McCloud is the longtime leader of the mercenary squadron Star Fox. It has been one year since the events of Star Fox Adventures, in which Fox saved the planet Sauria (also known as Dinosaur Planet) from the menace that is Andross. There, he met Krystal, a female fox with mysterious origins. Since then, the two have developed a bit of a love interest. Fox is the strong leader and skilled pilot of the team; the person everyone looks up to. Of course, the player plays as Fox in the single player campaign, making him one of the most important characters. In this adventure, he must defeat the threat of the Aparoids, and keep them from consuming the <a href=\"/lylat-system/3035-555\" data-ref-id=\"3035-555\">Lylat System</a>.</p><h3>Falco Lombardi</h3><figure style=\"width: 250px\" data-align=\"left\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/4997/400718-250px_starfox__1_.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-400718\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"1.704\" data-width=\"250\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:170.4%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/4997/400718-250px_starfox__1_.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-400718\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/4997/400718-250px_starfox__1_.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/4997/400718-250px_starfox__1_.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Falco Lombardi</figcaption></figure><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">Falco Lombardi was mysteriously missing in the last game. His reason for being absent was that he had grown bored with no action in the team. He is back now, this time sporting a bright red jumpsuit. He is the ace pilot of the team, with skills exceeding even those of Fox. As an effect of this, Falco is incredibly cocky and competitive. Despite his constant arguments with Fox (and the rest of the team), he really loves hanging out with his team, and is an indispensable part of the Star Fox team.</p><h3>Krystal</h3><figure style=\"width: 320px\" data-align=\"left\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/727/386293-krystal2.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-386293\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.8\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:80.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/727/386293-krystal2.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-386293\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/727/386293-krystal2.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/727/386293-krystal2.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Krystal</figcaption></figure><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">Krystal is a mysterious female fox who has only recently joined the Star Fox team. She was first encountered as the \"damsel-in-distress\" of Star Fox Adventures, in which Fox rescued her from the menace of Andross. She has since decided to join the team, and is a decent Arwing pilot herself. Krystal and Fox are a little bit of an item, as they are both interested in each other (which is poked fun at during the game). She is without her trademark staff in this game, instead using the more modern weapons used by the rest of the Star Fox team.</p><h3>Slippy Toad</h3><figure style=\"width: 320px\" data-align=\"left\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/7888/255057-slippy3.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-255057\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"1.4150943396226\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:141.5%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/7888/255057-slippy3.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-255057\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/7888/255057-slippy3.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/7888/255057-slippy3.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Slippy Toad</figcaption></figure><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">Slippy Toad returns as the team's trusty mechanic. Slippy repairs all of the vehicles, manages the team's equipment, and provides information on bosses and other important things. Slippy isn't as good of a pilot as Falco or Fox, but he can still hold for himself during an aerial battle (although during the single player campaign, Fox will have to rescue him several times). If he is rescued, however, he drops an item for Fox to use. Many players have found Slippy to be an annoyance, but according to many, he wasn't as annoying in this game, and was rather tolerable.</p><h3>Peppy Hare</h3><figure style=\"width: 320px\" data-align=\"left\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/1453/317946-peppy_i_6184.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-317946\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"1.687\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:168.7%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/1453/317946-peppy_i_6184.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-317946\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/1453/317946-peppy_i_6184.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/1453/317946-peppy_i_6184.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Peppy Hare</figcaption></figure><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">Peppy Hare is the elderly Star Fox team member. He has been in the team since the days of James McCloud, yet he still respects Fox and offers his sage wisdom from time to time. Peppy doesn't actually fly around in an Arwing this game, but rather sits in the Great Fox with R.O.B., and commands the team from there. At one point during the game, he appears to sacrifice himself to the Aparoids, but he and R.O.B. manage to utilize the escape pod on the Great Fox, and fly to freedom.</p><h3>Wolf O'Donnell</h3><figure style=\"width: 320px\" data-align=\"left\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/12062/416965-wolf.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-416965\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"1.4141176470588\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:141.4%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/12062/416965-wolf.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-416965\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/1/12062/416965-wolf.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/1/12062/416965-wolf.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Wolf O'Donnell</figcaption></figure><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">Wolf O'Donnell is the leader of the Star Wolf team, and a longtime rival of Fox. Wolf is also an expert pilot, with his skills rivaling those of even Falco. In fact, in multiplayer, he is the character with the best stats (five stars in every area). Wolf may seem like a heartless mercenary, but he does assist the Star Fox team in Assault. The teams join together to fight a common enemy, but by <a href=\"/star-fox-command/3030-498\" data-ref-id=\"3030-498\">Star Fox Command</a>, the teams are back to their usual rivalry.</p><h2>Vehicles</h2><figure style=\"width: 320px\" data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/7465/871625-561297_20040511_screen002.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-871625\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.707\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:70.7%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/7465/871625-561297_20040511_screen002.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-871625\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/7465/871625-561297_20040511_screen002.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/7465/871625-561297_20040511_screen002.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Arwing II</figcaption></figure><ul><li><b>Arwing</b> - The main vehicle of the Star Fox team. Naturally, the ship is slightly renovated, which has lead fans to unofficially call it the \"Arwing II.\"</li><li><b>Landmaster</b> - The Landmaster is a secondary vehicle of the Star Fox team; their \"tank\" ground vehicle. It also has many renovations, and fans have dubbed it the \"Landmaster II.\"</li><li><b>Great Fox</b> - The Great Fox has been completely redone, as last time it was seen, it was crumbling away into ruin. Thankfully, it has been fixed up and is now much sleaker.</li><li><b>Wolfen</b> - The main vehicle of the Star Wolf team. There are some more substantial differences than other models of the ship, leading fans to dub it the Wolfen III.</li></ul><h2>Items and Weapons</h2><figure style=\"width: 305px\" data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/7465/871631-ill15.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-871631\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"1.3770491803279\" data-width=\"305\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:137.7%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/7465/871631-ill15.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-871631\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/7465/871631-ill15.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/7465/871631-ill15.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>1-UP</figcaption></figure><ul><li><b>1-UP</b> - 1-UPs present Fox with an extra life. This allows the player to pick up mid-level, rather than starting over the game.</li><li><b>Barrier Sphere</b> - The Barrier Sphere is a helpful item that, when activated, makes the player temporarily invincible.</li><li><b>Shield Rings (Gold and Silver)</b> - Rings return from previous games to reward the player with ample amounts of health, if they are inside a vehicle. They can also be dropped by allies and enemies, so they are everywhere.</li><li><b>First Aid Kit (Green, Silver, and Gold)</b> - The First Aid Kits are the equivalent of the Shield Rings, except they heal the player when outside of a vehicle. The Green heals a little bit of health, the Silver heals about half, while the rare Gold heals fully.</li><li><b>Special Flag</b> - There are fifty flags in all to find in the single player campaign (five in each of the ten levels). Finding them will unlock various things, including the Devil Launcher in multiplayer.</li><li><b>Smart Bomb</b> - Smart Bombs are a Star Fox tradition. Smart Bombs can be picked up during the level (the player never starts with one), and then fired into a group of enemies, detonating and destroying them. They are much rarer than in previous games.</li><li><b>Laser Power Upgrade (Green and Red)</b> - Another Star Fox standard, the laser upgrades are the same that were in Star Fox Adventures and <a href=\"/star-fox-64/3030-19203\" data-ref-id=\"3030-19203\">Star Fox 64</a>. Picking them up will enhance the lasers, making them much more powerful, and changing their visual appearance.</li><li><b>Stealth Suit (Multiplayer Only)</b> - A multiplayer-only item that (upon being picked up) grants the player invisibility.</li><li><b>Blaster</b> - Fox's default weapon while on foot. Unlike many of the other weapons, it can be charged for a powerful blast. It also never runs out of ammo, making it an all-around versatile gun.</li><li><b>Gattling Gun</b> - The Gattling Gun is basically an automatic version of the Blaster. It lacks the ability to charge, but makes up for it in its ability to quickly clear large rooms of enemies.</li><li><b>Homing Launcher</b> - The Homing Launcher is a useful weapon that can even lock onto enemies. Its reload times aren't exactly stellar, however, so it is best to use it in an area with not many enemies.</li><li><b>Machine Gun</b> - The Machine Gun is essentially a more powerful version of the Gattling Gun. With a high rate of fire and powerful projectiles, it is a good alternative to the Blaster.</li><li><b>Plasma Cannon</b> - The Plasma Cannon can only be used during the single player campaign whenever Fox is riding on someone else's wing. It is incredibly powerful and has infinite ammo, making it quite fun to use when there is the chance.</li><li><b>Sniper Rifle</b> - The Sniper Rifle can only be used when the player is zoomed in and immobile. However, a fired shot is as powerful as a direct hit from the Homing Launcher. It can be quite helpful during a heated multiplayer match.</li><li><b>Grenade</b> - The Grenade is more of the icing on the cake than an actual useful weapon. It can be held onto, allowing the player to decide when it is detonated. It is pretty useful for clearing rooms of enemies, but otherwise it is useless.</li><li><b>Sensor Bomb</b> - The Sensor Bomb is essentially a motion sensing mine. The idea behind it is to lay a trap for the enemies. This makes it pretty useless in single player missions where Fox can run into a room guns blazing. However, it is useful during multiplayer matches, as the opponents are likely to stumble upon a Sensor Bomb at some point.</li><li><b>Devil Launcher (Multiplayer Only)</b> - The Devil Launcher is an incredibly powerful gun that must be unlocked for use in multiplayer. It is a \"one-hit kill\" gun, destroying anything that is aimed at.</li></ul>", "deck": "Star Fox returns to its shooter roots (with the bonus of new on-foot combat) in its fourth installment (developed by Namco), as Fox must lead the Star Fox team against a new threat bent on assimilating all lifeforms on Lylat.", "aliases": "Starfox Assault", "image": {"icon_url": {"duration": "1:05:00", "runner": "Simpol, Pro_JN", "data": {"site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/zelda-ii-the-adventure-of-link/3030-16241/", "expected_release_quarter": null, "description": "<h2>Overview</h2><figure data-ref-id=\"1300-932748\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/8430/932748-zelda2adventureoflink.jpg\" data-size=\"small\" data-align=\"right\" data-embed-type=\"image\" data-ratio=\"1.116\" data-width=\"320\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:111.6%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/8430/932748-zelda2adventureoflink.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-932748\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/8430/932748-zelda2adventureoflink.jpg\"/></a><figcaption>Like the original game, Zelda II's first NES release used special gold-colored cartridges.</figcaption></figure><p>Zelda II: The Adventure of Link is the second game in <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/nintendo/3010-90\" data-ref-id=\"3010-90\">Nintendo's</a> <a href=\"/the-legend-of-zelda/3025-9\" data-ref-id=\"3025-9\">The Legend of Zelda</a> franchise, as well as the second and final Zelda title on the <a href=\"/nes/3045-21\" data-ref-id=\"3045-21\">Nintendo Entertainment System</a>. It was released in the United States on December 1, 1988. Originally, the game was only released on the <a href=\"/famicom-disk-system/3045-91\" data-ref-id=\"3045-91\">Famicom Disk System</a> in Japan, and was converted in format to an NES cartridge game for American and European audiences.</p><p>As was the case for the original release of the first Legend of Zelda, Zelda II's original North American release used special gold-colored catridges. Across all territories, the game sold 4.8 million copies. Zelda II has since been rereleased on a variety of platforms in both physical and digital format, including the <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/game-boy-advance/3045-4\" data-ref-id=\"3045-4\">Game Boy Advance</a>, <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/wii/3045-36\" data-ref-id=\"3045-36\">Wii</a>, <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/nintendo-3ds/3045-117\" data-ref-id=\"3045-117\">3DS</a>, and <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/wii-u/3045-139\" data-ref-id=\"3045-139\">Wii U</a>.</p><h2 style=\"margin-right:0px;margin-left:0px;\">Franchise Influence</h2><p>Though many specifics of the game's format have not been used in the franchise since, it has had a strong influence on the franchise with elements it introduced. It was the first game in the series to feature towns houses that can be explored, and NPCs also have a much more expanded role and play a pivotal role in Link's journey. Zelda II is also the first game in the series to feature a proper magic system with a separate gauge used to measure Link's magical reserves.</p><p>Perhaps the most unique element of Zelda II is its side-scrolling action perspective. Sides-scrolling gameplay has not played a major role in the franchise since its use in this title, save for two of the three <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/cd-i/3045-27\" data-ref-id=\"3045-27\">Philips CD-i</a> Zelda titles produced without Nintendo's involvement. However, sidescrolling elements would later be reused in a minor way in some of the handheld Zelda adventures.</p><h2>Gameplay</h2><h3 style=\"margin-right:0px;margin-left:0px;\">Overworld</h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/5312/511932-zelda2aol_57.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-511932\" data-size=\"small\" data-embed-type=\"image\" data-ratio=\"0.875\" data-width=\"256\" style=\"width: 256px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:87.5%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/5312/511932-zelda2aol_57.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-511932\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/5312/511932-zelda2aol_57.png\"/></a><figcaption>The overworld.</figcaption></figure><p>Zelda II: The Adventure of Link eschews the gameplay format of the original <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/the-legend-of-zelda/3030-11949\" data-ref-id=\"3030-11949\">Legend of Zelda</a>, and no entry in the series has played like it since. While it keeps a top-down perspective for the overworld, combat does not directly take place from this viewpoint. Like many RPGs, the overworld perspective is used for travel throughout Hyrule, from town to town and dungeon to dungeon.</p><p>The overworld is broken down into segments which initially cannot be traversed until Link is able to acquire the appropriate item. For example, some routes are blocked by impassable boulders that cannot be circumvented in the early portions of the game. However, after Link acquires the hammer, he is gains the ability to smash boulders, clearing these paths. In this way, the game keeps a sense of linearity where most dungeons need to be completed in a certain order so that the appropriate item can be obtained.</p><h3 style=\"margin-right:0px;margin-left:0px;\">Sidescrolling and Combat</h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/5312/511968-zelda2aol_48.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-511968\" data-size=\"small\" data-embed-type=\"image\" data-ratio=\"0.875\" data-width=\"256\" style=\"width: 256px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:87.5%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/5312/511968-zelda2aol_48.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-511968\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/5312/511968-zelda2aol_48.png\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/5312/511968-zelda2aol_48.png\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Link takes on a dungeon boss.</figcaption></figure><p>When in the overworld, the player will find towns and caves to enter and explore, as well as roving icons representing monster encounters. When entering a town, dungeon, or a monster battle, the perspective shifts from overhead to a 2-D sidescrolling viewpoint in which Link is able to move left and right, jump, crouch, swing his sword, and guard using his shield. The majority of the game's primary action takes place in this viewpoint.</p><h3 style=\"margin-right:0px;margin-left:0px;\">Character Progression</h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/5312/511963-zelda2aol_23.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-511963\" data-size=\"small\" data-embed-type=\"image\" data-ratio=\"0.875\" data-width=\"256\" style=\"width: 256px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:87.5%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/5312/511963-zelda2aol_23.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-511963\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/5312/511963-zelda2aol_23.png\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/5312/511963-zelda2aol_23.png\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Link visiting a town.</figcaption></figure><p>Link earns <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/experience-points/3015-39\" data-ref-id=\"3015-39\">experience points</a> as he defeats enemies. Zelda II remains the only game in the franchise that features a proper experience point-based leveling mechanic. Each time Link levels up, he is able to spend experience points to upgrade one of three stats; his attack power, his magic gauge, or his health gauge. While exploring, the player can also acquire hearts or magic bottles that extend the maximum length of his health and magic gauges, respectively.</p><h3 style=\"margin-right:0px;margin-left:0px;\">Limited Lives</h3><figure data-ref-id=\"1300-511940\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/5312/511940-zelda2aol_65.png\" data-size=\"small\" data-align=\"right\" data-embed-type=\"image\" data-ratio=\"0.875\" data-width=\"256\" style=\"width: 256px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:87.5%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/5312/511940-zelda2aol_65.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-511940\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/5312/511940-zelda2aol_65.png\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/5312/511940-zelda2aol_65.png\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>The Game Over screen seen when Link loses all of his lives.</figcaption></figure><p>Unlike the other games in the series, the player has three lives when starting a game. When Link dies, either by running out of health or falling into a pit, he will restart at the entrance to the current screen. However, when Link has lost all of his lives, the game is over and the player has to restart from the North Castle; the starting point of the game. Extra lives in the form of small Link dolls can be found in secret locations around the world.</p><h3 style=\"margin-right:0px;margin-left:0px;\">Magic Spells</h3><p>The Adventure of Link was the first game in the series to feature a magic system. It is also the first game that provides Link with a list of spells, as well as a magic gauge that governs their usage. Similar to other role-playing games, any time Link uses a magic spell, it drains energy from the magic gauge. Link learns new spells as he travels, acquiring them from the wise men in each of the towns he visits on his quest. These spells don't come easy, however, as Link often has to complete side quests that involve such tasks as retrieving items and killing monsters before the wise men will teach him their spells. Many of the spells in the game are integral to the game's progress, such as the Jump spell that temporarily boosts Link's maximum jump height, or the Fairy spell that transforms Link into a small, flying fairy capable of crossing long gaps and chasms.</p><h2>Story</h2><p>Set after the original Legend of Zelda, The Adventure of Link revolves around Link's quest to remove a curse placed upon <a href=\"/zelda/3005-5\" data-ref-id=\"3005-5\">Princess Zelda</a>. When her father the king passed away, the <a href=\"/triforce/3055-18\" data-ref-id=\"3055-18\">Triforce</a> was supposed to go to Zelda\u2019s brother, the prince. However, the king, unsure of his son's true nature, had instead told Zelda the location of the final piece of the Triforce, the Triforce of Courage. The prince, eventually learning of this from a wizard, goes to Zelda, demanding to know the location of the Triforce of Courage, but Zelda refuses to tell him. The wizard casts a spell on the princess, causing her to sleep forever unless the full Triforce is recovered, but passes away before the prince can convince him to undo the spell. Realizing his error, the grief-stricken prince keeps Princess Zelda in the North Castle, where she is to sleep until her curse can be lifted. He also decreed that henceforth all princesses in Hyrule would be named Zelda.</p><figure data-ref-id=\"1300-528810\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/7128/528810-zelda_ii_shadow.jpg\" data-size=\"small\" data-align=\"left\" data-embed-type=\"image\" data-ratio=\"0.875\" data-width=\"256\" style=\"width: 256px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:87.5%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/7128/528810-zelda_ii_shadow.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-528810\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/7128/528810-zelda_ii_shadow.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/7128/528810-zelda_ii_shadow.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Link must face his own shadow at the end of the game.</figcaption></figure><p>Following Link's triumph over Ganon in the original game, Ganon\u2019s minions are in a state of unrest, as his spirit still remains, but needs Link\u2019s blood in order to come back to life. After Link learns of the curse placed upon Princess Zelda, he sets out to recover the Triforce of Courage. By doing so, he can destroy Ganon once and for all, bring peace back to Hyrule, and rouse Princess Zelda from her eternal sleep.</p><p>Link's quest takes him across Hyrule and into six different palaces, acquiring items and spells to help him along the way. Upon entering the final dungeon, Link is forced to once again fight the spirit of Ganon. However, even with Ganon defeated and the Triforce of Courage in sight, Link has one more trial he must overcome. He must fight his own <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/dark-link/3005-5534\" data-ref-id=\"3005-5534\">shadow</a>. After proving his worth, Link receives the Triforce of Courage and uses the power of the completed Triforce to awaken Zelda.</p><h2 style=\"margin-right:0px;margin-left:0px;\">Trivia</h2><figure data-ref-id=\"1300-2005787\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/7395/2005787-million.png\" data-size=\"small\" data-align=\"right\" data-embed-type=\"image\" data-ratio=\"0.875\" data-width=\"256\" style=\"width: 256px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:87.5%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/7395/2005787-million.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2005787\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/7395/2005787-million.png\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/7395/2005787-million.png\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>The completed Triforce.</figcaption></figure><ul><li style=\"margin-right:0px;margin-left:0px;\">Most of the town names in the game, specifically <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/rauru/3035-4649\" data-ref-id=\"3035-4649\">Rauru</a>, <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/ruto/3035-4648\" data-ref-id=\"3035-4648\">Ruto</a>, <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/saria/3035-4647\" data-ref-id=\"3035-4647\">Saria</a>, <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/nabooru/3035-4645\" data-ref-id=\"3035-4645\">Nabooru</a>, <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/mido/3035-4646\" data-ref-id=\"3035-4646\">Mido</a>, and <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/darunia/3035-4644\" data-ref-id=\"3035-4644\">Darunia</a>, were reused as the names of characters that appear in <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/the-legend-of-zelda-ocarina-of-time/3030-12572\" data-ref-id=\"3030-12572\">The Legend of Zelda: Ocarina of Time</a>. Of those characters, all save <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/mido/3005-10241\" data-ref-id=\"3005-10241\">Mido</a> are <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/sages-of-hyrule/3015-2248\" data-ref-id=\"3015-2248\">sages of Hyrule</a>.</li><li style=\"margin-right:0px;margin-left:0px;\">According to the book <em>Hyrule Historia</em>, Zelda II is currently the final game in the \"Decline of Hyrule\" timeline, which branches off from Ocarina of Time in the event that Ganondorf is victorious and is not stopped by Link.</li><li style=\"margin-right:0px;margin-left:0px;\">Zelda II is the first game in the series that does not feature <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/rupee/3055-44\" data-ref-id=\"3055-44\">rupees</a> or any other form of collectable currency, and there are no shops in the game.</li><li style=\"margin-right:0px;margin-left:0px;\">Zelda II is the first game in the series to depict the complete Triforce, with its distinct three-triangle appearance.</li></ul>", "deck": "Zelda II: The Adventure of Link is the second entry in the ground-breaking Zelda franchise. {"duration": "0:30:00", "runner": "PJ", "data": {"site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/bionic-commando/3030-20656/", "expected_release_quarter": null, "description": "<h2>Summary</h2><br />Halfway between a direct port and a remake, Bionic Commando follows roughly the same story as <a data-ref-id=\"3030-7860\" href=\"/bionic-commando/3030-7860\">   the game of the same name</a> on the <a data-ref-id=\"3045-21\" href=\"/nes/3045-21\">  Nintendo Entertainment System</a>. The protagonist is <a data-ref-id=\"3005-124\" href=\"/nathan-rad-spencer/3005-124\">     Rad Spencer</a>, the best of the bionic commando corps, and his mission is to rescue <a data-ref-id=\"3005-52\" href=\"/super-joe/3005-52\">    Super Joe</a> from Director Wiseman's Doraize Dukedom. Using an assortment of guns and his grapple-launching bionic arm, Rad is airdropped into various levels and must locate and destroy their command center or boss to continue.<br /><br />The game is a tried and true platformer, trading the ability to jump for a grappling hook that can be shot horizontally, upwards or up at an angle. It can stun enemies, retrieve items or latch onto solid objects so that Rad can swing about the stage and launch himself into the air. Between levels, Rad gets a ride from a helicopter that can follow branching paths between hostile levels and neutral zones where equipment and contacts can be found. Enemy dropships also patrol the paths; when the helicopter encounters them, Rad is dropped into a short, linear stage where he must defeat parachuting enemies and get to the end of the zone.<br /><br />Over the game, Rad gains specialized pieces of equipment that can offer additional strategic options when in battle. He also gets access to a growing selection of guns to choose from before being airdropped. As each gun can have its advantages, selecting the right tool for the job is the key to victory.<br /><br />The game does not use a save system, instead relying on a password mechanic to let the player pick up where he left off over multiple play sessions. Passwords consist of various geometric shapes arranged on a grid.<br /><br /><h2>Game Boy Vs N.E.S. Differences</h2><br />Despite sporting drastically different visual styles, both the Game Boy and the Nintendo versions of Bionic Commando have strong similarities. Being a reboot of sorts, Bionic Commando on the Game Boy takes the original story and tweaks it while still paying respect to the original Japanese version.<br /><br /><h3>Story</h3>Instead of going up against the Nazis lead by Adolf Hitler, or the Badds led by Generalissimo Killt, Rad instead takes the fight to the Doraize Dukedom and its leader, Director Wiseman (the original name of Killt's character from the Japanese version of the NES Bionic Commando). Additionally, while the NES version had the Badds plot to revive Master D, the Game Boy's Director Wiseman instead only sought to activate the Albatross, a mighty flying fortress.\u00a0 In the end, both games require the same precise finishing blow to achieve victory, except that the Game Boy's final explosion lacks a certain bit of color (in the form of an animated sequence of Hitler's head exploding).<br /><br /><h3>Visual Theme</h3>While the original NES title had a contemporary military theme overall, the Game Boy incarnation punches up the technology level into sci-fi territory. Characters leave the modern army templates aside to go for spiky hair, arm-mounted cannons, futuristic armour and the iconic grapple.<br /><br />Of note are the cinematics of the opening sequence, which are a step up from the NES ones. They go so far as to trick depth of field effects out of the limited Game Boy hardware to make backgrounds seem blurry and far away.<br /><br /><h3>Gameplay</h3>Travel over the overland map is still the same in both versions, except that enemy transports were changed from trucks to high-tech dropship aircraft. While in the original, the troop transport encounters were top-down, here they keep the same platform mechanics found in the rest of the game and enemies parachute down instead. The game as a whole is also more forgiving than the NES Bionic Commando, starting the player off with a three-hit lifebar (as opposed to the NES's one-hit-wonder commando) and using a mild RPG element for lengthening it as enemy tokens are obtained.", "deck": "The Game Boy version of Bionic Commando is technically the third in the series but is not a direct sequel. A remake of the N.E.S. Bionic Commando, but with a futuristic look, a different villain and light gameplay tweaks, all while keeping the level design nearly identical.", "aliases": null, "image": {"icon_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/square_avatar/8/87790/2768036-box_bcgb.jpg", "medium_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_medium/8/87790/2768036-box_bcgb.jpg", "tiny_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/square_mini/8/87790/2768036-box_bcgb.jpg", "small_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/8/87790/2768036-box_bcgb.jpg", "thumb_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_avatar/8/87790/2768036-box_bcgb.jpg", "screen_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/screen_medium/8/87790/2768036-box_bcgb.jpg", "super_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_large/8/87790/2768036-box_bcgb.jpg"}, "date_last_updated": "2015-07-24 04:11:22", "expected_release_month": null, "api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/game/3030-20656/", "number_of_user_reviews": 0, "original_release_date": "1992-09-19 00:00:00", "original_game_rating": [{"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/game_rating/3065-29/", "id": 29, "name": "ESRB: E10+"}], "date_added": "2008-05-18 18:01:00", "platforms": [{"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/platform/3045-3/", "abbreviation": "GB", "site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/game-boy/3045-3/", "id": 3, "name": "Game Boy"}, {"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/platform/3045-138/", "abbreviation": "3DSE", "site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/nintendo-3ds-eshop/3045-138/", "id": 138, "name": "Nintendo 3DS eShop"}], "expected_release_day": null, "expected_release_year": null, "id": 20656, "resource_type": "game", "name": "Bionic Commando"}, "platform": "NES", "title": "Bionic Commando"}
{"duration": "0:30:00", "runner": "Klaige", "data": {"site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/shatterhand/3030-18628/", "expected_release_quarter": null, "description": "<h2>Gameplay</h2><p>Shatterhand is a side-scrolling action-platforming game. Levels have horizontal and vertical progression, designed with multiple platforms, ledges and even fences on which to grab. Levels are generally capped off with a boss battle. Though not a one-hit-kill game, the player character can take damage merely by touching enemies. The protagonist can also jump and crouch. His jump is a fair mix between tight and floaty, allowing for lenient mid-air control resembling that of a <a href=\"/mega-man/3025-523\" data-ref-id=\"3025-523\">Mega Man</a> game. He can also punch while crouching and in the air, but can only punch left or right--he cannot throw uppercuts to take down enemies above his head.</p><p>While the primary means of self-defense is this simple punch, the player character can punch crates to collect power-ups in order to summon a floating drone which attacks with a different set of projectiles every time he punches. Drones are summoned once the player collects three drone power-ups, which are denoted as either Alpha or Beta. With the three slots and the two power-ups, there are six different possible combinations. Furthermore, punching a power-up changes it to its counterpart (punch an Alpha power-up and it will change into a Beta), so the player hascontrol over which drone they want to summon. If they happen to collect three alpha/beta power-ups while they already have a drone summoned, they will then don a metallic suit that increases strength and gives the player character a special attack corresponding to the combination of power-ups they've obtained.</p><p>The player can also collect currency from crates, which can be used on power-up platforms that increase the strength of their punches; give an extra life; or replenish their health. Some crates will yield a moneybag which can be collected, but it's more beneficial to actually <i>punch </i>the bag repeatedly to generate extra money--similar to how one might collect multiple coins repeatedly from the same block in <a href=\"/super-mario-bros/3025-1899\" data-ref-id=\"3025-1899\">Super Mario Bros.</a> games. Some creates yield grenades which will detonate after a short period of time. These cannot be picked up and must be avoided.</p>", "deck": "An action game in which the player controls a special agent with cybernetic hands.", "aliases": "Tokkyuu Shirei Solbrain", "image": {"icon_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/square_avatar/9/93770/2362193-nes_shatterhand.jpg", "medium_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_medium/9/93770/2362193-nes_shatterhand.jpg", "tiny_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/square_mini/9/93770/2362193-nes_shatterhand.jpg", "small_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/9/93770/2362193-nes_shatterhand.jpg", "thumb_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_avatar/9/93770/2362193-nes_shatterhand.jpg", "screen_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/screen_medium/9/93770/2362193-nes_shatterhand.jpg", "super_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_large/9/93770/2362193-nes_shatterhand.jpg"}, "date_last_updated": "2013-06-22 21:52:58", "expected_release_month": null, "api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/game/3030-18628/", "number_of_user_reviews": 0, "original_release_date": "1991-10-26 00:00:00", "original_game_rating": null, "date_added": "2008-04-01 16:41:47", "platforms": [{"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/platform/3045-21/", "abbreviation": "NES", "site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/nintendo-entertainment-system/3045-21/", "id": 21, "name": "Nintendo Entertainment System"}], "expected_release_day": null, "expected_release_year": null, "id": 18628, "resource_type": "game", "name": "Shatterhand"}, "platform": "NES", "title": "Shatterhand"}
{"duration": "0:24:00", "runner": "ShiningDragoon, Darkwing Duck", "data": {"site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/rygar/3030-10397/", "expected_release_quarter": null, "description": "<p><em>Note: This page refers to the Nintendo Entertainment System version of Rygar, which was an open-world action-adventure game, not the linear arcade release and its many ports which can be found <a href=\"/rygar/3030-26561\" data-ref-id=\"3030-26561\">here</a>.</em></p><h2>Overview</h2><p>Rygar is an open-world action-adventure game where the player assumes the role of a \"Legendary Warrior\" who battles through a hostile landscape. The main form of attack is a spinning shield on a chain called the \"diskarmor,\" which is tossed out like a yo-yo. The game is primarily set from a side-scrolling perspective, but there are also some occasional top-down sections.</p><p>The game is based on an arcade game of the same name, but the original version of the game is a straightforward action game, with none of the story or freedom allowed by this NES release.</p><p>Over time, <a href=\"/rygar/3005-342\" data-ref-id=\"3005-342\">Rygar </a>(known simply as the Legendary Warrior in Japanese versions of the game) collects additional items that open up access to different parts of the game, with the end goal being a final confrontation with the evil Ligar, who lives in a sky castle high above the land of Argool.</p><h2>Plot</h2><blockquote>\"4.5 billion years have passed since Earth's creation. Many dominators have ruled in all their glory, but time was their greatest enemy and it defeated their reign. And now a new dominator's reign begins...\"<br /><em>From the opening of the arcade game</em></blockquote><p>While this is very abstract, the manuals for the console releases reveal that the evil being Ligar has taken over the land of Argool, and that Rygar, a dead warrior who has risen from his grave, must use his Diskarmor along with a variety of other weapons to stop him. In console versions, clues and limited dialogue are given in the form of large, sage-like men encountered in stone green temples throughout the game. In the Japanese original, references to \"Ligar\" and \"Rygar\" are one and the same, due to the fact that the Roman syllables \"Li\" and \"Ry\" come from the same Japanese character. As such, the hero is only referred to as \"The Legendary Warrior\", while both \"Rygar\" and \"Ligar\" refer to the main villain.</p><p>The Japanese version of this game contains different music than its English localizations.</p><p>Despite existing as a counterpart to an existing arcade game, this NES version of Rygar was released back into arcades on Nintendo's PlayChoice-10 hardware in 1987.</p>", "deck": "Rygar is a classic game for many home consoles. {"duration": "0:11:00", "runner": "Skavenger216, feasel, Gyre, JamEvil", "data": {"site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/ironsword-wizards-warriors-ii/3030-12176/", "expected_release_quarter": null, "description": "<h2>Overview</h2><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/6518/343461-wizwar20000.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-343461\" data-size=\"small\" style=\"width: 256px\" data-ratio=\"0.875\" data-width=\"256\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:87.5%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/6518/343461-wizwar20000.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-343461\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_super/0/6518/343461-wizwar20000.png\"/></a><figcaption>The title screen</figcaption></figure><p>Ironsword was developed by Zippo Games which was a development studio under Rare. Acclaim Entertainment acquired the publishing rights, and wanted sequals despite sales of the game never being strong. Ironsword is seen as the most difficult and frustrating game in the series as a result of technical issues.</p><h2>Plot</h2><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/6518/343465-wizwar20001.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-343465\" data-size=\"small\" style=\"width: 256px\" data-ratio=\"0.875\" data-width=\"256\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:87.5%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/6518/343465-wizwar20001.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-343465\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_super/0/6518/343465-wizwar20001.png\"/></a><figcaption>The world map of Ironsword</figcaption></figure><p>Kuros, the protagonist of the first game, returns to battle his arch enemy the evil wizard Malkil. Malkil has taken control of the four elemental powers (wind, water, fire and earth) that bind the land. In order to defeat Malkil, Kuros must restore the only weapon that is powerful enough to defeat the wicked Wizard, the Ironsword. However, the lost pieces of the Ironsword is guarded by Malkil in form of the four elemental powers.</p><h2>Gameplay</h2><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/6518/343467-wizwar20002.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-343467\" data-size=\"small\" style=\"width: 256px\" data-ratio=\"0.875\" data-width=\"256\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:87.5%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/6518/343467-wizwar20002.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-343467\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_super/0/6518/343467-wizwar20002.png\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_super/0/6518/343467-wizwar20002.png\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>The shop where you buy items and weapons</figcaption></figure><p>Ironsword is mostly a platformer with role-playing and action elements. You will mostly use precision jumping skills to navigate through the game. You will occasionally fight enemy's and make your charactrer stronger, but these elements are not scene as frequent as platforming. The goal in the game is to collect the four lost pieces of the powerful Ironsword wich is needed to defeat Malkil. Each piece is guarded by an elemental power and you will go through a domain of two stages for each power. In the first stage you must find an animal king that will help you to next stage if you give him a golden object that is hidden somwhere in the stage. In the second stage of the domain you must find a certain magic spell that must be used to defeat the Elemental in the end of the stage.</p><p>When all four Elementals are defeated and the Ironsword is reassembled, you can climb the IceFire Mountain for a final confrontation with Malkil. However, the final boss is a battle with the four elements and not a fight with Malkil in his true form.</p><p>A shop can be found in every stage where Kuros can buy weapons and items. There is also a Pachinko style mini game in the shop were you can gamble in order to win more gems to use in the shop.</p>", "deck": "The second game in the Wizards and Warriors trilogy. 12:56:38", "expected_release_quarter": null, "first_appearance_people": [{"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/person/3040-58865/", "site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/masashi-kageyama/3040-100590/", "id": 100590, "name": "Masashi Kageyama"}], "description": "<h2>Overview</h2><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/8273/817045-1170738619_01.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-817045\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.876\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:87.6%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/8273/817045-1170738619_01.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-817045\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/8273/817045-1170738619_01.png\"/></a><figcaption>Mr. Gimmick.</figcaption></figure><p>Mr. Gimmick is a <a href=\"/nintendo-entertainment-system/3045-21\" data-ref-id=\"3045-21\">Famicom/NES</a> game by<a href=\"/sunsoft/3010-19\" data-ref-id=\"3010-19\"> Sunsoft</a> that was only released in Japan and Scandinavia. The game was supposedly scheduled for release worldwide, but was never released outside the aforementioned territories.</p><p>Since it was released so late in the FC/NES lifespan, the game sold poorly. The Japanese release is a bit more common, but the Scandinavian release is now considered to be one of the rarest and most expensive SCN region games released, and is sought after by collectors. It has a cult following these days due to its great gameplay and technically impressive graphics and soundtrack.</p><h2>Story</h2><p>The intro opens with a girl blowing out candles on her birthday. She receives a present which turns out to be Mr. Gimmick, a plush toy doll. She loves him more than any of her other toys. Because of this, the other toys get jealous and kidnap the girl while she sleeps, taking her into the dimension of toys. Now it's up to Mr. Gimmick to save her.</p><p>Mr. Gimmick features two endings. In order to get the good ending, the player must collect a secret item in each of the first six stages of the game without using any continues. Only by doing this is the path to the true final stage and boss unlocked.</p><h2>Gameplay</h2><figure data-align=\"left\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/8273/817047-1170738620_00.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-817047\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.876\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:87.6%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/8273/817047-1170738620_00.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-817047\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/8273/817047-1170738620_00.png\"/></a><figcaption>The world map.</figcaption></figure><p>Mr. Gimmick is a side-scrolling platformer. Mr. Gimmick's only weapon and tool is a star he can create and throw. The star is used to defeat enemies, and can be used to solve simple environmental puzzles.</p><p>The star features a simple physics system that affects how it bounces depending on from where it's dropped; the higher it's dropped from, the higher it will bounce. And so if Mr. Gimmick jumps before throwing it, or throws it from a platform, it will bounce higher. Mr. Gimmick can also stand on top of the star as it bounces if he jumps on top of it. Jumping on a thrown star is required to progress in some areas of the game.</p><p>In the game's first six levels, Mr. Gimmick must find a hidden item somewhere in the stage, and then defeat the boss at he end. As stated above, to get the good ending and rescue the girl, Mr. Gimmick must collect the hidden item in every level to make the final, secret level appear, and defeat the final boss. If any of the hidden items are missed, or any continues are used, the game will end after the boss on level 6, resulting in a bad ending where the girl is not rescued.</p><h2>Trivia</h2><ul><li>The Japanese version of the game starts Mr. Gimmick out with three lives, while the Scandinavian version starts him out with seven lives.</li></ul><ul><li>The Japanese release had a special version of the AY-3-8910 sound chip, also used in the Amstrad CPC and Atari ST computers, embedded in the MMC chip to help the regular Famicom sound chip with the music. This sound chip was not embedded in the MMC in the Scandinavian release because the NES does not have pins on the connector for external sound chips, instead having four pins for the lockout chip. Because of this, the Scandinavian version's soundtrack is reworked to only use the internal NES sound chip. As a result, some instruments are missing in some songs, or sometimes sound different than in the Japanese version.</li></ul><ul><li>The Scandinavian release, like most of Sunsoft's PAL releases, is optimized for 50hz. Because of this, the soundtrack does not sound correctly when played on an NTSC NES console. Not just that it runs faster, but the digitized drums and DPCM sounds are especially affected. Since the graphics have also been tweaked for the PAL NES, there are also major graphics glitches when playing on an NTSC NES.</li></ul><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/9560/1630637-dsc_8600.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1630637\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.66666666666667\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:66.7%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/9560/1630637-dsc_8600.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1630637\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/9560/1630637-dsc_8600.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/9560/1630637-dsc_8600.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>The PCB of the Scandinavian release, showing the custom mapper chip (the square-shaped chip).</figcaption></figure><ul><li>The game uses a custom mapper chip, the Sunsoft <a href=\"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Memory_Management_Controller#FME-7\" rel=\"nofollow\">FME-7</a>, which enhances the graphics capabilities of the console. This was included in both the Japanese and Scandinavian release, though the Japanese version includes the AY-3-8910 sound chip embedded as mentioned previously. Having a custom MMC chip was pretty common for Famicom games, but on the NES it was very unusual. Most other third party games that used a custom mapper chip, like <a href=\"/konami-corporation/3010-87\" data-ref-id=\"3010-87\">Konami</a>'s <a href=\"/contra/3030-4350\" data-ref-id=\"3030-4350\">Contra</a>, were reworked for Nintendo's MMC chips when released for NES. This chip, together with the sound chip in the Japanese release, probably added up to make this an expensive game to manufacture.</li></ul>", "releases": [{"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/release/3050-89880/", "site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/mr-gimmick/3030-6037/releases/", "id": 89880, "name": "Gimmick!"}, {"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/release/3050-89881/", "site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/mr-gimmick/3030-6037/releases/", "id": 89881, "name": "Mr. Gimmick"}], "franchises": null, "api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/game/3030-6037/", "number_of_user_reviews": 0, "objects": [{"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/object/3055-1818/", "site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/star/3055-1818/", "id": 1818, "name": "Star"}, {"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/object/3055-365/", "site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/beam-sword/3055-365/", "id": 365, "name": "Beam Sword"}, {"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/object/3055-97/", "site_detail_url": {"duration": "0:16:00", "runner": "digshake", "data": {"site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/demon-sword/3030-19193/", "expected_release_quarter": null, "description": "<h2>Overview</h2><p>Demon Sword (Fudo Myouoden in Japan, named after the Buddhist deity <a data-ref-id=\"3005-21908\" href=\"/fudo-myo-o/3005-21908\">Fudo Myo-o</a>) is a side-scrolling action game with a very fast pace, the hero Victar moving across the screen quite rapidly. The goal is to defeat a demon using a multi-pronged sword which requires some assembling before the final battle.</p><p>The game is a spiritual successor of sorts to <a data-ref-id=\"3010-135\" href=\"/taito-corporation/3010-135\">Taito</a>'s earlier <a data-ref-id=\"3030-10701\" href=\"/the-legend-of-kage/3030-10701\">The Legend of Kage</a>, as it shares a similar sense of speed and high-leaping action. The game is also quite reminiscent of <a data-ref-id=\"3010-7421\" href=\"/tecmo/3010-7421\">Tecmo</a>'s <a data-ref-id=\"3030-1653\" href=\"/ninja-gaiden/3030-1653\">Ninja Gaiden</a> games, with the difficult to avoid enemies and the array of ninja powers at Victar's command.</p><p>Though the game did receive an American version, it was greatly reduced in size to fit onto the standard 2mb cart. This includes losing almost half the stages in the game, several of the powers and a newly truncated ending sequence. Demon Sword's cover also inexplicably features a tanned western barbarian, rather than the svelte pale figure in red the game depicts.</p>", "deck": "Control Victar as he attempts to destroy the Dark Fiend's demonic horde in this NES action/adventure game.", "aliases": "Fudo Myouoden", "image": {"icon_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/square_avatar/9/93770/2361653-nes_demonsword.jpg", "medium_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_medium/9/93770/2361653-nes_demonsword.jpg", "tiny_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/square_mini/9/93770/2361653-nes_demonsword.jpg", "small_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/9/93770/2361653-nes_demonsword.jpg", "thumb_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_avatar/9/93770/2361653-nes_demonsword.jpg", "screen_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/screen_medium/9/93770/2361653-nes_demonsword.jpg", "super_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_large/9/93770/2361653-nes_demonsword.jpg"}, "date_last_updated": "2013-05-09 19:25:05", "expected_release_month": null, "api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/game/3030-19193/", "number_of_user_reviews": 0, "original_release_date": "1990-01-31 00:00:00", "original_game_rating": null, "date_added": "2008-04-01 16:45:33", "platforms": [{"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/platform/3045-21/", "abbreviation": "NES", "site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/nintendo-entertainment-system/3045-21/", "id": 21, "name": "Nintendo Entertainment System"}], "expected_release_day": null, "expected_release_year": null, "id": 19193, "resource_type": "game", "name": "Demon Sword"}, "platform": "NES", "title": "Demon Sword"}

A loose remake of the original <a href=\"/castlevania/3030-6673\" data-ref-id=\"3030-6673\">Castlevania</a>, Haunted Castle is one of the two <a href=\"/castlevania/3025-86\" data-ref-id=\"3025-86\">Castlevania </a>games to be released in American arcades (with the other being <a href=\"/castlevania/3030-6673\" data-ref-id=\"3030-6673\">Vs. Castlevania</a>). In Japan, the game was ported to the <a href=\"/playstation-2/3045-19\" data-ref-id=\"3045-19\">PlayStation 2 </a>by <a href=\"/hamster-corporation/3010-4703\" data-ref-id=\"3010-4703\">HAMSTER </a>in 2006 as Oretachi Geasen Zoku Sono 15: Akumajou Dracula.</p><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\"> </p><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\"> </p><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\"> </p><h2>Gameplay</h2><figure data-ref-id=\"1300-2554108\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/7/73970/2554108-0000map.png\" data-size=\"medium\" data-align=\"right\" data-embed-type=\"image\" data-ratio=\"0.875\" data-width=\"256\" style=\"width: 256px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:87.5%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/7/73970/2554108-0000map.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2554108\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_medium/7/73970/2554108-0000map.png\"/></a><figcaption>World map of Haunted Castle</figcaption></figure><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">The player controls <a href=\"/simon-belmont/3005-86\" data-ref-id=\"3005-86\">Simon Belmont</a>, who must rescue his bride, <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/serena/3005-27920\" data-ref-id=\"3005-27920\">Serena</a>, from the clutches of the evil <a href=\"/dracula/3005-348\" data-ref-id=\"3005-348\">Count Dracula </a>using his <a href=\"/vampire-killer/3055-284\" data-ref-id=\"3055-284\">whip </a>and other weapons like a chain or sword at his disposal.</p><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">There are six levels(1.Graveyard / 2.Cave / 3.Banquet Room / 4.Basement / 5.Clocktower / 6.Vampire's Room) Simon Belmont has fight through to free his bride Serena.
