{"duration": "0:33:00", "runner": "RogueLink", "data": {"site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/gargoyles-quest-ii-the-demon-darkness/3030-16653/", "expected_release_quarter": null, "description": "<h2>Overview</h2><p>Gargoyle's Quest II: The Demon Darkness is the second <a href=\"/gargoyles-quest/3025-911\" data-ref-id=\"3025-911\">Gargoyle's Quest</a> game, a spin-off series from <a href=\"/ghosts-n-goblins/3025-243\" data-ref-id=\"3025-243\">Ghosts 'N Goblins</a> (a.k.a. Makai-Mura). The player once again takes the role of <a href=\"/firebrand/3005-2548\" data-ref-id=\"3005-2548\">Firebrand</a>, or Red Arremer, as he first attempts to prove his worth by defeating his kingdom's training region before he is sent to investigate a larger menace that threatens the whole Ghoul realm. The game is a prequel, taking place long before both the original <a href=\"/gargoyles-quest/3030-13688\" data-ref-id=\"3030-13688\">Gargoyle's Quest</a> and the Ghosts 'N Goblins games (it pre-dates human civilization, in fact).</p><p>The game is mechanically similar to its predecessor: the game splits its game time between a top-down view that is reminiscent of RPGs like <a href=\"/dragon-quest/3025-160\" data-ref-id=\"3025-160\">Dragon Quest</a>, and side-scrolling action stages. In these action stages, Firebrand can grow more powerful by acquiring new weapons and upgrades, and can use his limited flight capacity to evade traps and reach new areas, and is another power that can be upgraded. The game uses a password system to save progress, despite being a 1992 release and thus late into the NES's lifespan.</p><p>Gargoyle's Quest II was followed by one more sequel: <a "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/screen_medium/11/117218/2476086-5218939409-Arika.jpg", "tiny_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/square_mini/11/117218/2476086-5218939409-Arika.jpg", "original_release_date": "1998-12-31 00:00:00", "first_appearance_characters": null, "developers": [{"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/company/3010-328/", "site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/arika-co-ltd/3010-328/", "id": 328, "name": "Arika Co., Ltd."}], "first_appearance_objects": [{"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/object/3055-1142/", "site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/meteor/3055-1142/", "id": 1142, "name": "Meteor"}, {"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/object/3055-1722/", "site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/tetromino/3055-1722/", "id": 1722, "name": "Tetromino"}], "expected_release_year": null, "publishers": [{"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/publisher/3010-367/", "site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/capcom/3010-367/", "id": 367, "name": "Capcom"}], "date_last_updated": "2015-01-28 20:25:38", "expected_release_quarter": null, "first_appearance_people": null, "description": "<h2>Overview</h2><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">Tetris: The Grand Master (abbreviated TGM) is a <a href=\"/tetris/3025-291\" data-ref-id=\"3025-291\">Tetris</a> game that was developed by <a href=\"/arika-co-ltd/3010-328\" data-ref-id=\"3010-328\">Arika</a> and released in 1998. In many ways, it can be considered a spiritual successor to <a href=\"/sega/3010-62\" data-ref-id=\"3010-62\">Sega</a>'s Tetris, which appeared in Japanese arcades in 1988. TGM inherits many defining traits from Sega's game and builds upon that core with new mechanics refinements and challenges.</p><h2>Gameplay</h2><h3>Rotation</h3><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">TGM adopts Sega's simple yet effective rotation tables. With the exception of the red I-piece, every pieces are always kept level when rotated (i.e. aligned with the bottom of the bounding box); this helps ensure a piece can rotate cleanly on the surface of the stack, which is crucial when the game reaches the highest fall speeds.</p><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">One addition to the rotation system comes in the form of wallkicks: if the piece collides with something when rotating, the game tries to nudge the piece one cell to the right or one cell to the left (in that order) before failing to rotate. There are a few exceptions where wallkicks will not be applied:</p><ol><li>for I or O pieces.</li><li>for L/J/T pieces, if the center column of the piece will be blocked after rotation.</li><li>when using Initial Rotation (see below).</li></ol><h3>Game flow</h3><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">Like Sega Tetris, TGM features a brief <em>entry delay</em> before each piece appears that can be used to prepare the next move. By holding left or right during this period, the player can \"warm up\" or <em>charge</em> movement so the next piece will enter the playfield moving full speed. The player may also \"pre-rotate\" (or <em>Initial Rotate</em>) the piece once by holding the desired rotation button until the piece appears.</p><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">TGM maintains the quick piece movement speed afforded in Sega Tetris. After holding left/right for a brief, quarter-second delay, the piece continues moving at a rate of one unit per frame (or, <em>1 </em><i>G)</i>. Holding down to drop a piece also moves at the rate of 1G.</p><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">Another crucial feature inherited from Sega is <em>lock delay</em>. Whereas most other early Tetris games would lock pieces into place as soon as they touched the ground, Sega allowed a half-second delay before the piece locked. This allowed Sega Tetris to offer challenging yet playable 1G fall speeds, where other games shied away or relegated it to use as a kill-screen. TGM continues in these footsteps and pushes beyond into new frontiers -- 2G, 3G, 5G, and even 20G (i.e., max gravity or instant drop) fall speeds are achieved.</p><h3>Levels</h3><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">Unlike many other <em>Tetris</em> games, progress is not solely tied to the number of lines cleared. Instead, the level counter increases by one for every piece placed or line cleared. As a result, game speed can gradually change as the player continues to place pieces, even if they are not necessarily clearing lines. (In another nod to Sega Tetris, at one or two level checkpoints the speed will actually drop to give the player a short breather rather than relentlessly continue to speed up.)</p><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">At the end of each <em>section</em> of 100 lines, the player must clear a line to progress to the next. (i.e., if the player reaches the <em>level stop</em> at 99, the counter will not continue to increase until a line is cleared.)</p><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">At level 500, the fall speed plateaus at 20G. The player must continue to endure the restrictions of max gravity play and reach level 999 to complete the game.</p><h3>Time Attack</h3><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">Another divergence from typical Tetris norms is a shift in focus to speed rather than just score. While earning points does play a key role in achieving some of the game's main goals, it does not directly impact one's position on a machine's leaderboard - instead, a player's ranking is determined by a combination of grade (see more on Grades below) and how quickly they achieved it. Once players have filled the game's ranking with Grand Master performances, earning a high score becomes a matter of racing to complete the game the quickest</p><h3>Scoring</h3><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">Points are scored whenever lines are cleared. A few factors determine the value of the line clear:</p><ul><li>number of lines cleared - as usual, scoring four line clears (or tetrises) is the most lucrative, triple and double line clears are moderately valued, and single line clears earn a pittance.</li><li>current level - point values gradually and linearly increase throughout the game.</li><li>number of rows the piece was forced by holding down.</li><li>combo bonus for continuing to clear lines with consecutive pieces.</li><li><em>Bravo</em> bonus - 4x multiplier for performing a \"perfect clear\" removing all blocks from the playfield.</li></ul><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">However, as earning points alone is not the core focus of the game, so it's not strictly necessary to employ more complex scoring methods; playing quickly and making tetrises will earn a sufficient number of points to achieve endgame goals.</p><h3>Grades</h3><p data-right-indent=\"0\" data-left-indent=\"0\">Another new feature is the Grade Recognition System. The player is awarded grades for passing certain score milestones or meeting other criteria. The player starts at grade 9 when the game begins and works their way up. The scale ranges from 9 to 1, S1 to S9, and finally the title of Grand Master (or GM). The player must meet various conditions throughout the game:</p><ul><li>achieve grade 1 and level 300 within 4 minutes 15 seconds.</li><li>achieve grade S4 and level 500 within 7 minutes 30 seconds.</li><li>earn at least 126,000 points and finish the game within 13 minutes 30 seconds.</li></ul>", "releases": [{"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/release/3050-139285/", The game is available both as a downloadable version and a retail version. There is a standard edition and a deluxe edition available, which includes the season pass for upcoming DLC tracks and bike parts.</p><h2>Gameplay</h2><p>The game uses the tried and true Trials formula: It's possible to control the acceleration and the brakes of the bike, and to make the rider lean forwards or backwards. If done right this can lead, to advanced techniques, e.g. bunny hopping.</p><p>The trick system, including a points and combo counter, is a new addition to a series that has focused more on precision and momentum than scoring points.</p><p>Tricks are performed by using the right stick to position the rider's legs. The trick system is entirely physics-based, instead of relying on canned animations or set button inputs.</p><p>Tricks can be performed on regular tracks, just for fun or to complete track specific challenges, or on specially designed FMX tracks, where the goal is to score as many points as possible.</p><p>New to the game is a useable <a href=\"/atv/3055-1420\" data-ref-id=\"3055-1420\">ATV</a>, which can be selected instead of a bike. A bicycle can also be unlocked, as already seen in the previous game. Skill Games also make a return.</p><p>The game includes local multiplayer (online multiplayer will be added at a later date through a patch), bike and rider customization, collectibles (in the form of the familiar squirrels) and of course a track editor.</p><h2>Story</h2><p>New to the game are small story bits, narrated by a female and a male A.I., called Cindy and George respectively, triggered by hitting certain checkpoints on a track.</p><p>The story alludes to other riders, that previously took part in Trials events, to how the Trials riders are perceived by the general public, to the state of the world in general and to genetic experiments, conducted by the makers of the A.I. voices, who apparently try to achieve a fusion of riders and bikes.</p><h2>System Requirements</h2><table {"duration": "0:32:00", "runner": "Puri_Puri", "data": {"site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/the-elder-scrolls-ii-daggerfall/3030-1129/", "expected_release_quarter": null, "description": "<h2>Overview</h2><p>Daggerfall is a computer RPG released by <a data-ref-id=\"3010-786\" href=\"/bethesda-softworks/3010-786\">Bethesda Softworks</a> in 1996. It was followed by two spin-offs; <a data-ref-id=\"3030-8456\" href=\"/an-elder-scrolls-legend-battlespire/3030-8456\">An Elder Scrolls Legend: Battlespire</a> and <a data-ref-id=\"3030-642\" href=\"/the-elder-scrolls-adventures-redguard/3030-642\">The Elder Scrolls Adventures: Redguard</a>, and eventually a sequel in May 2002, <a data-ref-id=\"3030-17367\" href=\"/the-elder-scrolls-iii-morrowind/3030-17367\">The Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind</a>. <a data-ref-id=\"3030-20238\" href=\"/the-elder-scrolls-iv-oblivion/3030-20238\">The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion</a> followed in 2006. The most recent game in the series, <a data-ref-id=\"3030-33394\" href=\"/the-elder-scrolls-v-skyrim/3030-33394\">The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim</a>, was released in November 2011. It received many awards including several Game of the Year awards.</p><h3>The World</h3><p>Daggerfall features the largest game world to date, containing 161,600 square kilometers (40,400,000 acres) of explorabale land and over 15,000 towns, cities and villages. According to <a data-ref-id=\"3040-57173\" href=\"/todd-howard/3040-57173\">Todd Howard</a>, Morrowind's land area is 0.01% the size of Daggerfall. This was down to an algorithm that generated terrain, which led to possibly the largest game world created. The design of the following Elder Scrolls games has been to move away from this technique and emphasis in size and instead to concentrate on detail.</p><p>The size of the world is so large that it merited a place in the Games edition of the Guiness Book of World Records, <a href=\"http://bethblog.com/index.php/2008/02/29/guinness-reveals-elder-scrolls-records/\" rel=\"nofollow\">stating</a> that the world has an estimated 63,125 square miles of land.</p><h3>Features</h3><p>To alleviate long wait times to travel from destination to destination in the large game world the game employs various forms of fast-travel in the game. Ships allow for free transport by sea, and ship can be accessed at any time in the inventory menu, transporting you into the middle of the huge ocean aboard your craft. The player may also use horses, which are also accessible from the inventory menu.</p><p>Unlike in the later games, gold in Daggerfall has weight, which necessitates that players use the banking system in order to prevent their holdings from weighing them down. The bank charges 1% to take in this money, and issues letters of credit, which have neglible weight. Banks also allow the player the chance to buy property in the towns in which that particular bank is located as well as buy ships or take out loans.</p><p>Also unlike its sequel Morrowind, Daggerfall had a wall-climbing system whereby if the player was skilled enough they could scale flat mountainous surfaces. This lead to great ways to circumvent obstacles, but also could get you stuck way too high to jump down, and it would sometimes lead to you being stuck outside of the games' geometry. An area fans of the game have called colloquially \"The Void.\"</p><p>When dungeon crawling, the player is treated to large dungeons like the game world. Dungeons tend to have a certain type of enemy spawned in them, for example one place might be a den of vampires, while another will have large natural critters. As these dungeons are procedurally generated it can extended periods of time to fully explore them. Because of their procedural nature dungeons can sometimes employ a strange combination dungeon elements as they are randomly combined from various designer parts. Dungeons can have entire underwater areas, and usually have special passageways as well as secret panels that lead the player to something interesting. For some of these dungeons there is a three-dimensional dungeon automap built-in to assist the players.</p><p>There are several dungeons which were hand-made to provide specific traps, treasures, and encounters in service of the game's plot. Also there are several endings based on how the player attacks the problems facing the empire.</p><h3>Bugs</h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/2010/305168-1048384669_00.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-305168\" data-size=\"small\" data-embed-type=\"image\" data-ratio=\"0.625\" data-width=\"320\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:62.5%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/2010/305168-1048384669_00.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-305168\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/2010/305168-1048384669_00.jpg\"/></a><figcaption>Adventuring on horseback.</figcaption></figure><p>Daggerfall was infamous for its proliferation of major bugs and <a data-ref-id=\"3015-511\" href=\"/glitch/3015-511\">glitches</a>, usually attributed to a rush to bring the game to shelves. Incredibly, there was a bug evident in the release version of the game which prevented the player from finishing the main questline. The majority of these bugs have been fixed with the final patch as well as sequential patches. However the ability to randomly fall through the floor and the occasional risk of having a save becoming corrupted still exists. There are also other bugs and exploits which still exist despite the final patch being issued, although some in the homebrew community have managed to address certain issues with later, non-official fixes.</p><p>Generally speaking, the most ruinous of bugs was the dreaded Void. Diagonal surfaces, stairs, and certain other terrain forms had clipping problems which would cause a character to fall through solid surfaces, plummeting them to their death far below in the box-like playing field that a dungeon or building resided. Players could survive this in various ways, but it was often impossible to return to a dungeon without teleportation or levitation spells.</p><p>Since the re-release of the free version no new bugs have been fixed, with the last official patch being frozen at \"213.\" Players are thus encouraged to save often, and in different save slots. Players can export their save folders to accomodate for new ones should they decide they want to use more than the six provided.</p><p>While not a bug, there are certain ways to <i><b>ruin your chances to finish the main quest of the game</b></i>, so it's advisable not to talk to anyone in the three main castles so as not to accidentally refuse a quest which would be necessary for the game's completion.</p><h3>Availability</h3><p>Daggerfall can be found on the Bethesda website as of 2009, as well as some abandonware sites. It requires DOSbox to run properly on non-DOS machines, though Bethesda has included a handy install guide for those who use Windows XP and DOSBox, downloadable from the same page as their release of Daggerfall.</p><h2>Gameplay</h2><h3>Privateer's Hold</h3><p>Priaveteer's Hold is the beginning dungeon, and is the same every time one begins a game. It is considered to be a brutal starting location, especially for non-combat classes, but meta-gaming it will allow players some experimentation for character balance that will result in a much more viable character should you emerge unscathed.</p><h3>The Procedurally Generated Side-Dungeons</h3><p>All other non-main dungeons are procedurally generated using elements familiar to those who know Privateer's Hold, plus many others. These dungeons are not generated in-game, but instead stored within the software, having been pre-generated procedurally when the game was first created. These labyrinths have basic laws which help players navigate them, but part of the gameplay is that one never quite knows what one will experience when one enters one of these made tangles of corridors.</p><p>Each of these dungeons have several points of interest where a quest object, such as an item, monster or person, will be spawned. These are marked in such a way that a cheat code can allow the player to transport to each of them in order to find quest objects easily. Corridors follow their own rules based upon their corridor type, so the player will have to navigate a certain style of corridor for a certain length, which may last for thousands of game steps. The procedural generation will allow for a corridor to link to another corridor or room type which lead to many cases of user confusion.</p><p>As with the points of interest mentioned above, rooms and some corridors have points where traps, usable objects, loot, and monsters may be spawned. While the contents of these spaces may change, the types won't. The player will find monsters in monster spaces, and loot in loot spaces, even if the loot will be randomly generated when you pick it up. Traps are especially devious, as they may be invisible areas that cause damage, or objects that when touched damage the player character, possibly at lethal levels. The player can also encounter random sprites that activate teleportation effects, and others (i.e. levers) can be used to open locked doors and passageways.</p><p>Teleportation effects are achieved through touching special objects, entering certain zones, or entering some red-brick doorways. These teleports are always circular, meaning enough exploration will lead the player character back to where he or she started, either through the maze or through further use of teleportation objects. This might give the player access to otherwise inaccessible loot, or even points of interest.</p><p>Finally, there are secret doors, which are sometimes obvious and sometimes cleverly hidden within the texture of a given wall. The best way to find these is by checking the automap, where one can easily see doorways within rooms and hallways. Crypts are notably minor variations of this, and have a very small amount of corridors, secrets, and loot. Crypts in certain regions often fall prey to a bug where an actual door will spawn at the entrance to a dungeon, which may cause the character to spawn outside of the dungeon upon entry, and it can create large, inaccessible areas of the crypt that are whole crypt regions in and of themselves.</p><h3>Overworld Locations</h3><p>Towns of four sizes, homes, crypt entry locations, dungeon entry locations, witches' covens, temples, and hermitages dot Daggerfall's immense landmass. All but the capital of Daggerfall itself are subject to a fairly standard encounters when not on a quest: when you rest a monster or humanoid may be randomly generated, and when manually traversing one can occasionally run into local wildlife. One cannot have random encounters when fast-traveling.</p><p>Any location with more than one building is procedurally generated, although this is usually less dramatic than the dungeons. Players will find certain building placement behaviors, like market squares, but for the most part the buildings are fairly separate and don't face in a certain direction except perhaps in the capital cities. Occasionally there will be errors in generation, such as buildings which are on the map but do not exist, buildings which will not label themselves or don't act as commercial buildings when labeled as such, and other anomalies.</p><p>Different regions also generate different sprites, so the more tropical home of the Redguard will have wilder plantlife, and in the north it is more likely to have snowy areas. The land itself is largely flat, with some bumpy 3D surfaces that can occasionally get a bit more rocky in mountainous areas. While navigating Daggerfall on foot the player may stumble upon an undiscovered site or loot.</p><p>In addition all of these, there is a corner of the map where a ship spawns if one purchases it. This ship is teleported to and exists in the middle of the ocean. Without teleporting it would take hours, perhaps days, real-time to swim back to shore from the ship. Within the ship, like houses that one purchases from the bank, one can place one's possessions in the ship, although they must be placed on the ground, not in containers, lest they disappear.</p><h3>The Void</h3><p>Outside of all buildings, when one is inside them, is a place commonly called The Void. It is a black non-play area that all buildings exist in. Buildings float in the void, and each building exists in its own void (meaning buildings that are next to each other in a city are not next to each other in the void). The void would be immaterial to the game except that during certain clipping or spawning errors, players can wind up outside of a given building. The void is lethal, in that you can fall to your death in it (one is often inexplicably paralyzed just before hitting this lethal bottom area), and it is very hard to enter back into a building once exiled, unless one cheats or teleports. Levitation allows the player to move the character about, and the player will be able to see inside building segments, and stand on top of them. Entry is possible occasionally by manipulating the same clipping weaknesses that likely got the player character into the void in the first place.</p><p>Creatures, too, can wind up in the void, causing a frustrating problem if your quest is to destroy these creatures. Creatures in the void are nigh impossible to kill without cheating or being stuck in the void too. On top of this creatures in The Void prevent a character from sleeping or being able to rest due to their proximity to the player.</p>", "deck": "The Elder Scrolls II: Daggerfall from Bethesda Softworks is an enormous RPG and sequel to The Elder Scrolls: Arena. It includes a massive gameworld and pioneering freeform play. It was well received for these factors, but was criticised for a number of crippling bugs.", "aliases": "Elder Scrolls 2", "image": {"icon_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/square_avatar/0/5150/1257508-daggerfall_box1.jpg", "medium_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_medium/0/5150/1257508-daggerfall_box1.jpg", "tiny_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/square_mini/0/5150/1257508-daggerfall_box1.jpg", "small_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/5150/1257508-daggerfall_box1.jpg", "thumb_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_avatar/0/5150/1257508-daggerfall_box1.jpg", "screen_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/screen_medium/0/5150/1257508-daggerfall_box1.jpg", "super_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_large/0/5150/1257508-daggerfall_box1.jpg"}, "date_last_updated": "2016-02-10 09:37:42", "expected_release_month": null, "api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/game/3030-1129/", "number_of_user_reviews": 0, "original_release_date": "1996-08-30 00:00:00", "original_game_rating": [{"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/game_rating/3065-16/", "id": 16, "name": "ESRB: M"}], "date_added": "2008-04-01 01:38:25", "platforms": [{"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/platform/3045-94/", "abbreviation": "PC", "site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/pc/3045-94/", "id": 94, "name": "PC"}], "expected_release_day": null, "expected_release_year": null, "id": 1129, "resource_type": "game", "name": "The Elder Scrolls II: Daggerfall"}, "platform": "PC", "title": "The Elder Scrolls II: Daggerfall"}
{"duration": "0:38:00", "runner": "AlbinoAlbatross", "data": {"site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/the-elder-scrolls-iii-morrowind/3030-17367/", "expected_release_quarter": null, "description": "<h2>Overview</h2><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/159/207264-morrowind_map.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-207264\" data-size=\"small\" style=\"width: 320px\" data-ratio=\"1.178313253012\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:117.8%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/159/207264-morrowind_map.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-207264\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/159/207264-morrowind_map.jpg\"/></a><figcaption>Vvardenfell</figcaption></figure><p>The Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind is the third game in the Elder Scrolls RPG series, preceded by Daggerfall, and is the first to release on a console (the <a href=\"/xbox/3045-32\" data-ref-id=\"3045-32\">Xbox</a>) as well as <a href=\"/pc/3045-94\" data-ref-id=\"3045-94\">PCs</a>. Morrowind takes place on a large volcanic island known as <a href=\"../../vvardenfell/95-266/\" rel=\"nofollow\">Vvardenfell</a> in the province of <a href=\"/morrowind/3035-514\" data-ref-id=\"3035-514\">Morrowind</a>.</p><p>As in other Elder Scrolls games, Morrowind's world is large and open to exploration, containing many distinct regions populated with villages, <a href=\"/non-player-character/3015-967\" data-ref-id=\"3015-967\">NPCs</a>, enemies, caves, temples, and other points of interest.</p><p> </p><h2>Story</h2><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/1852/208368-achitecture.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-208368\" data-size=\"medium\" style=\"width: 480px\" data-ratio=\"0.75\" data-width=\"480\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:75.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/1852/208368-achitecture.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-208368\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_medium/0/1852/208368-achitecture.jpg\"/></a><figcaption>An Ordinator guarding the city of Vivec</figcaption></figure><p>The Demigod <a href=\"../../dagoth-ur/94-7163/\" rel=\"nofollow\">Dagoth Ur</a> has successfully used the Heart of <a href=\"../../nirn/95-1634/\" rel=\"nofollow\">Lorkhan</a> to make himself immortal and now seeks to cast out the Imperial forces occupying Morrowind.</p><p>The game starts with the protagonist in <a href=\"../../prison/95-420/\" rel=\"nofollow\">prison</a>, a staple of the Elder Scrolls games. The player is released from a prison boat into a small fishing village called <a href=\"/seyda-neen/3035-2742\" data-ref-id=\"3035-2742\">Seyda Neen</a>.</p><blockquote><p><i>In the waning years of the</i></p><p><i>Third Era of Tamriel,</i></p><p><i>a prisoner born on a certain day</i></p><p><i>to uncertain parents was sent</i></p><p><i>under guard, without explanation, to Morrowind,</i></p><p><i>ignorant of the role he was</i></p><p><i>to play in that nation's history\u2026</i></p></blockquote><p>In the Census office the released prisoner is given a package by an Imperial Officer to be delivered to a man named <a href=\"/caius-cosades/3005-3588\" data-ref-id=\"3005-3588\">Caius Cosades</a> who is currently residing in the town of <a href=\"/balmora/3035-1351\" data-ref-id=\"3035-1351\">Balmora</a>. Thus begins the game, and story in earnest. The player at this point is given the freedom to visit any location and complete any side quest without harming or disrupting the main questline. If the prisoner so wishes, they continue onward to a new life and Balmora; the main hub of the Hlaalu faction and major economic center that effectively links the civilized western world with the technologically backwards and savage east.</p><p>Upon arriving at Cosades abode, the player is admitted as a novice into the Empire serving faction \"Blades\". The Blades is indicated to be an organization with the duty of spying for the Empire; \"We're spies. We're the Emperor's hidden eyes and ears in the provinces.\" Cosades gives the prisoner their second task: visit his friend Hasphat Antabolis at the Balmora Fighters Guild and get schooled on the local lore and learn of various cults gaining strength in Vvardenfell. Unfortunately, Hasphat Antabolis won't simply share his knowledge for nothing and thus gives the prisoner their third task: visit a nearby Dwemer ruin and find a specific artifact.</p><p>Upon the retrieval and delivery of the artifact, Antabolis gives the player notes to be delivered to Cosades and read by the prisoner. The note describes the various cults in Vvardenfell: the Sixth House, <i>\"House Dagoth is an extinct Great House. In the wake of the ancient Battle of Red Mountain, its leadership was revealed to have plotted treason, and was discredited\"</i>, and information on relevant historical events, the War of the First Council: \"<i>...a First Age religious conflict between the secular Dunmer Houses Dwemer and Dagoth and the orthodox Dunmer Houses Indoril, Redoran, Dres, Hlaalu, and Telvanni.</i>\". And the Nerevarine cult: \"When the Dunmer followed Veloth to Morrowind, they were many warring clans ... One Dunmer warlord, Nerevar, had the ambition to rule all the Dunmer.\"</p><p>The player is tasked, from Cosades, to seek further information on the Nerevarine by searching for ancient texts and informants scattered around Vvardenfell. Why all this is important to the player remains a mystery, until Cosades reveals that the Imperial Legion believes the player character could very well be the Nerevarine reborn. The benefits the Empire could reap from such an event would be immense; having an ancient Dunmer man-god ally would gain the Imperial Legion an even stronger foothold in Morrowind, and the continued attempts of thwarting Dagoth Ur and his fanatical cults would win some support amongst the native Dunmer.</p><p>Cosades is recalled to the <a href=\"/the-imperial-city/3035-1659\" data-ref-id=\"3035-1659\">Imperial City</a>; <i>\"Internal politics. Some concern about my sugar ... As the Emperor's health declines, factions are maneuvering for advantage. I may be gone a while ...\"</i>. The player is now the top ranking Blades agent in Vvardenfell. The player continues on his or her journey to discover whether they truly are the Nerevarine; and is soon on the search for ancient prophecies, 'the Lost Prophecies'.</p><blockquote><p><i>\"From seventh sign of eleventh generation,</i></p><p><i>Neither Hound nor Guar, nor Seed nor Harrow,</i></p><p><i>But Dragon-born and far-star-marked,</i></p><p><i>Outlander Incarnate beneath Red Mountain,</i></p><p><i>Blessed Guest counters seven curses,</i></p><p><i>Star-blessed hand wields thrice-cursed blade,</i></p><p><i>To reap the harvest of the unmourned house.\"</i></p></blockquote><p>The search leads the player to a monastery where they are informed they must go through a series of tests to determine if they truly are the Nerevarine. The first prophesy being that the Nerevarine, incarnate of Nerevar, is born from uncertain parents on a certain day. The second prophesy dictates that the Nerevarine must contract and overcome the Corprus disease. The fourth, the player character must find <a href=\"/indoril-nerevar/3005-16939\" data-ref-id=\"3005-16939\">Indoril Nerevar's</a> ring Moon-and-Star. Upon finding the Moon-and-Star, the player has a vision and <a href=\"/azura/3005-3578\" data-ref-id=\"3005-3578\">Azura</a>, a Daedric Queen, confirms that the player is indeed the Nerevarine.</p><p>The fifth and sixth prophesies see the Nerevarine rally the people of Vvardenfell under a single banner. In order to do so, the player must be acknowledged as a war leader, the so called Hortator, by all three Great Houses of Morrowind (Hlaalu, Redoran, and Telvanni), and as Nerevarine, the true incarnate of Nerevar, by four native Dunmer tribes (Ahemmusa, Zainab, Urshilaku, and Erabenimsun). Shortly after that, <a href=\"/vivec/3005-1384\" data-ref-id=\"3005-1384\">Vivec</a>, the warrior-poet man-God of Morrowind, invites the Nerevarine to his palace to discuss <a href=\"/dagoth-ur/3005-7163\" data-ref-id=\"3005-7163\">Dagoth Ur</a>, his followers, and the Heart of Lorkhan. The Heart is immune to normal weapons and requires the ancients Dwemer artifacts. 'Wraithguard' to protect the user, and 'Sunder' and 'Keening' to cause damage to the Heart itself.</p><p>After finding 'Sunder' and 'Keening', the Nerevarine then travels to Red Mountain to Dagoth Urs stronghold. The player finds Dagoth Ur deep within Red Mountain. Dagoth Ur attempts trick the Nerevarine into joining him and asks the Nerevarine his last questions: <i>\"My first question is: Are you really Nerevar reborn?\"</i> the Nerevarine responds: <i>\"By the grace of gods and fate, I am Nerevar reborn.\"</i>. After a short discourse, Dagoth Ur and the Nerevar incarnate, long ago brothers fighting together for the same cause, now commence fighting each other.</p><p>After overpowering Dagoth Ur, he retreats to the hall where the Heart of Lorkhan resides. Before the Nerevarine can hope to defeat Dagoth Ur, he must first destroy the Heart with 'Sunder' and 'Keening'. Upon destroying both Dagoth Ur and the Heart of Lorkhan, the Nerevarine escapes the crumbling cave and surfaces to find the Blight gone and Azura waiting for him or her;</p><blockquote><p><i>\"You no longer bear the burden of prophecy.</i></p><p><i>You have achieved your destiny.</i></p><p><i>You are free.</i></p><p><i>The doomed Dwemer's folly, Lord Dagoth's temptation,</i></p><p><i>the Tribunal's seduction, the god's heart freed,</i></p><p><i>the prophecy fulfilled.</i></p><p><i>All fates sealed and sins redeemed.</i></p><p><i>If you have pity, mourn the loss, but let the weeping cease.</i></p><p><i>The Blight is gone, and the sun's golden honey gilds the land.</i></p><p><i>Hail savior, Hortator, and Nerevarine.</i></p><p><i>Your people look to you for protection.</i></p><p><i>Monster and villains great and small still threaten the people of Vvardenfell.</i></p><p><i>Enemies and evils abound, yet indomitable will might rid Morrowind of all its ills.</i></p><p><i>For you, our thanks and blessings; our gift and token given.</i></p><p><i>Come; take this thing from the hand of god.\"</i></p></blockquote><p>This marks the end of the main story. After Defeating Dagoth Ur and the Heart of Lorkhan, the Nerevarine remains on Vvardenfell to protect and serve the people of Morrowind.</p><p>However, the player does not need to follow the main questline; after leaving the Census they can simple drop all main quest items and never touch the main quest. They can complete side quests for citizens of Vvardenfell in need of help. Alternatively, there are also guilds to join, each of which offer a line of quests of their own.</p><p>Besides the quest storylines, the Elder Scrolls III continues and furthers the deep and detailed fiction, or lore, surrounding <a href=\"/tamriel/3035-92\" data-ref-id=\"3035-92\">Tamriel</a> and Nirn. The Elder Scrolls series is well renowned and praised for its fiction, often being compared to <a href=\"/j-r-r-tolkien/3040-47777\" data-ref-id=\"3040-47777\">Tolkien</a>'s <a href=\"/middle-earth/3035-193\" data-ref-id=\"3035-193\">Middle-Earth</a> in depth and quality of writing.</p><p>For more on the setting, see <a href=\"/nirn/3035-1634\" data-ref-id=\"3035-1634\">Nirn</a>.</p><h2>Side-Quests</h2><p>At any time the player can undertake any number of side-quests. There are hundreds of quests to find in Morrowind. There are three political great house factions and seven lesser guilds. The player can only join one great house, but is free to join any and every lesser guild with the player character. The factions/guilds don't follow a linear story in the same vein as the main quest, but some do have a continuing story over several quests, and often have a set goal and/or \"end-quest\" for the player to work toward. They sometimes even intersect with one another across factions. Aside from the factions/guilds there are many other quests to find in towns, in all the different dungeons and other locations scattered across the map, or just out on the roads and plains.</p><h2>Gameplay</h2><p>Players start the game creating a character which they will advance throughout the course of the game. Eleven separate races are available to choose from, each having their own abilities and bonuses. Players can also choose their \"birthsign,\" which also adds bonuses and abilities, before they are released into the world almost immediately after starting the game. Morrowind's completely open world is all available to the player to explore from the moment they disembark from the prison ship, although certain towns and villages must be visited to advance the main quest. Unlike Oblivion, encounters do not scale to match the player's level. As such, it is quite possible to run into impossibly high-level situations as a weak player accidentally, or grind to a high level from the start (which requires a large time investment) and breeze through the low-level content.</p><h2>Races</h2><h3>High Elf</h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/1360/411890-altmer_official.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-411890\" data-size=\"small\" style=\"width: 220px\" data-ratio=\"1.3409090909091\" data-width=\"220\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:134.1%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/1360/411890-altmer_official.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-411890\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/1360/411890-altmer_official.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/1360/411890-altmer_official.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>High Elf</figcaption></figure><p><a href=\"/high-elves/3015-3914\" data-ref-id=\"3015-3914\">High Elves</a>, or Altmer in the elven language, are often seen as the most noble race in Tamriel or the most arrogant, depending on the observer. Tall and gold-skinned, High Elves originate from the <a href=\"/summerset-isle/3035-301\" data-ref-id=\"3035-301\">Summerset Isle</a> and are distant relatives of the <a href=\"/wood-elves/3015-3915\" data-ref-id=\"3015-3915\">Wood Elves</a> and Morrowind's <a href=\"/dark-elves/3015-2088\" data-ref-id=\"3015-2088\">Dark Elves</a>. They are especially gifted in magic but are also weak to it.</p><p><b>Special Abilities</b></p><ul><li>Resist Common Disease 75%</li><li>Weakness to Shock Magic 25%</li><li>Weakness to Frost Magic 25%</li><li>Weakness to Fire Magic 50%</li><li>Weakness to Magicka 50%</li><li>Fortify maximum Magicka 15 points</li></ul><p><b>Race Bonuses</b></p><ul><li>Destruction Magic 10 points</li><li>Enchant Magic 10 points</li><li>Alchemy Magic 10 points</li><li>Alteration magic 5 points</li><li>Conjuration Magic 5 points</li><li>Illusion Magic 5 points</li></ul><h3>Argonian</h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/1360/411970-argonian_official.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-411970\" data-size=\"small\" style=\"width: 203px\" data-ratio=\"1.512315270936\" data-width=\"203\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:151.2%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/1360/411970-argonian_official.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-411970\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/1360/411970-argonian_official.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/1360/411970-argonian_official.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Argonian</figcaption></figure><p>Argonians are a reptilian race that originates from the swamps of Black Marsh. They are well equipped for both land and water warfare, especially if it involves <a href=\"/stealth/3015-24\" data-ref-id=\"3015-24\">stealth</a>.</p><p><b>Special Abilities</b></p><ul><li>Water Breathing Spell.</li><li>Resist Poison 100%</li><li>Resist Common Disease 75%</li></ul><p><b>Race Bonuses</b></p><ul><li>Athletics 15 points</li><li>Alchemy 5 points</li><li>Illusion 5 points</li><li>Medium Armor 5 points</li><li>Mysticism 5 points</li><li>Spear 5 points</li><li>Unarmored 5 points</li></ul><h3>Wood Elf</h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/1360/412018-bosmer_official.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-412018\" data-size=\"small\" style=\"width: 195px\" data-ratio=\"1.6512820512821\" data-width=\"195\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:165.1%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/1360/412018-bosmer_official.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-412018\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/1360/412018-bosmer_official.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/1360/412018-bosmer_official.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Wood Elf</figcaption></figure><p>Looked down upon as barbarians by the other elf races, the Wood Elves, or Bosmer, live and originate in the trees of <a href=\"/valenwood/3035-681\" data-ref-id=\"3035-681\">Valenwood</a>. Expert marksmen and gifted in stealth, Wood Elves make especially good thieves and scouts.</p><p><b>Special Abilities</b></p><ul><li>Beast Tongue Spell - ability to command creatures</li><li>Resist Common Disease 75%</li></ul><p><b>Race Bonuses</b></p><ul><li>Marksman 15 points</li><li>Sneak 10 points</li><li>Light Armor 10 points</li><li>Alchemy 5 points</li><li>Acrobatics 5 points</li></ul><h3><b>Breton</b></h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/1360/412083-breton_official.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-412083\" data-size=\"small\" style=\"width: 204px\" data-ratio=\"1.6911764705882\" data-width=\"204\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:169.1%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/1360/412083-breton_official.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-412083\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/1360/412083-breton_official.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/1360/412083-breton_official.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Breton</figcaption></figure><p>The ancestral land of the Bretons is High Rock. Being gifted in the arts of magic, many Bretons become mages or sorcerers.</p><p><b>Special Abilities</b></p><ul><li>Dragon Skin Spell - Shield</li><li>Resist Magicka 50%</li><li>Fortify Maximum Magicka 5 points</li></ul><p><b>Race Bonuses</b></p><ul><li>Conjuration 10 points</li><li>Mysticism 10 points</li><li>Restoration 10 points</li><li>Alchemy 5 points</li><li>Alteration 5 points</li><li>Illusion 5 points</li></ul><h3>Dark Elf</h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/1360/412548-dunmer_official.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-412548\" data-size=\"small\" style=\"width: 210px\" data-ratio=\"1.1619047619048\" data-width=\"210\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:116.2%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/1360/412548-dunmer_official.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-412548\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/1360/412548-dunmer_official.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/1360/412548-dunmer_official.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Dark Elf</figcaption></figure><p>The Dark Elves, or Dunmer, inhabit the land of Morrowind. These dark-skinned elves are tough and fearless, having provided some of the fiercest resistance to Imperial hegemony under the leadership of their living gods, Vivec, Almalexia and Sotha Sil, making them known as some of the best warriors in the land. They are skilled in swordplay and several types of magic.</p><p><b>Special Abilities</b></p><ul><li>Ancestor Guardian Spell</li><li>Resist Fire 75%</li></ul><p><b>Race Bonuses</b></p><ul><li>Long Blade 5 points</li><li>Destruction 10 points</li><li>Light Armor 5 points</li><li>Athletics 5 points</li><li>Mysticism 5 points</li><li>Marksman 5 points</li><li>Short Blade 10 points</li></ul><h3><b>Imperial</b></h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/1360/412565-imperial_official.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-412565\" data-size=\"small\" style=\"width: 207px\" data-ratio=\"1.3091787439614\" data-width=\"207\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:130.9%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/1360/412565-imperial_official.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-412565\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/1360/412565-imperial_official.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/1360/412565-imperial_official.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Imperial</figcaption></figure><p>From their homeland in <a href=\"/cyrodiil/3035-127\" data-ref-id=\"3035-127\">Cyrodiil</a>, Imperials are the stewards and peacekeepers of the powerful Empire of Tamriel. Although not as physically imposing as other races, their martial discipline and diplomatic skills have</p><p><b>Special Abilities</b></p><ul><li>Star of the Wast Spell - Absorb 200 points of fatigue</li><li>Voice of the Emperor Spell - Charm</li></ul><p><b>Race Bonuses</b></p><ul><li>Speechcraft 10 points</li><li>Mercantile 10 points</li><li>Long Blade 10 points</li><li>Blunt Weapon 5 points</li><li>Light Armor 5 points</li><li>Hand to Hand 5 points</li></ul><h3><b>Khajiit</b></h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/1360/412719-180px_khajiit_official.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-412719\" data-size=\"small\" style=\"width: 180px\" data-ratio=\"1.3944444444444\" data-width=\"180\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:139.4%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/1360/412719-180px_khajiit_official.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-412719\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/1360/412719-180px_khajiit_official.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/1360/412719-180px_khajiit_official.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Khajiit</figcaption></figure><p>The Khajiit are feline creatures originating from the desert province of <a href=\"/elsweyr/3035-295\" data-ref-id=\"3035-295\">Elsweyr</a>. Khajiit's natural agility and acrobatic skills make them expert thieves.</p><p><b>Special Abilities</b></p><ul><li>Eye of the Night Spell</li><li>Eye of Fear Spell</li></ul><p><b>Race Bonuses</b></p><ul><li>Acrobatics 15 points</li><li>Athletics 5 points</li><li>hand to Hand 5 points</li><li>Light Armor 5 points</li><li>Security 5 points</li><li>Short Blade 5 points</li><li>Sneak 5 points</li></ul><h3><b>Nord</b></h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/1360/412789-nord_official.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-412789\" data-size=\"small\" style=\"width: 212px\" data-ratio=\"1.3584905660377\" data-width=\"212\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:135.8%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/1360/412789-nord_official.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-412789\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/1360/412789-nord_official.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/1360/412789-nord_official.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Nord</figcaption></figure><p>Tall and strong, Nords make tough and resilient warriors. Born in the cold lands of <a href=\"/skyrim/3035-684\" data-ref-id=\"3035-684\">Skyrim</a>, Nords are especially resistant to cold and frost. Nord are also known to be great warriors due to their skills in weaponry and armor.</p><p><b>Special Abilities</b></p><ul><li>Thunder Fist Spell - 25 Frost Magic damage points</li><li>Woad Spell - Shield</li><li>Resist Shock 50%</li><li>Resist Frost 100%</li></ul><p><b>Race Bonuses</b></p><ul><li>Axe 10 points</li><li>Blunt Weapon 10 points</li><li>Medium Armor 10 points</li><li>Heavy Armor 5 points</li><li>Long Blade 5 points</li><li>Spear 5 points</li></ul><h3><b>Orc</b></h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/1360/412859-orsimer_official.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-412859\" data-size=\"small\" style=\"width: 216px\" data-ratio=\"1.4351851851852\" data-width=\"216\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:143.5%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/1360/412859-orsimer_official.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-412859\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/1360/412859-orsimer_official.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/1360/412859-orsimer_official.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Orc</figcaption></figure><p>Courageous and strong, Orcs or Orsimer as they are sometimes called, are from the land of Orsinium, but inhabit many other areas of High Rock alongside the Bretons. With green skin and sharp teeth, Orcs are fearless on the front line and make brutally effective warriors.</p><p><b>Special Abilities</b></p><ul><li>Resist Magicka 25%</li><li>Berserk Spell</li></ul><p><b>Race Bonuses</b></p><ul><li>Armorer 10 points</li><li>Block 10 points</li><li>Heavy Armor 10 points</li><li>Medium Armor 10 points</li><li>Axe 5 points</li></ul><h3><b>Redguard</b></h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/1360/412907-redguard_official.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-412907\" data-size=\"small\" style=\"width: 210px\" data-ratio=\"1.3714285714286\" data-width=\"210\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:137.1%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/1360/412907-redguard_official.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-412907\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/1360/412907-redguard_official.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/1360/412907-redguard_official.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Redguard</figcaption></figure><p>Quick and agile warriors, Redguards make good skirmishers and scouts. They originate from the desert region of Hammerfell.</p><p><b>Special Abilities</b></p><ul><li>Adrenalin Rush Spell</li><li>Resist Poison 75%</li><li>Resist Common Disease 75%</li></ul><p><b>Race Bonuses</b></p><ul><li>Long Blade 15 points</li><li>Athletics 5 points</li><li>Axe 5 points</li><li>Blunt Weapon 5 points</li><li>Heavy Armor 5 points</li><li>Medium Armor 5 points</li><li>Short Blade 5 points</li></ul><h2>Birthsigns</h2><p>The following is an explanation of the birthsigns within the world of Morrowind (Tamriel). It is an excerpt taken from the book in the game called <i>The Firmament</i> which was written by Ffoulke.</p><p>\"The Stars of Tamriel are divided into thirteen constellations. Three of them are the major constellations, known as the Guardians. These are The Warrior, The Mage, and The Thief. Each of the Guardians protects its three Charges from the thirteenth constellation, The Serpent.</p><p>When the sun rises near one of the constellations, it is that constellation's season. Each constellation has a Season of approximately one month. The Serpent has no season, for it moves about in the heavens, usually threatening one of the other constellations.</p><table><tbody><tr><td><h3>The Warrior</h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/api/image/original/1415607-warrior.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1415607\" data-size=\"small\" style=\"width: 256px\" data-ratio=\"0.5\" data-width=\"256\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:50.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/api/image/original/1415607-warrior.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1415607\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/7242/1415607-warrior.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/7242/1415607-warrior.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>The Warrior</figcaption></figure> The Warrior is the first Guardian Constellation and he protects his charges during their Seasons. The Warrior's own seas is Last Steed when his Strength is needed for the harvest. His Charges are The Lady, The Steed, and The Lord. Those born under the sign of The Warrior are skilled with weapons of all kinds, but prone to short tempers.</td></tr><tr><td><h3>The Mage</h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/api/image/original/1415600-mage.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1415600\" data-size=\"small\" style=\"width: 256px\" data-ratio=\"0.5\" data-width=\"256\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:50.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/api/image/original/1415600-mage.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1415600\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/7242/1415600-mage.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/7242/1415600-mage.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>The Mage</figcaption></figure> The Mage is a Guardian Constellation whose Season is Rain's Hand when magicka was first used by men. His Charges are The Apprentice, The Golem, and The Ritual. Those born under the Mage have more magicka and talent for all kinds of spellcasting, but are often arrogant and absent-minded.</td></tr><tr><td><h3>The Thief</h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/api/image/original/1415605-thief.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1415605\" data-size=\"small\" style=\"width: 256px\" data-ratio=\"0.5\" data-width=\"256\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:50.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/api/image/original/1415605-thief.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1415605\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/7242/1415605-thief.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/7242/1415605-thief.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>The Thief</figcaption></figure> The Thief is the last Guardian Constellation, and her Season is the darkest month of Evening Star. Her Charges are The Lover, The Shadow, and The Tower. Those born under the sign of the Thief are not typically thieves, though they take risks more often and only rarely come to harm. They will run out of luck eventually, however, and rarely live as long as those born under other signs.</td></tr><tr><td><h3>The Serpent</h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/api/image/original/1415602-serpent.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1415602\" data-size=\"small\" style=\"width: 256px\" data-ratio=\"0.5\" data-width=\"256\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:50.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/api/image/original/1415602-serpent.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1415602\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/7242/1415602-serpent.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/7242/1415602-serpent.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>The Serpent</figcaption></figure> The Serpent wanders about in the sky and has no Season, though its motions are predictable to a degree. No characteristics are common to all who are born under the sign of the Serpent. Those born under this sign are the most blessed and the most cursed.</td></tr><tr><td><h3><b>The Lady</b></h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/api/image/original/1415597-lady.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1415597\" data-size=\"small\" style=\"width: 256px\" data-ratio=\"0.5\" data-width=\"256\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:50.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/api/image/original/1415597-lady.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1415597\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/7242/1415597-lady.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/7242/1415597-lady.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>The Lady</figcaption></figure> The Lady is one of The Warrior's Charges and her Season is Heartfire. Those born under the sign of the Lady are kind and tolerant.</td></tr><tr><td><h3><b>The Steed</b></h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/api/image/original/1415604-steed.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1415604\" data-size=\"small\" style=\"width: 256px\" data-ratio=\"0.5\" data-width=\"256\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:50.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/api/image/original/1415604-steed.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1415604\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/7242/1415604-steed.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/7242/1415604-steed.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>The Steed</figcaption></figure> The Steed is one of The Warrior's Charges, and her Season is Mid Year. Those born under the sign of the Steed are impatient and always hurrying from one place to another.</td></tr><tr><td><h3>The Lord</h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/api/image/original/1415598-lord.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1415598\" data-size=\"small\" style=\"width: 256px\" data-ratio=\"0.5\" data-width=\"256\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:50.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/api/image/original/1415598-lord.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1415598\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/7242/1415598-lord.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/7242/1415598-lord.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>The Lord</figcaption></figure> The Lord is one of The Warrior's Charges. Its Season is First Seed and he oversees all of Tamriel during the planting. Those born under the sign of the Lord are stronger and healthier than those born under other signs.</td></tr><tr><td><h3><b>The Apprentice</b></h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/api/image/original/1415595-apprentice.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1415595\" data-size=\"small\" style=\"width: 256px\" data-ratio=\"0.5\" data-width=\"256\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:50.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/api/image/original/1415595-apprentice.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1415595\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/7242/1415595-apprentice.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/7242/1415595-apprentice.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>The Apprentice</figcaption></figure> The Apprentice is one of The Mage's charges and its Season is Sun's Height. Those born under the sign of the apprentice have a special affinity for magick of all kinds, but are more vulnerable to magick as well.</td></tr><tr><td><h3>The Atronach</h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/api/image/original/1415596-atronach.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1415596\" data-size=\"small\" style=\"width: 256px\" data-ratio=\"0.5\" data-width=\"256\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:50.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/api/image/original/1415596-atronach.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1415596\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/7242/1415596-atronach.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/7242/1415596-atronach.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>The Atronach (Golem)</figcaption></figure> The Atronach (often called the Golem) is one of The Mage's Charges. Its season is Sun's Dusk. Those born under this sign are natural sorcerers with deep reserves of magicka, but they cannot generate magicka of their own.</td></tr><tr><td><h3>The Ritual</h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/api/image/original/1415601-ritual.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1415601\" data-size=\"small\" style=\"width: 256px\" data-ratio=\"0.5\" data-width=\"256\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:50.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/api/image/original/1415601-ritual.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1415601\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/7242/1415601-ritual.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/7242/1415601-ritual.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>The Ritual</figcaption></figure> The Ritual is one of The Mage's Charges and its Season is Morning Star. Those born under this sign have a variety of abilities depending on the aspects of the moons and the Divines.</td></tr><tr><td><h3>The Lover</h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/api/image/original/1415599-lover.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1415599\" data-size=\"small\" style=\"width: 256px\" data-ratio=\"0.5\" data-width=\"256\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:50.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/api/image/original/1415599-lover.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1415599\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/7242/1415599-lover.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/7242/1415599-lover.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>The Lover</figcaption></figure> The Lover is one of The Thief's Charges and her season is Sun's Dawn. Those born under the sign of the Lover are graceful and passionate.</td></tr><tr><td><h3>The Shadow</h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/api/image/original/1415603-shadow.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1415603\" data-size=\"small\" style=\"width: 256px\" data-ratio=\"0.5\" data-width=\"256\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:50.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/api/image/original/1415603-shadow.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1415603\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/7242/1415603-shadow.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/7242/1415603-shadow.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>The Shadow</figcaption></figure> The Shadow is one of The Thief's Charges and its Season is Second Seed. The Shadow grants those born under her sign the ability to hide in shadows.</td></tr><tr><td><h3>The Tower</h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/api/image/original/1415606-tower.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1415606\" data-size=\"small\" style=\"width: 256px\" data-ratio=\"0.5\" data-width=\"256\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:50.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/api/image/original/1415606-tower.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1415606\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/7242/1415606-tower.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/7242/1415606-tower.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>The Tower</figcaption></figure> The Tower is one of The Thief's Charges and its Season is Frostfall. Those born under the sign of the Tower have a knack for finding gold and can open locks of all kinds.</td></tr></tbody></table><h2>Skills and Attributes</h2><p>There are 27 skills governed by 8 attributes in Morrowind.</p><ul><li><b>Endurance</b> - Heavy Armor, Medium Armor, Spear.</li><li><b>Strength</b> - Acrobatics, Armorer, Axe, Blunt Weapon, Long Blade.</li><li><b>Agility</b> - Block, Light Armor, Marksman, Sneak.</li><li><b>Speed</b> - Athletics, Hand to Hand, Short Blade, Unarmored.</li><li><b>Personality</b> - Illusion, Mercantile, Speechcraft.</li><li><b>Intelligence</b> - Alchemy, Conjuration, Enchant, Security.</li><li><b>Willpower</b> - Alteration, Destruction, Mysticism, Restoration.</li><li><b>Luck</b> - No skills fall under luck.</li></ul><h2><b>Modifications</b></h2><p>Morrowind ships with The Elder Scrolls Construction Set, a program players can use to tweak aspects of the game. Mods exist for new races, different texture sets, completely new houses, player-made quests and guilds, and more. <a href=\"/mods/3015-5503\" data-ref-id=\"3015-5503\">Mods</a> are one of the principle reasons why Morrowind is so replayable. A number of websites exist that encourage player modifications to the game and host player-uploaded modifications.</p><h3>Websites</h3><ul><li><a href=\"http://planetelderscrolls.gamespy.com/\" rel=\"nofollow\">Planet Elder Scrolls</a></li><li><a href=\"http://planetelderscrolls.gamespy.com/\" rel=\"nofollow\">ElricM</a></li><li><a href=\"http://tesnexus.com/\" rel=\"nofollow\">TES Nexus</a></li></ul><h3>Commonly Recommended Mods</h3><p>The Elder Scrolls community have hand selected a few popular mods for their <a href=\"http://planetelderscrolls.gamespy.com/View.php?view=Mods.HOF\" rel=\"nofollow\">Hall of Fame</a>.</p><p><a href=\"http://morrowindoverhaul.net/blog/\" rel=\"nofollow\">Morrowind Overhaul- Sounds and Graphics</a></p><p>A complete compilation of replacements for the graphics in Morrowind. Includes all the notable mods, and greatly enhances the look of the game.</p><p><a href=\"http://btb2.free.fr/morrowind.html\" rel=\"nofollow\">BTB's must have mods list</a></p><p><a href=\"http://forums.bethsoft.com/index.php?/topic/1060141-mod-recommendations-for-new-players/\" rel=\"nofollow\">Pluto's Mod Recommendations to New Players</a></p><p><a href=\"http://forums.bethsoft.com/index.php?/topic/1155980-povuholos-tomorrowind-a-mod-recommendations-list-for-today/\" rel=\"nofollow\">Povuholo's ToMorrowind List</a></p><h2>Expansion Packs &amp; Game of the Year Edition</h2><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/3661/1624845-935550_79907_front.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1624845\" data-size=\"small\" style=\"width: 320px\" data-ratio=\"1.45\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:145.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/3661/1624845-935550_79907_front.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1624845\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/3661/1624845-935550_79907_front.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/3661/1624845-935550_79907_front.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>GOTY Edition for PC</figcaption></figure><p>Since Morrowind's release, Bethesda have delivered two expansion packs for the game. <a href=\"../../the-elder-scrolls-iii-tribunal/61-17949/\" rel=\"nofollow\">Tribunal</a> was released in the U.S. on November 6th 2002, whilst <a href=\"../../the-elder-scrolls-iii-bloodmoon/61-8121/\" rel=\"nofollow\">Bloodmoon</a> arrived on June 3rd 2003. Both featured completely new and unique settings, with Bloodmoon taking place on the island of <a href=\"../../solstheim/95-268/\" rel=\"nofollow\">Solstheim</a> to the north of <a href=\"../../wiki/Morrowind:Vvardenfell\" rel=\"nofollow\">Vvardenfell</a>, and Tribunal taking place in Morrowind's capital city, <a href=\"../../mournhold/95-1940/\" rel=\"nofollow\">Mournhold</a>. In addition to the new locations, the expansions featured new independent Main Quests alongside new side quests. The expansion made improvements to the game's <a href=\"../../diary/93-2022/\" rel=\"nofollow\">Journal</a>, organizing quest threads into separate sections instead of a linear format, which forced players to spend time flipping back through the Journal for long periods of time to find quest details. A <a href=\"../../game-of-the-year-edition/92-3825/\" rel=\"nofollow\">Game of the Year Edition</a> was released in October '03, which included the original game and both the expansions. This version (along with <a href=\"../../the-elder-scrolls-iv-oblivion/61-20238/\" rel=\"nofollow\">Oblivion</a>'s Game of the Year Edition) was also made available on <a href=\"../../steam/92-718/\" rel=\"nofollow\">Steam</a> on June 16, 2009.</p><h2>Soundtrack</h2><h3>Original Soundtrack</h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/3661/1711010-morrowind_front_full.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1711010\" data-size=\"medium\" style=\"width: 395px\" data-ratio=\"1.0126582278481\" data-width=\"395\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:101.3%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/3661/1711010-morrowind_front_full.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1711010\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_medium/0/3661/1711010-morrowind_front_full.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_medium/0/3661/1711010-morrowind_front_full.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Soundtrack Cover from the Collector's Edition</figcaption></figure><p>Morrowind's soundtrack was composed by <a href=\"/jeremy-soule/3040-17632\" data-ref-id=\"3040-17632\">Jeremy Soule</a> and earned an <a href=\"/interactive-achievement-awards/3015-4604\" data-ref-id=\"3015-4604\">AIAS</a> nomination for Best Soundtrack. The original CD was included with the Collector's Edition and contained the following 15 tracks.</p><table><tbody><tr><th>Track #</th><th>Track Name</th><th>Length (Total Length: Reprise</a></p></td><td><p>02:14</p></td></tr></tbody></table><h2>System Requirements</h2><h3>Minimum system requirements</h3><ul><li><b>Operating System</b>: Windows ME / 98 / XP / 2000</li><li><b>RAM Memory</b>: 128 MB RAM (Windows ME/98), 256 MB RAM (Windows XP/2000)</li><li><b>Processor</b>: 500 MHz Intel Pentium III, Celeron, or AMD Athlon processor</li><li><b>Hard Drive Space</b>: 1 GB</li><li><b>DirectX</b>: DirectX 8.1 (included)</li><li><b>Video Card</b>: 32MB Direct3D Compatible video card and DirectX 8.1 compatible driver</li><li><b>Sound Card</b>: DirectX 8.1 compatible sound card</li><li><b>Peripherals</b>: Keyboard; Mouse</li></ul><h3>Recommended</h3><ul><li><b>Processor</b>: 800 MHz or faster Intel Pentium III or AMD Athlon processor</li><li><b>RAM Memory</b>: 256 MB RAM</li><li><b>Video Card</b>: NVIDIA GeForce2 GTS or ATI Radeon 7500 or faster video card</li></ul>", "deck": "The third entry in Bethesda's series of expansive first-person role-playing games.
