{"duration": "0:10:00", "runner": "NachoYacopu", "data": {"site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/trip-world/3030-30396/", "expected_release_quarter": null, "description": "<h2>Gameplay</h2><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/12/126726/1762386-tripworld_screenshot.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1762386\" data-size=\"medium\" data-embed-type=\"image\" data-ratio=\"0.9\" data-width=\"160\" style=\"width: 160px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:90.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/12/126726/1762386-tripworld_screenshot.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1762386\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_medium/12/126726/1762386-tripworld_screenshot.png\"/></a><figcaption>The first boss (left), Chong Pei.</figcaption></figure><p>The player controls a creature known as Yakopoo through five levels. Areas are explorable, and also have secrets and <a data-ref-id=\"3015-2\" href=\"/easter-egg/3015-2\">easter eggs</a>. The object of the game is to find the flower of peace because the inhabitants of the world have gone mad. At the end of every level, the player fights a boss. On the fifth - and final level - the player must defeat several bosses.</p><p>Yakopoo is also able to shift between 3 main forms. His normal for, he is able to jump and fight by kicks and punches. In his flying form, his ears change to wings and he is able to fly. Swimming form: in this form, he is transformed into a fish and is able to swim.</p><p>Yakopoo can also pick up special power-ups and get special forms. The player also has four health points, when he loses those, he has to restart the level.</p><h2>Plot</h2><p>Yocapu lives on Trip World, the home of the Shabubu race. Yakopoo lives with his grandpa on the holy mountain, also known as Dubios. The Flower of Peace resides here, and Yakopoo's Grandpa must protect it from evil. One day, a band of thieves stole the flower and caused chaos. Now it is up to Yakopoo to get the flower and restore order.</p><h2>Reception</h2><p>The German magazine <i>ASM</i> rated the game an overall score of 9 out of 12. The reviewer stated that Trip World is \"in any case a treat for action fans\". <i>Video Games</i>, another German magazine, rated the game a score of 68%. The magazine referred to Trip World as a \"better\" platform game and lauded its graphics and music. The review's author commented that Trip World is \"ideally suited\" for inexperienced players due to its low level of difficulty. <i>Video Games</i> also praised the \"clear game structure\", but criticized the \"missing lasting appeal\" for experienced players.</p>", "deck": "A Game Boy platformer that was somewhat similar to Kirby.", "aliases": null, "image": {"icon_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/square_avatar/3/30116/1366335-trip_world_boxart.png", "medium_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_medium/3/30116/1366335-trip_world_boxart.png", "tiny_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/square_mini/3/30116/1366335-trip_world_boxart.png", "small_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/3/30116/1366335-trip_world_boxart.png", "thumb_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_avatar/3/30116/1366335-trip_world_boxart.png", "screen_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/screen_medium/3/30116/1366335-trip_world_boxart.png", "super_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_large/3/30116/1366335-trip_world_boxart.png"}, "date_last_updated": "2013-08-07 16:59:53", "expected_release_month": null, "api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/game/3030-30396/", "number_of_user_reviews": 0, "original_release_date": "1992-11-27 00:00:00", "original_game_rating": null, "date_added": "2010-03-15 20:07:29", "platforms": [{"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/platform/3045-3/", "abbreviation": "GB", "site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/game-boy/3045-3/", "id": 3, "name": "Game Boy"}, {"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/platform/3045-138/", "abbreviation": "3DSE", "site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/nintendo-3ds-eshop/3045-138/", "id": 138, "name": "Nintendo 3DS eShop"}], "expected_release_day": null, "expected_release_year": null, "id": 30396, "resource_type": "game", "name": "Trip World"}, "platform": "Gamecube", "title": "Trip World"}

{"duration": "0:16:00", "runner": "Protomagicalgirl", "data": {"site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/ninja-gaiden-shadow/3030-17825/", "expected_release_quarter": null, "description": "<h2>Overview</h2><figure data-ref-id=\"1300-508889\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/7539/508889-ninja_gaiden_shadow__u__41.png\" data-size=\"small\" data-align=\"right\" data-embed-type=\"image\" data-ratio=\"0.9\" data-width=\"160\" style=\"width: 160px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:90.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/7539/508889-ninja_gaiden_shadow__u__41.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-508889\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/7539/508889-ninja_gaiden_shadow__u__41.png\"/></a><figcaption>Ryu Hayabusa</figcaption></figure><p>Ninja Gaiden: Shadow (Ninja Ryukenden GB Matenro Kessen in Japan, literally Legend of the Ninja Dragon Sword GB: Skyscraper Showdown, and Shadow Warriors in PAL regions) is an action platformer developed and published by <a href=\"../../tecmo-inc/65-485/\" rel=\"nofollow\"> Tecmo</a> (with development assistance from <a href=\"../../natsume-inc/65-145/\" rel=\"nofollow\"> Natsume</a>). The game was released in 1991 in <a href=\"/north-america/3035-1664\" data-ref-id=\"3035-1664\"> North America</a> on the <a href=\"/game-boy/3045-3\" data-ref-id=\"3045-3\"> Game Boy</a>. The game stars <a href=\"../../ryu-hayabusa/94-104/\" rel=\"nofollow\"> Ryu Hayabusa</a> and is part of the <a href=\"/ninja-gaiden/3025-472\" data-ref-id=\"3025-472\"> Ninja Gaiden franchise</a>.</p><p>The game is commonly believed to be a licensed edit of the Natsume <a href=\"/nes/3045-21\" data-ref-id=\"3045-21\"> Nintendo Entertainment System</a> game <a href=\"../../shadow-of-the-ninja/61-1768/\" rel=\"nofollow\"> Shadow of the Ninja</a>. The two games share many similarities and have many differences, so credible evidence could be amassed to support either side.</p><h2>Plot</h2><figure data-ref-id=\"1300-508888\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/7539/508888-ninja_gaiden_shadow__u__40.png\" data-size=\"small\" data-align=\"right\" data-embed-type=\"image\" data-ratio=\"0.9\" data-width=\"160\" style=\"width: 160px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:90.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/7539/508888-ninja_gaiden_shadow__u__40.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-508888\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/7539/508888-ninja_gaiden_shadow__u__40.png\"/></a><figcaption>Emperor Garuda</figcaption></figure><p>The game follows Ryu Hayabusa in his battle against Emperor Garuda (his name is Emperor Gulf in the PAL version of the game). "http://www.giantbomb.com/bill-trinen/3040-6189/", "id": 6189, "name": "Bill Trinen"}, {"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/person/3040-131716/", "site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/tatsumi-kimishima/3040-131716/", "id": 131716, "name": "Tatsumi Kimishima"}], "description": "<h2>Overview</h2><p>Kirby &amp; The Amazing Mirror is a <a href=\"/game-boy-advance/3045-4\" data-ref-id=\"3045-4\">Game Boy Advance</a> game developed by <a href=\"/flagship-co-ltd/3010-1271\" data-ref-id=\"3010-1271\">Flagship Co., Ltd.</a> (with assistance from <a href=\"/dimps-corporation/3010-119\" data-ref-id=\"3010-119\">Dimps Corporation</a>) and published by <a href=\"/nintendo/3010-90\" data-ref-id=\"3010-90\">Nintendo</a>. It is the second Kirby title for the GBA and is somewhat inspired by Flagship's work on the Four Swords game included with the GBA port of <a href=\"/the-legend-of-zelda-a-link-to-the-past/3030-10276\" data-ref-id=\"3030-10276\">The Legend of Zelda: A Link to the Past</a>. However while Fours Swords keeps players working closely together, in The Amazing Mirror player are free to separate and conquer challenges independently. Playing without human partners results in the game AI controlling the three other Kirbys, which creates a markedly different experience. Regardless of the number of players engaged, the maze-like Mirror World holds a challenge unique to the series. Flagship would later revisit the Kirby series with <a href=\"/kirby-squeak-squad/3030-1239\" data-ref-id=\"3030-1239\">Kirby: Squeak Squad</a> on the <a href=\"/nintendo-ds/3045-52\" data-ref-id=\"3045-52\">Nintendo DS</a> .</p><h2>Gameplay</h2><p>Kirby &amp; The Amazing Mirror is unique from the rest of the series, in the way that it is structured in a way similar to <a href=\"/metroid/3025-3\" data-ref-id=\"3025-3\">Metroid</a> where the entire game is a large explorable area in which new areas and warps can be established.</p><p>There is a variety of extras hidden in chests such as maps, sound test tracks, different colors for Kirby, and additional health pieces. These chests are well hidden behind puzzles that require certain abilities. The Master Sword can be used to bypass any puzzle in the game. However, the sword is only accessible after defeating the game's final boss.</p><p>There is a total of nine areas in the game, each containing a boss who holds a piece of the mirror. When all nine mirror pieces are collected, the mirror will be completed and the final boss can be faced.</p><h2>Enemies</h2><h4>Regular enemies</h4><ul><li>Bang-Bang: Flies towards Kirby with little control, explodes upon impact.</li><li>Batty: Hangs from a surface and gives chase upon seeing Kirby.</li><li>Big Waddle Dee: A bigger version of Waddle Dee.</li><li>Blipper: A fish that can swim in the water, but flops around if it gets to land.</li><li>Blockin: Disguises himself as a star block and attacks if inhaled.</li><li>Bomber: Explodes killing all enemies on screen, but only if colliding with a surface or Kirby.</li><li>Boxin: Tries to punch Kirby while jumping back and forth.</li><li><a href=\"/bronto-burt/3015-3426\" data-ref-id=\"3015-3426\">Bronto Burt</a>: Flies towards Kirby in a zigzag pattern.</li><li>Chip: Hops around an a usually predetermined path.</li><li>Cookin: Throws a frying pan at Kirby, if it hits, Kirby is flipped and cooked on a frying pan.</li><li>Cupie: Flies through walls and shoots arrows at Kirby.</li><li>Droppy: Inhales Kirby and steals his ability, turning into whatever enemy Kirby inhaled to get said ability.</li><li>Flamer: Runs along walls until it notices Kirby, it will then break off the wall and fly towards Kirby.</li><li>Foley: Stays in a fixed position in the air, if Kirby gets too close, it will fall to the ground and explode upon impact.</li><li>Giant Rocky: A bigger version of Rocky.</li><li>Glunk: Stays underwater and fires at Kirby.</li><li>Golem: Attempts to attack Kirby, gives different abilities depending on its color, and whether it is rolling, punching, or doing nothing.</li><li><a href=\"/gordo/3015-4373\" data-ref-id=\"3015-4373\">Gordo</a>: Follows a predetermined path and cannot be killed.</li><li>Haley: Flies through the sky but will not change path if Kirby is spotted.</li><li>Heavy Knight: A bigger version of Sword Knight.</li><li>Hot Head: Tries to breathe fire on Kirby.</li><li>Jack: Stays in cannons, making them unusable, it can be blasted out of a cannon if the fuse is lit though.</li><li>Laser Ball: Can float through walls and shoot lasers at Kirby.</li><li>Leap: Flies through the air and kisses Kirby, making him unable to move as he wipes it off.</li><li>Metal Guardian: Stays in armor until Kirby gets close, will then fire lasers at Kirby.</li><li>Minny: A very small enemy that just moves around.</li><li>Mirra: Attaches to a Mirror Door and will burrow into the ground if it spots Kirby, taking the Mirror Door with it.</li><li>Noddy: Takes a few steps and then lies down.</li><li>Parasol Shotzo: A Shotzo that flies through the air with its attached Parasol.</li><li>Pengi: Blasts cold air at Kirby to freeze him.</li><li>Prank: Will attempt to throw projectiles at Kirby, or paint his face, both of which do damage. He will also sometimes throw banana peels, which trip Kirby and make him lose his ability.</li><li>Rocky: Leaps towards Kirby, attempting to crush him.</li><li>Roly-Poly: Rolls down hills to hit Kirby.</li><li><a href=\"/scarfy/3015-4346\" data-ref-id=\"3015-4346\">Scarfy</a>: Stays in on place unless Kirby tries to inhale it. If that is the case, it furiously chases towards Kirby, exploding on impact.</li><li>Shadow Kirby: Fights with Kirby, dropping a power up if defeated.</li><li>Shooty: Aims small laser beans at Kirby while flying through the air.</li><li><a href=\"/shotzo/3005-15651\" data-ref-id=\"3005-15651\">Shotzo</a>: Shoots projectiles at Kirby and cannot be defeated.</li><li>Sir Kibble: Throws a boomerang at Kirby.</li><li>Snooter: Eats power ups, and Kirby if he gets too close. Will also become enraged and faster if hit by a non-lethal attack.</li><li>Sorar: Flies in a predetermined path and fires blasts.</li><li>Sparky: Moves towards Kirby and then releases a spark blast.</li><li><a href=\"/squishy/3005-5745\" data-ref-id=\"3005-5745\">Squishy</a>: Moves through the water and jumps around if above land.</li><li>Sword Knight: Attacks Kirby with a sword.</li><li>Twister: Flies around like a tornado.</li><li>UFO: A rare enemy that flies around the screen attempting to hit Kirby. It also fires lasers.</li><li><a href=\"/waddle-dee/3015-2069\" data-ref-id=\"3015-2069\">Waddle Dee</a>: Runs towards Kirby.</li><li><a href=\"/waddle-doo/3015-2070\" data-ref-id=\"3015-2070\">Waddle Doo</a>: Fires a beam at Kirby, just like the Beam ability.</li><li>Wheelie: Rolls around the stage like a wheel towards Kirby.</li></ul><h4>Mini-bosses</h4><ul><li>Batafire: Flies through the air and charges at Kirby.</li><li><a href=\"/bombar/3005-29383\" data-ref-id=\"3005-29383\">Bombar</a>: Flies and shoots missiles at Kirby</li><li><a href=\"/box-boxer/3005-29384\" data-ref-id=\"3005-29384\">Box Boxer</a>: Throws projectiles, but can also punch and grab Kirby.</li><li>Boxy: Rams at Kirby or throws boxes at him, which contain food, batteries, or enemies.</li><li><a href=\"/bonkers/3005-29364\" data-ref-id=\"3005-29364\">Bonkers</a>: Attacks Kirby with his hammer, and sometimes throws projectiles at him.</li><li><a href=\"/master-hand/3005-730\" data-ref-id=\"3005-730\">Master Hand</a>: Attacks Kirby with attacks similar to when he appeared in the Super Smash Bros. series. Appears with Crazy Hand as a boss.</li><li><a href=\"/mr-frosty/3005-29358\" data-ref-id=\"3005-29358\">Mr. Flosty (Frosty)</a>: Throws ice at Kirby. His name in past games was Mr. Frosty, but was mistranslated this game as Mr. Flosty.</li><li><a href=\"/phan-phan/3005-29386\" data-ref-id=\"3005-29386\">Phan Phan</a>: Rolls at Kirby, throws him around, or throws apples at him.</li></ul><h4>Bosses</h4><ul><li><a href=\"/crazy-hand/3005-3319\" data-ref-id=\"3005-3319\">Crazy Hand</a>: Appears with Master Hand and retains many of his abilities from Super Smash Bros. Melee.</li><li><a href=\"/dark-meta-knight/3005-28207\" data-ref-id=\"3005-28207\">Dark Meta Knight</a>: Fights with a sword just like Meta Knight, but is faster and harder to avoid.</li><li><a href=\"/dark-mind/3005-29380\" data-ref-id=\"3005-29380\">Dark Mind</a>: The final boss who has three forms. Kirby fights him with the Master Sword.</li><li><a href=\"/gobbler/3005-29381\" data-ref-id=\"3005-29381\">Gobbler</a>: Moves around in the water and tries to bite Kirby, or fire torpedoes at him.</li><li>King Golem: Causes rocks to fall from the sky and can summon Golems to fight for him. Cannot Move.</li><li><a href=\"/kracko/3005-3074\" data-ref-id=\"3005-3074\">Kracko</a>: Summons Waddle Doos, Flamers, and Twisters. Also fires a beam at Kirby and causes rain.</li><li><a href=\"/mega-titan/3005-29382\" data-ref-id=\"3005-29382\">Mega Titan</a>: Fires his arms at Kirby, in his second form, his head floats around shoots missiles.</li><li>Moley: Burrows and attacks Kirby by throwing rocks at him.</li><li>Wiz: Flies around and pulls enemies and projectiles out of his hat.</li></ul><h2>Mini-Games</h2><ul><li>Speed Eaters: A pan reveals that there are either apples or bombs on a plate. If \"A\" is pressed Kirby inhales whatever is on the plate. Each apple is worth one point (first to eight points wins), and bombs make the player lost a turn.</li><li>Crackity Hack: Stop the bar when it's closest to the top and then hit \"A\" when the crosshairs line up to make Kirby jump up and make a large crack in the planet.</li><li>Kirby's Wave Ride: Press \"A\" when Kirby surfs at the height of a wave to make him go faster. Get to the finish first to win.</li><li>Boss Endurance: After beating the game, this mode is unlocked. Kirby fights multiple bosses and mid-bosses while only being able to use 4 maximum tomatoes throughout the whole run.</li></ul>", "releases": [{"api_detail_url": {"duration": "0:24:00", "runner": "Pearstrike", "data": {"site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/kirby-air-ride/3030-15550/", "expected_release_quarter": null, "description": "<h2>Overview</h2><p>Kirby's Air Ride is a kart racer starring the puffy, pink hero, Kirby. The game is notable for its simplistic control scheme that only uses the analog stick for direction and one button on the Gamecube controller for decelerating and using power ups. Unlike most other driving games, acceleration occurs regardless of player input. The game is primarily intended to be played with multiple people, as there are no dedicated career mode</p><h2>Game Modes</h2><h3>Air Ride</h3><p>Race to the Finish on one of several courses. You can utilize boost pads, triggers, copy abilities and more to gain an advantage. Free Run mode also acts as a Time Trial mode that allows to set records.</p><h3>Top Ride</h3><p>This mode plays the most differently compared to the other two which the various tracks only fill a single screen (reminiscent of <a data-ref-id=\"3030-32988\" href=\"/super-off-road/3030-32988\">Super Off Road</a>) You have access to only two vehicles in this mode; the free star (Where you can point in the direction you want to go) and the steer star (which has relative controls)</p><h3>City Trial</h3><p>Players have a limited time to traverse a city, collecting stat-building powerups to be used against other players in various minigames after the allotted time limit expires. You'll start in the Compact Star which has lower stats. By holding the action button and down on the control stick, you can dismount your Air Ride in order to board another one. However you won't be able to obtain any power ups while not riding a vehicle. Playing in Free Run mode allows you to use any unlocked vehicle</p><h2>LAN Play</h2><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/14355/2402308-emulator.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2402308\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.75\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:75.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/14355/2402308-emulator.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2402308\"><img src=\"/uploads/scale_small/1/14355/2402308-emulator.png\"/></a><figcaption>Four players playing in system link mode.</figcaption></figure><p>This game is one of the few titles compatible with the Broadband Adapater. Up to four systems can be linked together. When two systems are linked, up to two players can play on one system, however when playing with three or more systems, only one player per console can play. Any unlocked content located on the memory card can be used for LAN play. Only <b>Air Ride</b> and <b>City Trial</b> modes are playable with most of the customizable options available.</p><h2>Checklist</h2><p>The game also features several unlockables that become available via an achievement system labeled as the Checklist. This consists of a board with several panels that turn around only when certain conditions have been met. Some challenges will also reward additional vehicles, characters, songs in the Sound Test and more. Revealing purple spaces also allows you to clear a challenge without actually having to fulfill it's normal requirements. Not all challenges can be unlocked through this method however. This system would later appear in <a data-ref-id=\"3030-20588\" href=\"/super-smash-bros-brawl/3030-20588\">Super Smash Bros. Brawl</a> and <a data-ref-id=\"3030-31734\" href=\"/kid-icarus-uprising/3030-31734\">Kid Icarus Uprising</a>.</p><h2>Air Ride Machines</h2><table class=\"t-editor with-border full-width\"><thead><tr><th>Machine Name</th><th>Descriptor</th><th>Game Modes</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Free Star</td><td>Machine will steer based on the control stick's direction.</td><td>Top</td></tr><tr><td>Steer Star</td><td>Machine can be steered left or right.</td><td>Top</td></tr><tr><td>Compact Star</td><td>Slower, but easy to control. Using Kirby's unique sucking mechanic, you can suck up enemies and shoot them out in a star burst or swallow them and take over their power. These powers range greatly from giving Kirby a parasol for glide down with to having beams of plasma snaking around him.</p><h2>Gameplay</h2><p>Kirby: Nightmare in Dream land plays like other games in the series. Kirby scrolls across the screen to point A to point B. In each lever there are hidden treasure chests and other secrets that unlock extra rooms in the hub worlds. The game has 7 worlds that all contain 6 rooms, a boss and other unlockable rooms including warps, rooms with power ups, small boss fights and sub-games.</p><h2>Sub-games</h2><p>The sub-games, which are selectable in the main menu and in the hub world are simple games that can be played in multiplayer.</p><h4>Quick Draw</h4><p>A game where you press the A button at the perfect time to kill an enemy.</p><h4>Bomb Rally</h4><p>4 Kirbys hit a bomb back and forth at each other. If it's not hit at the right time, it explodes and the Kirby it was aimed at turns into a ball.</p><h4>Kirby's Air Grind</h4><p>4 Kirbys race Warp Stars on rails. Parts of the rails or rough and need to be slowed down over.</p><h4>Boss Endurance</h4><p>In this game, you fight all the bosses in the game (besides Nightmare) with only one life. Unlocked after game has been beaten.</p><p><strong>Extra Mode</strong></p><p>Kirby must replay the entire game with half the health. Unlocked after 100% completion.</p><p><strong>Meta Knightmare</strong></p><p>This mode stars <a data-ref-id=\"3005-1683\" href=\"/meta-knight/3005-1683\">Meta Knight</a>, as he plays through the entire course of the game with 3 hits and no ability to save. Rather then the copy ability, Meta Knight can attack with a selection of swords attacks. Unlocked after the 100% completion, and after extra mode has been beaten.</p><h2>Abilities</h2><ul><li>Backdrop</li><li>Ball</li><li>Beam</li><li>Burning</li><li>Crash</li><li>Cutter</li><li>Hi-Jump</li><li>Fire</li><li>Freezing</li><li>Hammer</li><li>Ice</li><li>Laser</li><li>Light</li><li>Mike</li><li>Parasol</li><li>Sleep</li><li>Sparks</li><li>Spike</li><li>Star "expected_release_day": null, "expected_release_year": null, "id": 21775, "resource_type": "game", "name": "Kirby: Nightmare in Dream Land"}, "platform": "Gamecube", "title": "Kirby: Nightmare in {"duration": "0:14:00", "runner": "Protomagicalgirl, TrUShade, eBloodyCandy", "data": {"site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/kirbys-dream-land/3030-19788/", "expected_release_quarter": null, "description": "<h2>Overview</h2><figure data-align=\"right\" data-size=\"small\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/12/129563/2788249-kirby%27s+dream+land.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2788249\" data-ratio=\"0.9\" data-width=\"160\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 160px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:90.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/12/129563/2788249-kirby%27s+dream+land.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2788249\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/12/129563/2788249-kirby%27s+dream+land.jpg\"/></a></figure><p>Kirby's Dream Land (published in Japan as \"Kirby of the Stars\") is a side-scrolling platformer developed by <a href=\"/hal-laboratory-inc/3010-753\" data-ref-id=\"3010-753\">HAL</a> and published by <a href=\"/nintendo-entertainment-system/3045-21\" data-ref-id=\"3045-21\">Nintendo</a> in 1992 for <a href=\"/game-boy/3045-3\" data-ref-id=\"3045-3\">Game Boy</a>. The first game in the <a href=\"/kirby/3025-420\" data-ref-id=\"3025-420\">long-running series</a> starring pink puffball <a href=\"/kirby/3005-726\" data-ref-id=\"3005-726\">Kirby</a>, Kirby's Dream Land is a simplistic and cutesy platformer in which the player has the ability to inhale objects, including enemies, and spit them out as projectiles. Unlike most platformers, Kirby can also fly indefinitely without assistance from <a href=\"/power-up/3015-700\" data-ref-id=\"3015-700\">power-ups</a>.</p><p>The game's plot involves <a href=\"/king-dedede/3005-1301\" data-ref-id=\"3005-1301\">King Dedede</a>, a large penguin and the self-proclaimed King of <a href=\"/dream-land/3035-340\" data-ref-id=\"3035-340\">Dream Land</a>, who has stolen all of Dream Land's food for a large feast. It's up to Kirby to confront Dedede and his minions in order to retrieve the stolen food.</p><p>Kirby's Dream Land was conceived by HAL developer <a href=\"/masahiro-sakurai/3040-66996\" data-ref-id=\"3040-66996\"> Masahiro Sakurai</a>. The protagonist's simple design was first used as a placeholder sprite by the development team, who intended to eventually replace the character with a more complex design. Originally named \"Popopo\" (the game's working title during development was \"Twinkle Popo\"), the main character's name was later changed to \"Kirby\" in reference to a brand of <a href=\"/vacuum-cleaner/3055-3084\" data-ref-id=\"3055-3084\">vacuum cleaners</a>. The game also contains references to HAL's preceding <a href=\"/adventures-of-lolo/3025-781\" data-ref-id=\"3025-781\">Adventures of Lolo</a> series, most notably the second stage boss fight against <a href=\"/lolo/3005-1598\" data-ref-id=\"3005-1598\">Lololo</a> and <a href=\"/lala/3005-1862\" data-ref-id=\"3005-1862\">Lalala</a>.</p><p>The game was digitally re-released for the <a href=\"/nintendo-3ds/3045-117\" data-ref-id=\"3045-117\">Nintendo 3DS</a> via <a href=\"/virtual-console/3015-2925\" data-ref-id=\"3015-2925\">Virtual Console</a> in 2011. It was also re-released for <a href=\"/wii/3045-36\" data-ref-id=\"3045-36\">Wii</a> as part of the <a href=\"/kirbys-dream-collection-special-edition/3030-38070\" data-ref-id=\"3030-38070\">Kirby's Dream Collection</a> compilation, while a timed demo version was used for <a href=\"/super-smash-bros-for-wii-u-nintendo-3ds/3030-35573\" data-ref-id=\"3030-35573\">Super Smash Bros. for Wii U</a>. Although the game never received a standalone release for home consoles, it was remade as \"Spring Breeze\", the first of seven main game modes featured in <a href=\"/kirby-super-star/3030-9233\" data-ref-id=\"3030-9233\">Kirby Super Star</a> for the <a href=\"/super-nintendo-entertainment-system/3045-9\" data-ref-id=\"3045-9\">Super Nintendo Entertainment System</a>. A more difficult version of \"Spring Breeze\" known as \"Revenge of the King\"was also included in <a href=\"/kirby-super-star-ultra/3030-21084\" data-ref-id=\"3030-21084\">Kirby Super Star Ultra</a>, the <a href=\"/nintendo-ds/3045-52\" data-ref-id=\"3045-52\">Nintendo DS</a> remake of Kirby Super Star.</p><h2>Gameplay</h2><figure data-align=\"right\" data-size=\"small\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/12/129563/2788250-kirbys_dream_land_whispy.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2788250\" data-ratio=\"0.9\" data-width=\"160\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 160px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:90.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/12/129563/2788250-kirbys_dream_land_whispy.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2788250\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/12/129563/2788250-kirbys_dream_land_whispy.jpg\"/></a></figure><p>As a fairly traditional platformer, Kirby's Dream Land follows the titular character's quest to save <a href=\"/dreamland/3035-340\" data-ref-id=\"3035-340\">Dream Land</a> across five stages. Kirby has the ability to suck in enemies and then shoot them out as projectiles. Pressing Down on the directional pad will make Kirby duck; if he has something in his mouth, this makes Kirby swallow the object to dispose of it. Pressing Up causes Kirby to inflate with air, allowing him to fly through the air indefinitely. If Kirby exhales afterward, he expels an puff of air which can be used as a weaker projectile. While floating or holding an object in his mouth, Kirby is slower and becomes an easier target for enemy attacks.</p><p>Kirby can eat certain food items to restore his six <a href=\"/health/3015-130\" data-ref-id=\"3015-130\">health points</a>; touching or inhaling the food will instantly restore some of his health. Kirby's Dream Land contains two healing items: \"<a href=\"/energy-drinks/3055-1060\" data-ref-id=\"3055-1060\">Pep Brew</a>\", a beverage which heals two points of health, and the \"Bag of Magic Food\" (later known as a <a href=\"/maxim-tomato/3055-391\" data-ref-id=\"3055-391\">Maxim Tomato</a>), which fully restores Kirby's health. There are also a variety of power-ups that Kirby can collect throughout the game to gain special abilities or attacks:</p><ul><li><a href=\"/bomb/3055-97\" data-ref-id=\"3055-97\"><strong>Bomb</strong></a>: Kirby can toss this item at enemies to create a large explosion, which can also damage Kirby if he's too close to the blast.</li><li><strong>Spicy Food</strong> (aka <a href=\"/superspicy-curry/3055-242\" data-ref-id=\"3055-242\">Superspicy Curry</a>): Kirby breathes damaging fire for several seconds. Contact with water will negate Spicy Food's effects.</li><li><a href=\"/microphone/3055-258\" data-ref-id=\"3055-258\"><strong>Microphone</strong></a>: Kirby will screech into a microphone, destroying all enemies on the screen.</li><li><a href=\"/candy/3055-560\" data-ref-id=\"3055-560\"><strong>Candy</strong></a>: A magic lollipop granting Kirby <a href=\"/temporary-invincibility/3015-266\" data-ref-id=\"3015-266\">temporary invincibility</a>.</li><li><a href=\"/mint-leaf/3055-6128\" data-ref-id=\"3055-6128\"><strong>Mint Leaf</strong></a>: Grants Kirby the ability to <a href=\"/rapid-fire/3015-2374\" data-ref-id=\"3015-2374\">rapid-fire</a> \"air pellets\" from his mouth while flying. Only found in the game's third stage.</li></ul><h2>Stages</h2><figure data-align=\"right\" data-size=\"small\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/12/129563/2788251-kdlboss4.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2788251\" data-ratio=\"0.9\" data-width=\"160\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 160px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:90.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/12/129563/2788251-kdlboss4.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2788251\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/12/129563/2788251-kdlboss4.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/12/129563/2788251-kdlboss4.jpg\"/></noscript></a></figure><p>Each of the five stages consist of a branching pathway to the boss room, where Kirby fights a large enemy before collecting the Sparkling Star, which transports him to the next stage. Most levels also contain sub-bosses, who must also be defeated in order to progress. The fifth level is the only unconventional one, as it is merely a tower where Kirby is required to fight through a <a href=\"/boss-rush/3015-1465\" data-ref-id=\"3015-1465\">boss rush</a> of Dream Land's previous four bosses before reaching the final boss, King Dedede.</p><ol><li><strong>Green Greens</strong> - <a href=\"/whispy-woods/3005-3076\" data-ref-id=\"3005-3076\">Whispy Woods</a></li><li><strong>Castle Lololo</strong> - <a href=\"/lolo/3005-1598\" data-ref-id=\"3005-1598\">Lololo</a> and <a href=\"/lala/3005-1862\" data-ref-id=\"3005-1862\">Lalala</a></li><li><strong>Float Islands</strong> - <a href=\"/kabula/3005-23502\" data-ref-id=\"3005-23502\">Kaboola</a></li><li><strong>Bubbly Clouds</strong> - <a href=\"/kracko/3005-3074\" data-ref-id=\"3005-3074\">Kracko</a></li><li><strong>Mt. Dedede</strong> - <a href=\"/king-dedede/3005-1301\" data-ref-id=\"3005-1301\">King Dedede</a></li></ol><figure data-align=\"left\" data-size=\"small\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/12/129563/2788255-dl_extra_mode.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2788255\" data-ratio=\"0.9\" data-width=\"160\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 160px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:90.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/12/129563/2788255-dl_extra_mode.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2788255\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/12/129563/2788255-dl_extra_mode.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/12/129563/2788255-dl_extra_mode.jpg\"/></noscript></a></figure><p>After defeating King Dedede, players are given a code to access the game's \"Extra Mode\", a more difficult version of Kirby's Dream Land. From the title screen, press Up, A and Select simultaneously to enable Extra Mode. This code can be entered from Dream Land's title screen regardless of whether the game has actually been completed or not.</p>", "deck": "The first game to star the iconic pink puffball Kirby, who is on a quest to recover Dream Land's stolen food supply from the gluttonous King Dedede.", "aliases": "Hoshi no Kirby\nTwinkle Popo", "image": {"icon_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/square_avatar/8/87790/1865071-box_kdl.png", "medium_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_medium/8/87790/1865071-box_kdl.png", "tiny_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/square_mini/8/87790/1865071-box_kdl.png", "small_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/8/87790/1865071-box_kdl.png", "thumb_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_avatar/8/87790/1865071-box_kdl.png", "screen_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/screen_medium/8/87790/1865071-box_kdl.png", "super_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_large/8/87790/1865071-box_kdl.png"}, "date_last_updated": "2016-02-03 17:53:36", "expected_release_month": null, "api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/game/3030-19788/", "number_of_user_reviews": 3, "original_release_date": "1992-02-17 00:00:00", "original_game_rating": [{"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/game_rating/3065-6/", "id": 6, "name": "ESRB: E"}], "date_added": "2008-04-01 16:49:50", "platforms": [{"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/platform/3045-3/", "abbreviation": "GB", "site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/game-boy/3045-3/", "id": 3, "name": "Game Boy"}, {"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/platform/3045-138/", "abbreviation": "3DSE", "site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/nintendo-3ds-eshop/3045-138/", "id": 138, "name": "Nintendo 3DS eShop"}], "expected_release_day": null, "expected_release_year": null, "id": 19788, "resource_type": "game", "name": "Kirby's Dream Land"}, "platform": "Gamecube", "title": "Kirby's Dream Land"}
{"duration": "0:16:00", "runner": "Protomagicalgirl", "data": {"site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/super-mario-land/3030-19834/", "expected_release_quarter": null, "description": "<h2>Overview</h2><figure data-ref-id=\"1300-294520\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/2714/294520-marioland11.png\" data-size=\"small\" data-align=\"right\" data-ratio=\"0.9\" data-width=\"160\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 160px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:90.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/2714/294520-marioland11.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-294520\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_super/0/2714/294520-marioland11.png\"/></a></figure><p>Super Mario Land is a 2D sidescrolling platformer developed and published by <a href=\"/nintendo/3010-90\" data-ref-id=\"3010-90\">Nintendo</a> for the <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/game-boy/3045-3\" data-ref-id=\"3045-3\">Game Boy </a>on July 31, 1989. A handheld successor to <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/super-mario-bros/3030-15544\" data-ref-id=\"3030-15544\">Super Mario Bros.</a>, it is one of the <a href=\"/launch-titles/3015-238\" data-ref-id=\"3015-238\">launch titles</a> for the Game Boy, developed with no input from series creator <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/shigeru-miyamoto/3040-614\" data-ref-id=\"3040-614\">Shigeru Miyamoto</a> (instead developed by Game Boy creator <a href=\"/gunpei-yokoi/3040-45151\" data-ref-id=\"3040-45151\">Gunpei Yokoi's</a> <a href=\"/nintendo-rd1/3010-928\" data-ref-id=\"3010-928\">R&amp;D1 devision</a>).</p><p>Players control hero plumber <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/mario/3005-177\" data-ref-id=\"3005-177\">Mario</a> as he ventures through the four tropical kingdoms of <a href=\"/sarasaland/3035-3896\" data-ref-id=\"3035-3896\">Sarasaland</a> to rescue <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/princess-daisy/3005-807\" data-ref-id=\"3005-807\">Princess Daisy</a> (and the hypnotized inhabitants of the lands) from mysterious space monster <a href=\"/tatanga/3005-2777\" data-ref-id=\"3005-2777\">Tatanga</a>.</p><p>The game would receive a direct sequel in 1992, titled <a href=\"/super-mario-land-2-6-golden-coins/3030-14425\" data-ref-id=\"3030-14425\">Super Mario Land 2: 6 Golden Coins</a>, which vastly improves upon the platforming aspects of the original while adding a new adversary, <a href=\"/wario/3005-24\" data-ref-id=\"3005-24\">Wario</a> (who would play as the protagonist in the series spin-off, <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/wario-land/3025-600\" data-ref-id=\"3025-600\">Wario Land</a>). Tatanga returns in this sequel (as a boss), while Daisy later becomes a regular in <a href=\"/mario/3025-1\" data-ref-id=\"3025-1\">Mario</a> spin-off games (starting with <a href=\"/mario-tennis/3030-6073\" data-ref-id=\"3030-6073\">Mario Tennis</a>). Super Mario Land was later released for the <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/nintendo-3ds/3045-117\" data-ref-id=\"3045-117\">Nintendo 3DS</a> (via <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/nintendo-3ds-eshop/3045-138\" data-ref-id=\"3045-138\">Virtual Console</a>) on June 6, 2011.</p><h2>Gameplay</h2><figure data-ref-id=\"1300-294519\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/2714/294519-marioland10.png\" data-size=\"small\" data-align=\"right\" data-ratio=\"0.9\" data-width=\"160\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 160px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:90.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/2714/294519-marioland10.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-294519\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/2714/294519-marioland10.png\"/></a></figure><p>Super Mario Land is a standard sidescrolling platformer (in similar vein to <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/super-mario-bros/3030-15544\" data-ref-id=\"3030-15544\">Super Mario Bros.</a>) where players must guide Mario through 12 levels (split into four unique areas, called \"Worlds\"), to reach each level's goal (at the rightmost part). Players move Mario using left and right on the d-pad, while holding the \"B\" button to run and hitting the \"A\" button to jump.</p><p>Like Super Mario Bros., Mario is vulnerable to touching most enemies and their projectiles. If he gets hit once (while not powered-up), falls off the level, or gets trapped in automatic side-scrolling stages, he loses a <a href=\"/lives/3015-323\" data-ref-id=\"3015-323\">life</a> and must restart the level. If the player loses all of his lives, then he must either use a <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/continue/3015-635\" data-ref-id=\"3015-635\">continue</a> (and restart the level with three lives and no score) or end the game with a <a href=\"/game-over/3015-372\" data-ref-id=\"3015-372\">game over</a>. Mario can knock out most enemies by jumping (or falling) on them, gaining points by doing so.</p><p>Scattered around all levels are <a href=\"/coin/3055-219\" data-ref-id=\"3055-219\">coins</a> which can be collected by touching them. Coins can also be found by hitting certain boxes (scattered around levels) from below. For every 100 coins collected, the player earns an <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/extra-life/3015-1806\" data-ref-id=\"3015-1806\">extra life</a>. For every 100,000 points earned, the player earns an extra continue.</p><p>The end of most levels contain two exits, one of which is located at the top of the screen and is more difficult to access. If Mario reaches the higher exit, then the player is rewarded with a mini-game in which players can earn a Fire Flower power-up or up to three extra lives.</p><h3>Power-ups</h3><p>By hitting certain boxes (scattered around levels), players can find special power-ups which grant Mario special abilities.</p><ul><li><a href=\"/super-mushroom/3055-49\" data-ref-id=\"3055-49\">Super Mushroom</a> - Transforms Mario into Super Mario, giving him a taller stature while allowing Mario to get hit once without losing a life.</li><li><a href=\"/fire-flower/3055-10\" data-ref-id=\"3055-10\">Fire Flower</a> - Only appears if Mario is Super Mario. If Mario is no longer Super Mario before touching one, it automatically applies the Super Mushroom power-up. Mario also has the ability to throw \"superballs\" (by tapping the B button), which bounce off surfaces and knock out most enemies.</li><li><a href=\"/starman/3055-23\" data-ref-id=\"3055-23\">Starman</a> - Grants Mario <a href=\"/temporary-invincibility/3015-266\" data-ref-id=\"3015-266\">temporary invincibility</a> (as indicated by a change in background music and Mario's clothes flickering). Mario can still lose a life by falling off the level or getting trapped in automatic side-scrolling levels.</li></ul><h3>Vehicles</h3><figure data-ref-id=\"1300-1815993\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/13641/1815993-super_mario_land_20110615022259627.jpg\" data-size=\"small\" data-align=\"right\" data-ratio=\"0.73290598290598\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:73.3%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/13641/1815993-super_mario_land_20110615022259627.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1815993\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/1/13641/1815993-super_mario_land_20110615022259627.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/1/13641/1815993-super_mario_land_20110615022259627.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>The Marine Pop - one of the game's vehicles.</figcaption></figure><p>In certain levels, Mario pilots a personal vehicle in an automatic side-scrolling level. While in the vehicles, Mario moves around the stage with the d-pad while shooting <a href=\"/torpedo/3055-977\" data-ref-id=\"3055-977\">torpedoes</a> or <a href=\"/missile/3055-74\" data-ref-id=\"3055-74\">missiles</a> with either A or B buttons.</p><p>During these levels, the screen scrolls right automatically up to the level's boss battle. If Mario gets trapped between the left edge of the level and an object, he automatically loses a life and must restart the level.</p><h2>Stages</h2><p>The game has 12 stages, all split up into four themed \"worlds\". The player progresses through each world in order, defeating a boss at the third stage of each world.</p><ul><li><b>Birabuto Kingdom</b> - An <a href=\"/egypt/3035-878\" data-ref-id=\"3035-878\">Ancient Egyptian</a>-themed world. The second stage takes place on top of giant <a href=\"/palm-tree/3055-1719\" data-ref-id=\"3055-1719\">palm trees</a> while the third stage takes place inside a <a href=\"/pyramid/3015-6581\" data-ref-id=\"3015-6581\">pyramid</a>. The boss of this world is King Totomesu, a large sphinx creature that jumps and spits fireballs at Mario.</li><li><b>Muda Kingdom</b> - A water-themed world. In the third stage, which is <a href=\"/underwater/3035-719\" data-ref-id=\"3035-719\">underwater</a>, Mario pilots his personal <a href=\"/submarine/3055-828\" data-ref-id=\"3055-828\">submarine</a> (the Marine Pop). The boss of this world is Dragonzamasu, a large <a href=\"/seahorse/3015-4393\" data-ref-id=\"3015-4393\">seahorse</a> creature that swims around and spits fireballs at Mario.</li><li><b>Easton Kingdom</b> - An island-themed world. The second stage takes place in a cavern. The boss of this world is Hiyoihoi, a <a href=\"/moai-head/3055-319\" data-ref-id=\"3055-319\">moai head</a> creature that throws large rocks at Mario.</li><li><b>Chai Kingdom</b> - An <a href=\"/china/3035-343\" data-ref-id=\"3035-343\">Ancient China</a>-themed world. In the third stage, which is in the sky, Mario pilots is personal <a href=\"/airplane/3055-910\" data-ref-id=\"3055-910\">aircraft</a> (the Sky Pop). The boss of this world is Biokinton, a <a href=\"/cloud/3055-1804\" data-ref-id=\"3055-1804\">cloud</a> creature that throws flying birds at Mario. After defeating it, Tatanga appears with his spacecraft as the <a href=\"/final-boss/3015-1537\" data-ref-id=\"3015-1537\">final boss fight</a>.</li></ul><p>By clearing all twelve levels, players can replay the game in \"Expert Mode\", where enemies are moved around in each stage to make the stages more difficult. Clearing the harder levels allows players to replay any of the game's levels.</p>", "deck": "Princess Daisy of Sarasaland has been kidnapped by the evil alien Tatanga and it's up to Mario to rescue her in this handheld platformer (and launch title) for the original Game Boy.", "aliases": null, "image": {"icon_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/square_avatar/8/87790/2269418-box_sml.png", "medium_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_medium/8/87790/2269418-box_sml.png", "tiny_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/square_mini/8/87790/2269418-box_sml.png", "small_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/8/87790/2269418-box_sml.png", "thumb_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_avatar/8/87790/2269418-box_sml.png", "screen_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/screen_medium/8/87790/2269418-box_sml.png", "super_url": "http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_large/8/87790/2269418-box_sml.png"}, "date_last_updated": "2016-05-30 00:14:59", "expected_release_month": null, "api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/game/3030-19834/", "number_of_user_reviews": 5, "original_release_date": "1989-04-21 00:00:00", "original_game_rating": [{"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/game_rating/3065-6/", "id": 6, "name": "ESRB: E"}], "date_added": "2008-04-01 16:50:07", "platforms": [{"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/platform/3045-3/", "abbreviation": "GB", "site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/game-boy/3045-3/", "id": 3, "name": "Game Boy"}, {"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/platform/3045-138/", "abbreviation": "3DSE", "site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/nintendo-3ds-eshop/3045-138/", "id": 138, "name": "Nintendo 3DS eShop"}], "expected_release_day": null, "expected_release_year": null, "id": 19834, "resource_type": "game", "name": "Super Mario Land"}, "platform": "Gameboy", "title": "Super Mario Land"}
{"duration": "1:18:00", "runner": "CujoIHSV", "data": {"site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/super-mario-bros-3/3030-10299/", "expected_release_quarter": null, "description": "<h2>Overview</h2><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/13/138495/1914251-smb3.000.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1914251\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.9375\" data-width=\"256\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 256px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:93.8%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/13/138495/1914251-smb3.000.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1914251\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/13/138495/1914251-smb3.000.png\"/></a><figcaption>The title screen.</figcaption></figure><p>Released in the United States in 1990, Super Mario Bros. 3 was one of the most highly anticipated games of its time. <a href=\"../../nintendo/65-90/\" rel=\"nofollow\">Nintendo</a>'s promotional campaign leading up to the game's release was unprecedented for a video game in the US, and included a key role in the climactic moments of the video-game-themed movie The Wizard. While the film was universally panned by movie critics and video gamers alike, it was successful in its ulterior purpose of promoting Super Mario Bros. 3.</p><p>Super Mario Bros. 3 is generally considered to be one of the <a href=\"../../nes/93-2794/\" rel=\"nofollow\">Nintendo Entertainment System's</a> best, one of the greatest Nintendo games of all time, and also one of the best <a href=\"../../mario/62-1/\" rel=\"nofollow\">Mario</a> games ever created. It was noted for being the top selling video game of all time, before being surpassed by <a href=\"/wii-sports/3030-13328\" data-ref-id=\"3030-13328\">Wii Sports</a>.</p><p>The game's popularity has resulted in a few ports and remakes, including <a href=\"/super-mario-all-stars/3030-18529\" data-ref-id=\"3030-18529\">Super Mario All-Stars</a> (a compilation of early Mario games), <a href=\"/super-mario-bros-3-super-mario-advance-4/3030-20748\" data-ref-id=\"3030-20748\">Super Mario Advance 4: Super Mario Bros. 3</a>, and a <a href=\"/virtual-console/3015-2925\" data-ref-id=\"3015-2925\">Virtual Console</a> port.</p><p><a href=\"/shigeru-miyamoto/3040-614\" data-ref-id=\"3040-614\">Shigeru Miyamoto</a> returned as lead designer along with <a href=\"/takashi-tezuka/3040-593\" data-ref-id=\"3040-593\">Takashi Tezuka</a>, and <a href=\"/koji-kondo/3040-606\" data-ref-id=\"3040-606\">Koji Kondo</a> as the game's music composer.</p><h2>Gameplay</h2><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/3957/203767-ss_smb3_nes.gif\" data-ref-id=\"1300-203767\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.875\" data-width=\"256\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 256px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:87.5%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/3957/203767-ss_smb3_nes.gif\" data-ref-id=\"1300-203767\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/3957/203767-ss_smb3_nes.gif\"/></a><figcaption>Super Mario Bros. 3 brings back the series' traditional gameplay.</figcaption></figure><p>The gameplay in Super Mario Bros. 3 is more akin to the original <a href=\"../../super-mario-bros/61-15544/\" rel=\"nofollow\">Super Mario Bros.</a> than the deviation found in <a href=\"/super-mario-bros-2/3030-7406\" data-ref-id=\"3030-7406\">Super Mario Bros. 2</a>. The game also expands on and introduces many new concepts, some of which stayed for future Mario titles. Notably, Super Mario Bros. 3 was the first Mario game to feature a <a href=\"/world-map/3015-611\" data-ref-id=\"3015-611\">world map</a>, allowing the player a certain level of freedom, including the occasional opportunity to skip sections of levels.</p><p>The game follows the traditional formula of <a href=\"../../mario/94-177/\" rel=\"nofollow\">Mario</a> chasing down <a href=\"../../bowser/94-337/\" rel=\"nofollow\">Bowser</a> to rescue the kidnapped <a href=\"../../peach/94-709/\" rel=\"nofollow\">Princess Peach</a>, though this time around Mario also has to deal with Bowser's children and their powerful <a href=\"/airship/3055-154\" data-ref-id=\"3055-154\">airships</a>.</p><p>Because of the new world map, certain areas are blocked by <a href=\"../../hammer-bros/92-783/\" rel=\"nofollow\">Hammer Bros.</a>, which Mario must defeat (or he can put them to sleep using an item found in the game). Along with these dangerous obstacles, there are <a href=\"/minigames/3015-116\" data-ref-id=\"3015-116\">minigames</a> found in a <a href=\"../../toad/94-845/\" rel=\"nofollow\">Toad</a>'s house. The minigames allow Mario to win items such as Super Mushrooms that can be stored in a bar at the bottom of the screen for future use in individual levels.</p><p>Super Mario Bros. 3 also includes a simultaneous multiplayer mode. Player one controls Mario while player two controls <a href=\"/luigi/3005-370\" data-ref-id=\"3005-370\">Luigi</a>, as the two traverse the game's eight worlds. Through this mode, even more minigames are accessible, including a retouched version of the original <a href=\"/mario-bros/3030-19726\" data-ref-id=\"3030-19726\">Mario Bros</a>.</p><h2>Worlds</h2><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/15051/453906-8.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-453906\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.9375\" data-width=\"256\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 256px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:93.8%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/15051/453906-8.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-453906\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/1/15051/453906-8.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/1/15051/453906-8.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Grass Land is the first world.</figcaption></figure><ul><li><b>Grass Land</b> (World One) - Grass Land is a basic Mario world, featuring a mix of slightly varied Mario environments such as straightforward outdoor stages, auto-scrolling stages that take place in the air, and even an underground stage. It is the smallest world in the game, its map taking up only one screen.</li></ul><ul><li><b>Desert Land</b> (World Two) - A desert world, as the name implies. Quicksand becomes a common obstacle, and one stage takes place inside of a pyramid.</li></ul><ul><li><b>Water Land</b> (World Three) - This world takes place next to the ocean. Levels begin to take place underwater, and even levels that are not underwater usually feature water of some kind.</li></ul><ul><li><b>Giant Land</b> (World Four) - Giant Land is very similar to Grass Land. The difference is that enemies and objects are all more than twice their normal size! Even so, most of them can be destroyed with the same amount of effort.</li></ul><ul><li><b>Sky Land</b> (World Five) - The first half of sky land is also similar to Grass Land. However, the tower stage that exists at the midpoint of this level will take Mario up into the sky, which means that the latter half of this world is composed mostly of air stages.</li></ul><ul><li><b>Ice Land</b> (World Six) - Ice Land's stages are all covered in ice. Mario will slip on ice if he is not carefully controlled, making control even more important than ever.</li></ul><ul><li><b>Pipe Land</b> (World Seven) - Pipe Land's stages feature an abundance of pipes! While the environments may be similar to Grass Land, pipes are absolutely everywhere in these stages, and Piranha Plants come with them.</li></ul><ul><li><b>Dark Land</b> (World Eight) - Dark Land features many stages that are similar to the auto-scrolling airship stages that end the other worlds. It does eventually feature a few \"normal\" stages that resemble earlier worlds, but even these appear to take place at night. Watch out, because nearly every enemy in the game can appear at any time. At the end waits Bowser's Castle.</li></ul><h2>Power-Ups</h2><p>Super Mario Bros. 3 brings back the old powers from the first game, and it also adds some new, more abstract upgrades.</p><h4><a href=\"../../super-mushroom/93-49/\" rel=\"nofollow\">Super Mushroom</a></h4><p>The classic Super Mario Bros. item returns in Super Mario Bros. 3. It turns Mario into Super Mario, allowing him to take one more hit before he dies.</p><h4><a href=\"../../fire-flower/93-10/\" rel=\"nofollow\">Fire Flower</a></h4><p>The Fire Flower is another classic Super Mario Bros. item. It gives Mario the ability to shoot fireballs and quickly destroy enemies. If he is hurt, Mario reverts to his Super Mario stage.</p><h4><a href=\"../../raccoon-suit/93-1246/\" rel=\"nofollow\">Raccoon Suit</a></h4><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/958/178716-tanooki_mario.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-178716\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"1.3559322033898\" data-width=\"295\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 295px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:135.6%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/958/178716-tanooki_mario.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-178716\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/958/178716-tanooki_mario.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/958/178716-tanooki_mario.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Tanooki Suit</figcaption></figure><p>A new item, this gives Mario the ability to fly for short periods of time. If he runs for a while and gets his P-Meter high up, Mario can soar through the sky. Pressing B makes Mario spin, which slows down his descent and hits enemies that get whacked by the raccoon tail.</p><h4><a href=\"../../frog-suit/93-40/\" rel=\"nofollow\">Frog Suit</a></h4><p>The Frog Suit is another new item, giving Mario the ability to swim faster in the water. However, he hops around on land, making him harder to control.</p><h4><a href=\"../../tanooki-suit/93-38/\" rel=\"nofollow\">Tanooki Suit</a></h4><p>Very similar to the Raccoon Suit, this item allows Mario to turn into a stone statue, making him invincible to enemies. In addition to that, it has all of the abilities of the Raccoon Suit.</p><h4><a href=\"../../hammer-bros-suit/93-1247/\" rel=\"nofollow\">Hammer Bro. Suit</a></h4><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/2986/559569-hammer_suit.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-559569\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.64\" data-width=\"200\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 200px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:64.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/2986/559569-hammer_suit.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-559569\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/2986/559569-hammer_suit.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/2986/559569-hammer_suit.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Hammer Bro. Suit</figcaption></figure><p>The Hammer Bro. Suit gives Mario the ability to throw hammers. Mario can also go into the shell and protect himself from enemies.</p><h4><a href=\"../../kuribos-shoe/93-12/\" rel=\"nofollow\">Kuribo's Shoe</a></h4><figure data-ref-id=\"1300-2720138\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/8/81005/2720138-smb3shoe.png\" data-size=\"medium\" data-align=\"right\" data-ratio=\"1\" data-width=\"64\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 64px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:100.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/8/81005/2720138-smb3shoe.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2720138\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_medium/8/81005/2720138-smb3shoe.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_medium/8/81005/2720138-smb3shoe.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Kuribo's Shoe</figcaption></figure><p>A unique power-up, this allows Mario to stomp around in a giant Goomba's shoe. He is impervious to attack from below while he is in Kuribo's Shoe, like Piranha Plants. It is only available in level 5-3. The shoe has not appeared as a power up in any game since Super Mario Bros. 3</p><h4><a href=\"../../starman/93-23/\" rel=\"nofollow\">Starman</a></h4><p>Another classic Super Mario Bros. power-up, this makes Mario temporarily invincible. In certain levels, Mario can string Starmen one after the other to the end of a level by hitting the right blocks along the way before running out of invincibility.</p><h4><a href=\"/warp-whistle/3055-468\" data-ref-id=\"3055-468\">Warp Whistle</a></h4><p>A rare power-up that could only be found in some areas, this lets Mario skip a world at any time, mimicking the pipe zones from the first game. Mario can only move between tiers of levels in this way, so the tiers were: Worlds 2-4, Worlds 5-7, and World 8.</p><h2>Bowser's Children</h2><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/7465/2163988-Koopalings7.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2163988\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.77386934673367\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:77.4%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/7465/2163988-Koopalings7.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2163988\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/7465/2163988-Koopalings7.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/7465/2163988-Koopalings7.jpg\"/></noscript></a></figure><p>Bowser's seven children are the bosses of each world preceding World Eight (Dark Land), in which the player faces Bowser himself. Each child is actually named after a famous musician. Each Koopa is felled after three hits.</p><h4><a href=\"/larry-koopa/3005-2289\" data-ref-id=\"3005-2289\">Larry Koopa</a></h4><p>Larry has no real special abilities beyond jumping high after taking two hits. He is the boss of Grass Land. It is uncertain who Larry is actually named after, but it is speculated to be Lawrence Welk, a well-known accordionist.</p><h4><a href=\"/morton-koopa-jr/3005-2271\" data-ref-id=\"3005-2271\">Morton Koopa, Jr.</a></h4><p>Morton is the boss of Desert Land, and the second youngest of the <a href=\"/koopalings/3015-3991\" data-ref-id=\"3015-3991\">Koopalings</a>. He is loud-mouthed and hot-tempered. While his facial features (the star on his left eye) resemble those of KISS member <a href=\"/paul-stanley/3040-48671\" data-ref-id=\"3040-48671\">Paul Stanley</a>, Morton is actually named after Morton Downey, Jr. (which also explains the \"Jr.\" in Morton's name, not insinuating that Bowser's real name is Morton).</p><h4><a href=\"/wendy-o-koopa/3005-2260\" data-ref-id=\"3005-2260\">Wendy O. Koopa</a></h4><p>Wendy is the only female Koopaling, and also the only Koopaling to have completely circular magical attacks. She is the third youngest, and is often portrayed as a whiny, spoiled brat. Wendy is named after Wendy O. Williams, the singer for the band The Plasmatics.</p><h4><a href=\"/iggy-koopa/3005-2308\" data-ref-id=\"3005-2308\">Iggy Koopa</a></h4><p>Iggy is the middle child of the Koopalings. He is considered a \"genius\", particularly in the cartoons, where he is twin brothers with Lemmy Koopa. His in-game representation differs from his artwork, in which he sports a rainbow <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/mohawk/3055-1709\" data-ref-id=\"3055-1709\">mohawk</a>. In-game, he lacks this, and only has a blonde tuft of hair. Iggy is named after the influential punk artist <a href=\"/iggy-pop/3040-62826\" data-ref-id=\"3040-62826\">Iggy Pop</a>.</p><h4><a href=\"/roy-koopa/3005-2324\" data-ref-id=\"3005-2324\">Roy Koopa</a></h4><p>Roy is the third oldest Koopaling. He is a bully, and enjoys seeing others' pain. He is the largest of the Koopalings, and thus, the worst at jumping. However, when he lands, he causes a ground-shaking blast, which stuns the player if they are still on the ground. Roy is based on Roy Orbison, who inspired Roy Koopa's shades.</p><h4><a href=\"/lemmy-koopa/3005-2337\" data-ref-id=\"3005-2337\">Lemmy Koopa</a></h4><p>Lemmy is the only Koopaling to ride around on a green ball. He uses this same green ball as a weapon in some cases, launching it with his magic wand. He is the second oldest of the Koopalings, and is based on <a href=\"/ian-kilmister/3040-92265\" data-ref-id=\"3040-92265\">Ian \"Lemmy\" Kilmister</a> of the band Mot\u00f6rhead.</p><h4><a href=\"/ludwig-von-koopa/3005-2243\" data-ref-id=\"3005-2243\">Ludwig von Koopa</a></h4><p>The oldest of the Koopa kids, Ludwig is also able to create ground-shaking blasts like Roy Koopa. Naturally, he is based on the famous composer <a href=\"/ludwig-van-beethoven/3040-4419\" data-ref-id=\"3040-4419\">Ludwig van Beethoven</a>, and even has a hairstyle similar to that of the well-known German composer.</p><h2>TV Series</h2><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/10/100719/1439989-super_mario_bros_3.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1439989\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.73394495412844\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:73.4%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/10/100719/1439989-super_mario_bros_3.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1439989\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/10/100719/1439989-super_mario_bros_3.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/10/100719/1439989-super_mario_bros_3.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>The Adventures of Super Mario Bros. 3.</figcaption></figure><p>In addition to the video game itself, Super Mario Bros. 3 also has a TV show and it is called The Adventures of Super Mario Bros. 3. The show introduced the <a href=\"../../koopalings/92-3991/\" rel=\"nofollow\">Koopalings</a> and it is the second Mario animated series following The Super Mario Bros. Super Show. The show was produced by Nintendo in association with DiC Entertainment and spanned a total of 26 episodes.</p><h2>The Wizard</h2><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/10/100719/1440833-tournament_03.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1440833\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.54545454545455\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:54.5%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/10/100719/1440833-tournament_03.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1440833\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/10/100719/1440833-tournament_03.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/10/100719/1440833-tournament_03.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>The game as seen in the finals of the video game tournament in The Wizard.</figcaption></figure><p>The game also appeared in the last scene of <i>The Wizard</i> where Jimmy Woods competed in the final round of the video game tournament. In this scene, Jimmy, Lucas, and Mora battled in the final round where the rules was to get the most points in 10 minutes using the game. At the final 60 seconds of play, Jimmy used a <a href=\"../../warp-whistle/93-468/\" rel=\"nofollow\">Warp Whistle</a> to give him big points and the win.</p>", "deck": "Super Mario Bros. 3 sends Mario on a whole new adventure across diverse worlds and sporting strange new suits and abilities.", "aliases": "SMB3", "image": {"icon_url":
