{"duration": "0:40:00", "runner": "xsvArea51, Bramz, truman", "data": {"site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/super-mario-world/3030-1334/", "expected_release_quarter": null, "description": "<h2>Overview</h2><figure data-ref-id=\"1300-1648575\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/14741/1648575-supermarioworld.jpg\" data-size=\"small\" data-align=\"right\" data-ratio=\"0.83823529411765\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:83.8%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/14741/1648575-supermarioworld.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1648575\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/1/14741/1648575-supermarioworld.jpg\"/></a></figure><p>Super Mario World (known in Japan as <em>Super Mario World: Super Mario Bros. 4</em>) is a side-scrolling platformer developed by <a href=\"/nintendo-ead/3010-463\" data-ref-id=\"3010-463\">Nintendo EAD</a> and published by <a href=\"/nintendo/3010-90\" data-ref-id=\"3010-90\">Nintendo</a> for the <a href=\"/super-nintendo-entertainment-system/3045-9\" data-ref-id=\"3045-9\">Super Nintendo Entertainment System</a> on November 21, 1990 (in Japan), August 31, 1991 (in North America), and April 11, 1992 (in Europe).</p><p>One of the <a href=\"/launch-titles/3015-238\" data-ref-id=\"3015-238\">launch titles</a> of the SNES (and <a href=\"/pack-in-game/3015-1247\" data-ref-id=\"3015-1247\">bundled</a> with early systems in North America), Super Mario World is the fifth main game in the <a href=\"/super-mario/3025-643\" data-ref-id=\"3025-643\">Super Mario</a> series. (starring Nintendo's mascot, <a href=\"/mario/3005-177\" data-ref-id=\"3005-177\">Mario</a>, and his brother, <a href=\"/luigi/3005-370\" data-ref-id=\"3005-370\">Luigi</a>). The game follows both Mario brothers as they explore <a href=\"/dinosaur-land/3035-480\" data-ref-id=\"3035-480\">Dinosaur Land</a> (known for its large amount of <a href=\"/dinosaurs/3015-711\" data-ref-id=\"3015-711\">dinosaurs</a>) to find and defeat the evil <a href=\"/koopa/3015-120\" data-ref-id=\"3015-120\">Koopa</a> king <a href=\"/bowser/3005-337\" data-ref-id=\"3005-337\">Bowser</a> (and his seven underlings, the <a href=\"/koopalings/3015-3991\" data-ref-id=\"3015-3991\">Koopalings</a>) while rescuing <a href=\"/princess-peach/3005-709\" data-ref-id=\"3005-709\">Princess Toadstool</a>.</p><p>Along with new abilities (such as the <a href=\"/spin-attack/3015-2017\" data-ref-id=\"3015-2017\">\"Spin Jump\"</a>), a new <a href=\"/power-up/3015-700\" data-ref-id=\"3015-700\">power-up</a> (the <a href=\"/feather-cape/3055-525\" data-ref-id=\"3055-525\">\"Cape Feather\"</a>) and more obstacles, the game introduces <a href=\"/dinosaurs/3015-711\" data-ref-id=\"3015-711\">dinosaur</a> companions (known as <a href=\"/yoshi/3015-4560\" data-ref-id=\"3015-4560\">Yoshi</a>) that Mario and Luigi can ride. Yoshi, known for using their long <a href=\"/tongue-attack/3015-2867\" data-ref-id=\"3015-2867\">tongues</a> to snare and eat enemies, have become a fan-favorite among the series (giving them <a href=\"/yoshi/3025-686\" data-ref-id=\"3025-686\">their own games and spin-offs</a>, most notably <a href=\"/super-mario-world-2-yoshis-island/3030-2866\" data-ref-id=\"3030-2866\">this game's prequel</a>).</p><p>Special bundles of the SNES in 1994 included a compilation cartridge mixing Super Mario World with <a href=\"/super-mario-all-stars/3030-18529\" data-ref-id=\"3030-18529\">Super Mario All-Stars</a>. The only difference in this version is a new sprite set for Luigi. The original game was later ported to the <a href=\"/game-boy-advance/3045-4\" data-ref-id=\"3045-4\">Game Boy Advance</a> on February 11, 2002 as <a href=\"/super-mario-world-super-mario-advance-2/3030-7551\" data-ref-id=\"3030-7551\">Super Mario World: Super Mario Advance 2</a>. Along with a special version of the original <a href=\"/mario-bros/3030-19726\" data-ref-id=\"3030-19726\">Mario Bros.</a>, the port includes a variety of differences, including Luigi as a selectable character (who now has unique features, such as his floating jump from <a href=\"/super-mario-bros-2/3030-7406\" data-ref-id=\"3030-7406\">Super Mario Bros. 2</a>), new voice acting, and the ability to save anywhere. The original game was also digitally re-released in Nintendo's <a href=\"/virtual-console/3015-2925\" data-ref-id=\"3015-2925\">Virtual Console</a> platform for the <a href=\"/wii/3045-36\" data-ref-id=\"3045-36\">Wii</a> (on February 5, 2007) and <a href=\"/wii-u/3045-139\" data-ref-id=\"3045-139\">Wii U</a> (on April 26, 2013).</p><h2>Gameplay</h2><p>Super Mario World plays like a standard sidescrolling platformer (similar to the previous <a href=\"/super-mario-bros/3025-1899\" data-ref-id=\"3025-1899\">Super Mario Bros.</a> games), where players must guide Mario or Luigi through over 75 stages, split into over seven unique areas (or \"Worlds\"). Each stage has a goal to reach, usually a giant moving goalpost (known as Giant Gates) at the rightmost part of the level (rarely a special mysterious exit reachable by a keyhole, requiring Mario/Luigi to carry a large <a href=\"/key/3055-105\" data-ref-id=\"3055-105\">key</a>).</p><h3>Yoshi</h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/13226/384242-mario_all_stars___super_mario_world___snes000.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-384242\" data-size=\"medium\" data-ratio=\"0.93359375\" data-width=\"256\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 256px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:93.4%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/13226/384242-mario_all_stars___super_mario_world___snes000.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-384242\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_medium/1/13226/384242-mario_all_stars___super_mario_world___snes000.png\"/></a><figcaption>Yoshi's first appearance</figcaption></figure><p>Mario can ride Yoshi in all stages of the game except for castles and fortresses, and can make Yoshi shoot out his long tongue to snare and eat enemies.</p><h3>Power-Ups</h3><figure data-ref-id=\"1300-1293396\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/7/79739/1293396-120px_smw_cape_mario_gliding.jpg\" data-size=\"small\" data-align=\"right\" data-ratio=\"0.95833333333333\" data-width=\"120\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 120px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:95.8%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/7/79739/1293396-120px_smw_cape_mario_gliding.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1293396\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/7/79739/1293396-120px_smw_cape_mario_gliding.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/7/79739/1293396-120px_smw_cape_mario_gliding.jpg\"/></noscript></a></figure><p>Throughout each level (usually in special <a href=\"/floating-blocks/3055-152\" data-ref-id=\"3055-152\">Blocks</a>), Mario and Luigi can find <a href=\"/power-up/3015-700\" data-ref-id=\"3015-700\">power-ups</a> to give themselves special abilities:</p><ul><li><a href=\"/super-mushroom/3055-49\" data-ref-id=\"3055-49\"><strong>Super Mushroom</strong></a> - Transforms into Super Mario/Luigi, giving them a taller stature while allowing them to get hit once without losing a life. They can also break some Blocks by hitting it from below and Spin Jump on Rotating Blocks to break them. This power-up glides across the ground before collected and can sometimes be found by running over special areas (like some bushes). All Yellow Exclamation Blocks contain this power-up. Running over checkpoint gates as regular Mario/Luigi automatically puts them in Super form.</li></ul><ul><li><a href=\"/fire-flower/3055-10\" data-ref-id=\"3055-10\"><strong>Fire Flower</strong></a> - Transforms into Fire Mario/Luigi. In addition to the benefits of the Super Mushroom, they can now throw <a href=\"/fireball/3055-120\" data-ref-id=\"3055-120\">fireballs</a> (which can damage and destroy most enemies) by tapping the X or Y buttons. Performing a Spin Jump also throws fireballs on both sides of them. This power-up is usually stationary before collected. In the GBA remake, getting hit while in Fire form changes them into Super form (similar to <a href=\"/super-mario-bros-3/3030-10299\" data-ref-id=\"3030-10299\">Super Mario Bros. 3</a>).</li></ul><ul><li><a href=\"/feather-cape/3055-525\" data-ref-id=\"3055-525\"><strong>Cape Feather</strong></a> - Transforms into Cape Mario/Luigi. In addition to the benefits of the Super Mushroom, they can now glide across the air by holding the X or Y buttons. In addition, making a running jump allows them to fly through the air (allowing them to sail with the cape by holding Up and Down on the joypad). This power-up floats left and right downward before collected. All Green Exclamation Blocks contain this power-up. Jumping on Super Koopas cause them to drop a Cape Feather.</li></ul><p>Somewhat similar to Super Mario Bros. 3, players can have the ability to store spare power-ups for use at a later time. If a player collects two of the same power-up (or if they collect a Super Mushroom while in Fire or Cape forms), it will be placed in the Reserve Box at the top of the <a href=\"/heads-up-display/3015-180\" data-ref-id=\"3015-180\">HUD</a>. Getting hit (or pressing the Select button in-game) causes the item to slowly descend from the Reserve Box. Also new to the game are Roulette Blocks, which can carry either of these power-ups (along with the Starman power-up below) and is chosen when the player hits the block.</p><p>In addition, Mario and Luigi can find two rare power-ups that do not permanently transform them, instead temporarily giving them a special ability:</p><ul><li><a href=\"/starman/3055-23\" data-ref-id=\"3055-23\"><strong>Starman</strong></a> - Grants them <a href=\"/temporary-invincibility/3015-266\" data-ref-id=\"3015-266\">temporary invincibility</a>, allowing them to bump onto any enemies to defeat them. Unlike previous games, players can chain combos by bumping onto enemies in quick succession (giving them easier <a href=\"/extra-life/3015-1806\" data-ref-id=\"3015-1806\">extra lives</a>). Usually found in Roulette Blocks.</li></ul><ul><li><strong>Power Balloon</strong> - Temporarily inflates them allowing them to hover in the air and gradually float upwards. Found in only four levels and is not necessary for normal game progression (only required for reaching secret exits).</li></ul><p> </p><h2>Worlds</h2><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/14477/340228-166.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-340228\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.75\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:75.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/14477/340228-166.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-340228\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/1/14477/340228-166.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/1/14477/340228-166.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Dinosaur Land.</figcaption></figure><p>There are over 75 levels in the game, each split into multiple areas (or \"Worlds\"). These worlds (along with the <a href=\"/koopalings/3015-3991\" data-ref-id=\"3015-3991\">Koopaling</a> boss in that world):</p><ol><li><strong>Yoshi's Island</strong> (<a href=\"/iggy-koopa/3005-2308\" data-ref-id=\"3005-2308\">Iggy</a>)</li><li><strong>Donut Plains</strong> (<a href=\"/morton-koopa-jr/3005-2271\" data-ref-id=\"3005-2271\">Morton</a>)</li><li><strong>Vanilla Dome</strong> (<a href=\"/lemmy-koopa/3005-2337\" data-ref-id=\"3005-2337\">Lemmy</a>)</li><li><strong>Cheese Bridge</strong> (<a href=\"/ludwig-von-koopa/3005-2243\" data-ref-id=\"3005-2243\">Ludwig</a>)</li><li><strong>Forest of Illusion</strong> (<a href=\"/roy-koopa/3005-2324\" data-ref-id=\"3005-2324\">Roy</a>)</li><li><strong>Chocolate Island</strong> (<a href=\"/wendy-o-koopa/3005-2260\" data-ref-id=\"3005-2260\">Wendy</a>)</li><li><strong>Valley of Bowser</strong> (<a href=\"/larry-koopa/3005-2289\" data-ref-id=\"3005-2289\">Larry</a>)</li></ol><p>While each world can be progressed in a narrow path, the game features an abundance of secret exits and alternate paths leading to hidden levels, bonus areas, and special shortcuts. Some of the more notable secret levels include the four Switch Palaces (allowing players to unlock special Exclamation Blocks for use as platforms and a way to earn power-ups), the Butter Bridge path (an alternate way to traverse both the 3rd and 4th Worlds), the Valley Fortress (a way to skip most of 7th World and end up at the back door of <a href=\"/bowsers-castle/3035-685\" data-ref-id=\"3035-685\">Bowser's Castle</a>), and the Top Secret Area (a hidden one-screen level in Donut Plains that gives players free power-ups and a Yoshi).</p><h3>Bonus Worlds</h3><figure data-ref-id=\"1300-803789\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/2788/803789-149.jpg\" data-size=\"small\" data-align=\"right\" data-ratio=\"1.308\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:130.8%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/2788/803789-149.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-803789\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/2788/803789-149.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/2788/803789-149.jpg\"/></noscript></a></figure><p>In addition, there are two secret areas only accessible through special Star Roads hidden throughout the game: <strong>Star World</strong> and <strong>Special Zone</strong>.</p><p>The Star World (up in the clouds) acts as a special <a href=\"/fast-travel/3015-676\" data-ref-id=\"3015-676\">\"fast travel\"</a> area between most of Dinosaur Land (from the Donut Plains to the Valley of Bowser). There are five Star Roads that lead to it, each with their own accompanying level. Reaching the secret Keyhole exit in each level opens up a path between the level and another Star Road (eventually making a circular path). All levels in this area also have a hidden red, blue, or yellow-colored baby Yoshi (allowing players to gain Yoshis with special abilities).</p><p>By completing both normal and Keyhole exits allows a new Star Road entrance to the Special Zone: eight challenging levels that must be completed sequentially (each with a level name resembling '80s slang for something positive). Completing all eight levels gives them a one-way Star Road back to Yoshi's House while changing the color scheme of the overworld (giving it a Fall apperance) and giving some enemies a Fall theme (<a href=\"/koopa-troopa/3015-2557\" data-ref-id=\"3015-2557\">Koopa Troopas</a> <a href=\"/halloween/3015-3967\" data-ref-id=\"3015-3967\">wearing Mario masks</a>, both jumping <a href=\"/piranha-plant/3015-794\" data-ref-id=\"3015-794\">Piranha Plants</a> and Beanstalks becoming haunted <a href=\"/pumpkin/3055-2734\" data-ref-id=\"3055-2734\">pumpkins</a>, and <a href=\"/bullet-bill/3015-1581\" data-ref-id=\"3015-1581\">Bullet Bills</a> resembling <a href=\"/crow/3015-4907\" data-ref-id=\"3015-4907\">crow</a>-like <a href=\"/pidgit/3015-2989\" data-ref-id=\"3015-2989\">Pidgits</a>).</p><p>While four of the Star Roads have no exit routes in Dinosaur Land (unless previously unlocked), the fifth Star Road immediately links to the front door of <a href=\"/bowsers-castle/3035-685\" data-ref-id=\"3035-685\">Bowser's Castle</a>, allowing players to <a href=\"/sequence-breaking/3015-980\" data-ref-id=\"3015-980\">skip a large majority of the game</a>.</p><h2>Enemies</h2><table><tbody><tr><td><h3>Amazing Flying Hammer Bro</h3><p>A flying enemy, throws hammers. monster that jumps out of the lava at Mario. mummy incarnation of the Buzzy Beetle.</td><td><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/api/image/original/1769902-sppbanzaibill.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1769902\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/12/126726/1769902-sppbanzaibill.png\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img {"duration": "0:50:00", "runner": "Iceless", "data": {"site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/mega-man-x3/3030-16948/", "expected_release_quarter": null, "description": "<h2>Overview</h2><figure data-ref-id=\"1300-2586379\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/8/87790/2586379-mmx3_jpbox.png\" data-size=\"small\" data-align=\"right\" data-ratio=\"1.2082474226804\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:120.8%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/8/87790/2586379-mmx3_jpbox.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2586379\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/8/87790/2586379-mmx3_jpbox.png\"/></a></figure><p>Mega Man X3 (known in Japan as Rockman X3) is a side-scrolling action platformer developed and published by <a href=\"http://www.giantbomb.com/capcom/3010-367\" data-ref-id=\"3010-367\">Capcom</a> for the <a href=\"http://www.giantbomb.com/super-nintendo-entertainment-system/3045-9\" data-ref-id=\"3045-9\">Super Nintendo Entertainment System</a> on January 1996.</p><p>The third game in the <a href=\"http://www.giantbomb.com/mega-man-x/3025-524\" data-ref-id=\"3025-524\">Mega Man X</a> series (and the sequel to the <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/mega-man-x2/3030-19801\" data-ref-id=\"3030-19801\">Mega Man X2</a>), players control android <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/mega-man-x/3005-1474\" data-ref-id=\"3005-1474\">Mega Man X</a> and, for the first time, his Reploid ally <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/zero/3005-1261\" data-ref-id=\"3005-1261\">Zero</a> (who can be called in to deal with tough situations thanks to his energy sword). It is the last game in the franchise to feature the original art and gameplay style of Mega Man X (as well as the <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/password/3015-38\" data-ref-id=\"3015-38\">password</a> system).</p><p>Set sometime after the events of Mega Man X2 (where X and the rebuilt Zero defeat the Maverick <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/sigma/3005-1837\" data-ref-id=\"3005-1837\">Sigma</a> for the second time), the Maverick rebellion becomes neutralized due to the technology of Reploid scientist <a href=\"/dr-doppler/3005-28897\" data-ref-id=\"3005-28897\">Dr. Doppler</a>. Reformed Mavericks form an utopia near the scientist (named Dopple Town) and lived peacefully before they suddenly go berserk and cause mayhem. Believing Doppler to be responsible, X and Zero must defeat the eight Maverick leaders of Dopple Town and foil the mad scientist's plans (while surviving his henchmen, <a href=\"/bit/3005-28898\" data-ref-id=\"3005-28898\">Bit</a> and <a href=\"/byte/3005-28899\" data-ref-id=\"3005-28899\">Byte</a>, and <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/vile/3005-5052\" data-ref-id=\"3005-5052\">a mysterious Maverick</a>).</p><p>An enhanced version of the game was released for the Sega Saturn and PlayStation in Japan (on April 26, 1996) and Europe (published by <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/virgin-interactive-entertainment-inc/3010-176\" data-ref-id=\"3010-176\">Virgin Interactive</a> on March 1997). While the core game remains the same, it includes animated <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/full-motion-video/3015-604\" data-ref-id=\"3015-604\">full-motion video</a> cutscenes, a rearranged soundtrack, and new sound effects. This version was later released for the <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/pc/3045-94\" data-ref-id=\"3045-94\">PC</a> in Japan (on March 28, 1997) and North America (on October 5, 1998) and is included in the <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/mega-man-x-collection/3030-1483\" data-ref-id=\"3030-1483\">Mega Man X Collection</a> compilation for the <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/playstation-2/3045-19\" data-ref-id=\"3045-19\">PlayStation 2</a> and <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/gamecube/3045-23\" data-ref-id=\"3045-23\">GameCube</a> (released on January 10, 2006).</p><h2>Gameplay</h2><p>The gameplay has only somewhat differed from <a href=\"/mega-man-x2/3030-19801\" data-ref-id=\"3030-19801\">Mega Man X2</a> by making the wall jumping slightly easier to preform while reploids become tougher. The gameplay compared to the Mega Man series is much more fast paced with more tricky and more powerful mavericks than ever giving rise to more difficult battles. As a side point, their battles can be completed faster than other bosses in previous games, as they are more susceptible to their weakness, and take more damage from their attacks.</p><h2>Boss Robots(Mavericks)</h2><p>At the end of every level X must fight a boss to proceed, and after fighting all 8 bosses he goes to the final fight against Doppler and his army. Here is a list of the boss robots in order to exploit all of their weaknesses.</p><figure data-align=\"right\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:80.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/5007/377153-capure_23_jul._29_22.00.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-377153\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/5007/377153-capure_23_jul._29_22.00.jpg\"/></noscript></a></figure><p><b>Boss-</b> <b><a href=\"/gravity-beetle/3005-1641\" data-ref-id=\"3005-1641\">Gravity Beetle</a></b>Weapon: Gravity Well</p><p>Power-6200rp</p><p>Speed-3600rp</p><p>Weakness-Ray Splasher</p><p><b>Boss-</b> <b><a href=\"/blast-hornet/3005-1640\" data-ref-id=\"3005-1640\">Blast Hornet</a></b></p><p>Weapon: Parasitic Bomb</p><p>Power-3400rp</p><p>Speed-8600rp</p><p>Weakness-Gravity Well</p><h2>Upgrades</h2><h3>Armor Capsules</h3><p><a href=\"/dr-light/3005-292\" data-ref-id=\"3005-292\">Dr. Light</a> has once again hidden some secret capsules that will enhance Mega Man X's abilities. When Mega Man X steps into one of these capsules, it will come to life and change the appearance of Mega Man X. Here are descriptions of some of the Capsules:</p><p><u><b>Boots</b></u>(Nothing required)</p><p>Gives X the ability to dash again while in the air</p><p>Location-Blizzard Buffalo's lair</p><p><u><b>Gun</b></u></p><p>(Boots and T.Fang)</p><p>Allows X to charge up one level and fire two powerful shots; also X can charge special weapons.</p><p>Location-Neon Tiger's lair</p><p><u><b>Helmet</b></u></p><p>(Gun and Triad T.)</p><p>A map will appear at the beginning of the level to show X where hidden items are located.</p><p>Location-Drill Rhino's lair</p><p><u><b>Armor</b></u></p><p>(Boots, G. Well and Gun)</p><p>Automatically creates a defense shield on Mega Man X's chassis that reduces damage by 50%. After getting hurt a shield will automatically form around X to lessen damage by 1/2</p><p>Location-Volt Catfish's lair</p><h3>Robot Ride Armor</h3><p>In addition to the armor capsules, Dr. Light has set out 4 different armors known as robot ride armor. Mega Man X and Zero must find these 4 armors, each with different capabilities and functions. The armor looks like a giant robot that they can activate by jumping into it. Once X finds an armor, he may use the armor in any stage where he may find the Robot Ride platforms.</p><p>If X has found an armor, the platform will activate. A menu will appear just to the left of the platform, so use the game pad or the arrow keys to select which armor X would like to use. While in the robot ride armor, Mega Man X and Zero will not be damaged. The armor can be damaged, but can be healed by returning to the platform. If the armor is destroyed, X cannot use it again until he enters a new stage. He can also jump out if need be by jumping while holding up on the D-pad.</p><p><u><b>Robot Ride Armors</b></u></p><p><b>Chimera</b></p><p><b>Hawk</b></p><p><b>Frog</b></p><p><b>Kangaroo</b></p><h2><b>Soundtrack</b></h2><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/4527/2062809-1.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2062809\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.9\" data-width=\"250\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 250px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:90.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/4527/2062809-1.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2062809\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/4527/2062809-1.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/4527/2062809-1.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Cover Art</figcaption></figure><p>In 2005 Capcom released a 5-disc box set called Capcom Music Generation Rockman X1~6. It contains the original music of Mega Man X through Mega Man X6 as well as some unused tracks. Mega Man X3 tracks span the entire second disc containing both the SNES (tracks 1-29) and Saturn/Playstation (tracks 30-69) arranged tracks. {"duration": "0:50:00", "runner": "Trogdor", "data": {"site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/mega-man-x2/3030-19801/", "expected_release_quarter": null, "description": "<h2>Overview</h2><figure data-ref-id=\"1300-2586378\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/8/87790/2586378-mmx2_jpbox.png\" data-size=\"small\" data-align=\"right\" data-ratio=\"1.2224622030238\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:122.2%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/8/87790/2586378-mmx2_jpbox.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2586378\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/8/87790/2586378-mmx2_jpbox.png\"/></a></figure><p>Mega Man X2 (known in Japan as Rockman X2) is a side-scrolling action platformer developed and published by <a href=\"http://www.giantbomb.com/capcom/3010-367\" data-ref-id=\"3010-367\">Capcom</a> (published by <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/laguna-gmbh/3010-2300\" data-ref-id=\"3010-2300\">Laguna</a> for Europe) for the <a href=\"http://www.giantbomb.com/super-nintendo-entertainment-system/3045-9\" data-ref-id=\"3045-9\">Super Nintendo Entertainment System</a> on January 1995.</p><p>The second game in the <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/mega-man-x/3025-524\" data-ref-id=\"3025-524\">Mega Man X</a> series (and the sequel to the original <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/mega-man-x/3030-9463\" data-ref-id=\"3030-9463\">Mega Man X</a>), players reprise the role of highly-advanced <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/android/3015-692\" data-ref-id=\"3015-692\">android</a> <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/mega-man-x/3005-1474\" data-ref-id=\"3005-1474\">Mega Man X</a>, who gains some of the major upgrades unlocked from the previous game (plus new upgrades, such as the ability to detect <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/secret-area/3015-1115\" data-ref-id=\"3015-1115\">secret areas</a>, perform a <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/dash/3015-2290\" data-ref-id=\"3015-2290\">Dash</a> in mid-air, store two charged beams at once for quick successive strikes, and perform a powerful <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/screen-cleaner/3015-2588\" data-ref-id=\"3015-2588\">screen-clearing attack</a>).</p><p>Set six months after the events of the original Mega Man X (where X destroys <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/mavericks/3015-359\" data-ref-id=\"3015-359\">Maverick</a> leader <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/sigma/3005-1837\" data-ref-id=\"3005-1837\">Sigma</a> and his forces, at the cost of the destruction of his mentor, <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/zero/3005-1261\" data-ref-id=\"3005-1261\">Zero</a>), X becomes the leader of the elite Reploid <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/police/3015-1011\" data-ref-id=\"3015-1011\">police</a> force \"Maverick Hunters\". As the Maverick rebellion kicks back up, X must destroy a new group of Mavericks while hunting down the remains of Zero (taken by the \"X-Hunters\", a trio of powerful Mavericks consisting of <a href=\"/serges/3005-28894\" data-ref-id=\"3005-28894\">Serges</a>, <a href=\"/agile/3005-28896\" data-ref-id=\"3005-28896\">Agile</a>, and <a href=\"/violen/3005-28895\" data-ref-id=\"3005-28895\">Violen</a>).</p><p>Along with upgrades to the game's mechanics and graphics, the game includes an in-cartridge enhancement chip (Cx4) that allowed the game to use limited 3D <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/wireframe-model/3015-3678\" data-ref-id=\"3015-3678\">wireframe</a> graphics (including rotating and scaling effects). This technology would later be used in <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/mega-man-x3/3030-16948\" data-ref-id=\"3030-16948\">Mega Man X3</a>.</p><p>The game was later released on the <a href=\"http://www.giantbomb.com/wii/3045-36\" data-ref-id=\"3045-36\">Wii</a> (via <a href=\"http://www.giantbomb.com/virtual-console/3015-2925\" data-ref-id=\"3015-2925\">Wii Virtual Console</a> on June 14, 2012) and <a href=\"http://www.giantbomb.com/wii-u/3045-139\" data-ref-id=\"3045-139\">Wii U</a> (via <a href=\"http://www.giantbomb.com/virtual-console/3015-2925\" data-ref-id=\"3015-2925\">Wii U Virtual Console</a> on January 2, 2014).</p><h2>Upgrades</h2><figure data-ref-id=\"1300-480581\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/7539/480581-mega_man_x2015.png\" data-size=\"small\" data-align=\"right\" data-ratio=\"0.875\" data-width=\"256\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 256px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:87.5%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/7539/480581-mega_man_x2015.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-480581\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/7539/480581-mega_man_x2015.png\"/></a><figcaption>X, using a Light Capsule to get an upgrade.</figcaption></figure><p>Like the previous game, X can find rare large blue Light Capsules, scattered throughout the game, which show him a holographic message from his creator, <a href=\"http://www.giantbomb.com/dr-light/3005-292\" data-ref-id=\"3005-292\">Dr. Light</a>. Depending on which Capsule X finds, Dr. Light briefs him on what the upgrade does before allowing him to step into the Capsule to receive it (giving him a shiny new replacement piece for his armor).</p><ul><li><strong>Helmet Piece</strong> - Allows X to use his \"Item Tracer\", in which a cursor (shown on the screen) automatically zooms in to hidden passages. Found in Crystal Snail's stage.</li><li><strong>Body Piece</strong> - Allows X to perform the \"Giga Crush\" technique, which clears all enemies on the screen (but uses a gauge that only fills up by taking damage and can only be used once per level). X also takes 50% less damage from attacks. Found in Morph Moth's stage.</li><li><strong>Arm Pieces</strong> - Allows X to both charge up his special weapons (for an alternate, more powerful effect) and grants him an X-Buster on his other arm (allowing him to further charge his standard X-Buster, which fires two consecutive super-charged blasts that can cut through enemies). Found in Wheel Gator's stage.</li><li><strong>Leg Pieces</strong> - Allows X to <a href=\"http://www.giantbomb.com/dash/3015-2290\" data-ref-id=\"3015-2290\">dash</a> in mid-air. Found in Overdrive Ostrich's stage.</li></ul><h3>Hidden Capsule</h3><p>Along with the four Capsules above, the game includes a very hidden fifth Capsule which grants X a powerful ability (in similar vein to the secret ability in the previous game).</p><p>If he manages to reach a certain point in the third stage of the X-Hunter's fortress after receiving all four armor parts and obtaining every Sub Tank and Life Up powerups, and then following a specific path (covered in spikes), he can reach a Capsule in which Dr. Light grants X the power to perform a <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/shoryuken/3015-496\" data-ref-id=\"3015-496\">Shoryuken</a> (made famous by <a href=\"http://www.giantbomb.com/ryu/3005-103\" data-ref-id=\"3005-103\">Ryu</a> and <a href=\"http://www.giantbomb.com/ken-masters/3005-212\" data-ref-id=\"3005-212\">Ken</a> of <a href=\"http://www.giantbomb.com/capcom/3010-367\" data-ref-id=\"3010-367\">Capcom's</a> <a href=\"http://www.giantbomb.com/street-fighter/3025-331\" data-ref-id=\"3025-331\">Street Fighter</a> series).</p><p>By inputting a specific combination (forward, then down, then down and forward, then the Attack button) while X is on the ground and has a full Life Energy gauge, X performs a powerful close-ranged rising <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/uppercut/3015-1128\" data-ref-id=\"3015-1128\">uppercut</a> that can deal serious damage to bosses. Earning this ability is not saved in the game's password system.</p><h2>Bosses</h2><h3>Bubble Crab</h3><figure data-ref-id=\"1300-2587850\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/8/87790/2587850-mmx2_boss_bc.png\" data-size=\"small\" data-align=\"right\" data-ratio=\"1.2666666666667\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:126.7%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/8/87790/2587850-mmx2_boss_bc.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2587850\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/8/87790/2587850-mmx2_boss_bc.png\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/8/87790/2587850-mmx2_boss_bc.png\"/></noscript></a></figure><p>Based on the <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/crab/3015-3691\" data-ref-id=\"3015-3691\">crab</a>, <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/bubble-crab/3005-1606\" data-ref-id=\"3005-1606\">Bubble Crab</a> (known as Bubbly Crablos in the Japanese version) controls a <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/underground/3035-1554\" data-ref-id=\"3035-1554\">subterranean</a> base located under the deep sea. His weakness is the Spin Wheel.</p><p>Eliminating him grants X the Bubble Splash.</p><h3>Crystal Snail</h3><figure data-ref-id=\"1300-2587851\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/8/87790/2587851-mmx2_boss_cs.png\" data-size=\"small\" data-align=\"right\" data-ratio=\"1.2666666666667\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:126.7%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/8/87790/2587851-mmx2_boss_cs.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2587851\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/8/87790/2587851-mmx2_boss_cs.png\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/8/87790/2587851-mmx2_boss_cs.png\"/></noscript></a></figure><p>Based on the <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/snail/3015-3929\" data-ref-id=\"3015-3929\">snail</a>, <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/crystal-snail/3005-1612\" data-ref-id=\"3005-1612\">Crystal Snail</a> (known as Crystar Mymine in the Japanese version) takes controls of a crystal mine. His weakness is the Magnet Mine.</p><p>Eliminating him grants X the Crystal Hunter.</p><h3>Flame Stag</h3><figure data-ref-id=\"1300-2587852\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/8/87790/2587852-mmx2_boss_fs.png\" data-size=\"small\" data-align=\"right\" data-ratio=\"1.2666666666667\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:126.7%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/8/87790/2587852-mmx2_boss_fs.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2587852\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/8/87790/2587852-mmx2_boss_fs.png\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/8/87790/2587852-mmx2_boss_fs.png\"/></noscript></a></figure><p>Based on the <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/moose/3015-2271\" data-ref-id=\"3015-2271\">stag-moose</a>, <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/flame-stag/3005-1613\" data-ref-id=\"3005-1613\">Flame Stag</a> (known as Flame Stagger in the Japanese version) controls a base within a <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/volcano/3035-2298\" data-ref-id=\"3035-2298\">volcano</a>. His weakness is the Bubble Splash.</p><p>Eliminating him grants X the Speed Burner.</p><h3>Magna Centipede</h3><figure data-ref-id=\"1300-2587853\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/8/87790/2587853-mmx2_boss_mc.png\" data-size=\"small\" data-align=\"right\" data-ratio=\"1.2666666666667\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:126.7%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/8/87790/2587853-mmx2_boss_mc.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2587853\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/8/87790/2587853-mmx2_boss_mc.png\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/8/87790/2587853-mmx2_boss_mc.png\"/></noscript></a></figure><p>Based on the <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/centipede/3015-1874\" data-ref-id=\"3015-1874\">centipede</a>, <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/magna-centipede/3005-1621\" data-ref-id=\"3005-1621\">Magna Centipede</a> (known as Magne Hyakulegger in the Japanese version) takes control of a central computer station. His weakness is the Silk Shot.</p><p>Eliminating him grants X the Magnet Mine.</p><h3>Morph Moth</h3><figure data-ref-id=\"1300-2587854\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/8/87790/2587854-mmx2_boss_mm.png\" data-size=\"small\" data-align=\"right\" data-ratio=\"1.2666666666667\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:126.7%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/8/87790/2587854-mmx2_boss_mm.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2587854\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/8/87790/2587854-mmx2_boss_mm.png\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/8/87790/2587854-mmx2_boss_mm.png\"/></noscript></a></figure><p>Based on the <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/moth/3015-5036\" data-ref-id=\"3015-5036\">moth</a>, <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/morph-moth/3005-1608\" data-ref-id=\"3005-1608\">Morph Moth</a> (known as Metamor Mothmeanos in the Japanese version) hides in a <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/junkyard/3035-2317\" data-ref-id=\"3035-2317\">junkyard</a> for robots. His weakness is the Speed Burner.</p><p>Eliminating him grants X the Silk Shot.</p><h3>Overdrive Ostrich</h3><figure data-ref-id=\"1300-2587855\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/8/87790/2587855-mmx2_boss_oo.png\" data-size=\"small\" data-align=\"right\" data-ratio=\"1.2666666666667\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:126.7%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/8/87790/2587855-mmx2_boss_oo.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2587855\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/8/87790/2587855-mmx2_boss_oo.png\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/8/87790/2587855-mmx2_boss_oo.png\"/></noscript></a></figure><p>Based on the <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/ostrich/3015-2792\" data-ref-id=\"3015-2792\">ostrich</a>, <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/overdrive-ostrich/3005-1555\" data-ref-id=\"3005-1555\">Overdrive Ostrich</a> (known as Sonic Ostreague in the Japanese version) controls a series of bases in the <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/desert/3035-1179\" data-ref-id=\"3035-1179\">desert</a>. His weakness is the Crystal Hunter.</p><p>Eliminating him grants X the Sonic Slicer.</p><h3>Wheel Gator</h3><figure data-ref-id=\"1300-2587856\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/8/87790/2587856-mmx2_boss_wg.png\" data-size=\"small\" data-align=\"right\" data-ratio=\"1.2666666666667\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:126.7%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/8/87790/2587856-mmx2_boss_wg.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2587856\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/8/87790/2587856-mmx2_boss_wg.png\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/8/87790/2587856-mmx2_boss_wg.png\"/></noscript></a></figure><p>Based on the <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/alligators/3015-3102\" data-ref-id=\"3015-3102\">alligator</a>, <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/wheel-gator/3005-1617\" data-ref-id=\"3005-1617\">Wheel Gator</a> (known as Wheel Alligates in the Japanese version) commands a <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/dinosaurs/3015-711\" data-ref-id=\"3015-711\">dinosaur</a>-shaped <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/tank/3055-92\" data-ref-id=\"3055-92\">tank</a> (which, at the time, is wreaking havoc in a city). His weakness is the Strike Chain.</p><p>Eliminating him grants X the Spin Wheel.</p><h3>Wire Sponge</h3><figure data-ref-id=\"1300-2587857\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/8/87790/2587857-mmx2_boss_ws.png\" data-size=\"small\" data-align=\"right\" data-ratio=\"1.2666666666667\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:126.7%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/8/87790/2587857-mmx2_boss_ws.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2587857\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/8/87790/2587857-mmx2_boss_ws.png\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/8/87790/2587857-mmx2_boss_ws.png\"/></noscript></a></figure><p>Based on a <a href=\"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sponge\" rel=\"nofollow\" data-ref-id=\"false\">sponge animal</a>, <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/wire-sponge/3005-1557\" data-ref-id=\"3005-1557\">Wire Sponge</a> (known as Wire Hetimarl in the Japanese version) controls the <a href=\"//www.giantbomb.com/weather/3015-1551\" data-ref-id=\"3015-1551\">Weather</a> Control Center (an structure allowing him to manipulate the weather inside it at any time). His weakness is the Sonic Slicer.</p><p>Eliminating him grants X the Strike Chain.</p><h2>Soundtrack</h2><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/4527/2062809-1.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2062809\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.9\" data-width=\"250\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 250px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:90.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/4527/2062809-1.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2062809\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/4527/2062809-1.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/4527/2062809-1.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Cover Art</figcaption></figure><p>In 2005, Capcom released a 5-disc box set called <em>Capcom Music Generation Rockman X1~6</em>. It contains the original music of Mega Man X through Mega Man X6 as well as some unused tracks. Mega Man X2 tracks span the second half of disc 1 and the tracks are as followed:</p><table><thead><tr><th>Track #</th><th>Title</th><th>Length</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>36.</td><td>CAPCOM This is the second game in the<a data-ref-id=\"3025-1034\" href=\"/mega-man-zx/3025-1034\" slug=\"mega-man-zx\">   ZX series</a> for the DS. It takes place just a few years after the <a data-ref-id=\"3030-11103\" href=\"/mega-man-zx/3030-11103\" slug=\"mega-man-zx\">  first ZX game</a>.<br/><br/>You play as one of the two protagonists, <a data-ref-id=\"3005-10113\" href=\"/grey/3005-10113\" slug=\"grey\">  Grey</a> or <a data-ref-id=\"3005-10114\" href=\"/ashe/3005-10114\" slug=\"ashe\">  Ashe</a> and must defeat the other Mega Man, and   Pseudoroids. The Mega Man have the same models from the last game, Model  <a data-ref-id=\"3005-6886\" href=\"/phantom/3005-6886\" slug=\"phantom\"> P</a>, <a data-ref-id=\"3005-6885\" href=\"/harpuia/3005-6885\" slug=\"harpuia\">  H</a>, <a data-ref-id=\"3005-6888\" href=\"/fefnir/3005-6888\" slug=\"fefnir\">  F</a> and <a data-ref-id=\"3005-6887\" href=\"/leviathan/3005-6887\" slug=\"leviathan\">  L</a>. Also  Vent and <a data-ref-id=\"3005-10109\" href=\"/aile/3005-10109\" slug=\"aile\">  Aile</a> return from the first game with the ZX model. however, unlike the first game, the protagonist can copy the defeated opponent to get the ability as well as the physical appearance, an ability similar to <a data-ref-id=\"3005-7795\" href=\"/axl/3005-7795\" slug=\"axl\">  Axl's</a> from <a data-ref-id=\"3030-4776\" href=\"/mega-man-x7/3030-4776\" slug=\"mega-man-x7\">  Mega Man X7</a> and <a data-ref-id=\"3030-554\" href=\"/mega-man-x8/3030-554\" slug=\"mega-man-x8\">  X8</a>.<figure data-align=\"right\" data-embed-type=\"image\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/3/30446/942264-mmzxa_grey___ashe_normal.png.jpeg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-942264\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"1.0235294117647\" data-width=\"170\" style=\"width: 170px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:102.4%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/3/30446/942264-mmzxa_grey___ashe_normal.png.jpeg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-942264\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/3/30446/942264-mmzxa_grey___ashe_normal.png.jpeg\"/></a><figcaption>the 2 protagonists, Grey(left) and Ashe(right)</figcaption></figure><br/> <br/>The  Pseudoroids are 8 robot mavericks and their data can be copied doubling the amount of data you can copy from the first game. <br/><br/>Depending on the protagonist chosen, each ability copied by Grey/Ashe will be different for the different Mega Man models, giving more variety in gameplay.<br/>Grey plays more like the traditional Mega Man character, while Ashe is much more powerful, but slower, in that she uses more powerful buster shots, but fires only 2 shots at a time.", "deck": "The sequel to the Nintendo DS hit, Megaman ZX. {"duration": "1:00:00", "runner": "mitchflowerpower, Andy, xsvArea51, Iateyourpie, GameJ06, usedpizza, Kronicsauce, grandpoobear", "data": {"site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/super-mario-maker/3030-46580/", "expected_release_quarter": null, "description": "<h2>Overview</h2><p>Super Mario Maker allows the user to create custom Mario levels. The game includes <a href=\"/super-mario-bros/3030-15544\" data-ref-id=\"3030-15544\">Super Mario Bros.</a>, <a href=\"/super-mario-bros-3/3030-10299\" data-ref-id=\"3030-10299\">Super Mario Bros. 3</a>, <a href=\"/super-mario-world/3030-1334\" data-ref-id=\"3030-1334\">Super Mario World</a>, and <a href=\"/new-super-mario-bros-u/3030-35574\" data-ref-id=\"3030-35574\">New Super Mario Bros. U</a> settings, and the user interface is deliberately reminiscent of the GUI from the <a href=\"/super-nintendo-entertainment-system/3045-9\" data-ref-id=\"3045-9\">Super Nintendo</a> classic, <a href=\"/mario-paint/3030-8791\" data-ref-id=\"3030-8791\">Mario Paint</a>, including the random appearance of flies on the screen that the player can swat and the use of a dog and a robot to represent the undo and save functions, respectively.</p><p>Though stages allow for a limited total width, they can be designed to force Mario to move both right and left. There also appears to be new power-ups not included in any previous Mario titles, including <a href=\"/luigi/3005-370\" data-ref-id=\"3005-370\">Luigi</a> Mushrooms, which make Mario much taller and skinnier, and Mystery Mushrooms, which give Mario one of a variety of costumes based on other Nintendo characters.</p><h2>Gameplay</h2><p>The player can freely switch between edit and play mode at any time, allowing the player to play-test stages in progress. Most elements of a stage's layout can be edited, including the placement of pits and their width, pipe placement and height, question mark blocks and other floating blocks, moving platforms, coins, and enemies. Items can be freely arranged in ways that would not be seen in a real Mario game, such as by stacking a <a href=\"/goomba/3015-2891\" data-ref-id=\"3015-2891\">Goomba</a>, a <a href=\"/koopa-troopa/3015-2557\" data-ref-id=\"3015-2557\">Koopa Troopa</a>, and a <a href=\"/piranha-plant/3015-794\" data-ref-id=\"3015-794\">Piranha Plant</a> on top of each other. Players can also include a variety of extra sound effects in their levels, including <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hoQF9zWVsZk\" rel=\"nofollow\">ones they record themselves</a>, though unfortunately, to prevent potentially exposing children to obscene language or noises, these recorded sound effects are not included when levels are shared online. These sound effects can be triggered by things such as enemies performing an attack, objects emerging from pipes, or even simply walking Mario over an invisible trigger.</p><p>Mario Maker supports the sharing of levels online as well a ranking system for the most popular levels. The game also includes a 100 Mario Challenge mode, wherein players must complete 16 randomly selected user levels with only 100 lives at their disposal, and a harder variant known as 10 Mario Challenge, where the player only has 10 lives to clear 8 premade courses.</p><h2>Amiibo Support</h2><figure data-ref-id=\"1300-2775624\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/24/249540/2775624-8185760408-8_bit.jpg\" data-size=\"small\" data-align=\"right\" data-ratio=\"0.56285714285714\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\" style=\"width: 320px\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:56.3%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/24/249540/2775624-8185760408-8_bit.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2775624\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/24/249540/2775624-8185760408-8_bit.jpg\"/></a><figcaption>The \"30th Anniversary 8-bit Mario\" amiibo, in both Classic and Modern varieties</figcaption></figure><p>A special \"30th Anniversary 8-bit Mario\" amiibo was released alongside the game in Classic colors faithful to the original Super Mario Bros. sprite and Modern colors which are more in line with Mario's current appearance. The amiibo itself is much larger than the standard figures and, appropriately, when used with the game will allow the player to add a Mega Mushroom to their course, causing Mario (or an enemy it's been applied to) to grow much bigger than normal.</p><p>Super Mario Maker supports over 100 other amiibo figures/cards, using them to unlock various costumes based on the appropriate character for use in the game which can be donned by using a Mystery Mushroom power up. However, these costumes can only be used in the original Super Mario Bros. tileset. These costumes (as well as many others not tied to amiibo) can also be unlocked on their own without the use of the amiibo figures by completing various challenges such as the 100 Mario Challenge.</p><h2>Development</h2><p>Super Mario Maker was announced during Nintendo's digital event at <a href=\"/e3-2014/3015-7932\" data-ref-id=\"3015-7932\">E3 2014</a> on June 10, 2014 as simply Mario Maker. The name change to Super Mario Maker was announced at the Nintendo World Championships on June 14th, 2015. It was released on September 11th, 2015 for the <a href=\"/wii-u/3045-139\" data-ref-id=\"3045-139\">Nintendo Wii U</a> and coincides with the 30th Anniversary of the release of <a href=\"/super-mario-bros/3030-15544\" data-ref-id=\"3030-15544\">Super Mario Bros.</a> for the <a href=\"/nintendo-entertainment-system/3045-21\" data-ref-id=\"3045-21\">Nintendo Entertainment System</a>.</p><h2>Mystery Mushroom Costumes</h2><ol><li><a href=\"/mario/3005-177\" data-ref-id=\"3005-177\">Mario</a> (modern recolor)</li><li><a href=\"/princess-peach/3005-709\" data-ref-id=\"3005-709\">Peach</a></li><li><a href=\"/luigi/3005-370\" data-ref-id=\"3005-370\">Luigi</a></li><li><a href=\"/bowser/3005-337\" data-ref-id=\"3005-337\">Bowser</a></li><li><a href=\"/goomba/3015-2891\" data-ref-id=\"3015-2891\">Goomba</a></li><li><a href=\"/mario-block/3055-702\" data-ref-id=\"3055-702\">?
