{"duration": "2:00:00", "runner": "MrLlamaSC", "data": {"site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/diablo-ii-lord-of-destruction/3030-15589/", "expected_release_quarter": null, "description": "<h2>Overview</h2><p>Diablo II: Lord of Destruction is an expansion set for the base game, Diablo II. The story picks up where <a href=\"/diablo-ii/3030-1119\" data-ref-id=\"3030-1119\">Diablo II</a> left off - <a href=\"/diablo/3005-849\" data-ref-id=\"3005-849\">Diablo</a> has been slain, but now his brother <a href=\"/baal/3005-1349\" data-ref-id=\"3005-1349\">Baal</a> has invaded the ancient barbarian highlands of Mount Arreat and corrupted the World Stone. The <a href=\"/expansion/3015-344\" data-ref-id=\"3015-344\">expansion</a> adds a slew of new features including 2 new <a href=\"/classes/3015-405\" data-ref-id=\"3015-405\">classes</a>, dynamic <a href=\"/mercenary/3015-2073\" data-ref-id=\"3015-2073\">mercenaries</a>, an entirely new act, class specific items, new socketables, <a href=\"/enchantment/3015-5736\" data-ref-id=\"3015-5736\">charms</a>, crafted items, new <a href=\"/horadric-cube/3055-1887\" data-ref-id=\"3055-1887\">Horadric cube</a> recipes, many new and improved unique items and set items, two new <a href=\"/in-engine-cinematic/3015-964\" data-ref-id=\"3015-964\">cinematics</a>, and new titles for completing the game on various difficulties.</p><h2>Character Classes</h2><p>The expansion introduces two new classes, adding even more depth and <a href=\"/replayability/3015-2559\" data-ref-id=\"3015-2559\">replayability</a> to the game. The classes are the <a href=\"/assassin/3005-14924\" data-ref-id=\"3005-14924\">Assassin</a> and the <a href=\"\">Druid</a>. Each plays differently than the other classes, with little to no overlap amongst other classes.</p><h3><a href=\"/druid/3005-14923\" data-ref-id=\"3005-14923\"><b>Druid</b></a></h3><figure data-align=\"left\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/178/266924-druid.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-266924\" data-size=\"small\" style=\"width: 300px\" data-ratio=\"1.4366666666667\" data-width=\"300\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:143.7%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/178/266924-druid.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-266924\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/178/266924-druid.jpg\"/></a><figcaption>Concept art for the Druid</figcaption></figure><p>A <a href=\"/hybrid-classes/3015-1190\" data-ref-id=\"3015-1190\">hybrid class</a>, the Druid is capable as a supportive caster or supportive tank. The Druid has a line of offensive elemental <a href=\"/spell/3055-807\" data-ref-id=\"3055-807\">spells</a>, from creating fiery <a href=\"/boulder/3055-1468\" data-ref-id=\"3055-1468\">boulders</a> or <a href=\"/twister/3015-3669\" data-ref-id=\"3015-3669\">cyclones</a> to rip through hordes of <a href=\"/demon/3015-557\" data-ref-id=\"3015-557\">demons</a>, to even commanding <a href=\"/volcano/3055-1817\" data-ref-id=\"3055-1817\">volcanoes</a> to erupt and blast enemies within range. He can summon various animals and nature spirits that help fight enemies or give the druid and his allies <a href=\"/buff/3015-2615\" data-ref-id=\"3015-2615\">buffs</a> such as increased life or attack speed. He can also transform into either a <a href=\"/bears/3015-1848\" data-ref-id=\"3015-1848\">bear</a> (werebear) or <a href=\"/wolf/3015-2265\" data-ref-id=\"3015-2265\">wolf</a> ( <a href=\"/werewolves/3015-543\" data-ref-id=\"3015-543\">werewolf</a>) in order to get into the fray up close and personal, gaining attack skills such as rabies.</p><p>More detailed information about the Druid can be found at the Druid page <a href=\"/druid/3005-14923\" data-ref-id=\"3005-14923\">here</a>.</p><h3><a href=\"/assassin/3005-14924\" data-ref-id=\"3005-14924\"><b>Assassin</b></a></h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/178/266927-assassin.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-266927\" data-size=\"small\" style=\"width: 300px\" data-ratio=\"1.63\" data-width=\"300\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:163.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/178/266927-assassin.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-266927\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/178/266927-assassin.jpg\"/></a><figcaption>Concept art for the Assassin</figcaption></figure><p>The Assassin uses various Wrist Blades to deal out concentrated melee damage. The <a href=\"/martial-arts/3015-515\" data-ref-id=\"3015-515\">Martial Arts</a> <a href=\"/skill-tree/3015-382\" data-ref-id=\"3015-382\">skill tree</a> allows for the development of burst damage in the form of charges dealing physical/elemental damage. She also has Shadow Disciplines, where she can increase her damage with Wrist Blade attacks, move faster, and create a <a href=\"/clone/3015-284\" data-ref-id=\"3015-284\">duplicate</a> to fight autonomously by her side. Lastly, she can set various <a href=\"/traps/3015-609\" data-ref-id=\"3015-609\">traps</a> in the environment to crowd control and destroy the many enemies of the game.</p><p>More detailed information about the Assassin can be found at the Assassin page <a href=\"/assassin/3005-14924\" data-ref-id=\"3005-14924\">here</a>.</p><h2>Items</h2><p>Many new items were added in the Lord of Destruction expansion. Beyond just expanding the existing categories of items (which was expanded quite extensively), many new item types were added.</p><h3>Class Specific Items</h3><p>Each class in the expansion was given a class-specific item type that only they could use. These could be either armor or weapons depending on the class.</p><ul><li><a href=\"/barbarian/3005-3717\" data-ref-id=\"3005-3717\">Barbarians</a> get <a href=\"/helmet/3055-737\" data-ref-id=\"3055-737\">Helms</a>.</li><li><a href=\"/amazon/3015-3665\" data-ref-id=\"3015-3665\">Amazons</a> get <a href=\"/spear/3055-573\" data-ref-id=\"3055-573\">Spears</a> and <a href=\"/bow/3055-73\" data-ref-id=\"3055-73\">Bows</a>.</li><li><a href=\"/sorceress/3005-3718\" data-ref-id=\"3005-3718\">Sorceresses</a> get magical <a href=\"/orbs/3015-566\" data-ref-id=\"3015-566\">Orbs</a>.</li><li><a href=\"/paladin/3005-4264\" data-ref-id=\"3005-4264\">Paladins</a> get <a href=\"/shield/3055-87\" data-ref-id=\"3055-87\">Shields</a>.</li><li><a href=\"/necromancer/3005-17296\" data-ref-id=\"3005-17296\">Necromancers</a> get <a href=\"/severed-head/3055-3389\" data-ref-id=\"3055-3389\">demon heads</a> (Shields).</li><li>Druids get <a href=\"/pelt/3055-3946\" data-ref-id=\"3055-3946\">Pelts</a> (Helms).</li><li>Assassins get Wrist Blades.</li></ul><h2>Runes</h2><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/8430/362241-runes.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-362241\" data-size=\"small\" style=\"width: 302px\" data-ratio=\"0.4205298013245\" data-width=\"302\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:42.1%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/8430/362241-runes.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-362241\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/8430/362241-runes.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/8430/362241-runes.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>The runes.</figcaption></figure><p>Runes are a new kind of socketable item. They range from <a href=\"/item-rarity/3015-4702\" data-ref-id=\"3015-4702\">common to rare</a>. Each <a href=\"/runes/3055-1061\" data-ref-id=\"3055-1061\">rune</a> has a unique effect it can add to a piece of <a href=\"/inventory/3015-513\" data-ref-id=\"3015-513\">gear</a>. They are gray with a design on them. What makes runes unique compared to <a href=\"/gem/3055-2744\" data-ref-id=\"3055-2744\">gems</a>, outside of the different modifiers they add to items, is that if combined properly in specific items in a specific order they can create:</p><h3>Runewords</h3><p>Runewords come about from specific use of Runes, with numerous examples for weapons, shields, and body armor. Runes must be inserted in a specific order to receive the bonuses for the runeword. For instance, you can form the runeword <b>Duress</b> by combining the runes \"Shael\", \"Um\" and \"Thul\" into a 3 socket piece of body armor. Doing so will give the following enhancements:</p><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/8430/362251-runewordduress.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-362251\" data-size=\"small\" style=\"width: 235px\" data-ratio=\"1.6851063829787\" data-width=\"235\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:168.5%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/8430/362251-runewordduress.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-362251\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/8430/362251-runewordduress.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/8430/362251-runewordduress.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>The Runeword 'Duress' in action</figcaption></figure><ul><li>40% Faster Hit Recovery</li><li>10-20% Enhanced Damage (varies)</li><li>Adds 37-133 Cold Damage 2 sec. Duration (Normal)</li><li>15% Chance of Crushing Blow</li><li>33% Chance of Open Wounds</li><li>150-200% Enhanced Defense (varies)</li><li>-20% Slower Stamina Drain</li><li>Cold Resist 45%</li><li>Lightning Resist 15%</li><li>Fire Resist 15%</li><li>Poison Resist 15%</li></ul><p>The benefit of the Runeword system lies in adding a form of player-directed item progression to the game. While the player is still at the whim of <a href=\"/random-number-generation/3015-816\" data-ref-id=\"3015-816\">RNG</a> with regards to whether they find a rune and which runes they will find, they can at least rely on the Runeword system to generate a specific set of stats on an item.</p><h2>Charms</h2><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/8430/362354-charms.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-362354\" data-size=\"small\" style=\"width: 235px\" data-ratio=\"0.65106382978723\" data-width=\"235\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:65.1%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/8430/362354-charms.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-362354\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/8430/362354-charms.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/8430/362354-charms.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Charms come in various shapes and sizes</figcaption></figure><p>Charms are items that give you a passive statistical bonus simply by sitting in your inventory. They come in 3 sizes, Grand (1x3), Large (1x2) and Small (1x1) they also come in 2 varieties, magical and unique. The charms can do many things like increase run/walk speed, add to base stats and <a href=\"/health/3015-130\" data-ref-id=\"3015-130\">health</a> and <a href=\"/mana/3015-257\" data-ref-id=\"3015-257\">mana</a>, add elemental damage, increase magic find, and much more. Charms present an interesting consideration to the player who must decide if their passive boost is worth the sacrifice in space in the <a href=\"/inventory-grid/3015-6164\" data-ref-id=\"3015-6164\">inventory grid</a>.</p><h3>Unique Charms</h3><p>Within the patches, ranging from 1.10 and up to 1.11, Blizzard released unique charms to be included in the game. These charms could only be triggered by certain events or drop randomly. Today these charms are very common cause of the numerous of bots and hacks people use. You can only have one of each unique charms in your inventory, meaning that you cannot stack these on one character.</p><h4>Annihilus</h4><figure data-align=\"right\" data-size=\"medium\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/13/130632/2719125-10anni.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2719125\" style=\"width: 265px\" data-ratio=\"0.59245283018868\" data-width=\"265\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:59.2%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/13/130632/2719125-10anni.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2719125\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_medium/13/130632/2719125-10anni.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_medium/13/130632/2719125-10anni.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>The Annihilus Small Charm</figcaption></figure><p>This was one of the first unique charm introduced back in the patch and ladder season 1.10 on October 28, 2003. This charm could only be obtained by a obtaining a random event, triggered when a ring called Stone Of Jordan was sold enough times back to <a href=\"/non-player-character/3015-967\" data-ref-id=\"3015-967\">N.P.C.'s</a> on a server. If your game was affected by this, a text message would pop out announcing how many of these <a href=\"/ring/3055-262\" data-ref-id=\"3055-262\">rings</a> were sold to a <a href=\"/merchants/3015-806\" data-ref-id=\"3015-806\">merchant</a>. If a player was lucky enough to achieve this, the game would simultaneously trigger the spawning of a Diablo \"clone\". This clone is extremely powerful, but it will drop one of the best charms in the game. Diablo Clone can spawn almost everywhere where a <a href=\"/mini-boss/3015-420\" data-ref-id=\"3015-420\">mini boss</a> is (e.g Rakanishu in Stony Field). Keeping Annihilus in the inventory grants a permanent +1 to all skills, attributes, and resistances which varies from 10 to 20. It also grants \"extra experience gained\" which varies from 5-10%.</p><p> </p><h4>Hellfire Torch</h4><p> </p><figure data-align=\"right\" data-size=\"medium\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/13/130632/2719126-images.duckduckgo.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2719126\" style=\"width: 433px\" data-ratio=\"0.65127020785219\" data-width=\"433\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:65.1%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/13/130632/2719126-images.duckduckgo.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2719126\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_medium/13/130632/2719126-images.duckduckgo.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_medium/13/130632/2719126-images.duckduckgo.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>The Hellfire Torch Large Charm</figcaption></figure><figure data-align=\"right\" data-size=\"medium\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/13/130632/2719127-screenshot089.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2719127\" style=\"width: 480px\" data-ratio=\"0.75\" data-width=\"480\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:75.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/13/130632/2719127-screenshot089.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2719127\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_medium/13/130632/2719127-screenshot089.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_medium/13/130632/2719127-screenshot089.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Uber Diablo</figcaption></figure><p>This charm was introduced in the patch 1.11 and ladder season 3 in August the 8th, 2005 and was known in the community as the father to the little Annihilus. The charm also introduced people to the \"Pandemonium Event\". This event is difficult to trigger owing to the requirement of specific items needed for its completion. First off you will need three <a href=\"/key/3055-105\" data-ref-id=\"3055-105\">keys</a> dropped from various <a href=\"/mini-boss/3015-420\" data-ref-id=\"3015-420\">mini bosses</a> throughout the game. Once you have the three different keys you can transmute these in your horadric cube to open a portal in Act 5's town. This will trigger a hard event with a boss. This boss will drop one of the three organs you will need (<a href=\"/diablo/3005-849\" data-ref-id=\"3005-849\">Diablo's</a> Horn, <a href=\"/baal/3005-1349\" data-ref-id=\"3005-1349\">Baal's</a> Eye and <a href=\"/mephisto/3005-1731\" data-ref-id=\"3005-1731\">Mephisto's</a> Brain) to trigger access to a zone called \"Uber Tristram\". Uber Tristram was intended only for the strongest players, since it pitted players against all the hardest bosses in the game at once, now in \"Uber\" form: Uber Diablo, Uber Baal and Uber Mephisto. Not only that but you will also have spawning minions around you. If you can take all of the bosses you will get this unique charm. The Hellfire Torch have a permanent 3-to all (random character class skill) and also <a href=\"/attributes/3015-1681\" data-ref-id=\"3015-1681\">attributes</a> and resistance which varies from 10 to 20. The Torch also got 8 to light radius, 10 charges on level 30 Hyrda and a 25% chance to cast level 10 Firestorm on striking (Nerfed to a 5% chance to cast with the patch 1.13). The concept of hunting for keys to open a portal to more difficult versions of the game's bosses was carried over into <a href=\"/diablo-iii/3030-20803\" data-ref-id=\"3030-20803\">Diablo III</a>, where players can hunt keywardens in order to use the Infernal Machine, a system which generates fights with Uber versions of King Leoric, Maghda, Siegebreaker, Zoltan Kulle, Rakanoth, Ghom, Diablo and more in the hopes of finding crafting materials required for extremely powerful legendary jewellery.</p><h4>Gheed's Fortune</h4><figure data-align=\"right\" data-size=\"medium\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/13/130632/2719128-g-z02.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2719128\" style=\"width: 340px\" data-ratio=\"0.57352941176471\" data-width=\"340\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:57.4%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/13/130632/2719128-g-z02.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2719128\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_medium/13/130632/2719128-g-z02.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_medium/13/130632/2719128-g-z02.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Gheed's Fortune Grand Charm</figcaption></figure><p>Also introduced in patch 1.10 and first ladder season. This unique charm could drop randomly from any enemy ranging from <a href=\"/minions/3015-1747\" data-ref-id=\"3015-1747\">minions</a> to <a href=\"/bosses/3015-229\" data-ref-id=\"3015-229\">bosses</a>. If the enemies killed have a monster level (mlvl) of minimum 62, Gheed's Fortune has a chance to drop. In other words, any monster in Hell difficulty and the end-game enemies in Nightmare difficulty. Gheed's Fortune has extra gold find which varies from 80-160%, reduced all vendor prices varies from 10-15% and better chance of getting magic items (Mf) varies from 20-40%.</p><h3><a href=\"/jewel/3055-1737\" data-ref-id=\"3055-1737\"><b>Jewels</b></a></h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-size=\"medium\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/13/130632/2719130-1028doe102.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2719130\" style=\"width: 291px\" data-ratio=\"0.54982817869416\" data-width=\"291\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:55.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/13/130632/2719130-1028doe102.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2719130\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_medium/13/130632/2719130-1028doe102.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_medium/13/130632/2719130-1028doe102.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>An example of the random modifiers a Jewel can possess</figcaption></figure><p>Jewels are another new socketable and come in three forms: magical, rare, and unique. Jewels differ from other socketables because, unlike gems and runes which have set bonuses depending on where they are socketed (A topaz will always add lightning damage if socketed inside a weapon, for example), the modifiers on jewels are random. Magical jewels can have up to 2 modifiers and rare ones can have up to 4. Their modifiers are random.</p><h3>Crafted Items</h3><p>Crafted items are created by combining the right recipes in the <a href=\"/horadric-cube/3055-1887\" data-ref-id=\"3055-1887\">Horadric Cube</a> in order to create a predefined, random item. Crafted items have 3-4 predetermined stats with a few random ones mixed in. Everything from rings and armor to weapons, shields and amulets can be crafted and to great effect. There are numerous recipes.</p><h2>Miscellaneous</h2><p>Along with all of the previously mentioned updates, there were many miscellaneous tweaks and updates introduced by the Lord of Destruction expansion.</p><h3>Mercenaries</h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/8430/362702-mercstatwindow.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-362702\" data-size=\"small\" style=\"width: 320px\" data-ratio=\"1.2330827067669\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:123.3%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/8430/362702-mercstatwindow.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-362702\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/8430/362702-mercstatwindow.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/8430/362702-mercstatwindow.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Mercenary stat / inventory screen.</figcaption></figure><p>No longer satisfied with being background noise, the mercenary was upgraded and updated with Diablo II's expansion. Mercenaries would now have their own, dynamically changing stats. They could <a href=\"/leveling-up/3015-475\" data-ref-id=\"3015-475\">level-up</a> and increase in power. They would do this automatically by fighting by your side. Experience is shared between you and your mercenary - they gain more experience for their own kills. Mercenaries are persistent (unless killed), meaning they will come with you from game to game regardless of whether you leave the game. If slain, they can be resurrected in any one of the five towns. You can also equip items to the mercenary. Each mercenary can equip a helm, armor and a weapon; which weapons they can wield are limited by which mercenary particular you have working by your side. There are no mercenaries for hire Act IV.</p><p>Act I: Rogue Scout</p><ul><li>Ranged Mercenary</li></ul><ul><li>Skills: Flaming Arrow / Inner Sight or Frozen Arrow / Inner Sight</li></ul><ul><li>Weapon: Bows (no crossbows or Amazon specific items)</li></ul><p>Act II: Mercenary</p><ul><li>Melee Mercenary</li></ul><ul><li>Skills: All Act II Mercenaries have Jab plus an aura based on whether they are combat/defense/offense and whether you hired them in normal, nightmare or hell difficulty</li></ul><ul><li>Weapon: Spears, Polearms, Javelins</li></ul><p>Act III: Ironwolves</p><ul><li>Melee/Caster Mercenary</li></ul><ul><li>Skills: Charged Bolt / Lightning or Inferno / Fireball or Glacial Spike / Ice Blast / Frozen Armor.</li></ul><ul><li>Weapon: Swords and Shields, only mercenary that can equip shields.</li></ul><p>Act V: Barbarian</p><ul><li>Melee Mercenary</li></ul><ul><li>Skills: Bash and Stun</li></ul><ul><li>Weapon: Swords, can also equip Barbarian class specific helms.</li></ul><h2>Soundtrack</h2><figure data-align=\"left\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/6/62890/1548516-diablo_lod_front_ost.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1548516\" data-size=\"small\" style=\"width: 320px\" data-ratio=\"1.0041152263374\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:100.4%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/6/62890/1548516-diablo_lod_front_ost.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1548516\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/6/62890/1548516-diablo_lod_front_ost.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/6/62890/1548516-diablo_lod_front_ost.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Front Cover</figcaption></figure><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/6/62890/1548537-diablo_lod_back_ost.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1548537\" data-size=\"small\" style=\"width: 320px\" data-ratio=\"1.0061728395062\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:100.6%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/6/62890/1548537-diablo_lod_back_ost.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-1548537\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/6/62890/1548537-diablo_lod_back_ost.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/6/62890/1548537-diablo_lod_back_ost.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Back Cover</figcaption></figure><p>The franchise's recurring composer <a href=\"/matt-uelmen/3040-3487\" data-ref-id=\"3040-3487\">Matt Uelmen</a> wrote a few songs specifically for the Lord of Destruction expansion-set.</p><table><tbody><tr><th>Track No.</th><th>Song Title</th><th>Running Time</th></tr><tr><td>01</td><td><b>Fortress</b></td><td>04.46</td></tr><tr><td>02</td><td><b>Halls</b></td><td>03.32</td></tr><tr><td>03</td><td><b>The Ancients</b></td><td>04.06</td></tr><tr><td>04</td><td><b>Siege</b></td><td>05.52</td></tr><tr><td>05</td><td><b>Ice</b></td><td>04.40</td></tr></tbody></table><h2>Today</h2><p>Currently, Diablo II is slated for a major content patch, patch 1.13. The patch was delayed due to an exploit experienced in Blizzard's sister title, <a href=\"/warcraft-iii-reign-of-chaos/3030-12567\" data-ref-id=\"3030-12567\">WarCraft 3</a> in which custom maps can be loaded with malware and distributed via a custom map. The Diablo \"legacy\" team had to swap out from working on 1.13 and help fix this major exploit. This has caused an uproar in the Diablo II community because a ladder reset was announced for before the 1.13 patch was to be released. Blizzard made the announcement because the patch was \"imminent\" but they were blind-sided by the WarCraft 3 issue.</p><p>The new 1.13 patch was to hit the Public Testing Realm in July 2009 according to a post made by Bashiok, a community manager for Blizzard. The patch was to include an increase in stash size and other changes as suggested by players on the official Diablo 2 forums.</p><p>This patch is now live on public testing realms awaiting further testing. Anyone can access this test server to try out the additions and changes. The increased stash size had to be removed as it threatened to undo the very game itself if they added an increased stash size. The game has however gained the ability to respec characters as well as some new bonus content and a few tweaks and balances.</p><p>The new 1.13 patch has now gone live. As of March 23rd, 2010 the Ladder has now been reset, sending all Ladder characters from before the patch to non-Ladder status.</p><h2>Patch 1.13</h2><p>Here are the changes introduced by the new patch:</p><figure data-align=\"right\" data-size=\"small\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/13/130632/2719131-token_of_absolution_%28diablo_ii%29.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2719131\" style=\"width: 316px\" data-ratio=\"0.73417721518987\" data-width=\"316\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:73.4%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/13/130632/2719131-token_of_absolution_%28diablo_ii%29.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2719131\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/13/130632/2719131-token_of_absolution_%28diablo_ii%29.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/13/130632/2719131-token_of_absolution_%28diablo_ii%29.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>The Token of Absolution allows players to respec</figcaption></figure><p><strong>A new mystery has been revealed</strong> within Diablo's bosses you will now have a chance to find essence which you can transmute in your cube to make a token which again you can use to respec your characters attributes and skills. Note that these items only will drop from the last act bosses and only in hell difficulty.</p><p><strong>Major bugs</strong></p><ul><li>-Fixed an item dupe bug (Dupe is an abbreviation for duplicate)</li><li>-Video improvements for Intel Mac machines with OS 10.5 or greater.</li><li><strong>-</strong>Fixed an issue where some players could kill other players while in town</li><li><strong>-</strong>Fixed an issue where some players could disconnect other players when they had too many active states.</li><li>-Fixed two issues where players could stack auras in an unintended way.</li></ul><h3>Minor bugs</h3><ul><li>-Uber Mephisto now checks for both Uber Baal and Uber Diablo to be killed before spawning summoned minions (Before he would only check for Uber Baal).</li><li>-The game will no longer stop and then restart the game music after the window loses and then regains focus.</li><li>-Fixed an issue where the game window would minimize when running in windowed mode when it lost focus.</li><li>-Fixed an issue where the game window wouldn't center properly when it was created.</li><li>-Fangskin should now properly drop loot in Hell difficulty.</li><li>-Fixed an issue where auras were not re-applied to your mercenary after it was resurrected.</li><li>-Fixed an issue where if you had two items which provided auras to a mercenary and you unequipped one, the aura from the remaining item never became active.</li><li>-Fixed an issue where the Paladin class runeword 'Principle' wasn't having all of its stats applied properly.</li><li>-Fixed an issue where the Paladin's Charge ability would become locked out if Holy Shield faded while charging.</li><li>-Fixed an issue where the Barbarian's Leap ability could become locked out if they were hit when they started to leap.</li></ul><h3>Specific changes/improvements</h3><ul><li>-Respecialization is now possible. Completing the 'Den of Evil' quest will now additionally reward 1 free respec which can be saved through all difficulties, meaning you can now have up to 3 free respec points. Talk to Akara in act 1 Rogue Encampment to claim your reward.</li><li>-Increased the drop rate of high Runes.</li><li>-Support for blit scaling in windowed mode. The game can now be maximized to the largest 4:3 resolution supported (hooray widescreen users).</li><li>-Some rare drop items now have an orange color. i.e. Runes and items required for Uber Tristam.</li><li>-Modified the gold bank limit to be a flat cap not bound by level.</li><li>-Removed the requirements to create a hardcore character.</li><li>-Greatly reduced the explosion damage dealt by Fire Enchanted monsters.</li><li>-Uber Mephisto and Uber Baal's summoned minions no longer give experience.</li><li>-Removed Oblivion Knight's Iron Maiden curse.</li><li>-Hellfire Torch Firestorm proc rate has been reduced to 5%.</li><li>-Users can now toggle the display of text over the Health and Mana globes by clicking on the bottom area of each orb.</li><li>-When creating a single player game, each difficulty button is now bound to a unique key: Normal 'R', Nightmare 'N', and Hell 'H'.</li><li>-The 'Enter Chat' Button in the battle.net waiting room is now bound to the 'Enter' key.</li><li>-Added the windows system buttons to the game window (MIN, MAX, CLOSE).</li><li>-Added new command line parameter '-nofixaspect' which allows users to not fix the aspect ratio to 4:3 when maximizing in windowed mode. This lets the game 'stretch' to fill your monitor.</li><li>-Added support for '-sndbkg' command line switch. This enables sound in background.</li><li>-Added the following aliases for pre-existing command line options, '-nosound', '-window', and '-windowed'.</li></ul><h3>Revised Skill balance for player character classes</h3><p><strong>Amazon</strong></p><ul><li>-Immolation Arrow - Increased radius of Explosion effect by 33% and Immolation effect by 50%.</li><li>-Immolation Arrow - Explosion effect damage increased by 20%.</li><li>-Immolation Arrow - Increased base duration by 33%.</li></ul><p><strong>Assassin</strong></p><ul><li>-Dragon claw - Synergy receives 4% additional damage per point of Claw Mastery.</li><li>-Dragon Talon - The bonus to Attack Rating per point has been increased to 35.</li><li>-Shadow Master - Increased resistance range per point from 5-80 to 5-90.</li><li>-Combo points awarded by combo moves now last 15 seconds, up from 9.</li></ul><p><strong>Barbarian</strong></p><ul><li>-Whirlwind - Reduced initial mana cost by 50%.</li><li>-Masteries - Changed critical strike chance from 0-25 to 0-35.</li></ul><p><strong>Paladin</strong></p><ul><li>-Blessed Hammer - No longer ignores resistances of undead and Demons.</li></ul><p><strong>Druid</strong></p><ul><li>-Werebear - Damage bonus increased by 15% across all ranks.</li><li>-Werebear - Increased health by 25% and armor by 1% per point.</li><li>-Shockwave - Synergy from Maul adds 5% damage per point.</li></ul><p><strong>Necromancer</strong></p><ul><li>-Blood Golem - player no longer loses life when the golem takes damage.</li><li>-Corpse Explosion - Increased base damage dealt from 60% - 100% to 70% - 120% of corpses health.</li><li>-Poison Nova- Increased base damage by 15%.</li></ul><p><strong>Sorceress</strong></p><ul><li>-Firewall- Synergy receives 1% damage per point of Inferno and 4% per point of Warmth.</li><li>-Blaze - Synergy receives 1% damage per point of Firewall and 4% per point of Warmth.</li><li>-Hydra - Increased base damage by 15% per rank.</li><li>-Hydra - Increased base speed of Hydra projectile.</li><li>-Hydra - Reduced cooldown by 25%.</li></ul>", "deck": "Diablo II:  Lord of Destruction features a new act and 2 new character classes, the Assassin and the Druid, as well as new items.", "aliases": "D2:LoD, LoD, Diablo 2: Lord of "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/object/3055-282/", "site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/table/3055-282/", "id": 282, "name": "Table"}, {"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/object/3055-1118/", "site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/pants/3055-1118/", "id": 1118, "name": "Pants"}, {"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/object/3055-6273/", "site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/soft-drink/3055-6273/", "id": 6273, "name": "Soft Drink"}], "expected_release_year": null, "publishers": [{"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/publisher/3010-90/", "site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/nintendo/3010-90/", "id": 90, "name": "Nintendo"}], "date_last_updated": "2015-11-12 16:51:02", "expected_release_quarter": null, "first_appearance_people": [{"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/person/3040-614/", "site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/shigeru-miyamoto/3040-614/", "id": 614, "name": "Shigeru Miyamoto"}, {"api_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/api/person/3040-46955/", "site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/satoru-iwata/3040-46955/", "id": 46955, "name": "Satoru Iwata"}], "description": "<h2>Overview</h2><p>Pok\u00e9mon Red and Blue are the first two releases in Nintendo's long-running Pok\u00e9mon franchise. Developed by Game Freak, Red and Blue were the studio's first major successes. The company would eventually go on to create several direct sequels to the games for Nintendo's portable consoles that followed the Game Boy.</p><h2>Plot</h2><p>The basic premise of Pok\u00e9mon Red and Blue involves a nameable protagonist who sets off on a journey to thoroughly train, catch, trade, and ultimately master as many Pok\u00e9mon as he can. After acquiring one of three Pok\u00e9mon from Professor Oak; Bulbasaur, Squirtle, or Charmander, and then fighting a subsequent training battle with his rival, the main character sets off to explore the world to fulfill his goals. In order to achieve ultimate success, he must use his Pok\u00e9mon team to fight and defeat eight Gym Leaders, specialists who each deal in a specific type of Pok\u00e9mon, as well as the Elite Four and Gary Oak. Only after all of that has been achieved does the story technically end.</p><h2>Gameplay</h2><figure style=\"width: 256px\" data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/3957/203263-pokemon_blue_version_gbc_screenshot1.gif\" data-ref-id=\"1300-203263\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.875\" data-width=\"256\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:87.5%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/3957/203263-pokemon_blue_version_gbc_screenshot1.gif\" data-ref-id=\"1300-203263\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/3957/203263-pokemon_blue_version_gbc_screenshot1.gif\"/></a><figcaption>Blue's title screen.</figcaption></figure><p>Most Pok\u00e9mon are acquired by \"catching\" them while they are still out and about in the wild. They can be found by the player simply roaming about in the Pok\u00e9mons' native habitats, which usually happens by walking around in grass, swimming around in a body of water, or in other similar instances. Once a battle has been initiated, it is up to the player to weaken the wild Pok\u00e9mon's Hit Points (HP) enough so that they can throw a Pok\u00e9ball at them. Pok\u00e9balls are the containers which hold each trainer's Pok\u00e9mon and as long as the wild Pok\u00e9mon cannot break free from one, it can be freely used by the trainer who owns it. If a trainer's team is full at the time of the capture, the newly acquired Pok\u00e9mon is then sent to a PC for storage and can be retrieved at a later point in time. Captured Pok\u00e9mon can also be given nicknames, although doing so is optional. In the anime this is shown through Ritchie, who also puts stickers on his Pok\u00e9balls to differentiate them.</p><figure style=\"width: 160px\" data-align=\"left\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/6372/225430-b6.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-225430\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.9\" data-width=\"160\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:90.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/6372/225430-b6.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-225430\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/6372/225430-b6.jpg\"/></a><figcaption>Pok\u00e9mon is a traditional role-playing game in many facets.</figcaption></figure><p>Pok\u00e9mon Red and Blue's battle system consists of gameplay mechanics which are common with many turn-based Japanese RPGs. Up to six Pok\u00e9mon can be a part of a trainer's roster at any time, which is where the game's defining characteristics come into play.</p><p>Since each Pok\u00e9mon can have a different type (Grass-type, Water-type, Fire-type, Normal-type, Flying-type, Electric-type, Ground-type, Rock-type, Ice-type, Psychic-type, Bug-type, Fighting-type, Poison-type, Ghost-type) a system of strengths and weakness is employed, in addition to the standard calculations based on their individual statistics. Every attack is also assigned a type, which is also taken into consideration during battle.</p><p>Although most Pok\u00e9mon have limitations regarding which attacks they can learn, they are allowed to learn some which aren't the same as their type. No attack can be used an infinite number of times, though, as the amount of usage is dependent upon the amount of Power Points (PP) each attack has. These Power Points can be restored either through the use of specific items or by visiting a Pok\u00e9mon Center, which is also used to fully heal a trainer's current roster of Pok\u00e9mon.</p><figure style=\"width: 320px\" data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/9560/238964-pokemon_yellow_gameplay.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-238964\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.89971346704871\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:90.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/9560/238964-pokemon_yellow_gameplay.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-238964\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/9560/238964-pokemon_yellow_gameplay.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/9560/238964-pokemon_yellow_gameplay.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Typical battle scene</figcaption></figure><p>As the Pok\u00e9mon enter into battles and continue to win them, they gain experience points. Once they accumulate a specified amount, they level up, which serves two purposes. Leveling up the Pok\u00e9mon in Red and Blue allows most Pok\u00e9mon to learn new attacks which can be added to their arsenal, in addition to raising their individual statistics.</p><p>However, because each Pok\u00e9mon is limited to four different attacks, considerations must be made as they reach progressively higher levels. Leveling up also allows most Pok\u00e9mon to evolve, enabling them to become a new species. The point at which each Pok\u00e9mon may evolve is different depending on the species, although the trainer is allowed to prevent a Pok\u00e9mon from doing so if they desire. One such advantage which comes from canceling an evolution is that more advanced and powerful attacks can be learned earlier if the Pok\u00e9mon doesn't evolve, assuming the attack can still be learned in an evolved form.</p><figure style=\"width: 160px\" data-align=\"left\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/608/367990-pokemon_blue_65.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-367990\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"0.9\" data-width=\"160\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:90.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/608/367990-pokemon_blue_65.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-367990\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/608/367990-pokemon_blue_65.png\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/608/367990-pokemon_blue_65.png\"/></noscript></a></figure><p>With Pok\u00e9mon, though, it is not always possible to evolve them via leveling up. In those instances, special stones can be given to the Pok\u00e9mon to force them to evolve. The most famous Pok\u00e9mon in the Red and Blue versions which are able to do this include <a href=\"/pikachu/3005-145\" data-ref-id=\"3005-145\">Pikachu</a>, Jigglypuff, and <a href=\"/eevee/3015-2004\" data-ref-id=\"3015-2004\">Eevee</a>, the latter of which has multiple evolutions depending on the stone applied. Some Pok\u00e9mon still do not evolve in this manner, however, which is elaborated upon below.</p><p>Outside of battling, one of the defining traits of Pok\u00e9mon Red and Blue is its trading feature. Because Red and Blue each have Pok\u00e9mon which are exclusive to their individual versions, collecting all of the Pok\u00e9mon requires trading with someone who owns the alternative version. Trading is done by connecting the two <a href=\"/game-boy/3045-3\" data-ref-id=\"3045-3\">Game Boys</a> via a link cable. Each person then decides which Pok\u00e9mon they wish to trade and the duo's choices are transferred. With a few very specific Pok\u00e9mon, the trading process allows them to evolve once the switching is complete. Although traded Pok\u00e9mon are under the command of their new trainer, they still carry identification which indicates who originally had them.</p><p>Two linked Game Boys can also be used by trainers to battle one another. The majority of the rules which govern battle in the single-player game remain the same, although items cannot be used in linked battles. Skirmishes are otherwise the same, with a winner being declared once one trainer's entire team of Pok\u00e9mon has fainted.</p><h2>Pok\u00e9mon glitch</td></tr></tbody></table><h2>Pok\u00e9mon Gyms</h2><p>During the adventure, there are eight different gym leaders to fight in order to acquire their badges. With these badges, the player is allowed get allowed to Victory Road, and reach Indigo Plateau for the Elite Four. Each Pok\u00e9mon Gym Leader is an specialist in some Pok\u00e9mon type, it's important to notice their type for better chances of counter-attacking with a more effective Pok\u00e9mon. Here are the gym leaders, their location, their specialty and Pok\u00e9mons used.</p><table><tbody><tr><th>City Gym</th><th>Leader</th><th>Badge</th><th>Pok\u00e9mon type</th><th>Pok\u00e9mon used</th></tr><tr><td>Pewter City Gym</td><td><a href=\"/brock/3005-5766\" data-ref-id=\"3005-5766\">Brock</a></td><td>Boulder Badge</td><td>Rock / Ground</td><td><ul><li><a href=\"/geodude/3015-1672\" data-ref-id=\"3015-1672\">Geodude</a></li><li><a href=\"/onix/3015-1949\" data-ref-id=\"3015-1949\">Onix</a></li></ul></td></tr><tr><td>Cerulean City Gym</td><td><a href=\"/misty/3005-2215\" data-ref-id=\"3005-2215\">Misty</a></td><td>Cascade Badge</td><td>Water</td><td><ul><li><a href=\"/staryu/3015-2148\" data-ref-id=\"3015-2148\">Staryu</a></li><li><a href=\"/starmie/3015-2147\" data-ref-id=\"3015-2147\">Starmie</a></li></ul></td></tr><tr><td>Vermilion City Gym</td><td><a href=\"/lt-surge/3005-7557\" data-ref-id=\"3005-7557\">Lt. data-ref-id=\"3015-2152\">Rhydon</a></li></ul></td></tr></tbody></table><h2>The Elite Four</h2><p>The very four best Pok\u00e9mon trainers are the ultimate challenge for this game. They have to be fought, along with the current Pok\u00e9mon Champion, in order to achieve the goal of becoming the greatest Pok\u00e9mon trainer.</p><table><tbody><tr><th>Elite Four</th><th>Pok\u00e9mon type</th><th>Pok\u00e9mon used</th></tr><tr><td><a href=\"/lorelei/3005-11455\" data-ref-id=\"3005-11455\">Lorelei</a></td><td>Water / Ice</td><td><ul><li><a href=\"/dewgong/3015-1973\" data-ref-id=\"3015-1973\">Dewgon</a></li><li><a href=\"/cloyster/3015-1978\" data-ref-id=\"3015-1978\">Cloyster</a></li><li><a href=\"/slowbro/3015-2160\" data-ref-id=\"3015-2002\">Lapras</a></li></ul></td></tr><tr><td><a href=\"/bruno/3005-11447\" data-ref-id=\"3005-11447\">Bruno</a></td><td>Fighting</td><td><ul><li><a href=\"/onix/3015-1949\" data-ref-id=\"3015-1949\">Onyx</a></li><li><a href=\"/hitmonchan/3015-1990\" data-ref-id=\"3015-1990\">Hitmonchan</a></li><li><a href=\"/hitmonlee/3015-1989\" data-ref-id=\"3015-1989\">Hitmonlee</a></li><li><a href=\"/machamp/3015-1967\" data-ref-id=\"3015-1967\">Machamp</a></li><li><a href=\"/onix/3015-1949\" data-ref-id=\"3015-1949\">Onyx</a></li></ul></td></tr><tr><td><a href=\"/agatha/3005-11448\" data-ref-id=\"3005-11448\">Agatha</a></td><td>Ghost</td><td><ul><li><a href=\"/gengar/3015-1979\" data-ref-id=\"3015-1979\">Gengar</a></li><li><a href=\"/golbat/3015-1350\" data-ref-id=\"3015-1350\">Golbat</a></li><li><a href=\"/arbok/3015-1270\" data-ref-id=\"3015-1270\">Haunter</a></li><li><a href=\"/arbok/3015-1270\" data-ref-id=\"3015-1270\">Arbok</a></li><li><a href=\"/gengar/3015-1979\" data-ref-id=\"3015-1979\">Gengar</a></li></ul></td></tr><tr><td><a href=\"/lance/3005-11446\" data-ref-id=\"3005-11446\">Lance</a></td><td>Dragon / Flying</td><td><ul><li><a href=\"/gyarados/3015-2000\" data-ref-id=\"3015-2000\">Gyarados</a></li><li><a href=\"/dragonair/3015-2014\" data-ref-id=\"3015-2014\">Dragonair</a></li><li><a href=\"/aerodactyl/3015-2012\" data-ref-id=\"3015-2012\">Aerodactyl</a></li><li><a href=\"/dragonite/3015-3285\" data-ref-id=\"3015-3285\">Dragonite</a></li></ul></td></tr></tbody></table><h3>Elite Four Champion <b><a href=\"/gary-oak/3005-5899\" data-ref-id=\"3005-5899\">Gary Oak</a></b> (Rival)</h3><p>Pok\u00e9mon Type - Gary has a very balanced team</p><p>Pok\u00e9mon Used - Gary's Pok\u00e9mon for the final battle will depend on which Pok\u00e9mon he chose at the Professor Oak's lab. HIs choice will depend on the player's, whatever Pok\u00e9mon the player chooses, he will choose the Pok\u00e9mon with a stronger type against the player's. For example, if the player chooses Bulbasaur he will choose Charmander because fire is naturally strong against grass. Here are the three sets of Pok\u00e9mon he might be using depending on the last evolution of the Pok\u00e9mon he chose at the lab in the beginning of the game:</p><table><tbody><tr><th>Gary's Starting Pokemon</th><th>Other Pokemon in Line Up</th></tr><tr><td>With <a href=\"/venusaur/3015-1038\" data-ref-id=\"3015-1038\">Venusaur</a></td><td><ul><li><a href=\"/pidgeot/3015-1041\" data-ref-id=\"3015-1041\">Pidgeot</a></li><li><a href=\"/alakazam/3015-1939\" data-ref-id=\"3015-1939\">Alakazam</a></li><li><a href=\"/rhydon/3015-2152\" data-ref-id=\"3015-2152\">Rhydon</a></li><li><a href=\"/arcanine/3015-1833\" data-ref-id=\"3015-1833\">Arcanine</a></li><li><a href=\"/gyarados/3015-2000\" data-ref-id=\"3015-2000\">Gyarados</a></li></ul></td></tr><tr><td>With <a href=\"/blastoise/3015-1130\" data-ref-id=\"3015-1130\">Blastoise</a></td><td><ul><li><a href=\"/pidgeot/3015-1041\" data-ref-id=\"3015-1041\">Pidgeot</a></li><li><a href=\"/alakazam/3015-1939\" data-ref-id=\"3015-1939\">Alakazam</a></li><li><a href=\"/rhydon/3015-2152\" data-ref-id=\"3015-2152\">Rhydon</a></li><li><a href=\"/exeggutor/3015-1986\" data-ref-id=\"3015-1986\">Exeggutor</a></li><li><a href=\"/arcanine/3015-1833\" data-ref-id=\"3015-1833\">Arcanine</a></li></ul></td></tr><tr><td>With <a href=\"/charizard/3015-1023\" data-ref-id=\"3015-1023\">Charizard</a></td><td><ul><li><a href=\"/pidgeot/3015-1041\" data-ref-id=\"3015-1041\">Pidgeot</a></li><li><a href=\"/alakazam/3015-1939\" data-ref-id=\"3015-1939\">Alakazam</a></li><li><a href=\"/rhydon/3015-2152\" data-ref-id=\"3015-2152\">Rhydon</a></li><li><a href=\"/gyarados/3015-2000\" data-ref-id=\"3015-2000\">Gyarados</a></li><li><a href=\"/exeggutor/3015-1986\" data-ref-id=\"3015-1986\">Exeggutor</a></li></ul></td></tr></tbody></table><h2>Glitches</h2><h3>MissingNo.</h3><figure data-ref-id=\"1300-2776160\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/9/95666/2776160-oie_overlay.gif\" data-size=\"medium\" data-align=\"right\" style=\"width: 160px\" data-ratio=\"0.9\" data-width=\"160\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:90.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/9/95666/2776160-oie_overlay.gif\" data-ref-id=\"1300-2776160\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_medium/9/95666/2776160-oie_overlay.gif\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_medium/9/95666/2776160-oie_overlay.gif\"/></noscript></a></figure><p>MissingNo.; Easily the most famous Pok\u00e9mon <a href=\"/glitch/3015-511\" data-ref-id=\"3015-511\">glitch</a> of all time. <a href=\"/missingno/3005-871\" data-ref-id=\"3005-871\">MissingNo.</a> is a buggy Pok\u00e9mon which, if caught, can make all kinds of strange things happen in the game.</p><p>To catch a MissingNo. is a very simple process. In <a href=\"/viridian-city/3035-208\" data-ref-id=\"3035-208\">Viridian City</a>, talk to the old man who teaches how to catch Pok\u00e9mon. Talk to him three times and when he asks the player if he wants to learn to catch Pok\u00e9mon, the player must select 'no' the first two times and then say 'yes' the third. After watching him catch a <a href=\"/weedle/3015-1040\" data-ref-id=\"3015-1040\">Weedle</a>, fly to <a href=\"/cinnabar-island/3035-1583\" data-ref-id=\"3035-1583\">Cinnabar Island</a> and surf along the right edge of the island and don't leave the edge. Once a Pok\u00e9mon battle happens, the player can run into a MissingNo. or one of the glitched Pok\u00e9mon over level 100.</p><p>Some strange things will happen to the game when the player catches a MissingNo.. The item in the sixth slot will be duplicated to over 99. Also, battle history with the Elite Four is completely glitched. If MissingNo gains one level the he will evolve into a level 1 Kangaskhan. If the player catches MissingNo. then it can effect the game cartridge by altering the text to gibberish when checking Pok\u00e9mon in the elite four.</p><h3>Duplicating Pokemon</h3><p>This is a trick that many players would do send a good Pok\u00e9mon to a friend and still be able to keep the Pok\u00e9mon to play with for themselves. To do this trick the player needs to find a Pok\u00e9mon that the player wants to duplicate for whomever the player is trading to and the recipient must get a Pok\u00e9mon they are willing to lose. Start a trade like normal but on the Game Boy that is trading the good Pok\u00e9mon switch it off before it says trade complete on the screen, on the other players game it will come up with the usual message and they will have the desired Pokemon.</p><h3>The Invisible PC</h3><p>In Celedon City, there is a hotel in the bottom right-hand corner of the city. When Red is in the hotel he needs to go all the way to the right and go as far north as he can, take two steps back and one forward and then he will be able to access a PC out of thin air!</p><h2>Misconceptions &amp; Rumors</h2><h3>Pok\u00e9Gods</h3><p>Along with MissingNo. there were always rumors about such Pok\u00e9mon called Pok\u00e9Gods. These Pok\u00e9mon were believed to be obtainable in many ways, but were never true.</p><p>One such rumored way of getting these Pok\u00e9mon was to get access to Bill's Garden, which was supposed to be a secret place behind Bill's house where powerful Pok\u00e9mon resided. Another rumored way was to get access to the Pok\u00e9Gods City. This was a place that would be accessible to after having beaten the Elite Four 50 times in a row without saving or healing, Professor Oak would saying something like \"I'm getting tired of this\" and let the player roam around the ending area, where a ladder would be located. This is also not true.</p><p>The more viable option was the truck off to the side before getting on the S.S. Ann. This was possible by finding a way to surf before actually boarding the S.S. Ann. In the back of the truck were rumored to be a Mew and a Togepi. Togepi actually turned out to be a real Pok\u00e9mon in <a href=\"/pokemon-goldsilver/3030-8210\" data-ref-id=\"3030-8210\">Silver and Gold</a>. Another Pok\u00e9god that turned out to be real was Pikablu. This Pok\u00e9mon turned out to be <a href=\"/marill/3015-3135\" data-ref-id=\"3015-3135\">Marill</a>, the little blue water Pok\u00e9mon.</p><p>Some of the Pok\u00e9Gods were rumored to have the names listed below (this is only a few of the many Pok\u00e9Gods):</p><ul><li>Charcolt</li><li>Rainer</li><li>Sapusaur</li><li>Locustud</li><li>Mewthree</li><li>Pikablu</li><li>Chrono Mew</li><li>Sandswipes</li><li>Nidogoddess</li></ul><p>Some Pok\u00e9Gods were believed to evolve from already fully evolved Pok\u00e9mon using an item called a Mist Stone. However, the Mist Stone was just another false rumor.</p><h2>Pok\u00e9mon Green Version</h2><figure style=\"width: 320px\" data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/12541/520519-pokemon_green_jap.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-520519\" data-size=\"small\" data-ratio=\"1.2626262626263\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:126.3%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/1/12541/520519-pokemon_green_jap.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-520519\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/1/12541/520519-pokemon_green_jap.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/1/12541/520519-pokemon_green_jap.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Pok\u00e9mon Green</figcaption></figure><p>Although it is commonly believed that the first releases in the Pok\u00e9mon series were Pok\u00e9mon Red and Pok\u00e9mon Blue, the Blue version of the game actually made its debut under a different title and was known as Pok\u00e9mon Green. The games were originally released in <a href=\"/japan/3035-37\" data-ref-id=\"3035-37\">Japan</a> as \"Pocket Monsters Red\" and \"Pocket Monsters Green\". Due to numerous glitches and bugs in these original versions of the game, such as being able to find Pok\u00e9mon in the wild which were only supposed to be obtainable at certain later stages in the game, they were amended and re-released as the more commonly known Red and Blue versions.</p><p>Many of the sprites were changed and there were also some slight changes to the locations of wild Pok\u00e9mon. These updated versions were later released in <a href=\"/the-united-states-of-america/3035-396\" data-ref-id=\"3035-396\">America</a> and <a href=\"/europe/3035-289\" data-ref-id=\"3035-289\">Europe</a>, therefore the Green version was never released outside of Japan. Interestingly enough, when the games were remade and updated for the <a href=\"/game-boy-advance/3045-4\" data-ref-id=\"3045-4\">Game Boy Advance</a>, <a href=\"/nintendo/3010-90\" data-ref-id=\"3010-90\">Nintendo</a> decided to reference the Green version rather than the Blue, and the new games were released as <a href=\"/pokemon-leaf-greenfire-red/3030-14522\" data-ref-id=\"3030-14522\">Pok\u00e9mon FireRed</a> and <a href=\"/pokemon-leaf-greenfire-red/3030-14522\" data-ref-id=\"3030-14522\">LeafGreen</a>.</p><h2>Cartridge Specifics</h2><p>Pok\u00e9mon Red and Blue both utilize a CR2025 battery for save data. Various sources on the Internet state that early cartridges used a 2016 battery, and it is possible to replace the existing battery with a CR2032.</p>", "releases": [{"api_detail_url": {"duration": "4:05:00", "runner": "bichphuongballz", "data": {"site_detail_url": "http://www.giantbomb.com/final-fantasy-vi/3030-6336/", "expected_release_quarter": null, "description": "<h2>Overview</h2><figure data-align=\"left\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/1762/286851-ff3.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-286851\" data-size=\"small\" style=\"width: 320px\" data-ratio=\"0.75\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:75.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/1762/286851-ff3.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-286851\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/1762/286851-ff3.jpg\"/></a><figcaption>Title screen of Final Fantasy III (US)</figcaption></figure><p>Final Fantasy VI (originally known as Final Fantasy III in North America) is a role-playing game developed and published by Square. It was released on the Super Famicom on April 2, 1994. Six months later, on October 11, 1994, it was released as Final Fantasy III on the <a href=\"/snes/3045-9\" data-ref-id=\"3045-9\">Super Nintendo Entertainment System</a> in North America. Final Fantasy VI was later rereleased on the Sony <a href=\"/playstation/3045-22\" data-ref-id=\"3045-22\">PlayStation</a> (its first European release) and <a href=\"/game-boy-advance/3045-4\" data-ref-id=\"3045-4\">Game Boy Advance</a>. The Playstation versions added <a href=\"/random-encounter/3015-123\" data-ref-id=\"3015-123\">load time pauses before each battle</a>, but it is still a good game despite this flaw. Both of these rereleases were developed by <a href=\"/tose-co-ltd/3010-1417\" data-ref-id=\"3010-1417\">TOSE</a> and published by various publishers.</p><p>Final Fantasy VI is generally considered by fans and critics alike to be one of the best console role-playing games (it has a 94% rating on GameRankings), let alone <a href=\"/final-fantasy/3025-194\" data-ref-id=\"3025-194\">Final Fantasy</a> games, ever made. The game was met with wide critical acclaim, being praised for its varied and complex characters, interesting story, and graphical excellence.</p><h3>Development</h3><p>Final Fantasy VI was the first Final Fantasy game to not be directed by Final Fantasy creator <a href=\"/hironobu-sakaguchi/3040-633\" data-ref-id=\"3040-633\">Hironobu Sakaguchi</a>, instead being co-directed by <a href=\"/yoshinori-kitase/3040-634\" data-ref-id=\"3040-634\">Yoshinori Katase</a> and <a href=\"/hiroyuki-itou/3040-16555\" data-ref-id=\"3040-16555\">Hiroyuki Ito</a>. The composer for the game was famed Final Fantasy composer <a href=\"/nobuo-uematsu/3040-635\" data-ref-id=\"3040-635\">Nobuo Uematsu</a>. <a href=\"/yoshitaka-amano/3040-639\" data-ref-id=\"3040-639\">Yoshitaka Amano</a> created the character design for the game, which were then converted into sprites (taking small liberties from time to time, such as changing hair color) by the graphic design team headed by <a href=\"/tetsuya-takahashi/3040-16562\" data-ref-id=\"3040-16562\">Tetsuya Takahashi</a> (head graphic designer), <a href=\"/hideo-minaba/3040-45954\" data-ref-id=\"3040-45954\">Hideo Minaba</a> (background graphics), Kazuko Shibuyo (object graphics), and <a href=\"/tetsuya-nomura/3040-637\" data-ref-id=\"3040-637\">Tetsuya Nomura</a> (who designed some characters).</p><p>The game also utilized the Super Nintendo's unique <a href=\"/mode-7/3015-184\" data-ref-id=\"3015-184\">Mode 7</a> capabilities. When exploring the map, the world scrolls in a pseudo-3D fashion, common to Mode 7 style graphics.</p><h3>Localization</h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/7465/716942-image1067.jpeg.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-716942\" data-size=\"small\" style=\"width: 237px\" data-ratio=\"2.5485232067511\" data-width=\"237\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:254.9%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/7465/716942-image1067.jpeg.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-716942\"><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/7465/716942-image1067.jpeg.jpg\"/></a><figcaption>The Japanese version's final battle screens</figcaption></figure><p>When released in North America, Final Fantasy VI had many changes from the original version. First and most noticeable is the name change; from Final Fantasy VI to Final Fantasy III. Despite the name change, the game is now commonly referred to as Final Fantasy VI, as to avoid confusion. There were no major gameplay changes, like previous games in the series, but much of the script was changed. The game's translator, <a href=\"/ted-woolsey/3040-50831\" data-ref-id=\"3040-50831\">Ted Woolsey</a>, said that the Japanese version contained much \"playfulness and sexuality\" that couldn't be carried over due to Nintendo of America's strict guidelines.</p><p>As is common in games, most of the names changed, for a variety of different reasons. Some names were changed because they broke the six character limit (Stragus to Strago), while others were changed to seem more exotic (Tina to Terra). Since the game came out before the ESRB ( <a href=\"/entertainment-software-ratings-board/3010-6476\" data-ref-id=\"3010-6476\">Entertainment Software Ratings Board</a>) was a standard, many changes had to be made due to sexual or violent content. The text files had to be shortened because of the limited space in the cartridge. It took Ted Woolsey only 30 days to complete the translation all by himself.</p><p>Many of the sprites in the Japanese version of the game were bordering on nudity, so these were edited. The woman form of the Chadarnook was edited to cover up more of the skin, as was the Critic, Goddess, and Siren sprites. The sprites used in the final battle also differ; the Japanese version is much larger than the American version.</p><h3>Other Versions</h3><figure data-align=\"left\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/7465/844491-final_fantasy_sgi_demo.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-844491\" data-size=\"small\" style=\"width: 320px\" data-ratio=\"0.55189873417722\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:55.2%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/7465/844491-final_fantasy_sgi_demo.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-844491\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/7465/844491-final_fantasy_sgi_demo.png\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/7465/844491-final_fantasy_sgi_demo.png\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Final Fantasy VI: The Interactive CG Game</figcaption></figure><p>Final Fantasy VI has been re released in various forms on a variety of systems after its original Super Famicom/SNES release. First, there was a technical demonstration based on the original Final Fantasy VI, called Final Fantasy VI: The Interactive CG Game. In the game, players controlled Terra, Locke, and Shadow in various battles by drawing patterns with a mouse, each pattern corresponding to a different move. The game was used to demonstrate the uses of SGI ( Silicon Graphics, Inc.) and a possible graphical direction for Square's next RPG. The technology was later put to use in Final Fantasy VII.</p><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/7465/784212-063.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-784212\" data-size=\"small\" style=\"width: 320px\" data-ratio=\"1.2380952380952\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:123.8%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/7465/784212-063.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-784212\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/7465/784212-063.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/7465/784212-063.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Celes Chere in a CG trailer available in the PlayStation version</figcaption></figure><p>Final Fantasy VI was also released three separate times for PlayStation: it was included in <a href=\"/final-fantasy-anthology/3030-30783\" data-ref-id=\"3030-30783\">Final Fantasy Anthology</a> (released on October 5, 1999) and <a href=\"/final-fantasy-collection/3030-18707\" data-ref-id=\"3030-18707\">Final Fantasy Collection</a> (released only in Japan on March 11, 1999), and was also released as a standalone title (only in Japan and PAL regions). The game was left relatively unchanged, save for the addition of CG opening and closing cutscenes, and added load times before each of the game's many <a href=\"/random-encounter/3015-123\" data-ref-id=\"3015-123\">randomly triggered encounters</a>. Other notable things included were a bestiary and artwork library that were accessible from the title screen. Various other things were added, such as new opening and closing effects to battles, the option to quicksave (although all saving still had to be initiated manually), and bug fixes (as well as new bugs being created). The standalone edition of the game had a limited edition that shipped fifty-thousand copies and came with an alarm clock. Final Fantasy Anthology has an 80% rating on Metacritc and an 85% on GameRankings, gaining it the status of \"generally favorable reviews.\"</p><figure data-align=\"left\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/7465/841249-final_fantasy_vi_advance07.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-841249\" data-size=\"small\" style=\"width: 240px\" data-ratio=\"0.66666666666667\" data-width=\"240\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:66.7%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/7465/841249-final_fantasy_vi_advance07.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-841249\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/7465/841249-final_fantasy_vi_advance07.png\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/7465/841249-final_fantasy_vi_advance07.png\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Title screen of Final Fantasy VI Advance</figcaption></figure><p>Final Fantasy VI Advance was released on the Game Boy Advance on November 30, 2006 in Japan, February 5, 2007 in North America, and June 29, 2007 in Europe. This version is more extensively changed than the PlayStation ports, but without the load times before each of the game's many <a href=\"/random-encounter/3015-123\" data-ref-id=\"3015-123\">randomly triggered encounters</a>. New gameplay features, redone graphics, and a retranslated script are among the most notable things included. Four new Espers were included in the game (Leviathan, Gilgamesh, Cactuar, and Diabolos), as well as two new locations: the Dragons' Den (which included a new boss, the Kaiser Dragon) and the Soul Shrine (in which players could battle enemies continuously). Three new spells are included in the game, and bugs from the original are fixed. A bestiary and music player are also included in the game. In addition, the boxart and game-related art has been redone as well, again by Yoshitaka Amano. One scene, in which Celes is beaten, has been removed from the game, presumably due to events in Japan at the time of release. The game was relatively well-received from both critics and fans alike; it holds a a 92% average rating on Metacritic and a 91% average on GameRankings.</p><h2>Gameplay</h2><figure data-align=\"left\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/1762/288241-ff329.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-288241\" data-size=\"small\" style=\"width: 320px\" data-ratio=\"0.75\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:75.0%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/1762/288241-ff329.jpg\" data-ref-id=\"1300-288241\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/1762/288241-ff329.jpg\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/1762/288241-ff329.jpg\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>An example of the overworld</figcaption></figure><p>The gameplay of Final Fantasy VI is similar to that of its predecessors and of other 16-bit Japanese RPGs. Player characters move about the game\u2019s fictional setting, completing a story-fueled series of objectives: reaching a certain location, defeating a certain enemy, retrieving a certain item, solving a puzzle, figuring out what to do next, etc. The gameplay is often broken up by story and dialogue sequences, which advance the story through generally non-interactive conversations and events. Over the course of the game, the player-controlled party grows to include a handful of unique characters; this group acts as the primary perspective from which players view the unfolding plot. As they battle enemies (which are <a href=\"/random-encounter/3015-123\" data-ref-id=\"3015-123\">encountered at random</a> and are unavoidable) these player characters gain EXP (experience points), which allow them to gain levels. Every time a character gains a level, his or her stats (attributes upon which combat capability depends) are raised, allowing the character to fight more powerful enemies more easily.</p><p>There are four main screens in the game.</p><p>In the overworld screen, the player party traverses an expansive land, moving between various locales (towns and dungeons). More parts of the overworld and more locales become accessible as the player makes progress through the game. The party is susceptible to <a href=\"/random-encounter/3015-123\" data-ref-id=\"3015-123\">randomly triggered battles</a> in the overworld.</p><p>Towns and dungeons are accessible from the overworld. In this screen, the player party moves about smaller-scale areas, interacting with NPCs and environmental objects. Towns generally include shops and inns, whose goods and services are bought with GP (currency). Towns are populated by numerous NPCs, with which the player can converse. Dungeons are more dangerous, as the party is vulnerable to enemy attacks while exploring them, due to <a href=\"/random-encounter/3015-123\" data-ref-id=\"3015-123\">randomly triggered encounters</a>, and no shops or inns are found within. (Although Tents can be used at save points to replenish the party's health and magic, serving the same purpose as an inn.) Often contained in a dungeon is one of many powerful boss enemies, most of which must be fought in the course of the game. Dungeons are usually larger and more complexly designed than towns. Towns and dungeons are the primary settings for cutscenes and plot events.</p><p>In the battle screen, the player controls the party as it fights against an enemy or enemies. The player enters the battle screen when a random or scripted battle is commenced, and exits by winning, fleeing, or losing the battle. (Losing a battle results in a game over, meaning that all the player's progress since their last save point is lost, and the player is sent back to the title screen without even being offered a chance to try that battle again). In battle, the player does not directly control character movement; instead, the player selects battle commands from menus unique to the individual party members.</p><p>The menu screen is accessible from the overworld and town/dungeon screens. Here, the player can use items, manage party members\u2019 equipment and abilities, view their stats, change game settings, and save their progress. (which has to be done manually)</p><h3>Combat</h3><figure data-align=\"right\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/7465/670302-final_fantasy_iii.042.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-670302\" data-size=\"small\" style=\"width: 320px\" data-ratio=\"0.875\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:87.5%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/7465/670302-final_fantasy_iii.042.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-670302\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/7465/670302-final_fantasy_iii.042.png\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/7465/670302-final_fantasy_iii.042.png\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>A typical battle screen.</figcaption></figure><p>Final Fantasy VI's battles (which are most often random) utilize the <a href=\"/active-time-battle/3015-95\" data-ref-id=\"3015-95\">Active Time Battle</a> system first implemented in <a href=\"/final-fantasy-iv/3030-20829\" data-ref-id=\"3030-20829\">Final Fantasy IV</a>. Each character has his or her own action gauge, which fills up at a rate dependent on the character's speed stat. When the gauge is full, the character can perform actions chosen from his or her command list. Such actions include performing a basic attack, casting a magic spell, using an item, and drawing upon the unique ability of the character.</p><p>Magic, as in all Final Fantasy games, can be used for a range of purposes. Primarily, spells are used to inflict damage, bestow status conditions (both positive and negative), and heal. To cast a spell, a character must use MP, which can be restored similarly to HP. If a character's current MP is lower than the MP cost of a spell, he or she will be unable to cast it. MP, like HP, is a stat; as it rises, the character's maximum MP count will rise.</p><p>As in many Final Fantasy games, the combat screen is separated into one large rectangle on top, in which all the action takes place, and one smaller one at the bottom of the screen, in which the player inputs commands. Certain non-interactive cutscenes also take place in the combat screen, with characters displayed as battle sprites.</p><p>When the party wins a battle, it gains EXP, GP, and (sometimes) AP (see the \"Equipment\" section below). Defeated enemies sometimes also drop items or equipment.</p><h3>Equipment</h3><figure data-align=\"left\" data-img-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/7465/671528-final_fantasy_iii.027.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-671528\" data-size=\"small\" style=\"width: 320px\" data-ratio=\"0.875\" data-width=\"320\" data-embed-type=\"image\"><a class=\"fluid-height\" style=\"padding-bottom:87.5%\" href=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/original/0/7465/671528-final_fantasy_iii.027.png\" data-ref-id=\"1300-671528\"><img class=\"js-lazy-load-image\" data-src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/7465/671528-final_fantasy_iii.027.png\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==\"><noscript><img src=\"http://static.giantbomb.com/uploads/scale_small/0/7465/671528-final_fantasy_iii.027.png\"/></noscript></a><figcaption>Browsing through items at an item store</figcaption></figure><p>There is a lot of equipment in the game, providing for great lengths of customization. The right hand, left hand, head, and body can all be customized with a wide variety of weapons and armor. Weapons determine the nature of characters' physical attacks, while shields and armor boost their stats (primarily defense and magic defense). Generally, one hand holds a weapon, one hand holds a shield, the head holds headgear, and the body holds body armor. However, the Genji Glove and Gauntlet relics (see below) allow characters to break the rules regarding weapon-equipping.</p><p>Relics are items that have effects less traditional than those of weapons and armor. Two can be equipped at once by each character, allowing them to bestow myriad potential bonus combinations. Examples of relics include the Sniper Sight (which ensures a 100% hit rate of basic attacks), the Black Belt (which grants a 50% chance of counterattacking against enemies' physical strikes), and the Alarm Earring (which prevents back attacks and pincer attacks). Relics can protect against various status conditions, bestow positive status conditions, change the nature of attacks or abilities, and boost stats. There are also relics that offer out-of-battle bonuses; for example, the Sprint Shoes double walking speed in towns and dungeons.</p><p>Espers add a deep customization element to the game's magic system. Although they are not introduced particularly early in the game, they are an essential part of the game's character customization.
